ARTICLE IV. - EXISTING PERSONNEL RULES AND REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 2-401. - Status. 
The existing personnel rules and regulations, including the Sections on Definitions and all Articles I—X, which are not in specific conflict herewith shall remain in full force and effect until modified or replaced as hereinabove provided. 
(Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971)  
ARTICLE V. - CITY LIBRARY BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-501. - Created; qualifications, appointment of members. 
There is hereby created and established a City Library Board. The Board shall consist of nine (9) voting members, two (2) of whom shall be students enrolled on a full-time basis in the ninth, tenth, eleventh, or twelfth grades of a public or private high school located in Pinellas County, Florida, or lawfully being home-schooled in Pinellas County, Florida. All members, including the teenage members, shall have been full-time residents of the City for at least one (1) year prior to their appointment, and shall remain full-time residents of the City throughout their terms. Any member who ceases to be a full-time resident of the City during his or her term shall no longer be eligible to serve as a member, and his or his position shall be deemed to be vacant. The members of the Board shall be appointed by a majority vote of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 130, 3-24-1960; Ord. No. 228, 5-28-1964; Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971; Ord. No. 681, 8-8-1974; Ord. No. 2295, 2-9-1995; Ord. No. 2579, 3-25-1999)  
Sec. 2-502. - Terms of office, compensation, organization designation, election of officers. 
The two (2) full-time high school student members shall be appointed for terms of one (1) year, and all other members shall be appointed for terms of three (3) years; and in cases of vacancies created by resignation, removal, ineligibility to serve, or otherwise, City Council shall fill such vacancy for the balance of the unexpired term. No member shall receive any pay or compensation for any service rendered as a member of the Board. Such members shall annually elect one of their number as chairperson, and another member as vice-chairperson, of the Board. 
Five (5) members of such Board shall constitute a quorum. Subject to the supervision and control of City Council, the members of the Board shall make and adopt such procedures, bylaws, rules, and regulations which are not inconsistent with law which they deem necessary and proper for the conduct of the business of the Board. 
The chairperson shall serve as liaison between the Board and the Library Director. He/she shall preside at all meetings. The vice-chairperson shall serve in the absence of the chairperson and in such other capacities as may be directed by the chairperson or the Board. 
Board members shall serve at the pleasure of City Council and may be removed at any time with or without cause by City Council. Any replacements at times other than at the expiration of a term of office shall be for the balance of said term then remaining. 
(Ord. No. 130, 3-24-1960; Ord. No. 228, 5-28-1964; Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971; Ord. No. 2295, 2-9-1995; Ord. No. 2579, 3-25-1999)  
Sec. 2-503. - Duties. 
Under policies established by the City Council, the Board: 
1.  Shall advise the City Manager or his/her designee on policies and procedures governing the library as may be deemed necessary for the Library's preservation and to maintain service to the community. 
2.  Shall advise the Library Director and review general rules, penalties and forfeitures for trespass or the library building, grounds, rooms, materials or other property, or fail to return any item, or for violation of any by-laws or regulation. 
3.  Shall have and exercise such power as may be delegated to it in order to carry out the spirit and intent of law in establishing and maintaining a public library. 
4.  Shall study and analyze reports prepared for presentation to the City Manager and City Council on the library's strength and weaknesses, adopt a long and short range plan for library growth in conjunction with the Library Director and City Manager and shall review and recommend policies needed to carry forward the library's plan effectively. 
5.  Shall review budget requests prepared by the Library Director; shall suggest any recommended changes and shall officially endorse the annual budget requests to the City Manager. The chairperson of the Board may appear with the Library Director at budget hearings held by the City Manager or City Council to interpret the financial needs of the library. 
6.  Shall explore all ways of increasing library's income from any and all sources. 
7.  Shall serve as liaison between the library and the community, interpreting one to the other, and shall uphold all policies adopted by the Board and the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 130, 3-24-1960; Ord. No. 228, 5-28-1964; Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971; Ord. No. 2295, 2-9-1995)  
Sec. 2-504. - Annual report to the City Council required; contents. 
The Library Board shall, make an annual report to the City Council of the condition of their trust by the last day of January of the following year. This report may include, but not be limited to, all monies received or expended, the number of books and other materials on hand, newspaper subscriptions, the number of items circulated, with such other statistics, information and suggestions as they may deem of general interest, or as the City Council may require, which report shall be reviewed by the Board. 
(Ord. No. 130, 3-24-1960; Ord. No. 228, 5-28-1964; Ord. No. 295, 10-13-1966; Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971; Ord. No. 2295, 2-9-1995)  
ARTICLE VI. - CITY PURCHASES 
 
Sec. 2-601. - Exclusive power of City Manager to make authorized improvements and expenditures; exception. 
The City Manager shall have exclusive power to make any and all public improvements and expenditures for the City in the manner authorized by resolutions or Ordinances, however, any expenditures in the amount of Thirty-Five Thousand Dollars ($35,000.00) or more shall first be submitted to and approved by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971; Ord. No. 1089, 7-9-1981; Ord. No. 1356, 2-23-1984; Ord. No. 1813, 11-10-1988; Ord. No. 2520, 9-24-1998; Ord. No. 3358, 8-11-2005; Ord. No. 3938, § 1, 4-9-2015; Ord. No. 3947, § 1, 5-28-2015)  
Sec. 2-602. - Bids and advertising required for certain purchases; emergency purchases; exceptions. 
(A)  When the cost or purchase price is in excess of Thirty-Five Thousand Dollars ($35,000.00), no purchase shall be made unless bids are received after advertising in accordance with the requirements contained in F.S. §§ 255.0525(2), 287.012(16) and 287.057(1)(a), as may be amended, provided, however, that if the City Manager, with the consent of the Mayor, shall determine that a real emergency exists in regard to contracting for work or services or for the purchase of any commodities so that the delay incidental to giving opportunity for bidding would be detrimental to the interest of the City, and affect the carrying out of necessary City functions, or in the event of a local disaster or catastrophe then, and in such event, the provisions herein for bidding shall not apply and the City Manager, after first securing written Mayoral approval, may enter into such contracts for work or services or authorize and make purchases of such commodities, with the Council being notified of such action as soon as possible, but not later than the next regular Council Meeting. 
(B)  There is excepted from bid requirements, items which are only available from one (1) source, but, in such instances, a written certification by the Purchasing Director is required; however, such acceptance shall be subject to the City Council approval as provided in Section 2-601 above. 
(C)  There is also excepted from the above bid requirement purchases of all types of insurance coverage to the extent that the same is procured by or through a duly licensed insurance consultant under contract with the City to implement and manage its insurance protection program at the direction of City Council or procured by the City's Risk Management Director. Any insurance coverage purchased other than through such consultant or Risk Management Director shall be subject to the above bid requirements. 
(D)  There is also excepted from the above bid requirement the procurement of live entertainment performances for City functions. 
(E)  1.  There is also excepted from the above bid requirement labor, services, and/or materials up to a maximum amount of Fifty Thousand Dollars ($50,000.00) for the repair, renovation, or improvement of City-owned real estate which is controlled under a real estate management contract, where the delay incidental to the formal bidding process would be detrimental to the interests of the City. The City Manager, after first securing as many quotations therefor as may be reasonably available under the circumstances, may enter into contracts for such labor, services, and/or materials, with City Council being notified of such action as soon as possible, but not later than the next regular City Council meeting. 
2.  There is also excepted from the above bid requirements commissions or similar fees payable to a real estate manager engaged in the management of city-owned real estate under a real estate management contract which has been previously approved by City Council. The City Manager shall make such payments in accordance with the requirements of such contract, and shall notify City Council of the amounts of such payments as soon as possible, but not later than the next regular City Council meeting. 
(F)  Notwithstanding the other provisions of this Article VI, the City may, in lieu of the competitive bidding procedures specifically provided for herein, accept a bid proposal or contract which has been secured by any other governmental entity, or agency thereof, procured through a competitive bidding process which is equal to or more stringent than the competitive bidding process required by this Section 2-602; provided, however, such acceptance shall be subject to City Council approval as provided in Section 2-601 above. 
(G)  There is also excepted from the above bid requirements any City improvement project, or the initial phase of any such project, if the same is critically time sensitive, or offers financial savings to the City, but does not qualify as an emergency as defined in Subsection 2-602(A). With the approval of the City Manager, an Agenda Item for the excepted project, or the excepted initial phase of a project, will be prepared and presented for City Council approval. If approved by City Council, a minimum of three (3) competitive price quotations shall be obtained, and the project shall thereafter be awarded by City Council, subject to the provisions of Section 2-605. If the approval is for the excepted initial phase of a project only, then the remainder of that project shall be bid in accordance with the requirements of this Article VI. 
(H)  There is also excepted from the above bid requirements any grant, award or purchase for which State or Federal funds are received and which by the terms of such grant, award or purchase require the utilization of a State or Federal bid process, provided the required State or Federal bid process is utilized and the utilization of such process has been approved by City Council. 
(I)  There is also excepted from the above bid requirements any contract with a vendor that is either an extension or a renewal of an existing contract, with or without modifications, or which serves as a novation or a new contract with an existing vendor for substantially the same or similar services, when such original contract with the vendor was awarded based upon competitive bidding; which term for the purpose of this ordinance shall include obtaining requests for proposals, requests for quotes, or other competitive solicitations of possible contracts. However, such extension or renewal shall be subject to City Council approval as provided in Section 2-601 above. 
(J)  The City Manager shall be authorized to approve any modifications or change orders of any contracts, as long as the total value of such modifications or change orders for any contract does not exceed Thirty-Five Thousand Dollars ($35,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971; Ord. No. 967, 6-28-1979; Ord. No. 1089, 7-9-1981; Ord. No. 1307, 9-8-1983; Ord. No. 1356, 2-23-1984; Ord. No. 1746, 12-10-1987; Ord. No. 1813, 11-10-1988; Ord. No. 2100, 9-26-1991; Ord. No. 2119, 3-12-1992; Ord. No. 2409, 11-14-1996; Ord. No. 2520, 9-24-1998; Ord. No. 2700, 3-23-2000; Ord. No. 3118, 6-12-2003; Ord. No. 3175, 10-9-2003; Ord. No. 3254, 9-26-2004 Ord. No. 3357, 8-11-2005; Ord. No. 3938, § 2, 4-9-2015; Ord. No. 3947, § 2, 5-28-2015)  
Sec. 2-603. - Preference to be given commodities manufactured, processed or merchandised in city. 
Whenever two (2) or more bids are received, one (1) or more of which relates to commodities manufactured or processed or merchandised within this City, and whenever all things stated in such received bids are equal with respect to prices and commodities, the commodities manufactured, processed or merchandised within this City shall be given preference in an amount not to exceed three (3) percent of the bid price. A similar preference shall be given to commodities manufactured, processed or merchandised within this City whenever purchases are made without. 
(Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971; Ord. No. 2100, 9-26-1991)  
Sec. 2-604. - Professional services; no bid required. 
Whenever the professional services of attorneys, fiscal agents, brokers, title or abstract companies and the like are required in connection with a public improvement or public purpose, contracts of employment may be entered into by the Council with such persons or firms without the necessity of public bids. All professional services covered by the Consultants Competitive Negotiation Act shall be obtained as required by F.S. § 287.055. 
(Brought forth from former City Charter—1977; Ord. No. 2100, 9-26-1991)  
Sec. 2-605. - Rejection of bids. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Article, the City Council shall have the right and power to reject any and all bids. If all bids are rejected City Council may, in its discretion, authorize the acceptance of new bids in accordance with the provisions of this Article. 
Without limiting the generality of the foregoing language, the City may reject, any bid that is submitted by any person or firm which has failed, in the opinion of the City, to faithfully perform any previous contract with the City or any other governmental entity within the State of Florida within the last five (5) years from the date the bid is received. The City may also reject any bids submitted by any person or firm which is in arrears to the City upon any debt or contract or which is in default as surety or is otherwise in default upon any obligation to the City. 
(Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971; Ord. No. 2100, 9-26-1991)  
Sec. 2-606. - Preference to be given to bidders utilizing local labor and/or materials. 
A preference, in an amount not to exceed three (3) percent of the bid price, may be given to those bidders who agree to utilize at least fifty (50) percent of the necessary labor and/or materials/supplies for the project from within the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 2100, 9-26-1991)  
Sec. 2-607. - Publication of notices required. 
All public notices required to be published by the provisions of this Section, may be published in any daily or weekly newspaper published in the City and, if there is no newspaper published in the City, then in a newspaper published in the County having a general circulation in the City. 
(Ord. No. 481, 2-11-1971; Ord. No. 2100, 9-26-1991)  
Sec. 2-608. - Prequalification requirements for contractors desiring to submit bids for city construction projects. 
The Bid process will not require the prequalification of bidders to submit bids for City construction projects. Excepted from the above stated non-prequalification rule are those projects for which grant, State, or Federal funds may be received, and the terms of receiving such funds would require the prequalification of bidders from such projects. 
(Ord. No. 3489, § 1, 10-12-2006)  
ARTICLE VIII. - UTILITY SERVICE ZONE 
 
Sec. 2-801. - Zone or area designated. 
Pursuant to F.S. ch. 180, the following described areas are hereby designated as the City of Pinellas Park's utility service zones or areas: 
1.  Potable Water Service Area: That area designated in Exhibit "A" attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference. 
2.  Sanitary Sewer Service Area: That area designated in Exhibit "B" attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2213, 9-9-1993)  
Sec. 2-802. - Utility connections into utility systems required. 
All persons or corporations living or doing business within the before-mentioned area are hereby required to connect, when available, into the utility system when constructed, erected and operating in the designated area by the City of Pinellas Park in accordance with the pertinent Ordinances of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, or any other that may hereinafter be enacted.

ARTICLE X. - PARKS AND RECREATION 
 
Sec. 2-1001. - Definitions. 
When used herein the following definitions shall apply: 
Director refers to the director of the Pinellas Park Parks and Recreation Division. 
Division when used hereinafter, is defined as the Pinellas Park Parks and Recreation Division. 
Free speech activities include, but are not limited to, public speaking, performances, distribution of printed material, displays and signs which are/is protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. Free speech activities do not include activities for commercial purposes. 
Park roads are defined as all surfaced areas ten (10) feet wide or wider designated for vehicular traffic, and passing through any legally defined park or recreational area or any part thereof. All other traffic ways, either unpaved or narrower than ten (10) feet are classified as work trails, bridle paths, or simple trails or paths. 
Parking area is defined to mean any designated part of any park road, drive or special area contiguous thereto that may be set apart for the standing or stationing of any vehicle.or operation by the Parks and Recreation Division. 
Parks and recreation are defined to mean parks, playgrounds, recreation fields, buildings, lakes, streams, canals and water areas therein and all public service facilities located on or in grounds, waters, buildings and structures in Pinellas Park which are under the control of or assigned for upkeep, maintenance 
Parks and recreation division property when used hereinafter, is defined to cover all areas, buildings, locations, facilities equipment and furnishings described in Parks . 
Person shall be understood, as employed herein, to mean any individual regardless of age or sex, or any corporation, company, association, firm, copartnership, club or society, or any association of person, or any agent or employee thereof. 
Vehicle is defined to mean any wheeled conveyance (except a baby carriage or wheel chair) for the transportation of persons or materials whether: 
(1)  Powered or drawn by a motor, such as an automobile, truck, motorcycle or scooter; or 
(2)  Animal-drawn, such as a carriage, wagon or cart; or 
(3)  Self-propelled such as a bicycle or tricycle; or 
(4)  Any trailer in tow of any size, kind or description. 
Exception is made as to any recreational or park transportation service, on rails or otherwise, where especially authorized by the Director of Parks and Recreation. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1002. - Traffic laws. 
Applicable state vehicle laws shall apply in and about all park property and in addition thereto the following rules shall be applicable on roads and driveways within parks: 
(A)  No person driving, operating, controlling or propelling any vehicle, motorized, horse drawn or self-propelled, shall use any other than the regularly designated paved or improved park roads or driveways, except when authorized or directed to do so by a law enforcement officer or designated City employee. 
(B)  The operator of any vehicle must obey all signs in regard to speed limits, danger, direction of traffic, and other traffic rules specifically applicable in park areas. 
(C)  All law enforcement officers and designated City employees are hereby authorized and instructed to direct traffic whenever and wherever needed in the parks and recreation areas and on the highways, streets or roads immediately adjacent thereto. All persons shall comply with any lawful order, signal, or direction of such officer or employee. All persons shall observe carefully all traffic signs indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping, or parking, and all others posted for proper control and to safeguard life and property. 
(D)  No person shall drive a vehicle at a speed greater than is reasonable or prudent, having due regard for the surface, width and condition of paving and the traffic thereon. All vehicles shall give right of way to pedestrians and bicyclists. Maximum speed shall be fifteen (15) miles per hour excepting at the more congested centers and near park buildings and picnic and play areas and in said last mentioned areas, maximum speed shall be determined by the Chief of Police who shall cause to be erected properly posted signs, giving notice thereof. All persons shall not exceed the speed limits as posted within the individual parks. 
(E)  Where a highway traverses a City park or recreation area and is available for public use at all times, said road shall be open to all through traffic permitted on any City road or highway, but such through traffic shall conform to park speed and traffic regulations. 
(F)  No vehicle shall enter any City park, except through the designated park entrance gate. No vehicle shall enter any City park until the required fee, if any, has been paid, except those entering on park business. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1003. - Trucks and other vehicles. 
No private or public trucks, carts, wagons, or other vehicles carrying building materials, merchandise, or other articles of freight or merchandise for sale, shall enter any park or recreation area or make use of park roads except traversing the park on roads especially designated for such passage to service adjacent lands not available via other than park roads, except on special authorization of the Parks and Recreation Director or in connection with park work and activities. Exception is made for empty trucks not for hire and used solely at the time for transporting persons to a park for recreational purposes. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1004. - Bicycles, tricycles, motorcycles and scooters. 
No person shall ride, drive or propel any motorcycle, scooter or similar vehicle on any but the regular vehicular roads or other paths designated for specific use by such vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1005. - Parking. 
(A)  No person shall park a vehicle any place on park property other than in the regular designated facilities provided for that particular type of vehicle, unless directed otherwise by law enforcement officers or designated City employees who are authorized to designate other areas for parking when conditions so warrant. 
(B)  No person shall park or station any vehicle in any zone designated and marked "No Parking", or otherwise marked for restricted use except briefly for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers or freight, and in no case in excess of five (5) minutes for passengers and ten (10) minutes for freight. 
(C)  No person shall double-park any vehicle at any time on any road or parkway or parking concourse, unless so directed by a law enforcement officer or designated City employee. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1006. - Preservation of property. 
Regulation of conduct with respect to protection of park property to prevent damage, removal or destruction is necessary to preserve park and recreation areas for the use of future generations. 
(A)  As all property in all parks is City property, no person shall willfully mark, deface, or injure in any way, or displace, remove, or tamper with, any park building or building material, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, park signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts, or other boundary markers, or other structures, or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(B)  No person shall dig, or remove from any park area any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs, plants, seeds, flowers, fruits or nuts, down timber or other wood or materials, or make any search, excavation by tool, equipment, metal detector, blasting, or other means or agency, or construct or erect any buildings or structures or whatever kind whether permanent or temporary in character, or run or string any public service utility into, upon or across such lands, except on special written permit from Parks and Recreation Director. 
(C)  Trees, shrubbery and lawns are property assets of the park. No person shall cut, carve or injure the bark, or break off limbs or branches or mutilate in any way, or pick the flowers, fruits, seeds, or nuts of any tree or plant, nor shall any person dig in or otherwise disturb the grass areas, or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any area. Additionally, it is prohibited to pile debris or material of any kind on or about any tree or plant, or attach any rope, wire or other contrivance to any tree or plant, whether temporary or permanent in character or use. 
(D)  No person shall transplant or remove any tree or plant or part thereof, or collect or remove flowers, except that scientists or students of botany may procure from the director special permission to collect plant specimens. 
(E)  No person, except in emergencies, shall change any parts, repair, wash, grease or perform other maintenance on a vehicle on any park roadway, parkway, driveway, parking lot or other park property. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1007. - Protection and preservation of wild life, hunting and fishing. 
(A)  No unauthorized person shall molest, harm, frighten, kill, net, trap, snare, hunt, chase, shoot or throw or propel by any means missiles at any wildlife creature be it mammal, aquatic or marine life, bird or reptile roaming free about the park or in captivity in a cage, nor shall any unauthorized person remove or possess the young of any wild animal or the nest or eggs of any reptile or bird or to collect, remove, possess, give away, sell or offer to sell, buy or offer to buy, or accept as a gift any specimen dead or alive. 
(B)  No person shall disobey posted notices prohibiting feeding mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, or fish. 
(C)  No person shall place, dump, abandon or leave any fish, mammal, reptile or bird, either wild or domestic, on park property. 
(D)  Commercial fishing, or the buying or selling of fish caught in any park waters, is strictly forbidden. 
(E)  No person shall fish in any park waters, and whether by the use of hook and line, seine, net, trap, spear, gig or other device, except in such waters thereof as are or may be designated by the Parks and Recreation Director for that use and under such regulations and restrictions as have been or may be prescribed by said director. 
(F)  No hunting, trapping, or pursuit of wildlife by any means or method whatsoever will be permitted on or in any park area by any unauthorized persons. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003; Ord. No. 3781, § 1, 10-13-2011)  
Sec. 2-1008. - Recreation activities, proper use of facilities. 
(A)  While using the parks, it is the responsibility of each visitor to conduct his activities in such a manner so as to prevent injury or loss of life to any person. 
(B)  No person shall engage in recreation or other activities other than those prescribed in areas set aside for such purposes. 
(C)  No person shall set up tents, shacks or any other temporary shelters, or any special vehicle to be used, or that could be used for such purpose; such as a house trailer, camp trailer, camp wagon, or the like, for the purpose of overnight camping except within such areas, if any, as may have been provided for such use. 
(D)  No person will loiter in or around any rest room, dressing room or bathhouse. 
(E)  No person shall dress or undress except in such bathhouse or structures as may be provided and maintained by the department for that purpose and dressing or undressing in any vehicle, toilet, rest room, or in any park area except as provided above is prohibited. 
(F)  No person shall conduct himself by improper immoral actions or dress, or use profane language. 
(G)  The City Manager, or his designated representative, shall publish, as appropriate, additional rules for the use of City parks and recreation areas. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1009. - Bathing and swimming. 
(A)  No person, regardless of age, sex, or manner of dress shall swim, wade, or bathe in waters or waterways in any park other than at such places as are posted for such activities, either lake, pond or pool. 
(B)  No person shall erect or cause to be erected any tent, shelter or structure on or in any bathing or wading area in such a manner that a guy wire, rope, extension, brace or support connected or fastened from any such structure to any other structure, stake, rock, or other object is necessary, nor shall any other such structure, tent or shelter lack an unobstructed view of the interior from at least two (2) sides. 
(C)  No person shall carry, transport or cause to be transported any glassware or any other potentially dangerous or sharp objects into any beach, bathing, wading, or swimming pool areas. 
(D)  No person shall frequent any park waters for the purpose of swimming or bathing, except between such hours of the day as shall be designated by the division, for such purposes for each individual area. However, swimming and bathing in all areas after dark is forbidden, except under controlled conditions. 
(E)  Swimming pools may be closed to the public and bathing therein may be prohibited at any time when in the opinion of the Parks and Recreation Division such bathing is dangerous or otherwise inadvisable. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1010. - Boating. 
(A)  No person shall bring or operate any boat, canoe, raft, or other watercraft, (except toys too small for human occupancy) in any park property watercourses, lakes, canals, rock pits, ponds, other than those so designated for such use of purpose by the Parks and Recreation Director. 
(B)  No person other than a concessionaire licensed by the City Council to operate within a City park shall be permitted to rent, hire, or operate for charge, any kind of boat or watercraft, whether powered or not, on any park waters. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1011. - Picnic areas and use. 
(A)  No person shall build, light or cause to be lighted any fire upon the ground or other object in any area except in an approved grill, stove, fireplace or other suitable container, nor shall any person starting a fire leave the area without extinguishing the fire. To maintain cleanliness and order as well as to reduce fire hazard, each picnic party shall see that its fire is completely extinguished before leaving and that all trash such as boxes, papers, cans, bottles, garbage and other refuse is placed in the disposal receptacles where provided. If there are no such trash receptacles available, then refuse shall be carried away from the park area to be properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(B)  No person will picnic, lunch or cook in any area not specifically designated for such usage. 
(C)  No person shall use a grill or other device in such a manner as to burn, char, mar or blemish any bench, table, or other object of park property. 
(D)  The Parks and Recreation Director, or a designated representative, will regulate activities in picnic areas when necessary to prevent congestion and to secure the maximum use for the comfort and convenience of all. If the facilities are crowded, persons holding picnics in any area, building or structure will avoid using same to the exclusion of others for an unreasonable time, the determination of what is unreasonable being at the discretion of the Parks and Recreation Director. Use of the individual fireplaces, together with tables and benches, follows generally the rule of "first come, first served." 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1012. - Horseback riding. 
No person shall engage in horseback riding in any park or recreation area other than those where provision for such is made by clearly marked bridle paths, trails, rings, and other necessary features and then only upon thoroughly broken and properly restrained animals are ridden with care, prevented from grazing, straying unattended, untethered to any rock, tree or shrub and not ridden or led on any park land other than that so designated. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1013. - Domestic animals. 
(A)  Dogs and other pets will be excluded from any place where food and drinks are sold. 
(B)  All dogs shall at all times be restrained and on adequate leashes not greater than six (6) feet in length. 
(C)  In compliance with the regulations of the State Board of Health, all pets are excluded from all swimming areas. 
(D)  Seeing eye, guide dogs and other service animals shall be excluded from these regulations concerning domestic animals, and shall be permitted in all park areas and facilities. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1014. - Toy firearms, fireworks, and explosives. 
(A)  No person shall at any time bring into, or have in his possession, or discharge anywhere, in any park or recreational area, any toy firearm, air rifle, air gun, toy cannon, slingshot, bow and arrow, or any toy or instrument that discharges projectiles either by air, elastic, explosive substance or any other force. 
(B)  No person may bring into or have in his possession, or set off or otherwise cause to explode, discharge or burn in any park area or on any public lands or highways adjacent thereto, any firecrackers, torpedoes, rockets, toy firearms, or cannon or other fireworks or explosives of inflammable material or any substance, compound, mixture, or article that, in conjunction with any other substance or compound may explode, discharge or burn unless in connection with a program sponsored by the Parks and Recreation Division. 
(C)  Parents or guardians will be held strictly responsible and accountable for the actions of minors in regard to the prohibitions in the foregoing subsections. 
(D)  Nothing contained in this Section or any other part of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pinellas Park shall be deemed or construed to be in contravention of the State's preemption of the regulation of firearms contained at Florida Statute § 790.33. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003; Ord. No. 3781, § 2, 10-13-11)  
Sec. 2-1015. - Refuse and trash. 
No person will deposit or drop or place any refuse including bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, tobacco products or containers or foil upon the ground or in or on any other park property, parkway, or other area operated or maintained by the division except in the receptacles provided for trash disposal. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1016. - Park hours. 
(A)  The Parks and Recreation Director shall establish, publish and post, as appropriate, hours of operation for the facilities under his or her control or supervision. 
(B)  No person shall enter upon any part of any park property which is in an unfinished state or under construction or withheld from general public usage, in the interest of public safety, health, or welfare. 
(C)  No person shall, without permission of the Parks and Recreation Director or designated representative, enter any park or recreation area at any time other than the established hours of operation. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1017. - Merchandising, vending, peddling, solicitation of alms, contributions petitions and fortune telling. 
(A)  No person, organizations or firm other than the Parks and Recreation Division will expose or offer for sale, rent, or trade, any article or thing, or station or place any stand, cart, or vehicle, for the transportation, sale or display of any article of merchandise within the limits of any park or recreation area or on the waters thereof, except by written permission of the City Manager or designee. 
(B)  No person shall solicit alms or contributions for any purpose, whether public or private, nor shall any person circulate petitions of any character in any parks or recreation area, except by written permission of the City Manager or a designated City employee. 
(C)  No person shall tell fortunes or foretell futures for money or any other consideration of value, by any means or method whatever, within the limits of any park or recreation area or any building pertaining thereto, or on any park road within the limits of any park or recreation area. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1018. - Reservation of City-owned or maintained athletic fields, permits, rules for use of athletic fields. 
(A)  Any person or group may reserve the use of any City-owned or maintained athletic field for a specific period of time by obtaining a permit therefore from the City Manager or his designee. The person or group obtaining a permit shall have priority over all other persons and groups for the use of such athletic facility during the period so reserved. Such permit shall be in a form prescribed by the City Manager or his designee. 
(B)  The City Manager or his designee shall promulgate regulations for the issuance of these permits and the use of City-owned or maintained athletic facilities pursuant thereto. Failure to comply with published rules and regulations shall result in the following action in addition to any other appropriate action which the City may take: 
1.  The first offense shall result in a written warning; 
2.  The second offense shall result in the violator being forbidden to use any such athletic facility for such period as may be determined by the City Manager or his designee, not to exceed six (6) months. 
(C)  Organized recreational league teams may utilize only those City-owned or maintained athletic fields for play or practice as may be designated by the City Manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1019. - Advertising, publicity and signs. 
(A)  No person shall use any area within the limits of any park or recreation area for the purpose of advertising or calling attention to any article or service for sale or hire, nor shall any signs, slogans, loudspeakers or advertising display of any nature whatever be used for such purposes. No person shall place or station within any park or recreation area any vehicle whatsoever displaying any such advertising, intent of advertising, or used for such purposes herein mentioned. 
(B)  No person shall display, distribute, post or affix any banner, sign, handbill, pamphlet, circular, placard, or any other printed matter containing commercial advertising within any park area the limits of any park or recreation area, except by written permit of the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1020. - Free speech activities. 
The City Council shall have the authority to designate certain parks or recreation areas, or portions thereof, which will be available for any free speech activities which, due to the size of the group or the nature of the activity, may interfere with the use and enjoyment or recreation area by the general public. 
(A)  Permits for use of a park or recreation area, or any portion thereof, in the exercise of free speech activities shall be obtained by application to the City Manager in accordance with the following: 
1.  A person seeking issuance of a permit hereunder shall file application stating: 
a.  The name and address of the applicant; 
b.  The name and address of the person or organization sponsoring the activity, if any; 
c.  The day and hours for which the permit is to be issued; 
d.  The approximate number of persons who may be attending the activity; 
e.  The park or recreation area, or portion thereof, for which the permit is to be issued; and 
f.  Variances required from park rules and regulations, if any. 
2.  Standards for issuance of a permit shall include the following findings: 
a.  That the proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public's enjoyment of the park or recreation area. 
b.  That the proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere or detract from the promotion of public health, safety, welfare and recreation. 
c.  That the proposed activity or uses that are reasonably anticipated will not include violence, crime or disorderly conduct. 
d.  That the proposed activity will not entail extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the City. 
e.  That the park or recreation area, or portion thereof, desired has not been reserved for other use on the date and hour requested in the application. 
f.  If the permit is to be issued only to use one (1) of the parks and recreation areas which City Council has designated under subsection (A) above, that the size of the group or the nature of the activity may unreasonably interfere with the use and enjoyment of the park or recreation area by the general public. 
(B)  Within ten (10) days after receipt of the application the City Manager shall inform an applicant in writing of the decision to grant or deny a permit; in the event of a denial, the notification shall include the reason for such denial, based on standards listed in subsection (B)(2) above. 
(C)  Any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal to, City Council by filing written notice thereof with the City Clerk within ten (10) working days of the date of the notification by the City Manager. The City Council shall, within ten (10) working days from the filing of the appeal with the City Clerk, or at its first regularly scheduled meeting after the filing of the appeal, whichever is later, decide whether or not to grant the permit. City Council shall apply the same standards listed in subsection (B)(2) above. The decision by City Council shall be final. 
(D)  A permitee shall be bound by all applicable park rules and all applicable City Ordinances fully as though same were inserted in such permits. 
(E)  The City Manager shall have the authority to revoke a permit upon a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance or upon good shown cause. The permit holder may appeal such revocation to the City Council in accordance with the procedure for appealing a permit denial, and the City Council shall have the same powers as in the case of a permit denial. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1021. - Use and sale of alcohol and use of narcotics. 
(A)  No individual under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or narcotics will be permitted entry to park areas and, if discovered therein, will be subject to immediate expulsion. 
(B)  The sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages shall not be permitted in any City Park except by written permission of the City Manager or a designated City employee. For the purposes of this Article, "alcoholic beverages" shall mean distilled spirits and all beverages containing one-half (½) of one (1) percent or more alcohol by volume. The sale or consumption of illegal drugs or narcotics of any form is prohibited in any City Park or recreation area. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1022. - Special permits. 
Other recreational activities may be allowed by special permit if authorized by the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1023. - Enforcement of regulations and permits. 
All rules and regulations and permits contained in this document are enforceable by employees. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1024. - Insurance requirements. 
Any group or person who makes application for a permitted activity, special event, or other activities set forth in this Article, may be required, prior to the commencement of any activity or issuance of any permit, to submit evidence of liability insurance covering injuries to members of the general public, and indemnifying the City and its officers and employees for liability arising out of such permitted activities in such amounts as may [be] from time to time determined by the Risk Management Director in consultation with the Parks and Recreation Director. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1025. - Penalties. 
Any person or persons who commit the offense of violating any of the provisions of this Section may be punished by a fine in the sum not to exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days, or both fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
Sec. 2-1026. - Severability. 
It is declared to be the intent of the City Council of Pinellas Park, that, if any Section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or provision of this Section be held invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not be so construed as to render invalid or unconstitutional the remaining provisions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 3140, 8-12-2003)  
ARTICLE XI. - LEGAL DEFENSE FUND 
 
Sec. 2-1101. - Purpose. 
The purpose of enacting an Article to establish a fund for reimbursing employees of the City of Pinellas Park, for Attorney's fees expended in the successful defense of criminal prosecution arising from action taken in the course of performing their official duties and while in the scope of their employment is: 
(A)  To guarantee that the City be able to attract, hire and retain qualified employees, agents and officials; that providing a fund for reimbursement of such legal fees is necessary to insure the attraction and retention of qualified individuals to serve as employees, agents or officials of the City of Pinellas Park; that to attract employees of the highest quality, it is necessary to provide them with assurances that should they wrongfully be subject to criminal prosecution arising from action taken while performing their official duties and furthering the business of the citizens of Pinellas Park that they will be reimbursed by the City for actions taken in good faith in its behalf; 
(B)  To insure fundamental fairness to all City employees, agents and officers; that the employee, agent or official, having been found innocent of wrongdoing, or having been discharged from prosecution, has been vindicated of any wrongdoing, and it is unfair and inequitable that such employee, agent or official should have to bear the heavy financial burden of Attorney's fees incurred while acting in his official capacity, in furtherance of the business of the citizens of Pinellas Park, and while in the scope of his employment; 
(C)  To insure freedom of action; that reimbursement of such Attorney's fees is necessary to insure freedom of action by City employees, agents or officials; that such reimbursement will allow each employee, agent or official to more fully perform his lawful duties, since he need not fear consequences arising from the lawful exercise of such duties; 
(D)  To maintain the good image and integrity of the City of Pinellas Park. The City's image and integrity are directly benefited by the vindication of any employee, agent or official from wrongdoing arising from action taken while acting in the course of his employment and while in furtherance of his official duties and the business of Pinellas Park. Vindication of City employees, agents or officers is a subject of great interest to the City, and reimbursement of such attorney's fees is an incentive to City employees, agents or officers to successfully defend prosecution wrongfully brought against them. 
(Ord. No. 739, 8-14-1975)  
Sec. 2-1102. - Limitations. 
Reimbursement to a City employee, agent or official for Attorney's fees incurred in successfully defending criminal prosecution arising out of his official duties is subject to all of the following requirements: 
(A)  The City employee, agent or official must have been subjected to criminal prosecution from action taken by him in his performance and furtherance of official City business or duties. 
(B)  The City employee, agent or official must have been acting, at the time of such action, directly in the scope of his employment, and within the scope of his authority. 
(C)  The City employee, agent or official must have acted in good faith. 
(D)  The City employee, agent or official must have been found innocent of wrongdoing, or the case against him must have been dismissed or otherwise discharged, in order for reimbursement to be allowed. 
(E)  The amount of reimbursement shall be for all reasonable Attorney's fees incurred in defending such prosecution. If the Council, by majority vote, shall determine that such Attorney's fees are unreasonable, then the Council shall award an amount which it determines to be reasonable. 
(F)  Reimbursement of Attorney's fees out of the fund herein created shall not be made if payment of such Attorney's fees is otherwise payable under an insurance policy providing for such reimbursement or payment. 
(Ord. No. 739, 8-14-1975)  
Sec. 2-1103. - Reimbursement of attorney's fees for criminal defense. 
Any City employee, agent or official who successfully defends criminal prosecution arising out of the performance of his official duties and in the scope of his employment and authority may present a petition and four (4) additional copies thereof to the City Council at a regular Council meeting, requesting the reimbursement of such Attorney's fees, and shall present with such petition a sworn affidavit itemizing and detailing all fees paid to the Attorney and swearing that such fees paid to the Attorney are the true and complete fees paid or agreed to be paid, and that there exists no separate, additional or secret agreement or contingencies between such City employee, agent or official and his attorney concerning payment of fees. The petition shall be considered by each Councilman, and voting thereon shall take place at the next regular meeting. If a majority of the City Council shall determine that such Attorney's fees were incurred defending a criminal prosecution arising out of his official duties and in furtherance of City business, and that such employee, agent or official was acting in the scope of his authority and employment and otherwise meets the requirements of this article, then such employee, agent or official shall be reimbursed for all such reasonable Attorney's fees. If the Council by majority vote, shall determine that such Attorney's fees are unreasonable, then the Council shall award an amount which it determines to be reasonable. 
(Ord. No. 739, 8-14-1975)  
ARTICLE XII. - CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-1201. - Intent. 
The intent of this Section is to create a Local Government Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrates in order to promote, protect, and improve the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the City of Pinellas Park by providing for an equitable, expeditious, effective and inexpensive method of enforcing, any of the codes or ordinances in force in the City of Pinellas Park. It is the intention that this Section shall supplement the provisions of F.S. Ch. 162, which shall govern the process and procedures for the Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrate proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 1150, 5-13-1982; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 3538, § 1, 3-22-2007; Ord. No. 3662, § 1, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 2-1202. - Definitions. 
The following definitions are applicable to this Article and have the following meanings: 
Code Enforcement Board. The City of Pinellas Park Municipal Code Enforcement Board. 
Community Compliance Specialists. Any employee or authorized agent of the City of Pinellas Park so designated by the City Manager to enforce any of the codes or ordinances in force in the City of Pinellas Park. 
Repeat violation. A violation of a provision of the City of Pinellas Park's Code of Ordinances by a person or entity who has previously been found through a Code Enforcement Board, Special Magistrate or any other quasi-judicial or judicial process, to have violated the same provision within five (5) years prior to the violation, notwithstanding the violation(s) occurred at different locations. 
Special Magistrate (Formerly Special Master). One (1) or more individuals designated by City Council, in addition to the Code Enforcement Board, to enforce any of the codes or ordinances in force in the City of Pinellas Park. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 1150, 5-13-1982; Ord. No. 1960, 2-22-1990; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 2419, 2-27-1997; Ord. No. 2705, 4-27-2000; Ord. No. 3662, § 2, 1-8-2009; Ord. No. 4025, § 1, 6-22-2017)  
Sec. 2-1203. - Composition: Appointment; terms of members; residency requirements; removal and vacancies. 
(A)  The Code Enforcement Board shall consist of seven (7) members, each to be appointed by a majority of the entire membership of City Council of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, for a term of three (3) years. The initial appointments to the Code Enforcement Board shall be as follows: 
1.  Two (2) members appointed for a term of one (1) year; 
2.  Three (3) members appointed for a term of two (2) years; 
3.  Two (2) members appointed for a term of three (3) years. 
Thereafter, all appointments shall be made for a term three (3) years. 
One (1) or more Special Magistrates may be appointed by a majority of the entire membership of the City Council of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida for a term of three (3) years. 
(B)  Any Code Enforcement Board member or Special Magistrate may be reappointed upon approval by a majority of the entire membership of the City Council. 
(C)  Appointments to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired term of office. 
(D)  Members of the Code Enforcement Board shall be residents of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, at the time of their appointment and throughout the term of office. Any member who is no longer a resident of the City of Pinellas Park shall be automatically removed, and that vacancy filled as provided herein. Special Magistrates need not be residents of the City of Pinellas Park, but preference for qualified City residents may be given in the appointment of Special Magistrates. 
(E)  If any board member fails to attend two (2) successive hearings without cause and without prior approval of the Chairman of the Code Enforcement Board, the Board shall declare the member's office vacant, and the vacancy filled as provided herein. If any Special Magistrate fails to attend two (2) successive hearings, for which the Special Magistrate was scheduled to preside, without cause and without prior approval of the City Manager or his/her designee, then the City Council shall declare the Special Magistrate's office vacant, and the vacancy filled as provided herein. 
(F)  Appointments shall be made, consistent with the Charter of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, on the basis of demonstrated experience or interest in the subject matter jurisdiction of the Code Enforcement Board in the sole discretion of the City Council. The membership of the Code Enforcement Board shall, whenever possible, consist of an architect, businessperson, engineer, general contractor, subcontractor, and a realtor. 
(G)  Board members and Special Magistrates may be removed for cause by the City Council after public hearing. Vacancies by such removal shall be filled as provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 1150, 5-13-1982; Ord. No. 1242, 3-10-1983; Ord. No. 1823, 1-26-1989; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 2328, 4-27-1995; Ord. No. 3662, § 3, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 2-1204. - Oath of office. 
Each member of the Code Enforcement Board and each Special Magistrate, upon appointment shall, before entering upon discharge of his or her duties of office, take an oath of office. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 3662, § 4, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 2-1205. - Organization and compensation of Code Enforcement Board; conduct at hearings; legal counsel to the Code Enforcement Board. 
(A)  Organization of Code Enforcement Board. 
1.  The members of the Code Enforcement Board shall elect a Chairman from among its members who shall be a voting member. The ex officio duties of the Chairman will include serving as Alternate Special Magistrate. 
2.  The presence of four (4) or more members shall constitute a quorum. A simple majority vote of members present and voting is required for official action by the Code Enforcement Board. 
3.  Board members and Special Magistrates shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for such travel, mileage, and per diem expenses as may be authorized by City Council or as otherwise provided by law. 
(B)  Conduct of hearings. The Code Enforcement Board and the Special Magistrates shall adopt rules for governing the conduct of its affairs not inconsistent with the provisions of this Article and specifically: 
1.  The Chairman may call hearings of the Code Enforcement Board. Hearings may also be called by written notice signed by at least three (3) members of the Code Enforcement Board. Special Magistrates may call Special Magistrate Hearings. 
2.  The Code Enforcement Board shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting every year. Special Magistrates shall convene once each month, but may meet more often or less often as the demand necessitates upon the approval or request of the City Manager or his/her designee. 
3.  The Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrates may, at any properly noticed hearing, set a future hearing date. 
4.  Minutes shall be kept of all hearings, specifically including the vote of each member upon each question, by the Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrates, and all hearings and proceedings shall be open to the public. All testimony shall be under oath and mechanically recorded. 
5.  The City shall provide a hearing room and such clerical and administrative personnel as may be reasonably required by the Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrates for the proper performance of their duties. 
6.  Each case before the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate shall be presented by legal counsel and/or the one (1) or more Community Compliance Specialists or other City employees who are charged with the responsibility for inspection and/or enforcement of the specific Code sections alleged to have been violated. If the local governing body prevails in prosecuting a case before the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate, it shall be entitled to recover all costs incurred in prosecuting the case. 
7.  All alleged violators who have failed to timely correct the violation, shall appear before either the Code Enforcement Board or a Special Magistrate, whichever the City Manager or his/her designee deems appropriate based upon the circumstances of the case, to respond to the charges. If the alleged violator appears before a Special Magistrate and wishes to contest the violation, the Special Magistrate shall refer the matter to the Code Enforcement Board for hearing. If the alleged violator has been properly noticed and fails to appear at a hearing before the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate, the Board or Special Magistrate shall proceed with the hearing and the notice shall so state. If the absent alleged violator is found guilty of the violation, or if the violator appears and admits the violation, the Board or Special Magistrate shall issue an order giving the violator a reasonable time to correct the violation(s) which order shall contain appropriate findings of fact and conclusions of law. In the event the violator fails to timely correct the violation(s) as ordered by the Board or Special Magistrate, the Board or Special Magistrate may assess an appropriate fine against the violator. If the Board or Special Magistrate assesses a fine against the violator for failing to timely correct the violation(s), an Administrative Fine Order shall be entered with appropriate findings of fact and conclusions of law. The provisions of Subsection 2-1208(D) shall apply to said order. A request for termination of such fine shall be heard by the Board or Special Magistrate. 
8.  The Code Enforcement Board and the Special Magistrate shall proceed to hear the cases on the agenda for that day; provided, however, that the Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrates may in its discretion continue any case until the next or a future agenda upon a showing of good cause at the time of or prior to the scheduled hearing. The Code Enforcement Board and the Special Magistrate shall take testimony from the Community Compliance Specialist(s) or other City employees, the alleged violator, and any other witnesses. Both sides shall have a right to give testimony, present witnesses, and to cross-examine adverse witnesses, in person or through their attorney. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings. 
9.  After the conclusion of the hearing, the Code Enforcement Board and the Special Magistrate shall issue findings of fact based on the evidence of record, and conclusions of law, and shall issue an Order affording the proper relief consistent with the powers granted herein. The finding shall be by an Order entered by the Special Magistrate or motion approved by a majority of those board members present and voting, except that at least four (4) of those members of the Code Enforcement Board must vote for the action to be official. The Order may include a notice that it must be complied with by a specified date and that a fine may be imposed and, under the conditions specified in Subsection 2-1208(A), the cost of repairs may be included, along with the fine, if the Order is not complied with by said date. 
A certified copy of an Administrative Fine Order shall be recorded in the Public Records of Pinellas County and shall constitute notice to any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest, or assigns if the violation concerns real property, and the findings therein shall be binding upon the violator and, if the violation concerns real property, any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest, or assigns. If an Order is recorded in the Public Records pursuant to this Subsection and the violation(s) are later corrected, the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate shall issue a Termination of Fine Order acknowledging compliance that shall be recorded in the Public Records. A hearing is not required to issue such an Order acknowledging compliance. 
10.  All hearings, deliberations before the Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrates shall be open to the public. 
(C)  Legal counsel to the Code Enforcement Board. Shall be provided by legal counsel retained from time to time by the City of Pinellas Park for the purpose of advising the Code Enforcement Board and the Special Magistrates. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 1150, 5-13-1982; Ord. No. 1242, 3-10-1983; Ord. No. 1823, 1-26-1989; Ord. No. 1960, 2-22-1990; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 2328, 4-27-1995; Ord. No. 2406, 10-10-1996; Ord. No. 2419, 2-27-1997; Ord. No. 3662, § 5, 1-8-2009; Ord. No. 3855, § 1, 8-22-2013; Ord. No. 3954, § 1, 7-23-2015; Ord. No. 4025, § 2, 6-22-2017)  
Sec. 2-1206. - Powers of the Code Enforcement Board. 
The Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrates shall have the power to: 
(A)  Adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings. 
(B)  Subpoena alleged violators and witnesses to its hearings. Subpoenas may be served by the Police Department of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
(C)  Subpoena evidence to a hearing. 
(D)  Take testimony under oath. 
(E)  Issue orders having the force of law commanding whatever steps are necessary to bring a violation into compliance. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 3662, § 6, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 2-1207. - Enforcement procedure. 
(A)  It shall be the duty of the Community Compliance Specialists or other City employees who are charged with code enforcement responsibilities to initiate enforcement proceedings of any of the codes or ordinances in force in the City of Pinellas Park; no members of the Board or Special Magistrates shall have the power to initiate such enforcement proceedings. 
(B)  If a violation of any of the codes or ordinances in force in the City of Pinellas Park is found, except in the case of a repeat violation, the Community Compliance Specialist or other City employee shall notify the violator and give him/her a reasonable time to correct the violation. At the same time, the Community Compliance Specialist or other City employee shall provide written notice, as herein provided, to the violator of the date, time and place of the hearing on the violation. If the violation is corrected and then recurs, or if the violation is not corrected by the time specified for correction by the Community Compliance Specialist or other City employee, the case may be presented to the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate even if the violation has been corrected prior to the hearing and the notice shall so state. The notice shall also state that if the alleged violator fails to appear, that the hearing will still take place in his or her absence. 
(C)  At a hearing before the Special Magistrate, if the alleged violator fails to appear or admits the violation, the procedure contained in Section 2-1205(B)7 shall be followed. If the alleged violator wishes to contest the violation(s), the Special Magistrate, through his or her clerical staff, shall refer the case to the Code Enforcement Board for hearing. The Code Enforcement Board, through its clerical staff, shall schedule a hearing and written notice of such hearing shall be provided to the alleged violator, as provided for herein. At the option of the Code Enforcement Board, notice may additionally be served by publication and posting. If the violation is corrected and then recurs, or if the violation is not corrected by the time specified for correction by the Community Compliance Specialist or other City employee, the case may be presented to the Code Enforcement Board even if the violation has been corrected prior to the Board hearing and the notice shall so state. 
The notice shall also state that if the alleged violator fails to appear, that the hearing will still take place in his or her absence. 
(D)  If an alleged repeat violation is found, the Community Compliance Specialist or other City employee shall notify the violator of same, but is not required to give the violator a reasonable time to correct the violation. The Community Compliance Specialist or other City employee, upon notifying the violator of a repeat violation, shall at the same time provide written notice, as herein provided, to the violator of the date, time and place of the hearing on the violation. The case may be presented to the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate even if the repeat violation has been corrected prior to the hearing, and the notice shall so state. 
If the repeat violator wishes to contest the alleged repeat violation at a Special Magistrate Hearing, the Special Magistrate shall refer the case to the Code Enforcement Board for hearing and a hearing shall be scheduled and written notice thereof provided to the violator as provided herein. If the alleged repeat violator has been properly noticed and fails to appear before the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate, the Board or Special Magistrate may proceed with the hearing. If the alleged repeat violator is found guilty of the violation, or appears and admits the repeat violation, the Board or Special Magistrate may impose an appropriate fine as provided for herein and an order with appropriate findings of fact and conclusions of law shall be entered. The provisions of Subsection 2-1208(D) shall apply to said order. A request for termination of said fine shall be heard by the Board or Special Magistrate. All notices required in this paragraph shall state that if the alleged violator fails to appear, that the hearing will still take place in his or her absence. 
(E)  If the Community Compliance Specialist has reason to believe that a violation or the condition causing the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety or welfare, or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible in nature, the Community Compliance Specialist shall make a reasonable effort to notify the alleged violator of the violation and of the hearing and may immediately notify the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate and request a hearing. The Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate shall conduct a hearing to determine if a violation exists and may enter appropriate orders. 
(F)  If the owner of property that is subject to an enforcement proceeding before an enforcement board, Special Magistrate or court, sells or otherwise transfers ownership of such property between the time the initial pleading was served and the time of the hearing, such owner shall: 
1.  Disclose, in writing, the existence and the nature of the proceeding to the prospective transferee. 
2.  Deliver to the prospective transferee a copy of the pleading, notices, and other materials relating to the code enforcement proceeding received by the transferor. 
3.  Disclose, in writing, to the prospective transferee that the new owner will be responsible for compliance with the applicable code and with orders issued in the code enforcement proceedings. 
4.  File a notice with the code enforcement official of the transfer of the property, with the identity and address of the new owner and copies of the disclosures made to the new owner, within 5 days after the date of the transfer. 
A failure to make the disclosures described in this section before the transfer creates a rebuttable presumption of fraud. If the property is transferred before the hearing, the proceeding shall not be dismissed, but the new owner shall be provided a reasonable period of time to correct the violation before the hearing is held. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 1823, 1-26-1989; Ord. No. 1960, 2-22-1990; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 2328, 4-27-1995; Ord. No. 2419, 2-27-1997; Ord. No. 3662, § 7, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 2-1208. - Administrative fines; liens. 
(A)  The Code Enforcement Board and a Special Magistrate, as the case may be, upon notification by the Community Compliance Specialist that an order of the Code Enforcement Board or the Special Magistrate, as the case may be, has not been complied with by the set time, or upon finding that a repeat violation has been committed, may order the violator to pay a fine as specified herein for each day the violation continues past the date set by the Code Enforcement Board or the Special Magistrate, as the case may be, for compliance, or in the case of a repeat violation, for each day the repeat violation continues beginning with the date the repeat violation is found to have occurred by the Community Compliance Specialist. In addition, if the violation is a violation described in Subsection 2-1207(E), the Enforcement Board shall notify the local governing body which may take all reasonable repairs which are required to bring the property into compliance, and charge the violator with the reasonable cost of the repairs, along with the fine imposed pursuant to this Section. Making such repairs does not create a continuing obligation on the part of the local governing body to make further repairs or to maintain the property and does not create any liability against the local governing body for any damages to the property if such repairs were completed in good faith. A fine imposed pursuant to this Section shall not exceed Two Hundred Fifty Dollars ($250.00) per day for a first violation and shall not exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) per day for a repeat violation and in addition, may include all cost of repairs pursuant to this subsection. The order setting the date for compliance shall state that a fine may be imposed if the order is not complied with by said date. However, if the Code Enforcement Board, or the Special Magistrate, as the case may be, finds the violation to be irreparable or irreversible in nature, it may impose a fine not to exceed Five Thousand Dollars ($5,000.00) per violation. 
(B)  In determining the amount of fine, if any, the Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrate shall consider the following factors: 
1.  The gravity of the violation; 
2.  Any actions taken by the violator to correct the violation; and 
3.  Any previous violations committed by the violator. 
(C)  City Council may, at a public hearing, reduce or eliminate a fine or lien imposed by the Code Enforcement Board or a Special Magistrate pursuant to this Article. The Code Enforcement Board or a Special Magistrate may make a recommendation to the City Council to reduce or eliminate a fine or lien imposed by it pursuant to this Article when a request application is received by the City Manager or his/her designee. A request to reduce or eliminate a fine or lien, shall not be considered until such time as the violation for which the fine has been assessed has been corrected. In recommending or in determining whether to reduce or eliminate any such fine or lien, City Council, the Code Enforcement Board, or Special Magistrate as the case may be shall consider the nature and extent of the violation, the length of time that the violation existed, the impact of the violation upon the community, the ability of the violator to eliminate the violation, actions taken by the violator to correct the violation, previous violations committed by the violator, and the cost to the City in processing the case and in obtaining compliance. 
(D)  A certified copy of an order imposing a fine shall be recorded in the Public Records of Pinellas County, Florida, and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the land on which the violation exists and upon any other real or personal property owned by the violator. A fine imposed pursuant to this Article shall continue to accrue until the violator comes into compliance, until the City Manager or his/her designee makes an administrative decision to discontinue fine accrual, or until judgment is rendered in a suit to foreclose on a lien filed pursuant to this Section, whichever occurs first. A lien arising from a fine imposed pursuant to this Section runs in favor of City Council and the City Council may execute a satisfaction or release of lien or a partial satisfaction or partial release of lien entered pursuant to this Section. After three (3) months from the filing of any such lien which remains unpaid, the City Council may authorize the City Attorney to foreclose on the lien. No lien created pursuant to the provisions of this Article may be foreclosed on real property which is homestead under Section 4, Article X of the State Constitution. Any person found guilty or responsible for any ordinance infraction or violation shall be liable for all court costs, all costs incurred by the City in prosecuting the case, any fine imposed, any reasonable cost of repairs, all costs incurred by the City in enforcing its codes and all costs of repairs related thereto, an administrative charge or fee in the amount of Seventy-Five Dollars ($75.00), post judgment interest at the legal rate of interest as established by the State of Florida Comptroller, and any other costs or fee imposed involving a debt owed, including all costs and reasonable attorney fee incurred in any foreclosure action, and all costs incurred in recording and satisfying a valid lien. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 1150, 5-13-1982; Ord. No. 1242, 3-10-1983; Ord. No. 1823, 1-26-1989; Ord. No. 1960, 2-22-1990; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 2328, 4-27-1995; Ord. No. 2419, 2-27-1997; Ord. No. 2705, 4-27-2000; Ord. No. 2831, 2-22-2001; Ord. No. 2899, 9-13-2001; Ord. No. 3662, § 8, 1-8-2009; Ord. No. 4025, § 3, 6-22-2017)  
Sec. 2-1209. - Appeal. 
An aggrieved party, including the City Council, may appeal a final administrative order of the Code Enforcement Board or a Special Magistrate to the Circuit Court. An appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days of the execution of the order to be appealed. Such an appeal shall not be de novo but shall be limited to appellate review of the record created before the Code Enforcement Board or a Special Magistrate. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 1150, 5-13-1982; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 3662, § 9, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 2-1210. - Notices. 
(A)  All notices required by this act shall be provided to the alleged violator by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of the property in question at the address listed in the tax collector's office for tax notices, and at any other address provided to the local government by such owner; by posting as described in this Article along with first class mail directed to the addresses furnished to the local government with a properly executed proof of mailing or affidavit confirming the first class mailing; by hand delivery by a process server, law enforcement officer or Community Compliance Specialist; or by leaving the notice at the alleged violator's usual place of residence with any person residing there who is above fifteen (15) years of age and informing such person of the contents of the notice or, in the case of commercial premises, leaving the notice with the Manager or other person in charge. 
(B)  In addition to providing notices as set forth in Subsection (A), at the option of the City Manager or his/her designee, a Special Magistrate, or the Code Enforcement Board, notice may also be served by publication or posting as follows: 
1.  Such notice shall be published once during each week for four (4) consecutive weeks (four (4) publications being sufficient) in a newspaper of general circulation in the County where the Code Enforcement Board is located. The newspaper shall meet such requirements as are prescribed under F.S. ch. 50 for legal and official advertisements. 
Proof of publication shall be made as provided in F.S. § 50.41 and § 50.051. 
2.  Such notice may be posted at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing, or prior to the expiration of any deadline contained in the notice, in at least two (2) locations, one of which shall be the property upon which the violation is alleged to exist and the other of which shall be the primary municipal government office. Proof of posting shall be affidavit of the person posting the notice, which affidavit shall include a copy of the notice posted and the date and places of its posting. 
(C)  Notice of publication or posting may run concurrently with or may follow an attempt or attempts to provide notice by hand delivery or by certified mail.
