Evidence that an attempt has been made to hand deliver or mail notice in compliance with this Section, together with proof of publication or posting as required herein shall be sufficient to show that the notice requirements of this Article have been met without regard to whether or not the alleged violator actually received such notice. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 1823, 1-26-1989; Ord. No. 1960, 2-22-1990; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 2419, 2-27-1997; Ord. No. 2705, 4-27-2000; Ord. No. 3662, § 10, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 2-1211. - Separability. 
Should any Section, Subsection, or provision of this Article be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the Article as a whole, or any part hereof other than the part so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982)  
Sec. 2-1212. - Optional enforcement. 
The provisions of this Article shall in no way be construed to limit the power of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, to proceed in any other civil or criminal proceeding or in any other forum to obtain enforcement of its Code provisions. The City of Pinellas Park may, by Ordinance, adopt an alternate Code Enforcement System which gives Special Magistrates designated by City Council the authority to hold hearings and assess fines against violators, in addition to, or in lieu of, Code Enforcement Boards. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 1960, 2-22-1990; Ord. No. 4025, § 4, 6-22-2017)  
Sec. 2-1213. - Conflict of interest provisions. 
(A)  No person who is or may become a party or a witness to a hearing before the Code Enforcement Board or a Special Magistrate shall communicate with any member of the Code Enforcement Board or a Special Magistrate concerning that violation except at the hearings provided for in this Article. This restriction shall extend to any person appearing or interceding on behalf of a party, whether or not such person may have a direct, personal or financial interest in the property which is the subject of the alleged violation. 
(B)  No member of the Code Enforcement Board or any Special Magistrate shall communicate with any party, witness, representative of a party, or interceding person concerning any alleged violation except at the hearings provided for in this Article. 
(C)  Failure on the part of a member of the Code Enforcement Board or on the part of a Special Magistrate to comply with the provisions of this subsection shall constitute grounds for removal of such member from the Code Enforcement Board or for removal of such individual as a Special Magistrate. 
(Ord. No. 1136, 1-14-1982; Ord. No. 2073, 4-25-1991; Ord. No. 3662, § 11, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 2-1214. - Public records searches relating to Code Enforcement Board and Special Magistrate liens. 
(A)  The City Manager or his/her designee is authorized to obtain a public records search for the purpose of determining whether to institute a lien foreclosure proceeding without the necessity of any action by City Council whenever the unpaid amount of the Code Enforcement Board or Special Magistrate lien exceeds One Hundred Dollars ($100.00); and 
(B)  No public records search for the purpose of determining whether to institute a lien foreclosure proceeding shall be obtained where the unpaid amount of the lien is less than One Hundred Dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 1850, 8-10-1989; Ord. No. 3662, § 12, 1-8-2009)  
Sec. 2-1215. - Supplemental municipal code enforcement procedures. 
The provisions herein shall apply to the enforcement of all provisions of the Code of Ordinances and the Land Development Code of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 3662, § 13, 1-8-2009)  
ARTICLE XIII. - FINANCE 
 
Sec. 2-1301. - City depositories. 
The Council shall from time to time in its discretion designate banks or trust companies as City depositories. Any bank acting as a City depository shall make monthly reports showing the balance on hand at the beginning of the month, the sums received and paid out during the month, and the balance on hand at the end of the month, and shall return with said report all checks or warrants properly cancelled, which the said bank has paid during the said month. Council may establish rules and regulations governing the deposits, withdrawals of funds, security to be deposited by the depository, and other safeguards for the deposited moneys of the City; providing that the same shall not be inconsistent with the provisions hereof.  
Sec. 2-1302. - Fees and moneys collected to be deposited. 
All fees and moneys collected and received by officers and employees shall be immediately paid over to the collecting officer of the City for deposit in City depositories as herein provided.  
Sec. 2-1303. - Accounts, accounting procedures; financial reports. 
Subject to the control and supervision of the City Manager, accounts shall be kept by the Finance Department showing the financial transactions of all departments and offices of the City. The forms of all such accounts and the financial reports rendered to or by the Department of Finance shall be prescribed and approved by the City Manager. The accounts and accounting procedure of the City shall be adequate to record all cash receipts and disbursements, all revenue accrued and liabilities incurred, and all transactions affecting the acquisition, custody and disposition of values, and the officer in charge of such accounting shall make such reports of the financial transactions and conditions of the City as may be required by law, this Charter or by Ordinance. The financial reports shall be prepared for each quarter and for each fiscal year, and for such other periods as may be required by the City Manager. 
(Section 43; brought forth from former City Charter—1977)  
Sec. 2-1304. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year of the City shall begin on the first day of October and shall end on the last day of September of each calendar year. Such fiscal year shall also constitute the budget and accounting year. As used in this Article, the term "Budget Year" shall mean the fiscal year for which any particular budget is adopted and in which it is administered. 
(Section 44; brought forth from former City Charter—1977)  
Sec. 2-1305. - Annual budget. 
Annually, within the period prescribed by the City Manager, the directors and chiefs of departments and divisions shall prepare and submit to the City Manager, detailed information and estimates of the expenditures and revenues of their respective departments and divisions for the ensuing year. The City Manager from such information and estimates shall compile, revise and submit to the City Council on or before the second regular meeting in August of each year a budget presenting a financial plan for conducting the affairs of the City for the ensuing fiscal year. The budget shall include the following information: 
(a)  Detailed estimates of the expense of conducting each department and office of the City for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(b)  Expenditures for corresponding items for the current year and last preceding fiscal year with reasons for increases and decreases recommended as compared with appropriations for the current year. 
(c)  The value of supplies and materials on hand at the date of the preparation of the estimates. 
(d)  The amount of the total and net debt of the City together with a schedule of maturities of bond issues. 
(e)  A statement of the total probable income of the City from taxes for the period covered by the estimate. 
(f)  An itemization of anticipated revenue from other sources. 
(g)  The amount required for interest on the City debt, for sinking funds and for maturing bonds. 
(h)  Such other information as may be required by the Council. 
(Section 45; brought forth from former City Charter—1977)  
Sec. 2-1306. - Annual appropriation ordinance. 
Upon receipt of the budget estimate, the Council shall review the same and shall prepare an appropriation Ordinance, using the City Manager's estimate as a basis. 
(A)  The Council shall have power to increase or decrease the amount recommended for any department, division or office, by items only. The Council shall provide for printing a reasonable number of copies of the budget estimate for distribution to those citizens who wish same, and provision shall be made for public hearings on the proposed appropriation Ordinance before the Council sitting as a committee of the whole. The appropriation Ordinance shall be passed on or before the first regular meeting in September each year. 
(B)  Before the annual appropriation Ordinance has been passed, the Council may make appropriations for the current expenses of the City, chargeable to the appropriations of the year when passed, to any amount sufficient to cover the necessary expense of the various departments, divisions and offices until the annual appropriation Ordinance is in force. No other liabilities shall be incurred by any officer or employee of the City, except in accordance with the provisions of the annual appropriation Ordinance. 
(C)  Upon the request of the City Manager, the Council may transfer any part of any unencumbered balance of an appropriation to a purpose or object for which the appropriation for the current year has been deemed insufficient, or may authorize a transfer to be made between items appropriated between departments, divisions or offices. The City Manager may authorize a transfer for line items to be made within departments, divisions or offices. 
(D)  Any accruing revenue of the City not appropriated as hereinbefore provided, and the balance at any time remaining after the purposes of an appropriation shall have been satisfied or abandoned may from time to time be appropriated by the Council to such uses as will not conflict with any uses for which specifically such revenue accrued. 
(E)  No money shall be drawn from the treasury of the City, nor shall any obligation for the expenditures of money be incurred, except pursuant to appropriations made by the Council. At the close of each fiscal year the unencumbered balance of each appropriation shall revert to the fund from which it was appropriated and shall be subject to future appropriation; but appropriations may be made in furtherance of improvements or other objects or works of the City which will not be completed within the current year. 
(F)  No liability shall be enforceable against the City upon any contract nor supported by the previous appropriation, nor shall the City be liable for any service, material or supplies furnished to the City, or to any department, division or office thereof, the financial requirements of which are to be met out of the proceeds of taxes or any other funds controlled by the Council, unless the Council shall previously have made an appropriation therefor. In the event contracts are made to extend over a period of longer than one (1) year, and which are to be met from current receipts of the City, it shall be lawful for the Council to make appropriations sufficient to answer the requirements of any such contracts for only one (1) year, and the contract shall be legal and binding upon the City notwithstanding the fact that no appropriation has been made for the ensuing years over which it is to be operative, and it shall be the duty of the Council to make appropriations from year to year as required for the purpose of such contracts. The obligations of the City under such contracts shall not be considered to be a part of the indebtedness of the City. 
(G)  Accounts shall be kept for each specific item of appropriation made by the Council, and every warrant on the treasury shall state specifically against which of such items the warrant is drawn. Each account shall show in detail the appropriations made thereto by the Council, the amount drawn thereon, the unpaid obligations charged against it. 
(H)  No claims against the City shall be paid except by means of a warrant on the treasury issued by the Director of Finance or his deputy and countersigned by the Mayor or Vice-Mayor. The Director of Finance shall examine all payrolls, bills, purchase orders and other claims and demands against the City, and shall issue no warrant for payment unless he finds the claim is in proper form, correctly computed and duly certified, and that it is justly and legally due and payable, that an appropriation has been made therefor which has not been exhausted, or that the payment has been otherwise legally authorized; and that there is money in the City treasury to make payment. All purchase orders must be approved by the City Manager prior to the payment therefor. The Director of Finance may require any claimant to make oath to the validity of a claim. He may investigate any claim and for that purpose may examine witnesses under oath, and if he finds a claim to be fraudulent, erroneous or otherwise invalid, he shall not issue a warrant therefor. If the Director of Finance issues a warrant on the treasury for any item for which no appropriation has been made, or for the payment of which there is not sufficient money in the proper fund, or which for any other cause should not be approved, he and his sureties shall be individually liable to the City for the amount of such warrant, if paid. 
(I)  All taxes, special assessments, license fees and other moneys accruing to the City shall be collected by the Director of Finance or other officer or employee designated by the City Manager. All money received by any officer or employee of the City for or in connection with the business of the City shall be paid promptly into the City treasury, and shall be deposited with such responsible banking institutions as furnish such security as the City Manager may determine. All interest on money so deposited shall accrue to the benefit of the City. The Council shall provide by Ordinance for the prompt and regular payment and deposit of all City moneys as required by this Section. 
(Section 46; brought forth from former City Charter—1977)  
ARTICLE XIV. - LEGAL COUNSEL FOR CITY OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES; PAYMENT OF JUDGMENTS 
 
Sec. 2-1401. - Legal counsel for city officials and employees; payment of judgments. 
(A)  Pursuant to F.S. § 111.07, in those instances when the City's insurance carrier does not provide legal counsel, the City shall provide legal counsel of its choice at its expense to defend any civil action brought against any of its elected or appointed officials, including members of advisory boards, or employees for alleged acts or omissions arising out and in the scope of their employment or function with the City, including authorized service in such capacity on other governmental bodies, unless, in the case of a tort action, such official or employee was acting in bad faith, with malicious purpose, or in a manner exhibiting wanton and willful disregard of human rights, safety or property. 
(B)  Pursuant to F.S. § 111.071, in those instances when the City's insurance does not provide coverage, the City shall expend available monies in the fund required to be established hereunder to pay: 
1.  Any final personal judgment, including damages, costs and attorney's fees, against any elected or appointed official, including members of advisory boards, and employees of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, held to be personally liable in a civil action for acts or omissions arising out of and in the scope of the employment or function with the City, including authorized service in such capacity on other governmental bodies, except as hereinafter limited. If the civil action arises under F.S. § 768.28, as a tort claim, the limitations and provisions of that section governing payment, including the specific limits on amount of payments as contained in F.S. § 768.28(5) and the exclusions for acts and omissions done in bad faith or with malicious purpose, or any manner exhibiting wanton and willful disregard of human rights, safety, or property as contained in F.S. § 768.28(9), shall apply. If the civil action arises under 42 U.S.C. Section 1983, or similar federal statutes, payments for the full amount of the judgment may be made unless the official or employee has been determined in the final judgment to have caused harm intentionally. 
2.  Any compromise or settlement of any claim or litigation as described in paragraph (1) shall be subject to the limitations set forth in that paragraph. 
(C)  For the purposes of this Article 14, the term "final judgment" means a judgment upon completion of any appellate proceedings. 
(D)  The City Manager shall cause a separate fund to be established from appropriate City revenues for the purpose of paying the authorized monies hereafter. The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to obtain the services of a licensed actuary and all such other persons as may be necessary and proper to establish an actuarially sound fund as provided for herein. 
(E)  This Article XIV is not intended to be a waiver of sovereign immunity or of any other defense or immunity. 
(Ord. No. 1594, 2-13-1986)  
ARTICLE XVI. - ENTITLED CITY OF PINELLAS PARK SALARY REDIRECTION BENEFIT PROGRAM AND DEPENDENT CARE ASSISTANCE PLAN 
 
Sec. 2-1601. - City of Pinellas Park Salary Redirection Benefit Program. 
The City of Pinellas Park hereby adopts the Salary Redirection Benefit Program attached hereto as Exhibit "A". The purpose of the program shall be to provide City employees with the option of obtaining noncash benefits (life insurance, health insurance, dental insurance) with pretax dollars under the program as set forth in the attached Salary Redirection Benefit Program. Participation in the program shall be optional. 
(Ord. No. 1962, 3-8-1990) 
Editor's note— Exhibit A cited in § 2-1601 has not been set out in the Code, but is on file in the office of the City Clerk.  
Sec. 2-1602. - City of Pinellas Park Dependent Care Assistance Plan. 
The City of Pinellas Park hereby adopts the Dependent Care Assistance Plan attached hereto as Exhibit "B". The plan is intended to qualify as a dependent care assistance program under Section 129 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. The purpose of the plan shall be to provide City employees with the option of paying with pretax dollars their dependent care expenses that are excludable from gross income under Section 129 of the Internal Revenue Code. Participation in the program shall be optional. 
(Ord. No. 1962, 3-8-1990) 
Editor's note— Exhibit B cited in § 2-1602 has not been set out in the Code, but is on file in the office of the City Clerk.  
ARTICLE XVII. - PROCEDURES FOR RESPONSES TO AND SETTLEMENTS FOR CLAIMS FILED UNDER THE BERT J. HARRIS, JR. PRIVATE PROPERTY RIGHTS PROTECTION ACT (THE "PRIVATE PROPERTY RIGHTS PROTECTION ACT") AND THE FLORIDA LAND USE AND ENVIRONMENTAL DISPUTE RESOLUTION ACT (THE "DISPUTE RESOLUTION ACT") 
 
Sec. 2-1701. - Procedures for responses to and settlements of claims filed under the Private Property Rights Act. 
A.  The Claimant shall file his written claim, together with the required appraisal, with the City Manager or his designee. Immediately upon receipt of the claim and appraisal, the City Manager shall transmit copies thereof to all members of City Council, the City Attorney, the Risk Management Director, all parties to any administrative action which gave rise to the claim, and the owners of real property contiguous to the claimant's property at the addresses listed on the most recent county tax rolls. Within fifteen (15) days from receipt of the claim, the City Manager or his designee shall, after consultation with the City Attorney, report the claim in writing to the Department of Legal Affairs and shall provide the Department with the name, address, and telephone number of the employee of the City from whom additional information may be obtained about the claim during the pendency of the claim and any subsequent judicial action. 
B.  As soon as is practicable after the service of the claim upon the City Manager or his designee, the City Attorney and the City Manager shall discuss the claim with City Council at an appropriate lawfully called meeting. Thereafter, the City Attorney and City Manager shall, to the extent they deem appropriate, engage in preliminary settlement negotiations with the claimant, or his or her legal counsel, with a view toward formulating a proposed settlement agreement to be presented to City Council for consideration. If requested by City Council, or if the City Attorney and City Manager deem it advisable, they may have additional discussions regarding the preliminary settlement negotiations with City Council at appropriate subsequent lawfully called meetings. 
C.  As a goal, and not as a mandatory time requirement, the City Attorney and City Manager shall attempt to conclude the preliminary settlement negotiations and present a proposed settlement agreement to City Council for its consideration within one hundred twenty (120) days after service of the claim upon the City Manager or his designee. 
D.  City Council shall thereafter consider the proposed settlement agreement. At the conclusion of its discussions regarding the proposed settlement agreement, City Council shall adopt an approved proposed settlement agreement, and shall authorize the City Attorney to transmit the approved proposed settlement agreement to the claimant, or to his or her legal counsel. The approved proposed settlement agreement shall, to the extent deemed appropriate by City Council, offer to effectuate: 
1.  An adjustment of land development or permit standards or other provisions controlling development or use of land; 
2.  Any increases or modifications in the density or use of areas of development; 
3.  The transfer of development rights; 
4.  Land swap or exchanges; 
5.  Mitigation, including payments in lieu of on-site mitigation; 
6.  Location on the least sensitive portion of the property; 
7.  Conditioning the amount of development or use permitted; 
8.  A requirement that issues by addressed on a more comprehensive basis than a single proposed use or development; 
9.  Issuance of the development order, a variance, conditional use, or other extraordinary relief; 
10.  Purchase of the real property, or an interest therein, by the City and/or any other governmental or nongovernmental third party; 
11.  No changes to the action of the City. 
Notwithstanding any other provisions of the Code of Ordinances to the contrary, City Council shall have the sole authority for the approval of any proposed settlement agreement without any action by any other board or commission of the City. In the absence of a specific requirement by City Council that a proposed settlement agreement be referred to any other board or commission of the City for review and input, the proposed settlement agreement shall not be so referred. City Council shall have full authority, without any action by any other board or commission of the City, to enter into appropriate development agreements, issue variances, approve special exceptions, grant extraordinary relief, and take any all further action as may be necessary to effectuate any such proposed settlement agreement, including those which would have the effect of a modification, variance, or a special exception to the application of a policy, resolution, or ordinance as it would otherwise apply to the subject real property. The proposed settlement agreement shall protect the public interest served by the regulations at issue and be the appropriate relief necessary to prevent the City's regulatory effort from inordinately burdening the subject real property. 
E.  Upon receipt of authorization from City Council, the City Attorney shall transmit the proposed settlement agreement to the claimant or to his or her legal counsel. 
F.  The City Attorney shall thereafter notify City Council as to whether the claimant has accepted or rejected the proposed settlement agreement. 
1.  If the claimant accepts the proposed settlement agreement, then the matter shall be returned to City Council for any necessary final action required to effectuate the same. If any such proposed settlement agreement accepted by the claimant which effectively contravenes the application of a statute as it would otherwise apply to the affected property, the City Attorney shall jointly with the Claimant file an action in the Circuit Court for Pinellas County, Florida, for approval by that Court to ensure that the relief granted protects the public interest served by the relevant statute and is the appropriate relief necessary to prevent the City's regulatory effort from inordinately burdening the real property in question. 
2.  If the claimant rejects the City's proposed settlement agreement, then the City Manager shall, after consultation with the City Attorney, issue a written ripeness decision identifying the allowable uses for the property in question to confirm what the claimant can and cannot do with the subject property. 
G.  Should the claimant reject the City's ripeness decision as well as the proposed settlement agreement and file a claim for compensation in the Circuit Court for Pinellas County, Florida, the claimant shall contemporaneously serve a copy thereof upon the City Manager or his designee. Immediately upon the service of such claim, the City Manager or his designee shall provide copies thereof to the City Attorney and to the risk Management Director. 
H.  Within fifteen (15) days after the execution of any settlement, or the issuance of any judgment, the City Manager or his designee shall, after consultation with the City Attorney, provide a copy of the settlement or judgment to the Department of Legal Affairs. 
(Ord. No. 2361, 11-9-1995)  
Sec. 2-1702. - Procedures for responses to and settlement of claims filed under the Dispute Resolution Act. 
A.  The Claimant shall file his written claim, with the City Manager or his designee. Immediately upon receipt of the claim, the City Manager shall transmit copies thereof to all members of City Council, the City Attorney, and the Risk Management Director. 
B.  Within ten (10) days from the service of the claim upon the City Manager or his designee, the City Attorney shall forward the request for relief filed by the claimant to the Special Master who is mutually agreed upon by the claimant, or his or her legal counsel, and the City Attorney. 
Additionally, within the same time-frame, the City Manager or his designee shall serve a copy of the request for relief by United States mail or by hand delivery to: 
1.  Owners of real property contiguous to the claimant's property at the address on the latest county tax rolls; and 
2.  Any substantially affected party who submitted oral or written testimony, sworn or unsworn, of a substantive nature, which stated with particularity objections to or support for any development order at issue, or any enforcement action at issue. However, such notice under this subparagraph 2. is required only if that party indicated a desire to receive notice of any subsequent special master proceedings occurring on the development order or enforcement action. The City shall maintain in its files relating to development orders and enforcement actions mailing lists of persons who have presented oral or written testimony, sworn or unsworn, and who have requested notice. All hearing notices shall contain a statement that only those persons who have presented oral or written testimony with respect to a development order or enforcement action and who have requested notice will be given notice of any subsequent special master proceedings in a claim initiated under The Dispute Resolution Act. 
C.  Within fifteen (15) days of service of the claim on the City Manager or his designee, the City Attorney, after consultation with the City Council at an appropriate lawfully called meeting or meetings, shall file a response delineating the City's position regarding the claimant's allegations and the public purpose of the regulations on which the development order is based with the special master and copy thereof upon the claimant or his or her legal counsel. 
D.  The City Attorney shall represent the City in proceedings before the special masters unless the City's insurance carrier has retained legal counsel to represent the City in such proceedings. 
E.  Upon receipt of the Special Master's decision, the City Attorney shall advise City Council and the City Manager of the same. If the special master finds that a development order at issue is unreasonable or unfairly burdens the use of the claimant's property, and the special master makes a recommendation, then within forty-five (45) days after the City Attorney's receipt of the special master's recommendation, the City and any other governmental entities participating in the proceeding shall consult among themselves, and City Council shall: 
1.  Accept the recommendation of the Special Master as submitted and proceed to implement it by development agreement, when appropriate, or by other method; or 
2.  Modify the recommendation as submitted by the Special Master and proceed to implement the same by development agreement, when appropriate, or by other method; or 
3.  Reject the recommendation as submitted by the Special Master. 
Notwithstanding any other provisions of the Code of Ordinances to the contrary, City Council shall have the sole authority to take any of the above described actions regarding the Special Master's recommendation without any action by any other board or commission of the City. In the absence of a specific requirement by City Council that a Special Master's recommendation be referred to any other board or commission for the City for review and input, the same shall not be so referred. City Council shall have full authority without any action by any other board or commission of the City to reject such recommendation or to approve development orders and take any and all further action as may be necessary to effectuate any such recommendations as submitted or as modified. 
F.  If the City accepts the Special Master's recommendation or modifies it, and the owner rejects the acceptance or modification, or if the City rejects the Special Master's recommendation, then the City Manager shall, after consultation with the City Attorney, issue a written response decision within thirty (30) days therefrom that describes as specifically as possible the use or uses available to the subject property. 
G.  The City Manager shall, upon request from the City Attorney, authorize payment of the City's portion of the reasonable special master fees and expenses, including the costs of providing notice and effecting service of the request for relief, from the appropriate City account(s). 
(Ord. No. 2361, 11-9-1995)  
CHAPTER 3 - SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS 
 
Sec. 3-101. - Canvasser and solicitor defined. 
The terms "canvasser" and "solicitor" shall be deemed to mean and include any person who goes from house to house or from place to place in the City taking orders for or offering to sell or take orders for any product or service for future delivery or sells or offers for sale any coupons or other tokens as evidence of payment or part payment on any product or service. Provided, however, that neither such term shall be deemed to include a bona fide employee of a newspaper of general circulation who goes from house to house or from place to place in the City soliciting written orders for subscriptions to such newspaper of general circulation. For purposes of this Chapter, the term "newspaper of general circulation" means a newspaper in which legal notices are authorized to be published pursuant to F.S. § 50.011. 
(Ord. No. 77, 2-25-1954; Ord. No. 1959, 1-25-1990)  
Sec. 3-102. - Permit—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a canvasser or solicitor within the City, without having first obtained a permit to do so and otherwise complying with the terms and provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 77, 2-25-1954)  
Sec. 3-103. - Permit—Application; license tax. 
Any person desiring to engage in the business of canvassing and soliciting within the City shall first make application in writing to the City Clerk which application shall be filed with the City Clerk and shall state the name and residence of the applicant, the product or service and location of employer, the length of time for which such canvasser or solicitor desires to engage in such business, the applicant's automobile tag number, if he shall own an automobile and two photographs of the applicant, to be not less than two inches by one inch. 
No permit shall be issued to any applicant until such applicant shall first have paid to the Business Tax Receipt Department of the City the proper business tax receipt, as provided in the current Fee Schedule for the City. 
(Ord. No. 77, 2-25-1954; Ord. No. 3538, § 2, 3-22-2007)  
Sec. 3-104. - Permit—Issuance; term. 
When any applicant shall have complied with the terms of this Chapter, the City Clerk shall issue to such canvasser and solicitor a permit for the time specified in such application, which permit shall be in no event for a period of time over one (1) year. 
It shall be unlawful for any canvasser to continue in business within the City after such permit shall have expired unless the canvasser shall establish a recognized place of business within the City. 
(Ord. No. 77, 2-25-1954)  
Sec. 3-105. - Orders in writing. 
All orders taken by any permit holder shall be in writing and in duplicate, stating fully the terms thereof together with the amount paid in advance and the balance remaining due on such order. One (1) copy of such order shall be delivered to the purchaser at the time the order is taken. 
(Ord. No. 77, 2-25-1954)  
CHAPTER 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 
 
Sec. 4-101. - Adoption of state law. 
The City hereby adopts by reference as fully as if set forth herein the Beverage Law of the State of Florida as that phrase is defined in F.S. § 561.01. The Beverage Law of the State of Florida and this Chapter shall be enforced by appropriate Officers of the City as well as by officers of the State Beverage Department and any other State officers charged with enforcement of the Beverage Law. 
(Ord. No. 321, 7-27-1967; Ord. No. 2114, 2-27-1992)  
Sec. 4-102. - Power to regulate the sale, dispensing and consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
The City Council shall have the power and authority to establish Zoning Ordinances restricting the locations wherein the sale, dispensing and consumption of alcoholic beverages may be permitted. No license shall be granted for the sale, dispensing or consumption of alcoholic beverages in a location where such sale, dispensing or consumption of alcoholic beverages is prohibited by Ordinance. This Section shall not apply to the sale of beer and malt beverages containing alcohol of five-tenths (0.5) percent or more by volume sold only for consumption off-premises. 
All business establishments engaged in the sale, dispensing or consumption of alcoholic beverages shall do so in accordance with City zoning regulations which permit same and shall also comply with the provisions of this Chapter and, where applicable, Sections 16-110, 16-112, 18-1507 and 18-1509.6. of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2114, 2-27-1992)  
Sec. 4-103. - Reserved.  
Sec. 4-104. - Closing hours. 
The opening and closing hours for all alcoholic beverage establishments and the hours for sale of alcoholic beverages shall be those established by Chapter 6, Article II, Sections 6-29 and 6-30 of the Pinellas County code of Ordinances, or amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1306, Referendum 11-8-1983; Ord. No. 3182, 11-13-2003)  
Sec. 4-105. - Activities prohibited during closing hours; exception. 
It shall be unlawful at any time during the closing hours prescribed in Section 4-104: 
(A)  For any person to sell, offer for sale, serve, dispense or consume alcoholic beverages at any establishment in the City dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(B)  For any person to suffer, permit or allow any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages to be and remain open for the transaction of any business of any kind whatsoever. 
(C)  For any person to suffer, permit or allow any person to consume any alcoholic beverage or to enter or to remain in any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(D)  For any person to enter or to be or remain in any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages, provided nothing contained in this Section shall be construed to prevent a vendor dealing in alcoholic beverages or a person authorized by such vendor from entering, being or remaining in such establishment during prohibited hours when the vendor or the person authorized by such vendor is actually engaged in duties other than the sale, serving, or consumption of alcoholic beverages in such establishment; nor shall this be construed to prevent any fireman or law enforcement officer or agent of the City from entering, being or remaining in such establishment in the performance of his duties. 
(E)  For purposes of this Chapter 4, the term "establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages" shall man every kind of commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are, or are available to be, sold, dispensed, consumed, or possessed, or are offered for sale or consumption on the premises, or are authorized or permitted to be consumed on the premises. This definition shall include any such commercial establishment not holding a valid alcoholic beverage license from the State of Florida but at which there is consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises by patrons or employees. 
(Ord. No. 321, 7-27-1967; Ord. No. 2114, 2-27-1992)  
Sec. 4-106. - Sale to habitual drunkard prohibited; notice of intemperance. 
No person, business establishment or vendor dealing in alcoholic beverages shall sell, furnish or deliver, or permit any person in his employ to sell, furnish or deliver any alcoholic beverages of any kind, in any quantity, to an habitual drunkard known to him, or whose intemperate habits such vendor has been notified of in writing protesting against the selling or furnishing of such alcoholic beverages, by the husband, wife, father, mother, sister, brother, son, or daughter of the habitual drunkard; and it shall be unlawful for any such vendor when so notified to allow, suffer or permit any habitual drunkard, as set forth in this Section, to be or remain in any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
It shall further be unlawful for any person, business establishment, or vendor to sell, furnish, dispense or deliver any alcoholic beverages to an habitual drunkard where the person, business establishment, or vendor has been notified in writing by any Court personnel or Police Officer that such habitual drunkard has been convicted on a charge of operating a motor vehicle, while under the influence of alcohol; or that such person has been convicted three (3) times or more on a charge of disorderly intoxication, and it shall be unlawful for any person, business establishment, or vendor to permit such person to be or remain in any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 321, 7-27-1967; Ord. No. 2114, 2-27-1992)  
Sec. 4-107. - Minor; prohibiting sale to, employment or permitting on premises. 
(A)  No person of by himself or another, shall sell or cause to be sold, furnished or delivered to any minor (as defined by State law) any alcoholic beverage. 
(B)  It shall be unlawful for any person, business establishment, or vendor licensed under the State Beverage Law to employ any person under eighteen (18) years of age. However, this Subsection shall not apply to: 
1.  Professional Entertainers seventeen (17) years of age who are not in school. 
2.  Persons under the age of eighteen (18) years who are employed in drugstores, supermarkets, grocery stores, convenient stores, or automobile service stations which have obtained licenses to sell beer or beer and wine, when such sales are made for consumption off the premises. 
3.  Persons seventeen (17) years of age or over or any person furnishing evidence that he is a senior high school student with written permission of the principal of said Senior High School or that he is a Senior High School graduate, or any high school graduate, employed by a bona fide food service establishment where alcoholic beverages are sold, provided such persons to not participate in the sale, preparation, or service of the beverages and that their duties are of such nature as to provide them with the training and knowledge as might lead to further advancement in food service establishments. 
4.  Persons under the age of eighteen (18) years employed as bellhops, elevator persons, and others in hotels or motels when such employees are engaged in work apart from the portion of the hotel or motel property where alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises. 
5.  Persons under the age of eighteen (18) years employed in bowling alleys in which alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed, so long as such minors do not participate in the sale, preparation, or service of such beverages. 
6.  Persons under the age of eighteen (18) years employed by a bona fide dinner theater as defined in this paragraph, as long as their employment is limited to the services of an actor, actress, or musician. For purposes of this paragraph a dinner theater means a theater presenting consecutive productions playing no less than three (3) weeks each in conjunction with dinner service on a regular basis. In addition both events must occur in the same room, and the only advertised price of admission must include both the cost of the meal and the attendance at the performance. 
(Ord. No. 321, 7-27-1967; Ord. No. 2114, 2-27-1992)  
Sec. 4-108. - Definitions; possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places prohibited; penalties. 
(A)  Definitions. As used in this Chapter, the following words shall be defined as follows: 
1.  Alcoholic beverage shall mean distilled spirits and all beverages containing one-half (½) of one (1) percent or more alcohol by volume. The presence of alcohol in the beverage may be determined by any person who, by experience in handling or the use of alcoholic beverages, or who by taste, smell, observing the labelling, or the drinking of such alcoholic beverages, has knowledge as to the presence of alcohol in the subject beverage. 
2.  Person shall include any individual, company, corporation, partnership, association, club or lodge, or any other legal entity. 
3.  Public place shall mean any public building, grounds or parking area, and any street, alley, sidewalk, park, parking area, or any other open property within the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, to which the general public is licensed or invited to enter, which such open property specifically includes all exterior areas, such as parking lots and parking areas, sidewalks, walkways, grassy areas or other open areas of any of commercial establishments. 
(B)  Possession of alcoholic beverages in open containers and consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places prohibited. 
1.  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any alcoholic beverage in a cup or other open or unsealed container in any public place in the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
2.  It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverages in any public place in the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
3.  This Section shall apply to persons who are in a motor vehicle in a public place whether such motor vehicle is being operated or not. 
(C)  Penalties. Any person who violates any provisions of this Chapter shall, upon conviction in a Court of competent jurisdiction, be punished by a fine not to exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, provided however, that any person found guilty of possessing an open container of an alcoholic beverage while operating a motor vehicle in the City or while a passenger in or on a motor vehicle being operated in the City is guilty of a noncriminal moving traffic violation, punishable as provided by State law. 
(Ord. No. 1116, 10-20-1981; Ord. No. 1222, 12-9-1982; Ord. No. 1774, 3-10-1988; Ord. No. 2114, 2-27-1992; Ord. No. 3718, § 1, 2-11-2010; Ord. No. 3750, § 2, 10-28-2010) 
Formerly, § 4-109. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3750, § 1, adopted October 28, 2010, repealed § 4-108, which pertained to proximity of business establishments dealing in alcoholic beverages to educational institutions (elementary, middle and senior), youth or public recreation centers, playgrounds, churches, temples and similar religious institutions, hospitals, and child care centers; method of measurement; exceptions and derived from Ord. No. 321, 7-27-1967; Ord. No. 1777, 4-28-1988; Ord. No. 1814, 11-22-1988; Ord. No. 2114, 2-27-1992; Ord. No. 3728, § 1, 5-13-2010. Subsequently, § 2 of Ord. 3750 renumbered and amended § 4-109 as § 4-108 to read as herein set out.  
CHAPTER 5 - ANIMALS AND FOWL  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3866, § 1, adopted October 11, 2013, repealed the former Art. I, §§ 5-101—5-104, and enacted a new Art. I as set out herein. The former Art. I pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 22, 4-15-1948; Ord. No. 296, 1-12-1967; Ord. No. 1081, 5-28-1981. 
 
Sec. 5-101. - Duty to fence premises, etc. 
It is hereby declared to be the duty of the owner and of the person in charge of livestock or fowl on any property within the City to keep same adequately fenced. 
(Ord. No. 3866, § 1, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-102. - Bird sanctuary; exceptions; destruction of birds deemed nuisances; penalty for violation of section. 
(A)  The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, be and hereby is designated as a bird sanctuary. 
(B)  It shall be unlawful to trap, hunt, shoot, or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl, or to rob bird nests or wild fowl nests; provided, if starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality within the City that they constitute a nuisance or menace to health or property in the opinion of the City Manager of the City, and no satisfactory remedy is found to abate such nuisance, then the City Manager shall apply to the Humane Society or other appropriate agency for the destruction of said birds in such numbers as is deemed advisable by said City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 3866, § 1, 10-11-2013)  
ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL 
 
Sec. 5-201. - Definitions. 
As used in this Article, and for the purpose of enforcement of the provisions imposed by this Article, the following terms shall mean: 
Animal - dangerous or vicious: Any animal, whether wild or domesticated that has aggressively bitten, attacked or endangered, or has inflicted severe injury on a human being on public or private property; has more than once severely injured or killed a domestic animal while off the owner's property; has been used primarily or in part for the purpose of fighting or trained for fighting; or has, when unprovoked, chased or approached a person upon the streets, sidewalks, or any private property other than the private property of its owner or public grounds in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack. 
Animal - domestic: Animals that are routinely kept for personal use or enjoyment, which are not exhibited to the public, nor raised for commercial purposes or profit. Domestic animals shall include dogs, cats, mice, hamsters, rabbits, birds, and similar animals that are owned by and raised for the personal enjoyment of the residents of the household where kept, or any other animal deemed appropriate by the City Manager or his designee. 
Animal - farm or livestock: Animals commonly associated with farm use, or raised for commercial purposes or profit, including, but not limited to, hoofed mammals such as cattle, sheep, goats, swine, and horses, fowl, or any other animal deemed appropriate by the City Manager or his designee. 
At large: Any animal shall be deemed to be at large when it is off the property of its owner and not under control of a competent person. 
Attack: An overtly aggressive act including but no limited to biting, scratching or clawing which involves actual physical contact between the animal and any person. 
Exposed to rabies: An animal has been exposed to rabies within the meaning of this Article if it has been bitten by, or been exposed to, any animal having been infected with rabies. 
Humane society: Any society whose duly constituted purpose is to prevent cruelty to animals, as so designated by the City Council, Board of County Commissioners or State of Florida. 
Kennel: Any person engaged in the commercial business of breeding, buying, or selling animals, or providing day care or boarding services for more than five (5) adult animals of the same species. 
Owner: Any person, group of persons, or corporation owning, keeping or harboring an animal or animals. 
Public nuisance animal or animal premises: Any animal or combination of animals, or animal premises, that unreasonably annoys humans, endangers the life or health of other animals or persons, or substantially interferes with the rights of citizens, or the enjoyment of life or property. 
Restraint: An animal is under restraint within the meaning of this Article if it is controlled by a leash, or at "heel" beside a competent person and obedient to that person's commands, or on or within a vehicle being driven or parked on the streets, or within the property limits of its owner or keeper. 
Spayed female: Any female animal which has been operated upon to prevent conception. 
(Ord. No. 211, 7-25-1963; Ord. No. 1081, 5-28-1981; Ord. No. 3192, 11-25-03; Ord. No. 3866, § 2, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-202. - Animals or animal premises creating nuisances. 
(A)  The owner, person acting for the owner, or person in control of any animal or animal premises that has been deemed a public nuisance animal or animal premises, as defined under this Article and outlined in this Section, shall be deemed to be in violation of this Section. 
(B)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor any animal which barks, whines, howls, or makes other utterances of noises in a repeated or constant manner so as to create a public nuisance, or to keep or harbor any animal which chases after vehicles, bicycles, persons, or other animals in a manner which is likely to cause injury to person or property, or to keep or harbor any animal which destroys or damages property of another, or to keep or harbor any animal or provide any animal premises which unreasonably interferes with the use and enjoyment of the property of another, or have control or custody of any animal which is running at large, causes fouling of the air by odor, defecates on the property of another, or is offensive or dangerous to the public health, safety, or welfare, or to keep or harbor any animal or provide any animal premises that is considered to be a nuisance or menace in the opinion of the City Manager and/or his designee. 
(C)  It shall be unlawful for any person to feed or distribute grain, other food or garbage of any kind or nature in such a manner as to attract wild or domestic birds, fowl, mammals, or other animals of any kind or nature in confined or concentrated areas in such numbers as to create a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 1081, 5-28-1981; Ord. No. 1117, 11-12-1981; Ord. No. 1464, 1-24-1985; Ord. No. 3192, 11-25-2003; Ord. No. 3866, § 3, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-203. - Licensing and vaccination required. 
(A)  License required. No person shall keep any animal required to be licensed within the City limits unless such animal is licensed as required by law. 
(B)  Vaccination of animals required. Every owner of an animal, whether or not such animal is required by law to be licensed, shall cause such animal to be vaccinated against rabies on an annual basis, when such vaccination is required in accordance with accepted veterinary practice. 
(Ord. No. 1081, 5-28-1981; Ord. No. 3866, § 4, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-204. - Keeping of Vietnamese Potbellied Pigs. 
(A)  Vietnamese Potbellied Pigs ( sus, scrofa domestica ) shall be prohibited in the City limits, except in "F" Farm District. 
(B)  Vietnamese Potbellied Pigs ( sus, scrofa domestica ) which lawfully existed and for which documentation exists with a date prior to the effective date of this Ordinance shall be limited to two (2) per dwelling unit, and nothing in this Code shall permit the breeding of said pigs. 
(Ord. No. 2118, 2-27-1992; Ord. No. 3866, § 5, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-205. - Restraint required. 
The owner or person acting for the owner shall keep his/her animal(s) under restraint as heretofore defined at all times and shall not permit such animal(s) to be at large and off the premises or property of the owner, unless under the control of a competent person. 
(Ord. No. 211, 7-25-1963; Ord. No. 3866, § 6, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-206. - Animals kept in residential zoning districts. 
(A)  Domestic animals, as defined in Section 5-201, may be kept in residential zoning districts. 
(B)  No more than four (4) female chickens (i.e., hens) per single-family residential lot are permitted. Such hens must be owned by the household occupants where kept and raised for personal enjoyment and/or in-home egg consumption, provided there shall be no breeding and no commercial use. No male chickens (i.e., roosters) are permitted. 
(C)  When animals permitted in this Section are housed in an outdoor coop or similar structure on a single-family residential lot, such coop or similar structure shall not be located within the front yard of any interior lot, shall not exceed six (6) feet in height, shall be erected to maintain a setback of fifteen (15) feet from all abutting property lines, shall be screened from view from the right of way by a six (6) feet high solid fence, and shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
(D)  Farm or livestock animals, as defined in Section 5-201, are prohibited in residential zoning districts, with the exception of the "F" Farm District, and where also permitted in this Section. 
(E)  No kennels, as defined in Sections 5-201 and Sec. 18-1502.2, are permitted in residential zoning districts. 
(F)  Nothing in this Section is meant to restrict equestrian uses which are provided for in the "F" Farm District, "RE" Residential Estate District, and "RR" Rural Residential District, nor equestrian riding which is provided for in Sections 5-301 and 5-302. 
(G)  Animal owners shall comply with all applicable State and/or County laws and regulations related to the keeping and/or housing of their animals. 
(Ord. No. 3866, § 7, 10-11-2013)  
Secs. 5-207, 5-208. - Reserved.  
Sec. 5-209. - Unlawful to have possession or control of certain animals. 
Unless authorized in writing by the State of Florida, the keeping or possession of any of the following types of animals is prohibited anywhere within the corporate limits of the City of Pinellas Park: 
Dangerous or vicious animals; 
Wild animals; 
Poisonous or venomous animals; and 
Any animal or animals otherwise prohibited by County, State or Federal law. 
(Ord. No. 2478, 5-14-1998; Ord. No. 3197, 11-25-2003; Ord. No. 3866, § 8, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-210. - Confinement of certain dogs and other animals. 
Every female animal which is in heat shall be kept confined in a building or secure enclosure in such a manner that such female animal cannot come in contact with a non-neutered male animal of the same species except for intentional breeding purposes. 
(Ord. No. 211, 7-25-1963; Ord. No. 1081, 5-28-1981; Ord. No. 3866, § 9, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-211. - Defecation in public places; including certain private property. 
No person who owns, possesses or is in charge of a dog shall permit such dog to defecate in any public place, or on any private property not belonging to the owner or person in charge of the dog, including, but not limited to: any municipal parks and public rights-of-way, any alleys, sidewalks, school premises, office buildings or common ground areas of condominiums and townhouse subdivisions or upon the floor of any hall of any multiple-dwelling unit which is used in common by the tenants thereof; or upon the fences, lawns, grounds or parkways of any premises, or the walls or stairways of any building abutting on a public way; or upon the floor of any theatre, store, factory or school, or any public rooms or places therewith connected; or upon any school grounds or public park grounds, or the public grounds of any hotel, motel or lodging house which is used in common by the guests thereof, unless such person shall immediately thereafter remove the fecal matter resulting from such defecation and place such matter in an enclosed container, such as, but not limited to, a plastic or paper bag, and remove it. 
(Ord. No. 1770, 2-11-1988)  
Sec. 5-212. - Disturbances unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor within the City any dog or other animal which barks, howls or makes other noises by day or night which affect the peace and quiet of any person, persons or family. 
(Ord. No. 211, 7-25-1963; Ord. No. 1770, 2-11-1988; Ord. No. 3866, § 10, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-213. - Cruelty to animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to torture or ill-treat any animal whether belonging to himself or to any other person. It shall be unlawful for any person to poison any animal or to distribute poison in any manner whatsoever, with the intent or the purpose of poisoning any such animal, or to willfully injure or disfigure any such animal within the City, except that any person who lawfully distributed poison to be taken by predatory animals or rodents, etc., shall be exempt from the provisions of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 211, 7-25-1963; Ord. No. 1770, 2-11-1988; Ord. No. 3866, § 11, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-214. - Rabies control. 
The laws of the State of Florida and/or Pinellas County and any rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto pertaining to rabies control by said State and/or County shall govern in every instance in which a person is bitten, scratched by the teeth or otherwise wounded by a dog or other animal, domestic or wild, or every instance in which a person has handled a known or suspected animal. 
(Ord. No. 211, 7-25-1963; Ord. No. 1770, 2-11-1988; Ord. No. 3866, § 12, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-215. - Investigation; enforcement of article provisions. 
For the purpose of discharging the duties imposed by this Article and to enforce its provisions, any Police Officer or Community Compliance Specialist is empowered by this Article or as otherwise provided by law to demand the keeper or owner of such animal produce for inspection the applicable and current documentation, registration papers, immunization records and/or the license for such animal. 
(Ord. No. 211, 7-25-1963; Ord. No. 1081, 5-28-1981; Ord. No. 1770, 2-11-1988; Ord. No. 2144, 4-9-1992; Ord. No. 3866, § 13, 10-11-2013)  
Sec. 5-216. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3866, § 14, adopted October 11, 2013, repealed § 5-216, which pertained to penalty for violation of article and derived from Ord. No. 211, 7-25-1963; Ord. No. 1770, 2-11-1988; Ord. No. 2144, 4-9-1992. Refer to Article IV for similar provisions.  
ARTICLE III. - EQUESTRIAN RIDING 
 
Sec. 5-301. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this Article, the following definitions, terms, words and phrases shall prevail: 
At large shall include any equine animal that is off lands owned or leased by the owner and when the person in charge of the animal has complete control of the animal. 
Developed property shall include any lot or tract which has commercial or residential structures or is landscaped within any of said commercial or residential areas including that portion of the public right-of-way not used as a public road. 
Landscape shall include any lot or tract which has been improved or ornamented and is so kept as to arrange and modify the effects of natural scenery over said tract for the purpose of aesthetic effect. 
Public right-of-way shall include the public owned property in the municipality which is devoted to or required for use as a public road. 
Running at large shall include any equine animal that is off lands owned or leased by the owner when said animal is unattended. 
(Ord. No. 438, 1-22-1970)  
Sec. 5-302. - Regulations pertaining to equestrian riding. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to move at large about the city streets or rights-of-way for the purpose of equestrian riding except as follows: 
(A)  Where there are streets with curbing adjacent to property that is developed, equestrian riding shall be allowed in the street from the outside curb to outside curb and on the sidewalks. Courtesy yielding by all parties is suggested and encouraged. 
(B)  Where there are streets with curbing adjacent to property that is not developed, equestrian riding shall be allowed on the public right-of-way. 
(C)  Where there are streets with no curbing adjacent to property that is developed, equestrian riding shall be allowed in the street from the edge of pavement to edge of pavement and on the sidewalks. Courtesy yielding by all parties is suggested and encouraged. 
(D)  Where there are streets with no curbing adjacent to property that is not developed, equestrian riding shall be allowed on the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 438, 1-22-1970; Ord. No. 2657, 11-23-1999)  
Sec. 5-303. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3866, § 15, adopted October 11, 2013, repealed § 5-303, which pertained to penalty for violation of article and derived from Ord. No. 438, 1-22-1970; Ord. No. 2144, 4-9-1992. Refer to Article IV for similar provisions.  
ARTICLE IV. - PENALTY FOR VIOLATION OF CHAPTER 
Any person, firm, corporation or other entity who violates any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be subject to a fine of up to Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) for each such violation. Each day of such violation shall be considered to be a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3866, § 16, 10-11-2013)  
CHAPTER 6 - BICYCLES 
 
Sec. 6-101. - Definitions. 
Bicycle. Every vehicle propelled solely by human power, or any moped propelled by a pedal-activated helper motor with a manufacturer's certified maximum rating of 1½ brake horsepower, upon which any person may ride, having two (2) tandem wheels, and including any device generally recognized as a bicycle though equipped with two (2) front or two (2) rear wheels. The term does not include such a vehicle with a seat height of no more than twenty-five (25) inches from the ground when the seat is adjusted to its highest position or a scooter or similar device. 
Crosswalk. That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway, measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway. 
Private road or driveway. Any privately owned way or place used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. 
Right-of-way. The right of one (1) vehicle or pedestrian to proceed in a lawful manner in preference to another vehicle or pedestrian approaching under such circumstances of direction, speed, and proximity as to give rise to danger of collision unless one grants precedence to the other. 
Roadway. That portion of a highway improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. In the event a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" as used herein refers to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways collectively. 
Sidewalk. That portion of a street between the curbline, or the lateral line, of a roadway and the adjacent property lines, intended for use by pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 1545, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 6-102. - Bicycle regulations. 
The bicycle regulations of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, are in accordance with F.S. ch. 316.2065, except that mopeds shall not be propelled except by human power upon any public sidewalk within the City. The following are the bicycle regulations of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida: 
(A)  Every person propelling a vehicle by human power has all of the rights and all of the duties applicable to the driver of any other vehicle under this Chapter, except as to special regulations in this Chapter, and except as to provisions of this Chapter which by their nature can have no application. 
(B)  A person operating a bicycle may not ride other than upon or astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. 
(C)  No bicycle may be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed or equipped, except that an adult rider may carry a child securely attached to his person in a backpack or sling. 
(D)  No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates, skateboard, sled, or toy vehicle may attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon a roadway. This Section may not prohibit attaching a bicycle trailer or bicycle semitrailer to a bicycle if that trailer or semitrailer has been designed for such attachment and solely for carrying cargo. 
(E)  Any person operating a bicycle upon a roadway at less than the normal speed of traffic at the time and place and under the conditions then existing shall ride as close as practicable to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway except under any of the following situations: 
1.  When overtaking and passing another bicycle or vehicle proceeding in the same direction. 
2.  When preparing for a left turn at an intersection or into a private road or driveway. 
3.  When reasonably necessary to avoid any condition, including, but not limited to, a fixed or moving object, parked or moving vehicle, bicycle, pedestrian, animal, surface hazard, or substandard width lane, that makes it unsafe to continue along the right-hand curb or edge. For the purposes of this Section, a "substandard width lane" is a lane that is too narrow for a bicycle and another vehicle to travel safely side by side within the lane. 
(F)  Any person operating a bicycle upon a one-way highway with two (2) or more marked traffic lanes may ride as near the left-hand curb or edge of such roadway as practicable. 
(G)  Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway may not ride more than two (2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. Persons riding two (2) abreast may not impede traffic when traveling at less than the normal speed of traffic at the time and place and under the conditions then existing and shall ride within a single lane. 
(H)  Any person operating a bicycle shall keep at least one (1) hand upon the handlebars. 
(I)  Every bicycle in use between sunset and sunrise shall be equipped with a lamp on the front exhibiting a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred (500) feet to the front and a lamp on the rear exhibiting a red light visible from a distance of six hundred (600) feet to the rear, except that a red reflector meeting the requirements of this Section may be used in lieu of the red light. A bicycle or its rider may be equipped with lights or reflectors in addition to those required by this Section. 
(J)  No parent of any minor child and no guardian of any minor ward may authorize or knowingly permit any such minor child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this Section. 
(K)  A person propelling a bicycle by human power upon and along a sidewalk, or across a roadway upon and along a crosswalk, has all the rights and duties applicable to a pedestrian under the same circumstances. 
(L)  A person propelling a bicycle by human power upon and along a sidewalk, or across a roadway upon and along a crosswalk, shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(M)  No person upon roller skates, skateboard, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device, may go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk; and, when so crossing, such person shall be granted all rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(N)  This Section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play street authorized herein or designated by State, County, or City authority. 
(O)  No person under fifteen (15) years of age may operate a moped. 
(P)  No moped may be propelled except by human power upon any public sidewalk within the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 1545, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 6-103. - Compliance with traffic laws, control signals lights and signs required. 
Every person who drives or propels any bicycle upon any street or highway of the City shall comply with all signal lights, stop signs and other traffic-control devices or signals, and shall be subject to and shall comply with all the traffic laws, applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except such provisions of the traffic laws which by their very nature can have no application to bicycles. 
(Ord. No. 103, 3-14-1957; Ord. No. 1545, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 6-104. - Operation of bicycles upon sidewalks in designated areas prohibited. 
The City Manager may, upon a finding that the operation of bicycles upon public sidewalks within a particular area constitutes a public safety hazard, prohibit the operation of bicycles upon the public sidewalks within such area. The City Manager shall file a written order with the City Clerk and with the Police Department describing the designated area and stating that the operation of bicycles upon the public sidewalks within such area is prohibited. Additionally, the City Manager shall cause appropriate official signage to be erected at one (1) or more places within the designated area to notify the public that the operation of bicycles upon public sidewalks therein is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1545, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 6-105. - Penalty. 
The penalty for violation of any provision of this Chapter, pursuant to F.S. ch. 318.14, shall be a fine of Five Dollars ($5.00). 
(Ord. No. 1545, 10-24-1985)  
CHAPTER 7 - TAXATION  
ARTICLE I. - TAXATION 
 
Sec. 7-101. - Tax on specified public services—Amount and levy of tax. 
(A)  Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this Chapter, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Access charge or right of access , local telephone service , private communication service , telecommunication service , and toll telephone service shall be defined as those terms are defined in F.S. § 203.012, as the same may be amended therein from time to time, which definitions are adopted and incorporated by reference. 
Purchase within the City means, with respect to public services subject to the tax levied by Section 7-101 (B) except telecommunication services, every instance in which the commodity or service is delivered to a purchaser or consumer within the City, regardless of whether the seller maintains its business office within the City or elsewhere. With respect to telecommunication services, the term shall be synonymous with the term "provided within the City". 
(B)  Levy. 
(1)  Utilities. There is levied by the City on every purchase in the City of electricity, metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, and water service a tax of ten (10) percent of the payments received by the seller of the item taxed by this Section from the purchaser for the purchase of such service. The seller of the item subject to this tax shall collect the tax levied by this Subsection from the purchaser at the time of payment. For purposes of this Section, "purchase of electricity" means the purchase of electric power by a person who will consume it within the City. 
(2)  Fuel Oil . There is hereby further levied by the City a tax on every purchase in the City of fuel oil at the rate of four cents ($0.04) per gallon. The purchaser of fuel oil shall in every case pay this tax to the seller of fuel oil. The seller of fuel oil shall collect the tax levied in this Section on fuel oil from the purchaser at the time of payment. The term "fuel oil" as used in this Subsection shall include fuel oil grade nos. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6, kerosene and coal oil. 
(3)  Telecommunications Services . There is levied by the City a tax on every purchase in the City of telecommunication service that originates and terminates in this state, at the rate of seven (7) percent of the total amount charged for any telecommunication service provided within the City, or, if the location of the telecommunication services provided cannot be determined as part of the billing process, the total amount billed for such telecommunication services to a telephone or telephone number, a telecommunications number, a service address, or device or a customer's billing address located within the City, excluding public telephone charges collected on site, charges for any foreign exchange service or any private line service except when such services are used or sold as a substitute for any telephone company switched service or dedicated facility by which a telephone company provides a communication path, access charges, and any customer access line charges paid to a local telephone company. However, telecommunications services as defined in F.S. § 203.12(5)(b), as may be amended from time to time, shall be taxed only on the monthly recurring customer service charges excluding variable usage charges. 
(Ord. No. 2743, 9-28-2000)  
Sec. 7-102. - Payment and collection of public service taxes. 
It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity, metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, water service, fuel oil or telecommunication service, to collect from the purchaser, for the use of the City, the tax levied in Section 7-101 at the time of collecting the selling price charged for each transaction, and to report and pay over, on or before the 20th day of each calendar month, or quarter if applicable, or if the 20th day is either a legal holiday or is not a City business day, then on or before the first City business day, that is not also a legal holiday, unto the Finance Administrator, all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding calendar month. 
Any seller of electricity, metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, water service, fuel oil, and telecommunications service failing to remit to the City on or before the twentieth 20th day of each calendar month or, if applicable, calendar quarter, will be subject to the provisions of Section 7-103. 
(Ord. No. 2743, 9-28-2000)  
Sec. 7-103. - Records of service and administrative provisions. 
(A)  Records of service. Each and every seller of electricity, metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, water service, fuel oil, or telecommunication service shall keep complete records showing all purchases thereof within the City and all delayed payment charges, which records shall show the price charged upon each purchase, the date thereof, and the date of payment thereof. 
(B)  Administrative provisions. Duly authorized agents of the City may during the seller's normal business hours audit the records of any seller of a service that is taxable by the City under Section 7-102 for the purpose of ascertaining whether taxable services have been provided or the correctness of any return that has been filed or payment that has been made. Each seller must provide to the City, upon the City providing the City the minimum written notice of intent to audit required by state law, access to the applicable records for such service, except that an extension of this period shall be granted by the City if reasonably requested by the seller. A seller may at its option waive the minimum audit notice requirement. If either the City or the seller requires an additional extension, it must give notice to the other no less than thirty (30) days before the existing extension expires, except in cases of bona fide emergency or waiver of the notice requirement by the other party. 
In an audit, the seller is liable only for its taxable accounts collected which correspond to the information provided to it by the City under F.S. § 166.233(3). As used herein, the term "applicable records" means records kept in the ordinary course of business which establish the collection and remittance of taxes due. No fee or any portion of a fee for audits conducted on behalf of the City shall be based upon the amount assessed or collected as a result of the audit, and no determination based on an audit conducted in violation of this prohibition shall be valid. Each seller of services that are taxable under Section 7-101 shall preserve applicable records relating to such taxes until the expiration time of within which the City may make an assessment with respect to that tax; however, a seller is not required to retain duplicate or redundant records. Any audit authorized hereby shall be conducted in accordance applicable with state law. 
A seller's liability for any tax, interest, or penalty may be settled or compromised by the City upon the grounds of doubt as to liability or doubt as to the collectibility of such tax, interest, or penalty. The City and the seller may enter into a written closing agreement that reflects the terms of any settlement that is binding upon both parties. The City's Internal Auditor is authorized to approve all compromises and to execute all closing agreements on behalf of the City. In addition, the City may enter into agreements for scheduling payments of taxes, interest, and penalties which agreements must recognize both the seller's financial condition and the best interest of the City, if the seller gives accurate, current information and meets all other tax obligations on schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2743, 9-28-2000)  
Sec. 7-104. - Tax on specified public services—Computation of tax where seller collects at monthly periods. 
In all cases where the seller of electricity, metered natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas either metered or bottled, manufactured gas either metered or bottled, water service, fuel oil, or telecommunication service collects the price thereof at monthly periods, the tax hereby imposed and levied may be computed on the aggregate amount of purchases per bill during such monthly period, provided that the amount of the tax to be collected per bill shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Ord. No. 2743, 9-28-2000)  
Sec. 7-105. - Tax on specified public services—Transactions taxable; exemptions. 
(A)  Transactions taxable.
