_____ 
State of Florida       ) 
      ) 	SS 
County of 
Pinellas       ) 	
 
BEFORE ME, the undersigned authority, personally appeared ___________, who being first duly sworn, deposed and said that he/she is a member of the Petitioner's Committee, that he/she personally circulated this Referendum Petition, that he/she obtained ________ ( ) signatures thereon, that all such signatures were affixed in his/her presence, that he/she believes them to be genuine signatures of the persons whose names they purport to be, and that each signer had an opportunity, before signing, to read the full text of the proposed Referendum Ordinance. 
SIGNED _____
Affiant 
Sworn to and subscribed to before me this _______ day of ________ 198___. 
	      Notary Public 
 	 
(F)  Petition blanks. Pursuant to Section CC-309(C), City Charter, petition blanks for each Ordinance sought to be repealed shall be of uniform size. The City Clerk may, at the committee's request, issue the appropriate petition blanks to the Petitioners' Committee at the committee expense. No blanks may be circulated for signature prior to the filing of the affidavit by the Petitioners' Committee. 
(G)  Sufficiency of petitions. Pursuant to Section CC-309(E)(1), City Charter, upon the filing of an referendum petition, the City Clerk shall determine if it is sufficient as to timeliness, form, content, and circulator affidavits. If not, the Clerk shall promptly issue an Insufficiency Certificate and mail it to the Petitioners' Committee by registered mail. 
A petition deemed insufficient for any reason other than lack of the required number of signatures may not be amended or resubmitted. 
(H)  Verification of signatures. Pursuant to Section CC-309(E)(1), City Charter, when a petition is deemed by the City Clerk to be sufficient as to form, content, and circulator affidavits, the petitioner's signatures shall be promptly verified. The City Clerk shall complete the verification no later than the twentieth day following the date of the filing of the petition. The City Clerk shall compare the number of verified signatures to the number equal to ten (10) percent of the registered electors of the City as of the last General City election, and if the number of verified signatures meets or exceeds the requisite number, the City Clerk shall issue a Certificate of Sufficiency, and transmit a copy by registered mail to the Petitioners' Committee, and deliver a copy of the certificate and the proposed Ordinance to the members of the City Council. 
(I)  Referendum petitions; suspension of effect of Ordinances. Pursuant to Section CC-309(F), City Charter, when a Referendum petition is filed with the City Clerk, the operation of the Ordinance sought to be reconsidered shall be automatically suspended. 
(J)  Failure to repeal the referred Ordinance; election. Pursuant to Section CC-309(G)(1), City Charter, if the City Council fails to repeal the Referred Ordinance within thirty (30) days of issuance of the Certificate of Sufficiency by the City Clerk, an election shall be held not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days from the date that the petition was determined sufficient pursuant to Section CC-309(G)(2), City Charter. Whenever possible, the election shall be held in conjunction with a regularly scheduled State, County or City election. 
(K)  Withdrawal of referred Ordinance petition. Pursuant to Section CC-309(G)(3), City Charter, at any time prior to the fifteenth day preceding the election, at least four (4) members of the Petitioners' Committee may file with the City Clerk a written request under oath for withdrawal of the initiative petition. Upon filing, the petition shall be considered withdrawn and no longer of any effect, and all proceedings thereon shall be terminated. If an election has been called prior to the petition withdrawal, the City Clerk shall, upon receipt of the request, transmit a notice thereof to the City Council and the Supervisor of Elections, and City Council shall by Resolution cancel the election. 
(L)  Adopting the referred Ordinance. If at any time prior to, or on, the thirtieth day following issuance of the Certificate of Sufficiency, City Council adopts the proposed Referred Ordinance, and an issue election has previously been called for the electors to vote on that Ordinance, City Council shall by Resolution cancel the election. 
(M)  Results of election. Pursuant to Section CC-309(H)(2), City Charter, if an Ordinance proposed by referendum is submitted to an election, it shall be adopted if a majority of the qualified electors voting in that election approve the Ordinance. The effective date of the Ordinance shall be the date the election results are certified in the manner provided in Article V of this Chapter. 
(N)  Multiple Ordinances in conflict. If two (2) or more Ordinances are approved at the same election, and in the opinion of the City Attorney two (2) or more such Ordinances are in conflict, in whole or in part, the election results shall be canvassed and certified, but the Ordinance in conflict receiving the largest number of affirmative votes shall be effective to the extent of the conflict, and the conflicting provisions of any other Ordinance shall be considered repealed by the Ordinance receiving the largest number of affirmative votes. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-310. - Recall. 
(A)  First petition. 
1.  Required amount of term served. No petition to recall any member of City Council shall be filed until he has served one-fourth (¼) of his term of office. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(6). 
2.  Grounds for removal. Grounds for removal of Members of City Council are limited to the following: 
1.  Malfeasance; 
2.  Misfeasance; 
3.  Neglect of duty; 
4.  Drunkenness; 
5.  Incompetence; 
6.  Permanent inability to perform official duties; or 
7.  Conviction of a felony involving moral turpitude. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(b). 
3.  Political Committee. Electors of the City making charges contained in the statement of grounds for recall and those signing the recall petition shall be designated as the "committee". 
State Law reference— F.S. § 106.361(1)(a)(6). 
The Committee shall be considered a political committee, and shall register as such pursuant to F.S § 106.03, prior to receiving any contributions or making any expenditures seeking the Recall Election of any member of City Council. 
4.  Chairman of Political Committee designated. A specific person shall be designated in the petition as Chairman of the committee to act for the committee. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 106.361(1)(a)(6). 
5.  Individual petition for each person sought to be recalled. If more than one (1) person is sought to be replaced, a separate petition is needed for each person. 
The petition shall contain the name of the person sought to be recalled, and a statement, not to exceed two hundred (200) words, of the grounds for recall. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(a). 
6.  Number of signatures required for the first petition. The required number of signatures needed for a recall petition shall be at least one thousand (1,000) electors or by ten (10) percent of the total number of registered electors as of the last City election. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(a)(5). 
7.  Time period for collecting signatures for the first petition. All signatures shall be obtained within a period of thirty (30) days, and the petition shall be filed within thirty (30) days after the date the first signature is obtained on the petition. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(a)(6). 
8.  Committee may not employ persons to circulate petitions. No person shall employ or pay another to accept employment or payment for circulating a recall petition. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(7). 
9.  Petition shall contain name, place of residence, and voting precinct of each elector. Each elector of the City signing the petition shall sign his name in ink as registered in the office of the Supervisor of Elections, and shall state his place of residence and voting precinct. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(c). 
10.  Affidavit of circulator required. Each petition shall contain a form of affidavit, to be executed by the circulator thereof, verifying the fact that the circulator saw each person sign the counterpart of the petition, that each signature appearing thereon is the genuine signature of the person it purports to be, and that the petition was signed in the presence of the circulator on the date indicated. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(c). 
11.  Filing of petitions; verification of signatures. The petition shall be filed with the City Clerk by the person designated as Chairman of the committee. The City Clerk shall submit the petition to the County Supervisor of Elections who shall, within a period of not more than thirty (30) days, determine whether the petition contains the required valid signatures. 
The Supervisor of Elections shall be paid, by the committee, ten cents ($0.10) for each signature checked. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(d). 
12.  Insufficient signatures; certification to city council; recall terminated. If the petition does not contain the required number of signatures, the City Clerk shall so certify to the City Council and file the petition without taking further action, and the matter will be at an end. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(e). 
13.  Sufficient signatures; notice to person sought to be recalled; defensive statement. If the petitions have the required number of signatures, the City Clerk shall at once serve upon the person sought to be recalled, a certified copy of the petition. 
Within five (5) working days after service, the person sought to be recalled may file with the City Clerk, a defensive statement of not more than two hundred (200) words. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(f). 
14  Counterparts of recall petition and defensive statement. After receipt of the defensive statement, the City Clerk shall, within five (5) working days, prepare a sufficient number of typewritten mimeographed counterparts of the recall petition and statement of grounds for recall and defensive statement, as well as the names and affidavits upon the original petition, and deliver them to the person who has been designated as Chairman of the committee, and take his receipt therefor. 
The prepared counterpart shall be entitled recall petition and defense, and shall contain: 
•Lines and spaces for signatures of registered electors. 
•Place of residence. 
•Election precinct number. 
•Date of signing. 
•Affidavits to be executed by the circulators. 
(B)  Second petition. 
1.  Number of signatures required in the second petition. The City Clerk shall deliver to the committee petition forms sufficient to carry the signatures of thirty (30) percent of the registered electors. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(f). 
The committee may circulate the petitions to obtain the signatures of fifteen (15) percent of the electors. (First petitions submitted may not be used as part of new petition.) 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(g). 
2.  Committee may not employ persons to circulate petitions. No person shall employ or pay another to accept employment or payment for circulating a recall petition. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(7). 
3.  Removal of names. Any elector who signed the petition shall have the right to demand, in writing to the City Clerk, that his name be stricken from the petition prior to the certification by the City Clerk of the total electors on the petition, to the City Council. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(g). 
4.  Filing of second petition; verification of signatures. Within sixty (60) days the Chairman shall file with the City Clerk the signed petitions. The City Clerk shall assemble all signed counterparts, check to see that each counterpart is properly verified by the affidavit of the circulator, and submit the petition to the County Supervisor of Elections who shall: 
• Ascertain the number of signatures. 
• Purge the names withdrawn. 
• Certify within thirty (30) days whether fifteen (15) percent of the qualified electors have signed the petition. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(h). 
The Supervisor of Elections shall be paid by the Committee ten (10) cents for each name checked. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(h). 
5.  Sufficient signatures; serve notice; certify percentage of signatures to City Council. If the signatures do amount to fifteen (15) percent of the qualified electors, the City Clerk shall: 
• Serve notice of that fact to the person sought to be recalled; 
• Deliver to the City Council a Certificate as to the percentage of qualified voters who signed. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(i). 
6.  Insufficient signatures; certification to city council; recall terminated. If the petitions do not contain the required number of signatures, the City Clerk shall report that fact to the City Council and file the petitions and the proceeding shall be terminated. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(1)(i). 
7.  Filing of written resignation; resignation irrevocable. If the person designated in the petition, files with the City Clerk, within five (5) days after the notice, his written resignation, the City Clerk shall, at once, notify the City Council, and the resignation shall be irrevocable. The City Clerk shall then proceed to fill the vacancy according to appropriate law. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(2). 
8.  Absence of resignation. In the absence of a resignation, the Chief Judge of the Sixth Judicial Circuit of the State of Florida shall fix a day for holding a Recall Election. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(2). 
9.  Election date. The election shall be held not less than thirty (30) days or more than sixty (60) days after the expiration of the five-day period, and at the same time as any other General or Special Election is held within that period. If no election is held within that period, the Judge shall call a Special Election to be held within the period aforesaid. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(2). 
10.  Campaign expenditures. No expenditures for campaigning for or against an officer being recalled shall be made until the date on which the recall election is to be held is publicly announced. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(7). 
11.  Form of ballot. Ballots shall conform to the following with respect to each person for whom removal is sought: 
"Shall _______ be removed from the office of _______ by recall?" 
Immediately following each question there shall be printed on the ballots the two propositions in the following order: 
"_______ should be removed from office." / / 
"_______ should not be removed from office." / / 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(3). 
12.  Candidates to fill vacancy. Candidates to succeed the person(s) being recalled for the unexpired term shall be voted on at the same election, and shall be elected in the same manner as provided by the City Charter for the City General Election. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(4)(a). 
13.  Filling of vacancies; special elections (multiple candidates to fill vacancy or vacancies). Candidates shall not be elected to succeed any particular member. If only one (1) member is removed, the candidate receiving the highest number of votes shall be declared elected to fill the vacancy. If more than one (1) member is removed, candidates equal in number to the number of members removed shall be declared elected to fill the vacancies; and, among the successful candidates, those receiving the greatest number of votes shall be declared elected for the longest terms. Cases of ties, and all other matters not herein specially provided for, shall be determined by the rules governing elections generally. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(4)(a). 
14.  Resignation submitted prior to recall election. If the person sought to be recalled resigns from office prior to the Recall Election, then the vacancy shall be filled pursuant to Section CC-306(A), City Charter. 
15.  Election to City Council—Two-year waiting period. No person removed by a recall, or resigning after a petition has been filed against him, shall be eligible to be elected or appointed to City Council within a period of two (2) years after the date of such recall or resignation. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(6). 
16.  Recall papers to be preserved for two (2) years. The City Clerk's office shall preserve all papers comprising or connected with a petition for recall for a period of two (2) years after they were filed. 
State Law reference— F.S. § 100.361(6). 
(C)  Campaign expenditures. No Expenditures for campaigning for or against an officer being recalled shall be made until the date on which the Recall Election is to be held is publicly announced. 
(Ord. No. 1788, 5-26-1988)  
Sec. 8-311. - Removal of names. 
Any person may request the removal of his or her name from a previously executed petition prior to the filing of the petition with the City Clerk. The responsibility for removal of any name pursuant to a request shall be that of the Petitioners' Committee and failure to promptly do so when requested shall be a violation of this Chapter and punishable as provided in Section 8-901 of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-312. - Bond authorization. 
(A)  An election to approve the issuance of bonds or other forms of indebtedness shall be called and conducted pursuant to F.S. §§ 100.291—100.342, and this Chapter to the extent not in conflict with State Law; provided, that nothing herein shall be constued to require the holding of an election to approve the issuance of bonds or other forms of indebtedness where such election is not required by State Law. 
(B)  No Bond Referendum shall be limited to voting by freeholders. Any registered elector residing within the City shall be qualified and eligible to vote in Bond Referenda, provided such elector has registered no less than thirty (30) days prior to the date of the election. 
(C)  Any person, group, association or corporation, seeking to influence the results of a Bond Referendum shall register as a political committee pursuant to F.S. § 106.03, prior to receiving any contributions or making any expenditures relating to such referendum in excess of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) in the aggregate. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-313. - Involuntary annexation. 
(A)  A referendum on the involuntary annexation of land shall be held and conducted pursuant to F.S. § 171.0413, and the provisions of this Chapter to the extent not inconsistent with Florida Statutes. 
(B)  The City Council shall call an Annexation Referendum by the adoption of an Ordinance describing the land to be annexed and setting the date for the election. A certified copy of the Ordinance shall be delivered to the Supervisor of Elections by the City Clerk. 
(C)  The Annexation Referendum election shall be administered by the City Clerk who shall report the results of the election as to both the City and the area sought to be annexed. The City Council shall serve as the Canvassing Board and certify the results of the elections. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-314. - Straw ballot. 
(A)  The City Council may at any time, by Resolution, call a Special election for the purpose of having the electors of the City vote on an issue in a nonbinding referendum. The Resolution shall call the election, set the date therefor, and prescribe the ballot language. The City Clerk shall cause a Notice of Election to be published in accordance with Section 8-304 of this Chapter. 
(B)  Whenever possible, the election may be held in conjunction with a regularly scheduled State, County or City election or at such other time as provided by the City Council. 
(C)  The campaign finance provisions of F.S. ch. 106, shall apply to elections called pursuant to this Chapter. 
(D)  The City Council shall canvass and certify the results of the election as provided in Article V of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-315. - Other issues. 
An election on any issue not otherwise provided for in this part shall be conducted in such manner as provided in the Ordinance or Resolution calling the election. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTION ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 8-401. - Dates of elections. 
(A)  General Elections. Pursuant to Section CC-303, City Charter, the General election to fill the office of a City Council Member, including Mayor, shall be held on the first Tuesday of March. 
(B)  Tie Elections. Pursuant to CC-604(A), City Charter, if in any election the returns, as certified by the canvassing board, result in a tie vote, the election shall be decided by lot, which shall mean that the name of each candidate who has tied shall be placed on a piece of paper, which shall be placed in a container so that the candidates' names are not visible. A member of the canvassing board designated by the board shall then select one (1) piece of paper from the container. The candidate whose name appears on that piece of paper shall be declared elected. 
(C)  Vacancies. Pursuant to Section CC-306(A), City Charter, vacancies in the City Council shall be filled by a majority vote of the remaining members of the City Council. Any person so appointed to Council to fill such vacancy shall hold office until the next regularly scheduled election if a regularly scheduled election is to be held within one (1) year from the date of the appointment; if no regularly scheduled election is to be held within that time, City Council must call a Special Election to fill the vacancy. 
Pursuant to Section CC-306(B), City Charter, in the event the remaining members of Council shall fail to appoint a person to fill such vacancy and such failure shall continue for more than thirty (30) days after such vacancy was created, such vacancy shall be filled by a Special Election called and held within one hundred twenty (120) days of such vacancy. 
(D)  Issue Elections. Issue elections shall be held on the date prescribed by applicable State Law or Resolution or Ordinance calling the election. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985; Ord. No. 3012, 7-11-2002; Ord. No. 3580, § 2, 10-25-2007)  
Sec. 8-402. - Precincts. 
(A)  Those precincts approved by the Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners pursuant to F.S. § 98.031, situated within the corporate limits of the City are hereby designated as the City precincts to be used in any and all City elections. 
(B)  The City Clerk shall see that a certified copy of any Annexation Ordinance approved by the City Council is sent to the Supervisor of Elections. Precinct boundaries may be altered to conform to the Municipal boundaries as changed due to annexation. 
(C)  In the event a precinct boundary is unable to be altered to conform to annexation by the date of a City election, any qualified elector residing within the area annexed shall be eligible to vote in the City election. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-403. - Polling places. 
(A)  There shall be one (1) Polling Place located within each precinct. Those polling places designated and used by the Supervisor of Elections shall be used for City elections. 
(B)  Whenever necessary, Polling Place locations may be changed by the Supervisor of Elections. The Supervisor of Elections shall consult with the City Clerk prior to relocating any Polling Place in a City election. 
(C)  Each Polling Place shall, whenever possible, be accessible to the handicapped and comply with the standards of accessibility set forth in F.S. § 101.715(1). 
(D)  The Polling Place shall be arranged in the manner prescribed in F.S. § 101.37. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-404. - Voting machines. 
(A)  Voting machines shall be used in each City election. The machines shall be owned by Pinellas County and supplied by the Supervisor of Elections. 
(B)  The number of voting machines in each precinct for City elections shall be determined by the Supervisor of Elections after consulting with the City Clerk. In making such determination, the Supervisor of Elections shall consider the traditional voting patterns and turnout in each precinct for a City election and furnish the number of machines necessary to handle efficiently the anticipated number of voters in that precinct for a City election. 
(C)  The voting machines to be used in a City election shall be prepared by the Supervisor of Elections in accordance with F.S. ch. 101. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-405. - Ballots. 
(A)  The form of the ballot in elections for City Council shall be in substantially the same form as the form of the ballot for the State General election Ballot prescribed in F.S. § 101.191. 
(B)  Ballots shall be prepared by the Supervisor of Elections pursuant to instructions from the City Clerk and in accordance with State Law and this Chapter. 
(C)  A sample ballot shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation prior to the day of the election, but no more than ten (10) days prior to the election. The City Clerk shall see to the publication of the sample ballot. Such publication shall be conspicuous and not be included within the legal notices and advertisements being published per F.S. ch. 50. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-406. - Poll workers. 
(A)  At each Polling Place there shall be a sufficient number of Poll workers, to handle the anticipated number of voters. The Supervisor of Elections and the City Clerk shall determine the necessary number and the City Clerk shall report the number of Poll workers, together with the names of the Poll workers, to the City Council prior to the date of the election. 
(B)  All Poll workers for the City election shall have completed training classes conducted by the Supervisor of Elections. 
(C)  One (1) Poll worker in each precinct shall be designated the Precinct Clerk and shall be in charge of, and responsible for, the conduct of the election at that Polling Place. 
(D)  At a City election not held in conjunction with a State or County election, the Supervisor of Elections and the City Clerk shall determine the appointment of a Precinct Deputy for each Polling Place. 
(E)  Poll workers shall conduct the election, and at the close of the polls ascertain the results for that precinct in the manner provided in F.S. chs. 101 and 102, to the extent not inconsistent with this Chapter, and report the results in the manner directed by the Supervisor of Elections and the City Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-407. - Absentee voting. 
(A)  An elector may request an absentee ballot and cast an absentee vote in any City election, provided the elector satisfies the definition of "absentee voter" in Section 8-102 of this Chapter. 
(B)  An absentee ballot may be requested in the manner provided in F.S. § 101.62, and voted in accordance with F.S. §§ 101.64 and 101.67. 
(C)  Absentee ballots for any City election must be requested from, and returned to the City Clerk, and received and kept in the same manner as provided in F.S. § 101.67. 
(D)  The City Clerk shall compare the absentee ballots presented to her so as to compare the number of ballots in her possession with the number of requests for ballots received as noted on the list on file in the Clerk's office, to insure all the absentee ballots to be counted are accounted for. Absentee ballots shall then be counted by the City Clerk in the presence of the Deputy City Clerk and the other members of the election team on duty, including the representative in attendance from the Supervisor of Elections office. The results will be submitted to the Canvassing Board along with all other precinct results, and any absentee ballots that have been rejected because of any legality. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985; Ord. No. 3580, § 2, 10-25-2007)  
Sec. 8-408. - Early voting. 
Early voting in municipal elections begins fifteen (15) days before the election. The City exercises its right to exempt itself from the provisions of F.S. § 101.657, and shall contract with the Pinellas County Supervisor of Elections to provide facilities and services for early voting. Voters who wish to participate in early voting may do so at the offices of the Supervisor of Elections of Pinellas County. 
(Ord. No. 3335, 5-26-2005)  
ARTICLE V. - CANVASSING; PROTESTING AND CONTESTS 
 
Sec. 8-501. - Canvassing Board. 
(A)  For any City election, those members of the City Council who are not candidates in the election being canvassed, and those members of City Council who are candidates without opposition in the election being canvassed, shall comprise and constitute the Canvassing Board, and as such shall meet as a canvassing board and duly canvass the election returns in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance, and as may be from time to time modified by State Law. City Council may designate the Pinellas County Supervisor of Elections as the Canvassing Board for any City election. 
(B)  The Canvassing Board shall convene within seven (7) days following the election and after the final election results are provided to the City Clerk by the Supervisor of Elections after any municipal election to canvass the returns. At that time the City Clerk shall present the returns by precinct and seat or issue, and any rejected absentee ballots. If it is determined by the Canvassing Board that any absentee ballot is illegal, then the envelope shall remain unopened, and shall be marked on the face of the envelope, "rejected as illegal." 
(C)  At such time as the Canvassing Board has canvassed the returns, disposed of any challenges thereto, and ascertained and certified the results, the successful candidates shall receive their Oath of Office, and the City Clerk shall issue a Certificate of Election to each candidate elected and issue and file a Certificate of Election of each issue; provided, however, the term of all members of City Council, including Mayor, shall begin on the Monday next following their election, and continue until their successor has been duly elected and installed. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985; Ord. No. 2867, 5-24-2001; Ord. No. 3375, 9-22-2005; Ord. No. 3580, § 3, 10-25-2007; Ord. No. 3606, § 3, 2-14-2008)  
Sec. 8-502. - Recounts 
(A)  In its discretion, the Canvassing Board, may order a recount of the returns of any election prior to the final certification of the results. 
(B)  Upon request of any candidate for good cause shown, the Canvassing Board may, prior to the final certification of results, order a recount in whole or in part of the election in which that candidate participated. Upon request of any elector for good cause shown, the Canvassing Board may, prior to final certification of results, order a recount of any issue election. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985; Ord. No. 3580, § 3, 10-25-2007)  
Sec. 8-503. - Protest. 
A candidate or any elector qualified to vote in the election related to such candidacy may file a protest of the election returns pursuant to F.S. § 102.166, in the form prescribed in F.S. § 102.167. The Canvassing Board shall consider the protest as provided in F.S. § 102.166(1), if filed with that board. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-504. - Contest. 
(A)  An unsuccessful candidate may contest the results of the election in which he or she participated as provided in F.S. § 102.168. 
(B)  A taxpayer of the City may contest the results of any question or issue submitted to a vote of the electors as provided in F.S. § 102.168. 
(C)  If the unsuccessful candidate filing a contest is determined to be entitled to the office, and some other individual has been issued a Certificate of Election or entered upon the duties of the office, a judgment of ouster may be entered by the Circuit Court and the contestant shall assume that office. 
(D)  If a judgment is entered setting aside an issue election, the election shall be regarded as having been void. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
ARTICLE VI. - PROHIBITED ACTS AND PRACTICES 
 
Sec. 8-601. - Prohibited acts and practices. 
(A)  Any person knowingly signing a petition more than one (1) time shall be guilty of a violation of this Chapter. 
(B)  Any circulator falsely executing the affidavit on any petition blank shall be guilty of a violation of this Chapter. 
(C)  Any person who, within one hundred (100) yards of any polling place on the day of any election, distributes or attempts to distribute any political or campaign material shall be guilty of a violation of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
ARTICLE VII. - CAMPAIGN SIGNS 
 
Sec. 8-701. - Campaign signs. 
(A)  Political campaign signs shall be placed and removed in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 8, Article VI, "Signs" of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pinellas Park, and F.S. § 479.22. 
(B)  The unauthorized alteration, destruction, or removal of a political sign of a candidate or political committee shall constitute a violation of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985; Ord. No. 3334, 5-26-2005)  
ARTICLE VIII. - CAMPAIGN FINANCES 
 
Sec. 8-801. - Application of State Law. 
(A)  Any candidate for elective City office, including an elected officer sought to be recalled, is subject to, and shall comply with, the provisions of F.S. ch. 106. 
(B)  Any group, club, association, or other combination of persons having a collective capacity receiving contributions or making expenditures in excess of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) seeking to influence the results of a City election constitute a political committee within the definition of F.S. § 106.011(1), and shall register and report as such pursuant to, and be subject to, F.S. ch. 106. 
(C)  Any individual making independent expenditures in a City election as defined in F.S. § 106.11(5), in the amount of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) or more shall be subject to, and comply with, F.S. § 106.071. 
(D)  Any individual, person, partnership, committee, association, corporation, or other combination of individuals having collective capacity seeking to influence the outcome of any issue election, including any efforts to have the election called, by the receipt of contributions in an aggregate amount in excess of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) or making of expenditures in an aggregate amount in excess of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00), shall report such contributions and expenditures in the manner provided in F.S. § 106.07, in the case of a political committee, and F.S. § 106.071, in the case of any individual making independent expenditures. 
(E)  A committee circulating petitions seeking a Recall election of an elected official pursuant to F.S. § 100.361, a petitioner's committee proposing an initiative pursuant to Section CC-309(A), City Charter, and a petitioners' committee proposing the repeal of an Ordinance by the referendum provisions of Section CC-309(B), City Charter, shall constitute a political committee under F.S. ch. 106, and shall register as provided in F.S. § 106.03, prior to soliciting and collecting any petition signatures, and shall file campaign finance reports as required by F.S. § 106.07, provided such committee anticipates receiving, or does receive, contributions in the aggregate in excess of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00), and anticipates making, or does make, expenditures in the aggregate in excess of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00). 
(F)  Any violation of F.S. ch. 106, shall be enforced in the manner provided in F.S. §§ 106.25—106.28. Any violation in connection with any election pursuant to this Chapter shall also constitute a violation of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-802. - Campaign treasurer and depository. 
Pursuant to F.S. § 106.021(1)(a), each candidate for nomination or election to office and each political committee shall appoint a campaign Treasurer. Any person who seeks to qualify for election or nomination to any office by means of the petitioning process shall appoint a Treasurer and designate a Depository on or before the date he obtains the petitions. 
No person shall accept any contribution or make any expenditure with a view to bringing about his nomination, election, or retention in public office, or authorize another to accept such contributions or make such expenditure on his behalf, unless such person has appointed a campaign Treasurer and designated a campaign Depository. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
Sec. 8-803. - Report filing pursuant to F.S. § 106.07. 
(A)  Each campaign Treasurer designated pursuant to Section 8-802 of this Chapter shall file regular reports of all contributions received, and all expenditures made, by or on behalf of a candidate or political committee. 
(B)  Reports shall be filed on the tenth day following the end of each calendar quarter from the time the campaign Treasurer is appointed. 
(C)  Following the last day of qualifying for office, the reports shall be filed: 
1.  On the Friday preceding the General Election, for a candidate who is unopposed in seeking nomination and election to any office. 
2.  On the fourth, eighteenth, and thirty-second days immediately preceding each election, for a candidate who is opposed in seeking nomination or election to any office, or for a political committee. 
(D)  Reports shall be filed not later than 5:00 p.m. on the reporting dates. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)  
ARTICLE IX. - PENALTIES FOR VIOLATION OF THIS CHAPTER 
 
Sec. 8-901. - Penalties. 
Any person who shall be convicted in a court of competent jurisdiction of a violation of this Chapter shall be punished by a fine not to exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed sixty (60) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 1546, 10-24-1985)

CHAPTER 9 - TRAFFIC 
 
Sec. 9-101. - Uniform traffic control law adopted. 
The City Council of Pinellas Park, does by reference adopt F.S. ch. 316, being known as the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, in its entirety, and all matters contained in Chapter 316 shall now be as prescribed and regulated under said Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 618, 12-28-1972)  
Sec. 9-102. - Speed limit—Local City streets. 
It shall be unlawful for any person(s) to operate any motor driven vehicle in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour on any local street within the City of Pinellas Park, as defined in the Traffic Element of the Comprehensive Plan of the City of Pinellas Park, unless otherwise posted. 
(Ord. No. 1870, 10-26-1989)  
Sec. 9-103. - Speed of railroad trains or locomotives. 
It shall be unlawful for any engineer or other person to operate any locomotive or railroad train over a street or crossing in excess of the speed of twenty-five (25) miles per hour within the corporate limits of the City of Pinellas Park. 
(Ord. No. 620, 2-8-1973)  
Sec. 9-104. - Impoundment and towing of vehicles. 
(A)  Impounding. The Police Department is authorized to impound vehicles under the following circumstances: 
1.  Abandoned, wrecked, nonoperating, or junked vehicles in violation of Section 16-108 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, where the owner cannot be located. If the owner may reasonably be contacted, prior to having the abandoned, wrecked, non-operating, or junked vehicles towed, a written notice shall be hand delivered or mailed to the last known residence by certified mail, stating: 
(a)  That the vehicle has been determined to be an abandoned, wrecked, non-operating, or junked vehicle within the meaning of Section 16-108, and is therefore subject to removal; 
(b)  That the owner of the vehicle shall have seventy-two (72) hours from receipt of such notice within which to appeal such determination in writing to the City Manager at 5141 78th Avenue North, Pinellas Park, Florida 33565; 
(c)  That if no such written appeal is filed with the City Manager within the prescribed time, the vehicle will be towed away at no expense to the City; and 
(d)  That if a written appeal is filed within the prescribed time, the City Manager or his designee shall hold a hearing within seven (7) days from receipt of the written appeal to determine whether the vehicle is in fact abandoned within the meaning of City Ordinance No. 16-137. The owner shall be given a minimum of twenty-four (24) hours' written notice of such hearing. If after the vehicle is determined to be abandoned, wrecked, nonoperating, or junked within the meaning of Section 16-108, the vehicle shall be towed away without further notice to the owner. 
2.  Abandoned vehicles which constitute an immediate traffic hazard, and no owner or driver can be immediately located. 
3.  When the driver is arrested and no other person is present who is competent to accept responsibility for custody and removal of the vehicle. 
4.  When the vehicle and/or contents will be used as evidence in a criminal proceeding. 
5.  Recovered stolen vehicles where the owner cannot be contacted or the vehicle is needed for evidence processing. 
6.  When a vehicle is found being operated upon the streets and is in an improper or unsafe condition. 
7.  When a vehicle is left unattended continuously upon a street, highway, or right-of-way for more than twenty-four (24) hours, and the owner or operator cannot be located. 
8.  When removal is necessary in the interest of public safety because of fire, flood, storm, or other emergency reason. 
9.  When a vehicle is involved in a traffic accident upon a street, highway or right-of-way, rendering it inoperable. 
(B)  Police Department Wrecker Services Rotation Lists. The City of Pinellas Park Police Department shall maintain a Class "A" and Class "B" Wrecker Service Rotation List and a separate Class "C" Wrecker Service Rotation List. 
1.  Eligibility. 
(a)  Storage area. In order to be eligible to be placed on the City of Pinellas Park Police Department Wrecker Service Rotation List, a wrecker service company must maintain a storage area as required hereby within the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. For purposes of this Section, a storage area shall be deemed to be within the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, if the same is located on property in unincorporated Pinellas County within one (1) mile of City boundaries which is under a binding agreement for voluntary annexation into the City. All such storage areas must be located on property which has the proper zoning and land use plan classification for that use. 
(b)  Wreckers. All wrecker service companies on the City of Pinellas Park Police Department Class "A" and Class "B" Wrecker Service Rotation List shall station at least one (1) Class A wrecker or at least one (1) Class B wrecker at a permitted location within the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, on a permanent basis. All wrecker service companies on the City of Pinellas Park Police Department Class "C" Wrecker Service Rotation List shall station at least one (1) Class "C" wrecker at a permitted location within the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, on a permanent basis. For purposes of this Section, wreckers shall be deemed to be stationed within the City of Pinellas Park if they are stationed at a permissible location on property in unincorporated Pinellas County within one (1) mile of City boundaries which is under a binding agreement for voluntary annexation into the City. All such wreckers shall be stationed at a location allowed under zoning, land use, and other applicable resolutions, and nothing herein shall be deemed to permit parking or storage thereof in residential areas. 
2.  Wrecker Service Rotation List Regulations. The Wrecker Service Rotation List Regulations outlined below shall govern the provision of Police Department Rotation List Wrecker Services within the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
(a)  Operator requirements. 
(1)  In order to be placed on the Pinellas Park Police Department Wrecker Services Rotation List, the towing service company must submit an application to the Pinellas Park Police Department. Such application shall be in a form approved by the Chief of Police. 
(2)  Each towing service on the Pinellas Park Police Department Class "A" and "B" Wrecker Service Rotation List must own or possess at least one (1) operable Class A or one (1) operable Class B wrecker. Each towing service on the Pinellas Park Police Department Class "C" Wrecker Service Rotation List must own or possess at least one (1) operable Class "C" wrecker. 
In addition, the towing service must have access to a trailer for towing motorcycles and fiberglass specialty cars. 
(3)  Tow Truck/Wrecker Defined: A motor vehicle which has been designed, manufactured, equipped for and used in the business of towing of other vehicles by crane, hoist, tow-bar. 
(4)  All wrecker operators shall be familiar and comply with the Florida Regulatory Traffic Laws and have a chauffeur's license. 
(5)  All wrecker operators shall be familiar with and know how to safely and efficiently operate the equipment they are using. 
(6)  The wrecker operator on duty must have ready access to the wrecker and be available for service on demand at all hours. 
(b)  Equipment requirements. 
(1)  Wreckers shall be inspected by designated personnel of the Pinellas Park Police Department before being placed on the rotation list, and thereafter, shall be inspected at such time as may be determined by the Pinellas Park Police Department; however, all wreckers shall undergo an annual inspection. 
(2)  Towing services premises must be properly identified by signs on the exterior of the structure and prominently painted upon the wrecker. 
(3)  A reasonable state of cleanliness must be maintained for both services premises and wreckers. 
(4)  Wrecker shall be equipped with fenders, hood, doors, bumpers, windshield, etc. 
(5)  Sirens on wreckers are prohibited. 
(6)  There shall be a rotor beam-type light mounted on top of the wrecker in such a manner that it can be seen from the front, rear, and both sides. This light shall be amber in color. It shall only be used at the scene and when having vehicle under tow. It shall not be used when proceeding to a call. 
(7)  Headlights, taillights, stoplights, and side reflectors shall conform to requirements of Florida State Law. 
(8)  All wreckers will be equipped with two-way radios capable of contacting their base office. 
(9)  Wrecker shall have all of the following equipment: 
a.  Sand—50 pounds white fine or medium. 
b.  Heavy-duty push broom. 
c.  Reflectors—State Statute. 
d.  Shovel—Square. 
e.  Extra towing chain—six (6) feet to eight (8) feet with hooks—No less than ten-ton capacity. 
f.  Axe—Thirty-two-inch handle. 
g.  Scotch blocks and/or electrical or hydraulic wheel locks. 
h.  Fire extinguisher—One (1) five-lb. ABC rated dry chemical, underwriter approved. 
i.  First aid kit—One (1) on each truck. 
j.  One (1) extension cord of sufficient length for use in displaying a light to the rear of a towed vehicle when such vehicle is without the capability of providing its own lights. 
k.  All clearance lamps, head lamps, tail lamps, stop lamps, flags, flares, and fuses necessary to comply with the Florida State Statute. 
l.  One (1) Pry Bar—Thirty-six (36) inches or longer. 
m.  One (1) set of tools for opening locked vehicles. 
n.  A sufficient assortment of tools necessary to change tires, drop drive shafts, pull transmission pins or perform similar functions in preparation of towing a vehicle. 
o.  Flashlight. 
p.  Bolt cutter. 
q.  Jumper cables. 
r.  Amber revolving light. 
s.  Dolly. 
(c)  Insurance, When making application to be placed on the rotation list, the towing/wrecker service shall comply with all insurance requirements developed by the Pinellas Park Risk Management Division. 
An original Certificate of Insurance, complying with required insurance coverages and limits, shall be furnished to the Risk Management Division prior to being placed on the rotation list. 
The Risk Management Division will notify all towing/wrecker service companies on the rotation list of any changes in insurance requirements and said towing/wrecker service companies shall comply with said insurance requirements in order to remain on the rotation list. 
It shall be the responsibility of the towing/wrecker company to furnish the Risk Management Division an original renewal Certificate of Insurance each time the company changes a policy or the present policy expires. 
(d)  Procedures and policies. 
(1)  Only qualified wrecker operators will be dispatched on wrecker calls. 
(2)  Wreckers must be available for immediate response twenty-four (24) hours a day. If not available, place in rotation will be passed and next wrecker will get call. 
(3)  Call rotation will be on a unit basis so that all companies could conceivably be called on any one (1) day, depending upon the number of demands. 
(4)  Special wrecker needs will not affect the rotation order. After a special need is satisfied, the wrecker would return to regular order on the rotation list. 
(5)  Each wrecker company shall be listed one (1) time on the rotation list, regardless of the number of wrecker units owned and operated by a company. Each individual wrecker company on each rotation list shall be required to own or possess all equipment and facilities required hereunder; no such equipment or facilities shall be used by more than one (1) wrecker company for rotation list services. 
(6)  Requests for wreckers shall be filled from the top of the rotation list, except when a special wrecker is needed or when a specified wrecker or auto club is required by the vehicle owner. 
(7)  When a specific wrecker is requested by the vehicle owner, the call shall be recorded and the wrecker placed back in normal rotation flow. 
(8)  A wrecker shall not be permitted to handle a vehicle unless it has been called by rotation or specific request and will not be permitted to stand in for another wrecker which is not available for service. 
(9)  Any wrecker company which pulls in a damaged or wrecked vehicle without it having been investigated or reported to a proper police agency may be removed from the rotation list. 
(10)  A wrecker operator called to the scene of an accident shall be under the jurisdiction and supervision of the investigating officer. He shall clean up all debris from the street which was caused by the accident. No additional charge will be levied for this service. No police officer shall require any wrecker operator to repair any vehicle, other than moving it out of the flow of traffic, unless the owner or his agent requests same and is willing to pay for such service. However, the officer may, at his discretion, not permit such labor in the interest of safety and traffic flow. 
(11)  Wrecker company telephone requirements: 
a.  Rotation wrecker request will be given to the wrecker company licensee, owner, or employee. 
b.  Rotation wreckers will furnish the Pinellas Park Police Department with not more than two (2) telephone numbers where they are to be contacted for wrecker services. (No answering services or pager will be accepted.) 
c.  If a wrecker company's phone is not answered within one (1) minute of the call, the company will be rotated. 
d.  A busy phone will be dialed twice; if still busy, the wrecker will be rotated. 
(12)  All wrecker companies will forward copies of each towing slip which shall include all charges made by the wrecker company to the owner or the agent of the owner of the vehicle which is towed, and to the Chief of Police, prior to the tenth day of the month following the month in which the tow is made. However, if the vehicle has not been picked up by the owner or said agent of the owner by that date, then the wrecker company shall instead forward the copy of the towing slip by the tenth day of the month following the month in which the vehicle is picked up. Each towing slip will be filled in completely, and will be signed by the wrecker operator, and shall include all charges made to said customer, including charges made under the Section (f)(1)b., c. and d. 
(13)  All wrecker companies must comply with F.S. § 715.05, and all other applicable state laws pertaining to reporting of unclaimed vehicles. 
(e)  Storage facility requirements. 
(1)  Rotation wrecker companies must have storage facilities which encompass the following: 
a.  Outside storage for a minimum of five (5) vehicles on property zoned for vehicle storage. 
b.  Outside storage must be fenced (six (6) feet high), locked and/or under guard twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week, for the protection of vehicles and their contents. 
c.  Towed vehicles shall not be stored on public right-of-way. 
d.  Inside storage facilities must be available when weather or other conditions require inside storage for protection of the vehicle or personal property. (Minimum of space for two (2) vehicles.) 
e.  Telephone numbers of persons to be contacted during nonbusiness hours, who have authority to release vehicles, shall be on a sign posted conspicuously on storage facilities at the gate of such facility. 
(2)  Hold orders placed by any police officer of the Pinellas Park Police Department on vehicles stored for any reason shall be honored by the wrecker company. Vehicles involved in a fatality and sealed by a police officer or investigator will remain intact until removed by said officer. If no fatality occurred, then the vehicle and property may be released by the wrecker company upon valid proof of ownership and a signed release from the Pinellas Park Police Department. 
(3)  The wrecker company will be held responsible for parts and contents taken from vehicles while under their protection. 
(4)  Any deviation or variations from these rules, pertaining to storage must be approved by designated Pinellas Park Police Department personnel. 
(f)  Rates. 
(1)  The maximum rates for all motor vehicles including motorcycles, not exceeding ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross vehicle weight are as follows: 
a.  The basic hook-up charges shall be One Hundred Dollars ($100.00). 
b.  In addition to the basic hook-up charge, there shall be a basic tow charge of Three Dollars ($3.00) per mile. Such charge shall be calculated from the point of hook-up to the storage area by the most direct allowable route. 
c.  In addition to the basic hook-up charge and basic tow charge, when dolly services are required, there shall be a charge of Twenty Dollars ($20.00). 
d.  In addition to the basic hook-up charges, basic tow charges, and dolly charges, there shall be a storage fee of Twenty Dollars ($20.00) per day, whether such storage be inside or outside. Whenever possible, such storage shall be inside. 
e.  In addition to the basic hook-up charges, basic tow charges, dolly charges, and storage charges, a Thirty Dollar ($30.00) processing fee may be charged after the first twenty-four (24) hours of storage so long as the towing service has actually complied with the requirements of F.S. § 713.78. A filing of lien notice fee of Thirty Dollars ($30.00) may also be charged to cover the execution and mailing of the lien notice so long as the towing service has actually complied with the requirements of F.S. § 713.78. Further, a tarpaulin fee in the amount of Fifteen Dollars ($15.00) may be assessed when the towing service reasonably finds it necessary to install and maintain tarpaulin coverage on any stored vehicle in order to protect the interior accessories or upholstery of such vehicle from damage by inclement weather. The wrecker/towing service shall provide documentation of said costs to the Pinellas Park Police Department by the tenth day of the month following the month in which said costs were imposed. 
f.  In addition to the basic hook-up charges, basic tow charges, dolly charges, storage charges, and processing fee, there shall be a ten (10) percent fuel adjustment fee, which shall be calculated at 10% of the sum of the basic hook-up charge and the total calculated basic tow charge. 
g.  The rate scheduled herein is for the use of wreckers under normal towing situations. It does not include special recovery situations for which the rates charged shall be the usual and customary charge for such situations. 
h.  Since the City of Pinellas Park Police Department will not call out a wrecker until one is actually needed, there will be no charges for "waiting time" or other similar charges made by the wrecker company. 
i.  The basic hook-up charges, basic tow charges, dolly charges, storage charges, processing fees, and ten (10) percent fuel adjustment fee provided for herein shall apply seven (7) days per week, are the maximum charges allowable by the wrecker company, and are the only permissible charges by a wrecker company, for services rendered in connection with the City of Pinellas Park Police Department rotation wrecker calls. However, nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent wrecker companies rendering such services in connection with the City of Pinellas Park Police Department rotation wrecker calls from charging less than the maximum charges. 
(2)  Towing rates of each wrecker company shall be on file with inspection and application forms, and any changes will necessitate a re-application on all affected wrecker units. 
(3)  A complete schedule of rates from each wrecker company will be filed with the Pinellas Park Police Department and will be updated annually. 
(4)  Rates shall be posted in each wrecker establishment and a written copy of said posted rates shall be given to the towed vehicle owners or drivers by the wrecker operator. 
(g)  Complaints. 
(1)  All wrecker complaints will be made a matter of record and must be filed in writing over complainant's signature. Complaints will be filed with designated personnel in the Pinellas Park Police Department. 
(2)  The designated personnel in the Pinellas Park Police Department will investigate all complaints against a wrecker company's service. 
(3)  The investigation will then be filed with the Chief of Police for determination as to whether the wrecker company has violated the provisions hereof. 
(h)  Penalties. 
(1)  Wrecker companies may be temporarily suspended or permanently removed from the rotation list by the Chief of Police for: 
a.  Violation of any of the provisions hereof, including rate violations. 
b.  Failure to respond promptly to calls or refusal of a call without just reason. 
c.  Conviction of any principal/owner of the wrecker service of a felony or misdemeanor in a court of competent jurisdiction involving operation of the wrecker service. 
d.  Failure to clean debris from street after accident as stated in (d)(10). 
(2)  Term of penalty: 
First Violation—Three-month suspension. 
Second Violation—Six-month suspension. 
Third Violation—Permanent removal. 
(3)  Appeal: Any wrecker company that is temporarily suspended or permanently removed from the rotation list by the Chief of Police and does not believe that the suspension or removal is justified, shall have the opportunity to appeal the decision before City Council. 
(i)  Rotation and logging procedure. 
(1)  Rotation wrecker receiving a call for service from the Pinellas Park Police Department where, in fact, the wrecker rendered the requested service shall then rotate to the bottom of the list. 
(2)  If the owner of a vehicle arrives at the scene while his vehicle is in the process of being impounded, the police officer will release the car to the owner unless the circumstances require otherwise. The wrecker responding to the call shall be placed back on the top of the rotation list and shall not lose his original place on the rotation list. 
(3)  A police officer may request a wrecker out-of-rotation when there is a special need for a wrecker of a capacity that is not available from the wrecker company on the top of the list. The specially called wrecker shall revert to the original place on the rotation list after handling the special call. 
(j)  Collection of fees. 
(1)  All towing charges shall be paid by the owner of the vehicle to the wrecker service. 
(2)  Collection of fees from the owner of the vehicle is the sole responsibility of the wrecker service and the City shall in no way be liable. 
(k)  Exceptions to rotation list use. 
(1)  The Chief of Police may authorize exceptions to use the rotation list in selective investigations. 
(2)  In the event a vehicle is impounded as a result of an error, the vehicle will be released to the owner or designee upon being authorized in writing to do so by the designated Pinellas Park Police Department personnel with no charge to the owner. The wrecker responding to the call shall be placed back on the top of the rotation list and shall not lose his original place on the rotation list. 
EQUIPMENT REQUIRED 
(A)  CLASS A—Cars and light trucks. 
1.  Tow truck shall have a minimum manufacturer capacity of ten thousand (10,000) pounds GVW. 
2.  Boom capacity of not less than four (4) tons. 
3.  Power winch pulling capacity of not less than four (4) tons. 
4.  Minimum of two hundred (200) feet of three-eighth-inch cable. 
5.  Cradle or tow plate or tow sling to pick up vehicles. Cradle or tow plate to be equipped with safety chains and so constructed that no further damage will occur when picking up vehicles. 
6.  Dual wheels. 
(B)  CLASS B—One- and two-ton trucks. 
1.  Tow truck shall have a minimum manufacturer capacity of fifteen thousand (15,000) pounds GVW. 
2.  Boom capacity of not less than six (6) tons. 
3.  Power winch pulling capacity of not less than ten (10) tons. 
4.  Minimum of two hundred (200) feet of at least 7/16 -inch cable. 
5.  Double booms so constructed as to permit splittings or single boom hydraulic elevated and extendable. Each boom to operate independently or jointly. 
6.  Cradle tow or tow sling to pick up vehicle. Cradle or tow plate to be equipped with safety chains and so constructed that no further damage will occur when picking up vehicles. 
7.  Dual wheels. 
(C)  CLASS C—Semitrucks, house trailers, buses, etc. 
1.  Tow truck shall have a minimum manufacturer capacity of not less than twenty-five thousand (25,000) pounds GVW. 
2.  Boom capacity of not less than fifteen (15) tons. 
3.  Power winch pulling capacity of not less than twenty-five (25) tons. 
4.  Minimum of two hundred (200) feet of at least 9/16 -inch cable. 
5.  Double boom so constructed to permit separating each boom to operate independently or jointly or single boom hydraulic elevated and extendable. 
6.  Airbrakes so constructed as to lock all wheels automatically upon failure. 
7.  Cradle tow plate or tow sling to pick up vehicles. Cradle or tow plate to be equipped with safety chains and so constructed that no further damage will occur when picking up vehicles. 
8.  Dual wheels.
