The posting shall be placed on the interior of a window so that it is legible from the street to the front of the property, or secured to the exterior of the building/structure so that it is legible from the street to the front of the property, or if no such area exists, placed on a stake of sufficient size to support the posing in a location that is legible from the street to the front of the property but not readily accessible to vandals. Exterior posting shall be constructed of and printed on weather-resistant materials. 
(E)  Registration. Any mortgagee who holds a mortgage on real property located within the City that is in default, whether vacant or occupied, shall, no later than ten (10) days after the initial inspection, register the property with the City Manager, his/her designee, or the City's designee, which registration may be via electronic submission on the Internet. A separate registration is required for each property, whether vacant or occupied. 
Each property registration shall include the physical address and parcel number of the property being registered, the name of the mortgagee and the mortgagee's mailing address, a direct contact name, email address, telephone number and facsimile number of the mortgagee, and the direct contact name of the mortgagee's local property manager and said person's physical address, e-mail address, telephone number, and facsimile number. The mortgagee's local property manager shall be located within twenty (20) miles of the City of Pinellas Park. There shall be an annual registration fee, as outlined in the city's administrative fee schedule, for each property registration and the City may assign and delegate the collection of such fee to its designee. The mortgagee shall ensure each property registration is kept current with updated mortgagee and local property manager information as required herein. 
(F)  This Article shall also apply to properties that have been the subject of a foreclosure sale where title was transferred to the mortgagee as well as any properties transferred to the mortgagee under a deed-in-lieu of foreclosure. 
(G)  Properties subject to this Article, whether vacant or occupied, shall remain under the requirements of this Article as long as they remain subject to having been declared by a mortgagee to be in default. 
(H)  Any mortgagee, person, or other legal entity that has registered a property under this Article must report to the City or its designee any change of information contained in the registration within ten (10) days of the change. 
(Ord. No. 3712, § 1, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 12-115. - Availability and response requirements. 
(A)  Availability. The mortgagee shall ensure the local property manager is available to be contacted by the City, Monday through Friday between 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., holidays and the 12:00 p.m.—1:00 p.m. lunch hour accepted. 
(B)  Response. The local property manager shall serve as the mortgagee's agent and shall be duly authorized by the mortgagee to timely respond and to correct violations of the Code of Ordinances and Land Development Code as required by the City. 
(Ord. No. 3712, § 1, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 12-116. - Security and maintenance requirements. 
(A)  Security. Properties subject to this Article shall be maintained in a secure manner so as not to be accessible to unauthorized persons. A "secure manner" shall include, but not be limited to, the closure and locking of windows, doors, gates and other openings of such size that may allow a child or adult to access the property, including fenced areas and structures. Broken windows shall be secured by reglazing or as otherwise approved by the Building Official or designee. 
(B)  Maintenance. In addition to complying with the City's Code of Ordinances and Land Development Code, properties subject to this Article shall be maintained so as to not give the appearance that the property is vacant, shall be free of weeds, undergrowth and overgrowth, dead vegetation, trash, debris, and outdoor storage, swimming pools shall be maintained with clear and clean water free of pollutants and debris, and shall be free of graffiti or similar markings. Property maintenance shall include all areas of the property, including but not limited to, dwellings and structures, lawns and landscaping, and accessory structures such as sheds, swimming pools, fences, patios, and mechanical or electrical equipment, etc. 
(Ord. No. 3712, § 1, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 12-117. - Opposing, obstructing community compliance specialist; penalty. 
Whoever opposes, obstructs, or resists any Community Compliance Specialist, enforcement officer, or any person authorized by the City, in the discharge of duties as provided in this ordinance, upon conviction may be sanctioned as provided in the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pinellas Park, or F.S. Ch. 162. 
(Ord. No. 3712, § 1, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 12-118. - Immunity of Community Compliance Specialist. 
Any Community Compliance Specialists, enforcement officer, or any person authorized by the City to enforce this ordinance, shall be immune from prosecution, civil or criminal, for reasonable, good faith entry or trespass upon real property while in the discharge of duties imposed by this Article. 
Absent emergency situations, any entry onto such private residential property for purposes other than attempts to contact the occupants, shall first be approved by the City Manager or the Neighborhood Services Department Administrator. 
(Ord. No. 3712, § 1, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 12-119. - Additional authority. 
The City Manager or designee shall have authority to require the mortgagee and/or owner of record of any property affected by this ordinance to post an on-site security guard. Failure to comply with this requirement shall constitute a continuing public nuisance, and the City shall have the authority to promptly abate the public nuisance, in whole or in part, at the expense of the mortgagee and/or property owner. 
(Ord. No. 3712, § 1, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 12-120. - Penalties. 
Any violation of this Article shall be subject to enforcement as provided in the City's Code of Ordinances, which may include a hearing before the Special Magistrate or Code Enforcement Board and/or the issuance of a Pinellas County Court Citation. Upon a finding by the Code Enforcement Board, Special Magistrate, or Pinellas County Court that a violation of the City's Code of Ordinances or Land Development Code exists upon the property, the City may take any necessary action to ensure compliance with its ordinances, including necessary repairs, and may place liens on the property for the cost of the work performed to benefit the property and to bring it into compliance, which liens may be assigned to either the entity that performs the work or arranges to have the work performed. 
(Ord. No. 3712, § 1, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 12-121. - Supplemental provisions. 
Nothing contained in this Article shall prohibit the City from enforcing its codes by any other means, including, but not limited to, injunction, abatement or as otherwise provided by code. 
(Ord. No. 3712, § 1, 12-10-2009)  
ARTICLE II. - RAT CONTROL 
 
Sec. 12-201. - Short title. 
This Article may be known and may be cited as a "Rat Control Ordinance of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida". 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-202. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this Article the following definitions shall apply: 
Building. The term "building" shall mean any structure, whether public or private, that is adapted for occupancy for transaction of business, for rendering or professional services, for amusement, for the display, sale or storage of goods, wares or merchandise, or for the performance of work or labor, including hotels, rooming houses, residences, apartments, trailer parks or mobile homes or homesites, office buildings, public buildings, churches, schools, hospitals, penal institutions, stores, theaters, houses, workshops, factories, buildings where people may assemble or congregate, and all outhouses, sheds, barns and other structures on premises used for business, residential or recreational purposes. 
Occupant. The term "occupant" shall mean the individual, partnership or corporation that has the use of or occupies any building or a part or fraction thereof, or vacant or unimproved lands, whether the actual owner or tenant. In the case of vacant buildings or lands, or any vacant portion of a building or lands or any vacant portion of a building, the agent or other person having custody of the buildings or lands shall have the same responsibilities as if he were the occupant of the building so vacated. 
Owner. The term "owner" shall mean the actual owner of any building or vacant or unimproved lands, whether individual, partnership or corporation, or the agent of the building or vacant or unimproved lands, or other person having custody of the building or land to whom rent is paid. In the case of buildings leased with a clause in the lease specifying the lessee is responsible for the maintenance and repairs, the lessee will be considered in such cases as the "owner" for the purpose thereof. 
Rat harborage. The term "rat harborage" shall mean any condition existing in, under, over or outside a structure of any kind or in or about vacant or unimproved lands, which provides shelter or protection for rats, thus favoring their multiplication. 
Rat-stoppage or rat-proofing. The term "rat-stoppage" or "rat-proofing", as used herein, applies to a relatively inexpensive form of rat-proofing to prevent the ingress or rats into buildings from the exterior or from one building to another. It consists essentially of the closing of all openings in the exterior walls, ground or first floors, basements, roofs or foundations, that may be reached by rats from the ground by climbing or burrowing, with materials impervious to rat gnawing and materials for poisoning or killing rats on vacant or unimproved lands. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-203. - Buildings to be rat-free and rat-proof; approval of specifications. 
All buildings in the City shall be freed of rats and maintained in a rat-proof and rat-free condition. All buildings constructed in the City after November 10, 1960, shall be made rat-proof and any existing buildings undergoing major repairs shall be made rat-proof. In order to assure compliance with this Section, it shall be the duty of the owner of the property on which the structure is being newly built or undergoing major repair, to obtain the Building Division Director's approval of specifications for such structural plans as it relates to rat-freeing and freedom from rat-harborage. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-204. - Notice to free premises of rats; quarantine of infested premises. 
(A)  Upon receipt of a written notice or order from the City, the owner and occupant, within the time specified therein, shall take immediate measures for rat-freeing such building or vacant or unimproved lands, and, unless such work and improvements have been completed by the owner within the time specified in such written notice or order, in no event to be less than fifteen (15) days, or within the time of a written extension which may have been granted by the City, then the owner of the building or lands so failing to comply with the directions and terms of the notice or order shall be deemed guilty of an offense under the provisions of this Article. 
(B)  Upon receipt of written notice or order from the City, the occupant or any such building or lands shall proceed with the eradication work (poisoning, trapping, harborage removal, fumigation or means of rat-freeing) necessary to free the building of rats in a manner and under conditions approved by the City and shall continue this work until the building or lands is freed of rats. It shall be the responsibility of the occupant to free the building or lands of rats and to maintain the building or lands in a rat-free condition thereafter. In the event the building or lands become reinfested with rats through accident or otherwise, the occupant shall proceed with approved measures to again free it from rats. In case of failure to comply with the directions and terms of the written notice or order from the City, the occupant may be charged in County Court and the City may further order the building or lands quarantined and prohibit any person from entering the building or lands in the same manner as provided in Subsection (A) above. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-205. - Duty of occupants to maintain premises in rat-proof condition. 
The occupants of all rat-proofed buildings are required to maintain the premises in a rat-proofed condition and to repair all breaks or leaks that may occur in the rat-proofing, unless such breaks or leaks develop as the result of natural deterioration of the building, in which event it shall be the responsibility of the owner to make the repairs. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-206. - Inspection of buildings and lands. 
The City is empowered to make such unannounced inspections of the exterior of buildings or vacant and unimproved lands as, in his opinion may be necessary to determine full compliance with this Article. The City shall make periodic inspections of all rat-stopped buildings or lands to determine evidence of rat infestation and the existence of new breaks or leaks in any rat-proofing. When any evidence is found indicating the presence of rats or openings through which rats may again enter buildings or lands, or affording a rat-harborage, the City shall serve the owners or occupants with notices and/or orders to abate the conditions found. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-207. - Elimination of rat-harborage. 
Whenever conditions inside or under buildings or on vacant and unimproved lands provide such extensive harborage for rats that the City deems it necessary to eliminate such harborage, he may require the owner and occupant to eliminate such rat-harborage. He may further require the owner and occupant to correct such other conditions related to rat-harborage as may be necessary in order to facilitate the eradication of rats in a reasonable time and thereby to reduce the cost thereof, and to place materials for poisoning or killing rats on vacant or unimproved lands. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-208. - Removal of rat-proofing. 
It shall be unlawful for the occupant, owner, contractor, public utility company, plumber or any other person to remove the rat-proofing from any building or vacant lands for any purpose and fail to restore the same in a satisfactory manner or to make any new openings that are not closed or sealed against the entrance of rats. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-209. - Storage of feed for chickens, cows, etc. 
All food and feed kept within the City for the purpose of feeding chickens, cows, pigs, horses and other animals shall be kept and stored in rat-free and rat-proof containers, compartments or rooms, unless kept in a rat-proof building. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-210. - Storage of garbage and refuse. 
Within the corporate limits of the City, all garbage or refuse consisting of waste animal or vegetable matter upon which rats may feed shall be placed and stored, until collected in covered containers of a type prescribed by the City, and it is hereby declared unlawful for any person to dump or place on any premises, land or waterway, any dead animals or any waste, vegetable or animal matter of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-211. - Accumulations of garbage, refuse, etc., prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, leave, dump or permit to accumulate any garbage, refuse, or trash in any buildings or vacant or unimproved lands or premises in the City so that same shall or may afford food or harborage for rats. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
Sec. 12-212. - Accumulations of boxes, lumber, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit to accumulate on any premises, anywhere within the City limits, improved or vacant, and on any open lot or alley in the City, any lumber, boxes, barrels, bricks, stones or similar materials that may be permitted to remain thereon, unless the same shall be placed on open racks that are elevated not less than eighteen (18) inches above the ground and evenly piled or stacked so that such materials will not afford harborage for rats. Any exception of this Section shall ensue only with approval of the City and only when the owner or occupant of the property carries on a continuous rat eradication program that meets the approval of the City on such property where such unlawful accumulation exists. 
(Ord. No. 166, 11-10-1960; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987)  
ARTICLE III. - JUNKED ARTICLES 
 
Sec. 12-301. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this Article: 
Junk shall mean worn-out, scrapped, partially dismantled, discarded, nonoperative or unusable objects or materials, including vehicles, boats, or parts thereof, or other items of junk. 
Operative vehicle shall mean any vehicle which is mechanically functional and is capable of being lawfully operated on the public streets and highways, and which shall display a valid license plate. 
Person shall mean any person, firm partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 407, 7-10-1969; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987; Ord. No. 1749, 12-22-1987)  
Sec. 12-302. - Keeping of junk unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, keep, store, or allow to remain any junk in or upon any yard, garden, lawn or upon any property within the City, except within a totally enclosed building, unless such person is lawfully in possession of a valid, current City Business Tax Receipt allowing such outdoor storage of junk, and is otherwise is in full compliance with all applicable provisions of this Code. 
On and after July 1, 1969, it shall be unlawful for any person to store any inoperative vehicle, or parts thereof, on private or public property within the incorporated limits of the City, except within a totally enclosed building, unless such person is lawfully in possession of a current, valid City Business Tax Receipt, allowing the storage of inoperative vehicles or parts thereof, and is otherwise in full compliance with all applicable provisions of this Code. 
A vehicle shall be presumed to be inoperative for purposes of this Section if such vehicle is not moved from substantially the same location for a period of one (1) week or longer from the date that such vehicle is first observed by the complaining officer. 
(Ord. No. 407, 7-10-1969; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987; Ord. No. 1749, 12-22-1987; Ord. No. 3538, § 3, 3-22-2007)  
ARTICLE IV. - WATER POLLUTION CONTROL 
 
Sec. 12-401. - Intent. 
The Council finds and determines that the reasonable control and regulation of activities which are causing or may cause pollution or contamination of water and property is required for the protection and preservation of the public health, safety and welfare. It is the intent and purpose of this Article to provide and maintain for the citizens and visitors of Pinellas Park standards which will insure the purity of all waters consistent with public health and public enjoyment thereof, and the propagation and protection of wildlife, birds, game, fish and other aquatic life. 
The provisions of this Article are not intended and shall not be construed as superseding or conflicting with any statutory provisions relating to, or rules and regulations promulgated by, the Florida State Department of Environmental Regulation, but shall be construed as implementing and assisting the enforcement thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988)  
Sec. 12-402. - Definitions. 
In construing the provisions of this Article, where the context will permit and no definition is provided herein, the definitions provided in Chapter 67-436, Laws of Florida 1967, and in rules and regulations promulgated thereunder shall apply. The following words and phrases when used in this Article shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this Section: 
Adverse environmental impact shall mean any change in the physical or biological conditions of the natural environment within or adjacent to the area that results in a substantial detrimental effect upon flora, fauna, air, water, minerals or other natural characteristic(s) or the area. 
Environment shall mean the complex of climatic, edaphic and biotic factors that act upon an organism or an ecological community and ultimately determine its form and survival and which will be affected by the proposed work. 
Facility shall mean anything that is built or purchased to make an action or operation easier or to serve a special purpose. 
Hazardous materials means any waste, product, substance, or combination or breakdown product thereof which, because of its biological or chemical characteristics will be harmful or potentially harmful to human, plant or animal life or property or the conduct of business. 
Hazardous wastes refers to the definition of that term as utilized in Florida Department of Environmental Regulation Chapter 17-30, F. A. C. 
Heated-water discharges shall mean the effluent from commercial or industrial activities or processes in which water is used for the purpose of transporting waste heat. 
Nuisance shall mean and include the use of any property, facilities, equipment, processes, products or compounds, or the commission of any acts or any work that causes or materially contributes to: 
(A)  The discharge into any of the waters of this City or any organic or unorganic matter or deleterious substance or chemical compounds, or any effluent containing the foregoing, in such quantities, proportions or accumulations as to be detectable at any point beyond the property limits of the premises occupied or used by the person responsible for the source thereof, so as to interfere with the health, repose or safety of any considerable number of persons or the public, or to cause severe annoyance or discomfort, or which tends to lessen normal food and water intake, or produces symptoms of nausea, or is offensive or objectionable to normal persons because of inherent chemical or physical properties, or causes injury or damage to real property, personal property, human, plant or animal life of any kind, or which interferes with normal conduct of business, or is detrimental or harmful to the health, comfort, living conditions, welfare and safety of the inhabitants of this City. 
(B)  Any violation to the provisions of this Article which becomes detrimental to health or threatens danger to the safety of persons or property, or gives offense to, is injurious to, or endangers the public health and welfare, or prevents the reasonable and comfortable use and enjoyment of property by an considerable number of the public. 
On-site means within the boundaries of a facility location, property or site including those sites spatially separated by public or private rights-of-way. 
Person shall be construed to include any natural person, individual, public or private corporation, firm, association, joint venture, partnership, municipality, governmental agency, political subdivision, public officer or any other entity whatsoever, or any combination of such jointly or severally. 
Point of discharge (POD) for a heated-water discharge shall mean either that point at which the effluent physically leaves its carrying conduit (open or closed) and discharges into the waters of the City or a specific point designated by the Florida Department of Environmental Regulation for that particular thermal discharge. 
Pollution shall mean the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological, biological or thermal) in water which tends to degrate its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water. 
Right-of-way is a strip of ground dedicated by the subdivider, or deeded by the owner, for public use. 
Sanitary nuisance shall mean the commission of any action by an individual, municipality, organization or corporation, or the keeping, maintaining, propagation, existence or permission of anything, by an individual, municipality, organization or corporation, by which the health or life of an individual or the health or life of individuals, may be threatened or impaired or by which or through which, directly or indirectly, disease may be caused. 
Secondary containment system shall mean an impervious layer of materials which is installed so that any volume of hazardous materials which may be discharged from an underground or aboveground storage facility will be prevented from contacting the environment outside said impervious layer for the period of time necessary to detect and recover all the discharged hazardous materials. Materials or devices used to provide a secondary containment system may include concrete, impervious liners, slurry walls or other devices or materials approved by the City Manager or his designee. 
Seepage means the introduction of water into a subsurface excavation from which the water enters the groundwater. 
Solid waste means garbage, rubbish, refuse, or other discarded material, including solids or contained gaseous material resulting from domestic, industrial, commercial, mining, agricultural, or governmental operations. 
Standard methods shall mean the Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Waste Water, according to the most recent edition, as published jointly by APHA, AWWA, and WPCF. Technical terms used in this Article are those defined in the Glossary—Waste and Sewage Control Engineering, published jointly by APHA, ASCE, AWWA, and WPCF, latest edition, and the Condensed Chemical Dictionary, published by Reinhold, latest edition. 
Storm sewer shall mean any conduit which is designed to carry stormwater runoff. 
Water dependent use means a use which cannot exist or occur without association with marine, freshwater or esturine water masses. 
Waste discharge shall mean any outfall, ditch, pipe, soakage pit, drainage well, drainfield, or any other method or device by which treated or untreated sewage, industrial waste, or other wastes can enter the surface waters, tidal salt waters, or groundwaters, so as to cause water pollution as herein defined. 
Water pollution shall mean the introduction in any surface or underground water, or tidal salt water, of any organic or unorganic matter or deleterious substance in such quantities, proportions or accumulations which are injurious to human, plant, animal, fish and other aquatic life, or property, or which unreasonably interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property, or the conduct of business. 
Work shall mean any project, activity, or any artificial or manmade alteration of the environment, including, but not limited to, the construction or maintenance of roads, landclearing, trimming or cutting of a mangrove tree (or trees) dredging, filling, construction or placement of structures, floating structures, facilities or dwellings, and excavations. 
(Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988)  
Sec. 12-403. - City Manager—Duties and powers. 
The duties, functions, powers and responsibilities of the City Manager or his designee, shall including the following: 
(A)  The enforcement of the provisions of this Article and the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder, and the federal pretreatment standards, promulgated under the authority of Section 307 of the Federal Clean Water Act. 
(B)  Investigation of complaints, study and observation of water pollution conditions, institution of actions necessary to abate nuisances caused by water pollution, and initiation of proceedings to prosecute violations of this Article. 
(C)  Appropriate surveys, tests and inspections to determine whether the provisions of this Article to determine whether the provisions of this Article are being complied with, and whether water pollution is being effectively controlled throughout the City. 
(D)  Inspections of property, facilities, equipment and processes operating under the provisions of this Article to determine whether the provisions of this Article are being complied with, and make recommendations for methods by which water pollution may be reduced or eliminated. 
(E)  All possible assistance and technical advice to persons operating equipment, facilities and processes, the use of which may cause water pollution, provided that the City Manager, or his designee, shall not design equipment or facilities for any person. 
(F)  Assistance to the State of Florida Department of Environmental Regulation in connection with the review of plans, specifications and processes filed in accordance with the requirements of this Article. 
(G)  All possible cooperation and assistance to federal, state and local agencies in the accomplishment of the effective control of water pollution. 
(H)  Enlistment and encouragement of public support, and the assistance of civic, technical, scientific and educational organizations, and the cooperation of industrial and business enterprises and organizations. 
(I)  Periodic reports concerning the status of water pollution in this City and the enforcement of the provisions of this Article, and recommendations concerning the improvement of pollution requirements. Such reports shall be made available to the City Council, the State of Florida Department of Environmental Regulation, and other cognizant agencies. 
(J)  Continuing studies and periodic reports and recommendations for the improvement of water pollution controls in the City, and work in cooperation with the State of Florida Department of Environmental Regulation, the United States Public Health Service and other appropriate agencies and groups interested in the field of water pollution. 
(K)  Investigation of water pollution control programs and activities in operation in other areas and make recommendations for the improvement of the regulation, administration, and enforcement of pollution controls in this City. Publicize the importance of adequate pollution controls, to hold public hearings, discussions, forums and institutes, and arrange programs for the presentation of information by experts in the field of water pollution, and visit and study pollution control programs conducted in other metropolitan areas, subject to budget limitations. 
(L)  Whenever evidence has been obtained or received establishing that a violation of this Article has been committed, the City Manager, or his designee shall issue a notice to correct the violation or a citation to cease the violation or a citation to cease the violation and cause the same to be served upon the violator by personal service or certified mail. Such notice or citation shall briefly set forth the general nature of the violation and specify twenty (20) days within which the violation shall be rectified or stopped, commensurate with the circumstances. If notice to correct the violation or citation to cease the violation is not obeyed within the time set forth therein, the City Manager, or his designee, shall have the power and authority to issue an order requiring the violator to restrict, cease or suspend operation of the facility causing the violation until the violation is corrected. Any orders issued by the City Manager, or his designee, hereunder may be enforced by appropriate legal action. 
(M)  Whenever a violation of this Article has been committed, the City Manager, or his designee, may initiate proceedings to prosecute the violator in the appropriate court for such violation, whether or not a notice to correct the violation or citation to cease the violations has been issued by him. 
(N)  In the event a violation of this Article creates a health hazard or threatens serious damage to the public health, aquatic life or property or creates a nuisance as herein defined, the City Manager, or his designee, shall have the power and authority to order immediate cessation of the operations causing such conditions. Any person receiving such emergency order for cessation of operations shall immediately comply with the requirements thereof. It shall be unlawful for any persons to fail or refuse to comply with this Article. Any person who is convicted of willfully failing or refusing to comply with such an emergency order shall be punished by a fine not exceeding Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in the County Jail for not more than one hundred twenty (120) days, or both, in the discretion of the appropriate court. Each day during which the willful failure or refusal to comply with such an emergency order continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(O)  Appointment of deputies who are hereby empowered to perform the duties of the City Manager, as provided by this Article, subject to the City Manager's control and direction. 
(P)  Where necessary the City Manager, and his duly authorized deputies are hereby empowered to seek all search warrants reasonable and necessary to carry out their powers and duties as established by this Article, in accordance with the requirements of the Constitution of the United States and the State of Florida, the Laws of Florida, and in accordance with the procedures established by the City Code of Pinellas Park. 
(Q)  The powers and duties enumerated in this Section shall be in addition to and not a limitation of any other power or duty specifically granted to the City Manager, by any other provision of this Article. 
(R)  Whenever this Article specifies the need for approval, a determination, permits, review or the promulgation of standards or criteria by an undisclosed entity, said approval, review, permitting, or promulgation shall be the duty and responsibility of the City Manager, or his designee, unless otherwise specifically provided. Said approvals, determinations, decisions to permit, and the promulgation of standards and criteria shall be based upon generally accepted concepts and standards of the particular professional discipline concerned. 
(S)  When a violation of this Article has occurred or continues to exist or when there may be an imminent endangerment to the public health or welfare or the environment because of a threatened release or discharge of a hazardous material, the City Manager, or his designee, in his discretion may: 
1.  Take action necessary to prevent such violation per the powers allocated to the City Manager or his designee in this Article and/or by judicial process. 
2.  Restore the air, water, and property, including but not limited to animal, plant, and aquatic life affected by said violation. This provision shall not be construed to provide a defense to or otherwise relieve or limit the liability or responsibility of any person violating the provisions of this Article. Furthermore, the City Manager, or his designee, may institute suit in a court of competent jurisdiction to recover the sums expended by the City for the aforesaid restoration and prevention from the persons responsible. All sums recovered by the City Manager, pursuant to this provision shall be deposited by the City Manager into the fund from which said sums were expended. 
(T)  Order testing by the person who is or may be responsible for a violation of this Article. The design and nature of such testing shall be approved by the City Manager, or his designee, prior to implementation of the testing. Said testing shall be accomplished and the results thereof submitted to the City Manager, for review no later than such time as determined by the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988)  
Sec. 12-404. - Appeals from actions or decisions of the City Manager. 
Any person aggrieved by an action or decision of the City Manager, or his designee, may appeal to the City Council by filing within fifteen (15) days after the date of the action or decision complained of, a written notice of appeal. The City Council shall set such appeal for hearing at the earliest possible date, and cause such notice thereof to be served upon the appellant and the City Manager. The City Council shall hear and consider all facts material to the appeal, and render a decision promptly. The City Council may affirm, reverse or modify the action or decision appealed from, provided that the City Council shall not take any action which conflicts with or nullifies any of the provisions of this Article. The decision of the City Council shall constitute final administrative review and no rehearing or reconsideration shall be considered. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the City Council on any appeal shall be entitled to appeal the decision to the Circuit Court. An appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days of the execution of the decision to be appealed. The words "action" and "decision" as used herein shall not include the filing of any action by the City Manager, in any court. The City Council shall not have jurisdiction to reconsider the subject matter of any appeal after the final administrative determination for a period of six (6) months from the date of the City Council's final action, unless the City Council determines that there has been material and substantial change in the circumstances; provided, however, the City Manager, may reconsider at any time any action or decision taken by him and therefore may modify such an action or decision. 
(Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988)  
Sec. 12-405. - Prohibitions against water pollution. 
(A)  Prohibitions against discharge. Except as set forth under Subsection (G) of this Section or in accordance with a valid National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit, it shall be unlawful for any person to throw, drain, run or otherwise discharge into any waters of this City, or to cause, permit or suffer to be thrown, run, drained, allowed to seep, or otherwise discharged into such water any organic or inorganic matter which shall: 
1.  Breach the values set forth in Chapter 17-3, F.A.C., as the same from time to time exists; or 
2.  To cause water pollution as defined in this Article; or 
3.  To cause a nuisance or sanitary nuisance as herein defined; or 
4.  To cause any discharge which is not composed entirely of stormwater into the City's separate storm sewer system. 
(B)  Discharges affecting water quality. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge sewage, industrial wastes, cooling water and solid wastes, or any other wastes into the waters of this City, including but not limited to surface water, tidal salt water estuaries, or ground water in such quantities, and of such characteristics as: 
1.  May cause the receiving waters, after mixing with the waste streams, to be of poorer quality than the water quality standards set forth in Chapter 17-3, F. A. C; 
2.  To cause water pollution as defined in this Article; or 
3.  To cause a nuisance or sanitary nuisance as herein defined. 
(C)  Prohibitions against water pollution. Any discharge containing any sewage, industrial waste, or other waste materials, or containing any materials in violation of federal, state, or local laws, rules, regulations, ordinances, orders, or permits, or which causes in whole or in part a violation of federal, state, or local water quality standards, into the waters of the United States and/or the City's separate storm sewer system is prohibited. 
(D)  Compliance tests. Sampling points to determine compliance with this Article shall be selected as follows: 
1.  Sampling stations may be required to be installed if reasonable access is not available, as determined by the City Manager, or his designee. 
2.  Surface water and tidal salt water. The sampling for compliance should normally be taken at a point at least fifty (50) feet from the point of discharge of the waste stream. Where possible the samples should be taken upstream and downstream from the point of discharge. 
3.  Groundwater. For compliance, samples shall be taken from wells nearest to and encircling the point of entry of a waste stream into the ground water table. Test wells may be required to be installed and maintained if existing sampling points are found to be inadequate in the judgment of the City Manager, or his designee. 
4.  Methods. All sampling and analysis shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures set forth in the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater including Bottom Sediments and Sludges published jointly by the American Public Health Association, American Water Works Association, and Water Pollution Control Federation or accepted sanitary engineering practices. 
(E)  Notification of spills. Any person who is responsible for any discharge into the waters of the City and/or into the City's separate storm sewer system in violation of this Article shall immediately notify the City thereof, and shall take immediate action to insure the containment and cleanup of such discharge. The responsible party shall follow-up any such oral notification in writing to the City within three (3) calendar days after such oral notification is given. 
(F)  Prohibited connections. No person may maintain, use or establish any direct or indirect connection to the City's separate storm sewer system which results in any discharge in violation of this Article. This prohibition applies to connections made in the past which result in any discharge in violation of this Article, regardless of whether such connections were permissible under laws or practices applicable or prevailing at the time such connections were made. Any connections which result in any discharge in violation of this Article shall not thereafter be used without the express prior written approval of all governmental agencies having jurisdiction. 
(G)  Authorized exceptions. The following discharges are exempt from the general prohibition set forth under Subsection (A) of this Section: 
1.  Lawful flows from firefighting, water line flushing, and other contributions from potable water sources; 
2.  Lawful landscape irrigation and lawn watering discharges; 
3.  Lawfully diverted stream flows; 
4.  Rising ground waters; 
5.  Direct infiltration of ground water to the City's separate storm sewer system; 
6.  Uncontaminated lawfully pumped groundwater; 
7.  Lawful discharges from foundation and footing drains; 
8.  Water lawfully discharged from crawl space pumps; 
9.  Uncontaminated lawful discharges from air conditioning condensation; 
10.  Lawful discharges from natural springs; 
11.  Lawful discharges from individual residential car washing and filter backwash from residential swimming pools; and 
12.  Lawful flows from riparian habitats and wetlands. 
Provided, however, that all discharges permitted hereby shall be in full compliance with all applicable federal, state, and local laws, rules, regulations, ordinances, orders and permits. 
(Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988; Ord. No. 2508, 8-27-1998)  
Sec. 12-406. - Nuisance prohibited. 
No person shall cause, or allow to be caused, any nuisance or sanitary nuisance as defined herein. In addition to all other remedies he may have, the City Manager, or his designee, is authorized to seek, in the appropriate court, injunctive relief, both of a temporary and permanent nature, against any person causing or allowing to be caused, any such nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988)  
Sec. 12-407. - Enforcement; procedure; remedies. 
(A)  The City Manager or his authorized representative may enter and inspect any property, premises or place, to investigate complaints, study and observe water pollution conditions, make appropriate surveys, tests and inspections at any reasonable time for the purpose of ascertaining the state of compliance with this Article. No person shall refuse immediate entry or access to the City Manager or his authorized representative upon request for such entry or access for the purpose of inspection, and upon presentation of appropriate credentials; nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such inspection. If requested, the owner of the premises shall receive a report setting forth all facts found which relate to compliance status. 
(B)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this Article, any lawful rules and regulations promulgated under this Article, any lawful order of the City Manager, or his designee, or any condition, limitation or restriction which is part of an operating permit. It shall be the duty of all municipal officials and employees to enforce the provisions of this Article. In addition to any other remedies provided by this Chapter, the City Manager, or his designee, shall have the following judicial remedies available to him for violations of this Article, any lawful rule or regulation promulgated under this Article, any lawful order of the City Manager, or his designee, or any condition, limitation or restriction which is part of an operating permit: 
1.  The City Manager may institute a civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction to establish liability to recover damages for any injury to the waters, or property, including animal, plant, and aquatic life, of the City caused by such violation. 
2.  The City Manager may institute a civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction to impose and recover a civil penalty for each violation in an amount of not more than Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) per offense. However, the court may receive evidence in mitigation. Each day during any portion of which such violation occurs constitutes a separate offense. 
3.  The City Manager may institute a civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction to seek injunctive relief to enforce compliance with or prohibit the violation of this Article, any lawful rule or regulation promulgated under this Article, any lawful order of the City Manager, or his designee, or any condition, limitation or restriction which is part of an operating permit; and to seek injunctive relief to prevent injury to the waters, and property, including animal, plant, and aquatic life of the City, and to protect human health, safety, and welfare caused or threatened by any violation. 
(Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988)  
Sec. 12-408. - Penalties generally. 
If any personal shall fail or refuse to obey or comply with, or violate any of the provisions of this Article, or any lawful rule or regulation promulgated hereunder, or any lawful order of the City Manager, or his designee, or any condition, limitation or restriction which is part of an operating permit; issued or rendered under and pursuant to the provision of this Article, such persons, upon conviction of such offense, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment not to exceed one hundred twenty (120) days in the County Jail, or both in the discretion of the court. Each day of continued violation shall be considered as a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988)  
Sec. 12-409. - Civil liability; joint and several liability. 
(A)  Whoever commits a violation of this Article or any lawful rule or regulation promulgated under this Article is liable to the City of Pinellas Park for any damage caused to the waters, or property, including animal, plant, or aquatic life, of the City and for reasonable costs and expenses of the City in tracing the source of the discharge, in controlling and abating the source and the pollutants, and in restoring the waters, and property, including animal, plant, and aquatic life, of the City to their former condition, and furthermore is subject to the judicial imposition of a civil penalty for each offense in an amount of not more than Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) per offense. However, the court may receive evidence in mitigation. Each day during any portion of which such violation occurs constitutes a separate offense. Nothing herein shall give the City Manager the right to bring an action on behalf of any private person. 
(B)  Whenever, two (2) or more persons pollute the waters of the City in violation of this Article, or any lawful rule or regulation promulgated under this Article or any order of the City Manager, so that the damage is indivisible, each violator shall be jointly and severally liable for such damage and for the reasonable cost and expenses of the City incurred in tracing the source of discharge, in controlling and abating the source and the pollutants, and in restoring the waters and property, including the animal plant and aquatic life of the City to their former condition. However, if said damage is divisible and may be attributed to a particular violator or violators, each violator is liable only for that damage attributable to his violation. 
(C)  In assessing damages for fish killed, the value of the fish is to be determined in accordance with a table of values for individual categories of fish which has been promulgated by the Florida Department of Environmental Regulation. 
(D)  All the judicial remedies in this Article are independent and cumulative. 
(E)  Whenever a violation of this Article occurs or exists, any person, individually or otherwise, who has a legal, beneficial, or equitable interest in the facility or instrumentality causing or contributing to the violation or who has a legal, beneficial, or equitable interest in the real property upon which such facility or instrumentality is located shall be jointly and severally liable for said violation regardless of fault and regardless of knowledge of the violation. This provision shall be construed to impose joint and several liability, regardless of fault and regardless of knowledge of the violation, upon all persons, individually or otherwise, who, although no longer having any such legal, beneficial or equitable interest in said facility or instrumentality or real property, did have such an interest at any time during which such violation existed or occurred or continued to exist or to occur. This provision shall be liberally construed and shall be retroactively applied to protect the public health, safety, and welfare and to accomplish the purposes of this Article. 
(F)  Any persons violating any provision of this Article shall immediately restore the water, and property, including and not limited to animal, plant, and aquatic life, affected by said violation to the condition existing prior to the violation. 
(G)  Owners of real property shall be liable for the sums expended by the City to correct violations of this Article when the violation of this Article occurred or continued to exist or appeared imminent upon the real property aforesaid, regardless of fault and regardless of knowledge of the aforesaid violation. All sums expended by the City to correct violations of this Article shall constitute and are hereby imposed as special assessments against the real property aforesaid, as per FSA 170.09, and until fully paid and discharged or barred by law, shall remain liens equal in rank and dignity with the lien of County ad valorem taxes and superior in rank and dignity to all other liens, encumbrances, titles and claims in, to or against the real property involved. All such sums shall become immediately due and owing to the City upon expenditure by the City and shall become delinquent if not fully paid within sixty (60) days after the due date. All such delinquent sums shall bear a penalty of fifteen (15) percent per annum. Unpaid and delinquent sums, together with all penalties imposed thereon, shall remain and constitute special assessment liens against the real property involved for the period of five (5) years from due date thereof. Said special assessment liens may be enforced by the City Manager, by any of the methods provided in F.S. ch. 85, or, in the alternative, foreclosure proceedings may be instituted and prosecuted by the City Manager, pursuant to the provisions of F.S. ch. 173, or the collection and enforcement of payment thereof may be accomplished by any other method provided by law. All sums recovered by the City pursuant to this provision shall be deposited by the City into the fund from which said sums were expended. 
(H)  The provisions of this Article shall be deemed to be cumulative and supplemental to state law pertaining to the protection and/or restoration of water quality. 
(I)  If any Section, Subsection, sentence, clause, or provision of this Article is held invalid, the remainder of this Article shall not be affected by such invalidity. 
(Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988)  
ARTICLE V. - DISASTER ACCESS AND DEBRIS REMOVAL 
 
Sec. 12-501. - Purpose. 
The City needs an efficient and effective system for disposing of disaster debris. The Disaster Access and Debris Removal Ordinance is designed to advise property owners of their duties and responsibilities with respect to disaster debris, to provide for an efficient system for collection and removal of disaster debris and to eliminate threats to health, safety and welfare created by disaster debris. 
(Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
Sec. 12-502. - Findings of fact. 
The City Council finds that disaster debris can pose a serious and immediate threat to life, health, safety and welfare, and poses an immediate threat of significant damage to improved property. 
(Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
Sec. 12-503. - Access for emergency response and disaster debris removal. 
(A)  The City, through its contract agents, provides basic life safety services to the public. In order to facilitate emergency response to disasters that have caused disaster debris to be produced throughout the City, the City will clear disaster debris from public and private rights-of-way throughout the City. 
(B)  Upon declaration of a state of emergency affecting the City or the declaration of a state of local emergency by the City, and until the state of emergency and/or state of local emergency has been lifted or otherwise ceased, communities with private rights-of way, whether gated or ungated, shall allow unlimited access through all community entrances to the City and its agents for response to emergencies and circumstances that pose serious and immediate threats to life, health and/or safety to the public. 
(C)  To facilitate unlimited access throughout communities with private rights-of-way: 
1.  Community entrances with gatehouses that are staffed shall provide access to the City's agents and vehicles upon display of proper identification; 
2.  Community entrances with gatehouses that are staffed less than twenty-four (24) hours a day shall keep gates open when the gatehouses are not staffed; and 
3.  Community entrances without staffed gatehouses shall keep gates open twenty-four (24) hours a day. 
(Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
Sec. 12-504. - Collection and removal of disaster debris, generally. 
(A)  The City will only remove disaster debris if the City Manager or his/her designee determines, pursuant to Section 12-507, that the presence of disaster debris throughout the City is so widespread or of such a severe nature as to pose a serious and immediate threat to life, health, and/or safety. 
(B)  The City will only remove disaster debris piles from public and private rights-of-way. 
(C)  The City will only remove disaster debris piles that have been collected and located as required by Section 12-505. The City may prioritize the removal of different types of quantities of disaster debris. 
(D)  All actions of property owners, or their agents, to collect, reduce, remove or otherwise dispose of disaster debris shall comply with all provisions of federal and state law, and with the City's Code of Ordinances. 
(E)  Burning of disaster debris is prohibited at all times. The City will not remove large stumps or limbs or any debris that is not a direct result of the disaster, including debris generated by land clearing operations, house cleaning efforts or other attempts to have the City remove debris that is not disaster debris. 
(Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
Sec. 12-505. - Disaster debris from residential property. 
(A)  Residential property owners are responsible for the collection and removal of disaster debris from their property. 
(B)  As provided in Section 12-504, the City may remove disaster debris collected from residential property. Residential property owners desiring the City to remove disaster debris shall collect and locate in piles all disaster debris as required by this section before the City's last pass for removal of disaster debris. Disaster debris piles put out for removal after the City makes its last pass will not be removed by the City. 
(C)  Residential property owners must segregate structural debris piles from the vegetative debris piles, and these piles, must be segregated from household waste. Household waste shall be bagged and placed in garbage cans. Structural debris and vegetative debris shall not be bagged, except that loose vegetative debris may be placed in large plastic bags. 
(D)  Residential property owners shall place disaster debris piles: 
1.  In front of their residence in the swale area immediately adjacent to the edge of the public or private roadway; and 
2.  In such a manner as to allow ingress and egress to all residential properties. 
(E)  Residential property owners may combine their several piles of segregated disaster debris into larger piles to accomplish this requirement. 
(F)  The City and its agents shall not be responsible for damage to sidewalks or mailboxes when disaster debris is placed on or adjacent thereto. 
(G)  If the City determines that: 
1.  A residential property owner's structural debris, vegetative debris and/or household waste is commingled, or has not been collected in accordance with Sec. 12-505, the residential property owner shall have forty-eight (48) hours to properly segregate the disaster debris. If the residential property owner fails to properly segregate his or her disaster debris within forty-eight (48) hours, then the residential property owner is required to remove and dispose of the disaster debris at his or her expense; 
2.  Any disaster debris from non-residential property, including community property, has been commingled with the disaster debris of a residential property owner, then the City will not remove the disaster debris and the residential property owner is required to remove the disaster debris piles at his or her expense; or 
3.  Any disaster debris has been moved or transported by a motorized machine, then the City will not remove the disaster debris and the residential property owner is required to remove the disaster debris at his or her expense. 
(Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
Sec. 12-506. - Disaster debris removal from non-residential property. 
(A)  The City will not remove disaster debris that has come from or been commingled with disaster debris from: 
1.  Non-Residential property; 
2.  Landscape medians or culs-de-sac in communities with private rights-of-way; or 
3.  Privately owned parks or other privately owned properties that are not residential. 
(B)  Non-residential property owners, including entities owning community property, shall collect, reduce, remove and otherwise dispose of all disaster debris on their property within 60 days of the end of the disaster. 
(C)  Non-residential property owners, including entities owning community property, shall not: 
1.  Move disaster debris from their property to residential property; or 
2.  Collect their disaster debris and commingle it with residential property owner's disaster debris piles. 
(D)  Tub grinding operations or any other operation to reduce disaster debris from non-residential property must be conducted at least 200 feet away from residential property. 
(Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
Sec. 12-507. - Determination of immediate threat to life, health or safety. 
(A)  The City Manager or his or her designee shall determine whether the presence of disaster debris is so widespread or of such a severe nature as to pose a serious and immediate threat to life, health and/or safety of the public as provided in this section. 
(B)  In the event that a disaster has caused or is causing the presence of disaster debris in the City, or any part thereof, the City Manager or his or her designee shall determine the scope of the disaster, the scope of the disaster debris spread, and the nature of the disaster debris. After compiling this information, the City Manager shall assess the seriousness and immediacy of threats to life, health and/or safety posed by disaster debris present throughout the City. 
(C)  It is in the public interest to remove disaster debris where City action is necessary to eliminate an immediate threat to life and/or public health and/or public safety. 
(D)  The City Manager or his or her designee shall determine, based upon his or her assessment of the seriousness and immediacy of threats to life, health and/or safety posed by disaster debris, whether it is in the public interest to remove disaster debris anywhere in the City. 
1.  The City Manager or his or her designee shall consider the presence and/or imminent development of any of the following dangers or aggravating factors in assessing whether the removal of disaster debris is in the public interest: 
(a)  Downed or disabled power lines or other utility connections; 
(b)  Glass, metal or other sharp debris; 
(c)  Biological or chemical waste and/or contaminants; 
(d)  Risk of fire; 
(e)  Risk of infestation by vermin; 
(f)  Risk of disease spread; 
(g)  Risk of preventing or impairing emergency response; 
(h)  Risk of the collapse of structures; 
(i)  Risk of disaster debris becoming wind blown projectiles; 
(j)  Risk of attractive nuisance; and 
(k)  Impairment of drainage by disaster debris, and risk associated therewith. 
2.  The City Manager or his or her designee shall also consider any other danger or aggravating factor he or she finds applicable to assessing whether the removal of disaster debris is in the public interest. 
3.  The City Manager shall promulgate any rules and forms necessary to detail determinations made pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
Sec. 12-508. - Federal government indemnification, defense and hold harmless. 
To the extent that the City enters private rights-of way to clear and/or remove disaster debris, the owner of the right-of way shall indemnify, defend and hold the federal government and its agencies harmless for claims arising from the City's removal of disaster debris. 
(Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
ARTICLE VI. - ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 12-601. - Enforcement. 
The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all of the provisions of this Chapter. Upon presentation of proper credentials, the City Manager or his designee, may enter at reasonable times, any lot or parcel of land in the City of Pinellas Park to perform any duty imposed upon him by this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 407, 7-10-1969; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987; Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988; Ord. No. 2420, 2-27-1997; Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
ARTICLE VII. - PENALTY 
 
Sec. 12-701. - Penalty for violations of this Chapter. 
Except as otherwise provided in Article VI, any person who shall violate the provisions of this Chapter shall, upon conviction thereof in a court of competent jurisdiction, be punished as provided in Section 1-109 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 407, 7-10-1969; Ord. No. 1716, 8-27-1987; Ord. No. 1781, 4-28-1988; Ord. No. 3643, § 1, 9-25-2008)  
CHAPTER 13 - BUSINESS TAX RECEIPTS[1]
