Any and all persons, firms or corporations engaged in business as a pawnbroker, a junk dealer or secondhand dealer, as defined in this Chapter, shall keep a register in connection with such business, and, at the close of business on each day, shall enter or cause to be entered therein an accurate description of the person or persons from whom any article of personal property is purchased or received, or to whom any loan is made on personal property and shall include in such description the name, age, sex, color, nationality and place of residence of such person or persons. An original right thumbprint of such person or persons shall be affixed to the register, which can only be used to identify the person whose name appears on the register when probable cause exists that the secondhand goods are stolen. The register shall also contain an accurate description of any article of personal property so purchased or received, or upon which a loan is made, and said description shall contain any mark, brand, monogram, word or letters blown, stamped, etched or otherwise permanently marked upon such article, and all articles so purchased or received shall be so arranged in stock as to enable the same to be inspected by the Police Department or any other person in authority; and the said register shall at all times be kept open for the inspection and examination of the Chief of Police or any other person authorized by the Chief of Police to inspect the same. 
(Ord. No. 175, 8-24-1961; Ord. No. 2040, 8-9-1990)  
Sec. 15-103. - Copy of register to be furnished Chief of Police. 
All pawnbrokers, junk or secondhand dealers shall, not later than 10:00 a.m. of each day, furnish to the Chief of Police a full and complete copy or transcript of the register in which is entered the transactions of the preceding day as required by the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 175, 8-24-1961)  
Sec. 15-104. - Penalty of violation of Chapter. 
Any person, including the managing officers of corporations, violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined not to exceed Two Hundred Dollars ($200.00) or sentenced to serve at hard labor in the City Jail not to exceed ninety (90) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the Municipal Judge, and, in addition thereto, the Municipal Judge may, in his discretion, revoke the license of said person, firm or corporation. 
(Ord. No. 175, 8-24-1961)  
CHAPTER 16 - OFFENSES 
 
Sec. 16-101. - Doing business on streets and sidewalks prohibited; prohibiting soliciting and selling within road rights-of-way. 
(A)  No person shall sell or offer for sale any goods, services, wares or merchandise, or transact any other business upon the public streets or sidewalks of the City. Provided, this Section shall not apply to the distribution of advertising literature when such distribution shall be otherwise lawful and not in violation of any other Ordinance of the City. Provided further, that nothing in this Section shall prevent the sale of newspapers. 
(B)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in soliciting donations or contributions within road rights-of-way in the City. 
(C)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the sale of or accepting orders for any goods, wares, merchandise or any other item of any kind or description within road rights-of-way in the City. Provided, this Section shall not apply to licensed vendors from selling goods within a road right-of-way during a validly licensed parade. Provided further, that nothing shall preclude the sale of newspapers from newspaper racks located within road rights-of-way. 
(D)  Solicitation for charities by public safety officers. 
1.  Public safety officers may solicit for a charitable organization in the road rights-of-way that the City of Pinellas Park has original jurisdiction after having obtained a permit. Permits to solicit on a State- or Federal-maintained road right-of-way shall require the approval of the State agency, which has jurisdiction. The permit will allow the solicitation. 
2.  For the purposes of this Section, a "charitable organization" means an organization that is qualified under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and registered pursuant to Chapter 496 of the State of Florida. 
3.  For the purposes of this Section, public safety officers means members of the Pinellas Park Fire Department and members of the Pinellas Park Police Department. 
4.  The permit for solicitations in the road rights-of-way may be obtained from the Traffic Division and approved by the City Council provided the applicant meets the following criteria: 
(a)  The applicant's name and address in the City of Pinellas Park, including the name and address of the charitable organization to receive funds from the solicitation. 
(b)  The applicant shall provide a plan for review and comment by the City's Traffic Division Director, which plan will maximize the safety of the applicant's representatives, as well as the motoring public, at the locations where the solicitation will take place. 
(c)  The applicant shall indicate in specific detail the location of such solicitation, together with the hours thereof, not to exceed three (3) consecutive days. 
(d)  The applicant shall provide an indemnification and hold harmless in favor of the City in a form satisfactory to the City Attorney. 
(e)  No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall participate in any solicitation in the right-of-way pursuant to a permit granted under this Section. 
(f)  All solicitation shall occur during daylight hours only. 
(g)  The applicant shall provide proof of commercial general liability insurance against claims for bodily injury and property damage occurring on City roadways and rights-of-way or arising from the applicant's solicitation activities or use of the City roadways and rights-of-way by applicant or the applicant's agents, contractors or employees having limits of not less than One Million Dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence for the general aggregate (per location). The certificate of insurance shall name the City of Pinellas Park as an additional insured and shall be filed with the Risk Management Division by no later than forty-eight (48) hours before the date of solicitation. 
(h)  All funds raised from the solicitation shall be donated to a not-for-profit charitable organization licensed and registered to do business in the State of Florida. 
(i)  The applicant shall comply with all other laws, City codes and regulations pertaining to public safety, traffic and solicitation. 
(j)  The Traffic Division may decline to issue subsequent permits to any individual or group violating the parameters of a previously issued permit or violating any requirements of this Section, any other City ordinance or any State statute. 
(k)  During active solicitation, at least one (1) solicitor at each location shall be in possession of a copy of the authorizing permit and the certificate of insurance and shall display the copy to any law enforcement officer upon request. All solicitors shall possess picture identification. 
(l)  No charitable organization shall be granted more than two (2) permits per calendar year. 
(m)  Soliciting in the right-of-way without a valid permit issued pursuant to this Section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding Fifty Dollars ($50.00) for a first offense and Two Hundred Fifty Dollars ($250.00) for a second or subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 117, 6-26-1958; Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984; Ord. No. 1657, 9-25-1986; Ord. No. 3141, 7-24-2003)  
Sec. 16-102. - Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 32, 12-13-1948; Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984; Ord. No. 3378, 9-22-2005)  
Sec. 16-103. - BB guns, air or gas operated guns; unlawful to discharge. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge any BB gun, air or gas operated gun, as defined by State Law, within the limits of the City, except in a duly licensed shooting gallery, gun club or rifle range. 
(Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984)  
Sec. 16-104. - Misdemeanors; State law adopted. 
It shall be unlawful to commit within the limits of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, any act which is or shall be recognized by the laws of the State of Florida as a misdemeanor; and the commission of such act or acts is hereby forbidden. 
(Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984)  
Sec. 16-105. - Noise. 
(A)  Declaration of necessity. It is found and declared that: 
1.  The making and creation of excessive, unnecessary or unusually loud noises within the limits of the City of Pinellas Park is a condition which has existed for some time and the amount and intensity of such noises is increasing. 
2.  The making, creation or maintenance of such excessive unnecessary, unnatural or unusually loud noises which are prolonged, unusual and unnatural in their time, health, comfort, convenience, safety, welfare and prosperity of the residents of the City of Pinellas Park. 
3.  The necessity in the public interest for the provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained and enacted is declared as a matter of legislative determination and public policy, and it is further declared that the provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained and enacted are in pursuance of and for the purpose of securing and promoting the public health, comfort, safety, welfare and repose of Pinellas Park and its inhabitants. 
(B)  Noise exceeding certain limits prohibited generally. It shall be unlawful, except as expressly permitted herein, to make, cause or allow the making of any noise or sound within the boundaries of Pinellas Park, Florida, which exceeds the limits set for in this Section. 
(C)  Definitions. The words or phrases used in this Section are defined as follows: 
1.  A-weighted level (DBA). The total broad band sound level of the noise spectrum as measured using the "A-weighted network" of a sound level meter. The unit of measurement is a DBA. Sound level meter settings shall be for slow response, except for motor vehicle measurements which shall be fast response. 
2.  Ambient noise. The all-encompassing noise associated with a given environment, being usually a composite of sound from many sources near and far. 
3.  Continuous noise. A noise which remains essentially constant in level during the period of observation. 
4.  Decibel (dB). A division of a logarithmic scale used to express the ratio of two (2) like quantities proportional to power or energy. The ratio is expressed by ten (10). 
5.  Emergency. A situation wherein immediate work is necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity or immediate work is required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. 
6.  Gross combination weight rating (GCWR). The value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a combination vehicle. 
7.  Gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR). The value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle. 
8.  Impulsive noise. A noise which is characterized by brief excursions of sound pressure which significantly exceed the ambient noise level. 
9.  Intermittent noise. A noise whose sound pressure level exceeds the ambient noise level at either regular or irregular intervals. 
10.  Motor vehicle. Any vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolly wires, but not operated upon rails. 
11.  Motorcycle. Any motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
12.  Motor-driven cycle. Every motorcycle and every motor scooter with a motor which produces not to exceed five (5) brake horsepower, including every bicycle with a motor attached. 
13.  Noise. One (1) or a group of loud, harsh, nonharmonious sounds or vibrations that are unpleasant and irritating to the ear. 
14.  Noise level. As referenced in this Section, the noise level is the sound pressure level as measured in dBA unless otherwise specified. A measurement of noise must be at least five (5) dB above the ambient noise level. 
15.  Person. Any individual, natural person, public or private corporation, firm, association, joint venture, partnership, or any other entity whatsoever or any combination of such, jointly and severally. 
16.  Sound level meter. An instrument to measure the sound pressure level or relatively continuous and broadband noises. The sound level meter used to determine compliance with this Section shall meet or exceed the requirements for Type 2 sound level meter in accordance with ANSI Standard S1-4. 
17.  Sound pressure level. The squared ratio expressed in decibels, of the sound pressure under consideration to the standard reference pressure of 0.0002 dyne/cm2. The ratio is squared because pressure squared, and not pressure, is proportional to energy. 
18.  Vehicle. Any device, in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
19.  Residential zone. Any geographic area designated for single- or multifamily dwelling by the zoning authority having jurisdiction over such area. 
20.  Commercial zone. Any geographic area designated for commercial or professional activities by the zoning authority having jurisdiction over such area. 
(D)  Noises specifically prohibited. 
1.  Vehicle noise. 
(a)  No person shall operate or permit to be operated a motor vehicle without a muffling device at least as effective as that installed as original equipment by the manufacturer. 
(b)  No person shall operate or permit to be operated a vehicle at any time or under any condition of roadway grade, load, acceleration or deceleration in such a manner as to generate a sound level in excess of the following limit for the category of motor vehicle and applicable speed limit at a distance of fifty (50) feet from the center of the lane of travel: 
(1)  For motorcycles other than motor-driven cycles: 
Sound Level Limit 
Speed Limit 	Speed Limit 
35 MPH or less 	Over 35 MPH 
82 dBA 	86 dBA 
78 dBA 	82 dBA 
 
(2)  For any motor vehicle with a GVWR or GCWR or ten thousand (10,000) pounds or more: 
Sound Level Limit 
Speed Limit 	Speed Limit 
35 MPH or less 	Over 35 MPH 
86 dBA 	90 dBA 
 
(3)  For motor-driven cycles and any other motor vehicle not included in Subsections (D)1.(b)(1) or (2): 
Sound Level Limit 
Speed Limit 	Speed Limit 
35 MPH or less 	Over 35 MPH 
76 dBA 	82 dBA 
70 dBA 	79 dBA 
 
(c)  The sounding of any horn or signaling device, except as a danger warning, is prohibited. 
2.  Construction noise. 
(a)  No person shall operate or permit to be operated any power-driven construction equipment without a muffler or other noise reduction device at least as effective as that recommended by the manufacturer or provided as original equipment. 
(b)  No construction activities shall be permitted between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, and all day Sunday, that produce noise exceeding fifty-five (55) dBA, measured at the nearest property line of an adjacent residential area. Construction equipment that must be operated near a residentially zoned area on a twenty-four-hour per day basis (i.e., pumps, well tips, generators, etc.) shall be shielded by an acoustical enclosure during the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. unless the unshielded noise level is less than fifty-five (55) dBA, measured at the closest adjacent residentially zoned property line. 
3.  Industrial or commercial noises. 
(a)  No noise shall be created or permitted to be created in an industrial or commercial zone which exceeds those levels given in Table 2, below, as measured on the adjacent property line. 
_____
TABLE 2 
MAXIMUM NOISE LEVELS PERMITTED IN INDUSTRIAL AND COMMERCIAL ZONES 
Zone from which noise 
emanates 	Adjoining commercial zone (no time limit) 	Adjoining residential zone (7:00 a.m.—6:00 p.m., Monday— 
Saturday) 
Industrial 	72 dBA 	66 dBA 
Commercial 	66 dBA 	60 dBA 
 
_____ 
The maximum permitted noise level emanating from a commercially or industrially zoned district, measured at the nearest adjacent residentially zoned property line for the hours between 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday and during all hours of Sunday, shall be fifty-five (55) dBA. 
(b)  An exception to the noise levels listed in Table 2 may be permitted by the granting of a waiver, under circumstances in which the activity creating the noise is of such importance to the public welfare, health or safety that the activity cannot be shut down, even though its noise levels exceed those given in Table 2. Responsibility for the granting of such waivers shall lie with the City Manager or his duly authorized representative. 
(c)  A further exception to the noise levels listed in Table 2 shall be permitted in instances where an industry or commercial business had in prior years established its place of business in an area away from a residential zone, and subsequently, through the encroachment of residential development, or rezoning, now finds itself adjoining a residential zone. In instances of this latter nature, the noise ordinance pertaining to industrial-commercial boundaries shall govern, and the business shall not be required to meet those noise levels pertaining to residential boundaries. 
(d)  In cases of impulsive noises, the noise levels listed in Table 2 shall be increased by ten (10) dBA (as measured on a sound level meter) during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, but shall not exceed the levels of Table 2 during the period from 6:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday and all day Sunday. 
4.  Noises created within residential zones. Except for those noises otherwise specifically provided for within this Section, it shall be unlawful to create or to permit to be created any noise within a residential zone that exceeds seventy-two (72) dBA, during the hours between 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. or fifty-five (55) dBA during the hours between 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., daily, measured at the nearest adjacent property line. 
It shall be unlawful to operate or permit to be operated any air conditioning, heating or ventilating unit at any time that produces a noise exceeding sixty (60) dBA, measured at the nearest adjacent property line. 
In the case of multifamily dwelling units, it shall be unlawful to create or permit to be created any noise that exceeds fifty-five (55) dBA, during the hours between 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m., or forty (40) dBA during the hours between 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. daily, measured from a neighbor's dwelling. 
5.  Noise emanating from boats or barges on water areas adjoining residential zones. No craft shall be operated or permitted to be operated on water areas adjoining residential zones which produces noise that exceeds fifty-five (55) dBA, measured at the nearest adjacent residential property line, during the hours of 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m., daily, except as provided below. 
In the case of construction barges or dredges, a permit from the City Manager must be obtained in order to operate during the hours of 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. This permit will only be granted when the barge or dredge operator has satisfied the City Manager that he has done all that is reasonably possible to minimize the noise impact on the adjacent residential community. 
6.  Noises within outdoor public recreation areas and parks. It shall be unlawful to operate or permit to be operated any mechanical or electrical device within an outdoor public recreation area or park that produces a noise exceeding seventy-two (72) dBA during the hours between 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m., or fifty-five (55) dBA during the hours between 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. daily, measured at the nearest adjacent residentially zoned property line, except for planned community events, including but not limited to concerts, speeches, sporting events, fireworks displays, etc. When a planned community event will create noise in excess of the limits specified herein, a permit must be obtained prior to the event. 
(E)  Exceptions. The following shall be permitted: 
1.  The operation of warning or emergency signal devices such as sirens, horns, and bells when utilized for their intended purpose. 
2.  Noises resulting from equipment or operations incidental to the emergency repair of facilities or restoration of services such as public utilities or other emergency activities in the public interest. 
3.  Ordinary noise created by the operation of railways, shipping lanes and aircraft. 
4.  Noises consistent with cultural, historical or traditional observances, holidays and ceremonies, provided that a permit for such event has been obtained from the City Manager in accordance with Subsection (D) above. 
(F)  Waivers. Applications for a waiver for relief from the maximum allowable noise level limits designated in this Subsection shall be made in writing. Such applications for waivers shall be made to the City Manager or his duly authorized representative. Any waiver granted by the City Manager or his duly authorized representative may grant the waiver as applied for under the following conditions: 
1.  The City Manager may prescribe any reasonable conditions or requirements they deem necessary to minimize adverse effects upon the community or the surrounding neighborhood, including but not limited to the use of mufflers, screens or other sound attenuating devices. 
2.  Waivers from maximum allowable noise level limits may only be granted for noises created within an industrial or commercial zone by operations which were in existence on the effective date of this Section. 
3.  Waivers may be issued for no longer than one hundred eighty (180) days, renewable by further application to the City Manager. 
Any party feeling aggrieved by the denial of its application for waiver by the City Manager may appeal such denial to the City Council, such appeal to be filed within thirty (30) days from the date of denial. 
(G)  Penalties. Any person or persons, firm or corporation, or any agent thereof who violates any of the provisions of this Section shall upon conviction be subject to a fine not exceeding the sum of Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment in the County Jail for a period not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(H)  Enforcement. The penalty provided for in Subsection (G) hereof shall in no way be construed to limit the power of the City of Pinellas Park to proceed in any other civil or criminal proceeding or to proceed under any other provision of the City of Pinellas Park's Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984; Ord. No. 2145, 4-9-1992)  
Sec. 16-106. - Abandoned, discarded, and stored appliances. 
(A)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly abandon, discard or store, or to permit to be abandoned, discarded, or stored, on premises under his control any icebox, refrigerator, deep-freeze locker, clothes washer, clothes dryer, or similar airtight unit having an interior storage capacity of one and one-half (1½) cubic feet or more from which the door has not been removed. 
(B)  The provisions of this Section shall not apply to an icebox, refrigerator, deep-freeze locker, clothes washer, clothes dryer, or similar airtight unit which is crated or securely locked from the outside by means of a lock and chain or other secure locking device, or is in normal use on the premises of a home, or rental unit, or is held for sale or use in a place of business; provided, however, that the term "place of business" as used herein shall not be deemed to include a junkyard or other similar establishment dealing in secondhand merchandise for sale on open unprotected premises. 
(C)  It shall be unlawful for any junkyard dealer or secondhand furniture dealer with unenclosed premises used for display of secondhand iceboxes, refrigerators, deep-freeze lockers, clothes washers, clothes dryers, or similar airtight units to fail to remove the doors from such secondhand units having an interior storage capacity of one and one-half (1½) cubic feet or more from which the door has not been removed. This Section shall not apply to any dealer who has fenced and locked his premises. 
(Ord. No. 1149, 5-13-1982; Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984)  
Sec. 16-107. - Obstructing public sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for persons to congregate together upon the public sidewalks of the City in such a manner or to such an extent as to unreasonably impede, block or obstruct public pedestrian travel thereon. 
(Ord. No. 117, 6-26-1958; Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984)  
Sec. 16-108. - Abandoned, wrecked, nonoperating or junked vehicles. 
(A)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this Section of the City Code: 
Abandoned, wrecked or junked automobiles or vehicles shall mean any vehicle, including a trailer which is without a currently valid license plate or is wrecked, or discarded, or dismantled, or partially dismantled, or inoperative, which reasonably appears to have been abandoned, or the owners of which cannot reasonably be located. 
Person shall mean any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
Property shall mean any real property within the City which is not a street or highway. 
Street or highway shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
Vehicle shall mean a machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners, or slides and transport persons or property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitation, automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy, wagon, etc. 
(B)  Abandonment of vehicles prohibited. No person shall abandon any vehicle within the City and no person shall leave any vehicle at any place within the City for such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. 
(C)  Leaving of wrecked, nonoperating vehicle on street prohibited. No person shall leave any partially dismantled, nonoperating, wrecked or junked vehicle on any street or highway within the City. 
(D)  Wrecked, discarded vehicles; time limit for disposition; exception. No person in charge or control of any property within the City, whether as owner, tenant, occupant, lessee, or otherwise, shall allow any wrecked, junked, automobile or vehicle or discarded vehicle to remain on such property longer than seventy-two (72) hours; and no person shall leave any such vehicle on any property within the City for a longer time than seventy-two (72) hours, except that this Section shall not apply with regard to a vehicle in an enclosed building; a vehicle on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner when necessary to the operation of such business enterprise; or a vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the City. 
(E)  Impounding of vehicles. 
1.  City Manager's authority. The City Manager, or his designated representative, are hereby authorized to remove or have removed any vehicle left at any place within the City which reasonably appears to be in violation of this Section, or lost, stolen, or unclaimed. Such vehicle shall be impounded until lawfully claimed or disposed of in accordance with the City Code of Ordinances. 
2.  Notice. The City Manager shall first cause to be placed either on such vehicle, or on the property where the vehicle is located, a notice stating that such vehicle is in violation of this Section, and ten (10) days shall be allowed from the posting of such notice for the owners of the vehicle or premises to cause the same to be removed, which time shall be stated in the notice. In the case of vehicles in violation of this Section located on any public street or highway, such notice may require the vehicle to be removed within twelve (12) hours from the placing of the notice on such vehicle, and if it should be determined by the City Manager that the location of such vehicle on the public street or highway of the City constitutes a hazard, such vehicle may be, under such circumstances, immediately impounded to protect the public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of this community. 
3.  Disposition of junk vehicle. If any vehicle is not removed and caused to be in compliance with the terms of this Section within the time allowed and such vehicle be impounded, the vehicle may be impounded, the vehicle may be disposed of as junk if the vehicle is not reasonably repairable, and any sums received from the sale of such junk shall be deposited in the general fund of the City to assist in defraying expenses for the enforcement of this Section. 
4.  Disposition of repairable vehicle. If such vehicle so impounded may be reasonably repaired so that title thereto may be transferred by appropriate authority, the same may be done through the procedure authorized under the provisions of F.S. ch. 705, or under such other procedure as may be authorized by law. 
5.  Disbursement of funds. From the funds received from any such sale, there shall be deposited in the General Fund of the City to assist in defraying expenses of the enforcement of this Section all necessary expenses incurred in connection with the impounding and sale of such vehicle, and the balance thereof may be claimed by the rightful owner within thirty (30) days from the date of such sale. 
(Ord. No. 625, 3-8-1973; Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984)  
Sec. 16-109. - Disposition of abandoned and confiscated property. 
(A)  Authority. The Police Department of the City is hereby granted the authority to dispose of all abandoned, and confiscated personal property in the possession of such department for a period of more than ninety (90) days. Except that Subsection (C) herein shall govern the disposition of weapons and arms taken by the Police Department of the City pursuant to arrest. During the period of ninety (90) days the Police Department shall make reasonable effort to notify the owner of any of the personal property or automobiles that the same is being retained under the provisions of this Section, and shall throughout the period of ninety (90) days permit the owner to regain possession thereof upon proof of ownership and upon payment of storage charges and costs connected with the confiscation and storage of such personal property, and that upon failure of the owner to pay the same such personal property shall be sold pursuant to the terms of this Section. Such personal property shall first be advertised for sale by publication. Notice of such sale shall be placed in a conspicuous location in the City Hall, providing that the City must give notice to all owners at their last known address by registered or certified mail fifteen (15) days prior to the sale mentioned therein. All such property not purchased at such sale may be sold at private sale or be donated to an organized charity. All funds received from the sale of such abandoned or confiscated property shall be placed in the general fund of the City. The City shall have the power to execute a bill of sale for property sold to any purchaser, and the Motor Vehicle Commissioner of the State of Florida is hereby directed to take notice thereof, and upon proper application by the purchaser to issue to said purchaser a motor vehicle certificate of title. 
(B)  Abandoned property. For the purpose of this Section, the term "abandoned property" shall mean any wrecked or derelict property having no value other than nominal salvage value, if any, which has been left abandoned and unprotected from the elements and which include wrecked, inoperative, or partially dismantled motor vehicles, trailers, boats, machinery, refrigerators, washing machines, plumbing fixtures, furniture, and any other similar article which has no value other than nominal salvage value, if any, and which has been left abandoned and unprotected from the elements. Confiscated property shall not include property which is being held for uses evidence for judicial proceedings. 
(C)  Weapons, arms, electric weapons or devices. 
1.  Every Pinellas Park Police Officer making an arrest under F.S. § 790.07 or under any other State law or Municipal Ordinance of the City of Pinellas Park shall take possession of any weapons, electric weapons or devices or arms found upon the person arrested and deliver them to the Chief of Police, who shall retain the same until after the trial of the person arrested. 
2.  If a person arrested as aforesaid is convicted of violating F.S. § 790.07, or of any other offense involving the use or attempted use of such weapons, electric weapons, devices or arms, in violation of any State laws or Municipal Ordinances of the City of Pinellas Park, such weapons, electric weapons, devices or arms shall become forfeited to the City of Pinellas Park without any order of forfeiture being necessary, and such weapons, electric weapons or devices or arms, shall be forthwith delivered to the Chief of Police who is hereby made the custodian of such weapons, electric weapons or devices or arms. 
3.  If the person arrested is acquitted of the offenses for which he was arrested, or the charges against him are dismissed, the said weapons, electric weapons, devices or arms taken from him shall be returned to him unless he fails to call for or receive the same within sixty (60) days from and after his acquittal or dismissal of the charges against him in which case the same shall be forfeited to, and become the property of, the City of Pinellas Park, and no action or proceeding for their recovery shall thereafter be maintained. 
4.  All weapons now in or hereafter coming into the hands of any of the Police Officers of Pinellas Park which have been found abandoned or otherwise discarded or left in their hands and not reclaimed by the owners shall forthwith be delivered by such Police Officers to the Chief of Police, and if such weapons are not reclaimed by the owner within six (6) months from the date that the same come into the hands of the said Chief of Police, or six (6) months from the date that this Section shall become effective, whichever date is later, such weapons shall be forfeited to, and become the property of, the City of Pinellas Park and no action or proceeding for their recovery shall thereafter be maintained. All weapons which are useless or unfit for use shall be destroyed. 
(D)  Exemptions provision. 
1.  The provisions of this Section shall not apply to intangible personal property. All personal property of the City, the title to which has been acquired by gift, purchase or devise is specifically excluded from the operation of this Section. 
2.  The provisions of this Section shall not apply to any personal property lost or abandoned on the campus of any institution in the State University System as governed by F.S. § 705.18. 
3.  The disposition procedures authorized by this Section shall not apply to any property which is being held for use as evidence for judicial proceedings nor to any evidence or personal property in the custody of the Court of competent jurisdiction which is or may be disposed of in accordance with F.S. § 925.06. 
4.  Nothing contained herein shall be construed to limit the right of a finder of personal property as conferred by F.S. § 715.01(1). 
(Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984; Ord. No. 1707, 8-13-1987)  
Sec. 16-110. - Nudity—Regulation of commercial exploitation of. 
(A)  Intent of section. The City Council of the City of Pinellas Park, Pinellas County, Florida, does hereby find that there exists within the City of Pinellas Park an increasing trend toward nudity in commercial businesses serving food or drink to the public, and that such activities and such competitive commercial exploitation of nudity is adverse to the public health, peace, welfare, and safety, and that it is in the best interests of the public health, safety, convenience, and welfare to restrict such nudity, and the commercial promotion and exploitation thereof, as hereinafter set forth. 
(B)  Purpose. The purpose of this Section is to proscribe conduct and activities which encourage competitive commercial exploitation of nudity in commercial establishments serving food or drink to the public where such conduct and activity is not related to any live act, demonstration, exhibition, performance, or entertainment which may be protected by the United States and Florida constitutional provisions guaranteeing freedom of expression. 
(C)  Definitions. 
Business shall include every kind of commercial establishment, occupation, calling, or operation of institutions where food or drink are served to members of the public. 
Person shall mean any individual or entity, including without limitation, corporations, partnerships, and joint ventures. 
(D)  Conduct prohibited. 
1.  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning, leasing, or operating a business as defined herein to suffer, permit, require, or otherwise direct any person, while serving food or drink to any customer, or while seating or directing customers to seats in such business, to expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic hair region, or buttocks or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, where the areola and nipple are not covered by a fully opaque covering. 
2.  It shall be unlawful for any person while serving food or drink to any customer, or while seating or directing customers to seats within any business, to expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic hair region, or buttocks or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, where the areola and nipple are not covered by a fully opaque covering. 
3.  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning, leasing, or operating a business to suffer, permit, require, or otherwise direct any person, while said person is mingling, coming into contact with, or likely to come into contact with, or in close proximity to customers of said business within the areas where food or drink are prepared or served to expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, pubic hair region, or buttocks or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, where the areola and nipple are not covered by a fully opaque covering. 
4.  It shall be unlawful for any person while mingling, coming into contact with, or likely to come into contact with, or in close proximity to customers of said business within areas where food or drink are prepared or served to expose his or her genitals, pubic hair, public hair region, or buttocks or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola, where the areola and nipple are not covered by a fully opaque covering. 
(E)  Penalty. Any person convicted of a violation of this Section by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be punished by a fine not to exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment of a term not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(F)  Suspension and revocation of Business Tax Receipt. Upon conviction of any person of a violation of subsection (D) of this Section, the business tax receipt of the business where said violation took place shall be automatically suspended, provided that: 
1.  Within thirty (30) days of a conviction of any person of a violation of subsection (D) of this Section, the holder of such business tax receipt may file a written request with the City Clerk for a hearing before City Council. Within thirty (30) days after receipt of such written notice, the City Clerk shall set a hearing before City Council when the holder of such business tax receipt shall have an opportunity to appear and to show cause why said business tax receipt shall not be suspended for a definite time period or revoked. The City Clerk shall give at least seven (7) days' written notice to the holder of such business tax receipt of the date, place, and time of such hearing. Such notice shall be deemed to be complete upon mailing thereof. 
2.  Upon completion of said hearing, the City Council shall take one of the following actions: 
(a)  Reinstate the business tax receipt of said business. 
(b)  Reinstate the business tax receipt of said business, subject to conditions as shall be deemed reasonably necessary by the City Council to assure compliance with the provisions of this Section. 
(c)  Suspend the business tax receipt of said business for a period of time not to exceed one (1) year. 
(d)  Revoke the business tax receipt of said business. 
(G)  Severability. It is the intention of City Council that if any provision of this Section is declared invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, all other provisions shall remain in effect, valid, and enforceable. 
(Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984; Ord. No. 1658, 9-25-1986; Ord. No. 3538, § 4, 3-22-2007)  
Sec. 16-111. - Amusement centers—Hours of operation. 
(A)  For purposes of this Section, the term "amusement center" shall mean a place of business having at least three (3) amusement games or machines on the premises which are available for use by the public; provided, however, that business establishments properly licensed to dispense alcoholic beverage for consumption on the premises be excluded from this definition. 
(B)  Amusement centers may be open for business only between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday, and between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
(C)  Any person convicted of a violation of this Section by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be punished by imprisonment for a period of ten (10) days or a fine not to exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00), or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 1342, 1-26-1984; Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984)  
Sec. 16-112. - Live nude or semi-nude entertainment in establishments dealing in alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
(A)  Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases when used in this Section shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them: 
Establishments dealing in alcoholic beverages shall include every kind of commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are, or are available to be, sold, dispensed, consumed, or possessed, or are offered for sale or consumption on the premises, or are authorized or permitted to be consumed on the premises. This definition shall include any such commercial establishment not holding a valid alcoholic beverage license from the State of Florida but at which there is consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises by patrons or employees. 
Nude or semi-nude entertainment shall mean: 
1.  The actual or simulated displaying of the vulva, pubic area, buttocks, anus, or anal cleft or cleavage. 
2.  The actual or simulated displaying of a female breast at or below the top of the areola, where the areola and nipple are not covered by a fully opaque covering. 
Person shall mean any individual or entity, including without limitation, corporations, partnerships and joint ventures. 
(B)  Conduct prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in nude or semi-nude entertainment in any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages. It shall also be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning, leasing, or operating any establishment dealing in alcoholic beverages to suffer, permit, require, or otherwise direct any person to engage in nude or semi-nude entertainment thereat. 
(C)  Penalties. Any person convicted of a violation of this Section by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be punished by a fine not to exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment of a term not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(D)  Severability. It is the intention of City Council that if any provision of this Section is declared invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, all other provisions shall remain in effect, valid, and enforceable. 
(Ord. No. 1435, 9-13-1984; Ord. No. 1659, 9-25-1986)  
Sec. 16-113. - Alarm systems—False alarms. 
(A)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicated a different meaning: 
Alarm system means any mechanical or electrical or radio-controlled device which is designed to be used for the detection of any fire, medical emergency unauthorized entry into a building, structure, or facility, or which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when activated. Alarm systems include but are not limited to direct dial telephone devices, audible alarms and proprietor alarms. Excluded from the definition of alarm systems are devices which are designed or used to register alarms that are audible, visible or perceptible in or from any motor vehicle or auxiliary devices installed by telephone companies to protect telephone systems from damage or disruption of service. 
Automatic dialing device means an alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by direct connection, or otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect. 
Commercial premises means any structure or area which is not defined herein as residential premises. 
False alarm means the activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or the negligent or intentional misuse by the owner or lessee of an alarm system or by his employees, servants or agents; or by any other activation of the alarm system not caused by or because of a forced entry, robbery, attempted robbery, other forcible felony fire or medical emergency. Such terminology does not include alarms caused by acts of nature such as hurricanes, tornadoes, other severe weather conditions, or those alarms intentionally activated by an owner or lessee of an alarm system or by his servants, or agents who visually observed or heard suspicious circumstances which would cause a careful and prudent person to believe that a forcible entry, attempted forced entry, robbery, attempted robbery other forcible felony, fire or medical emergency was in progress at the premises protected by the alarm system. 
False alarm response shall result when any Police or Fire Fighter is dispatched to the activation of an alarm system which subsequently is found to be a false alarm. 
Fee means an assessment of costs imposed pursuant to this Section to defray the expense of responding to a false alarm. 
Fire Department official means the Chief of the Fire Department of Pinellas Park, or his designee. 
Law enforcement officer means the Chief of Police of the City of Pinellas Park, or his designee. 
Person means any natural person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
Residential premises means any structure or combination of structures which serve as dwelling units including single-family, duplex and multifamily units. 
(B)  False alarms. The following procedures apply to false alarms: 
1.  Responsibility for false alarms. For purposes of this Section, the responsibility for a false alarm may be borne by either the owner, lessee, or person or persons occupying and/or controlling the premises at the time of the false alarm. Determination of responsibility between owners and tenants should be defined in their rental agreements, however, in the absence of specific assignment of responsibility, the person or persons occupying and/or controlling the premises on which the alarm is located will be held liable. 
2.  Fee for false alarms. All premises, commercial, and residential, will be allowed one (1) false alarm within any one calendar month period without incurring any fee. A second, or subsequent responses to false alarms at the same premise within any one calendar month period will result in the assessment of Fifty Dollars ($50.00) fee for each additional false alarm. The owner/occupant will be notified in writing by the respective City of Pinellas Park Department that they have exceeded the allowed number of false alarms and that they have been assessed the Fifty Dollars ($50.00) fee for each false alarm. In addition, the owner/occupant will be required to respond to this notification within thirty (30) days from the date of receipt citing actions taken to investigate the cause of the repeated false alarms, and corrective measures instituted to prevent their recurrence. Failure to pay the assessed fee or to adequately respond to the notification within the prescribed time frame will result in an additional administrative fee of Twenty-Five Dollars ($25.00) for each notification or invoice. 
The allowing of a penalty assessed pursuant hereto to remain outstanding for a period of longer than thirty (30) days and not be paid, shall constitute a separate, ongoing violation of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, punishable as provided in the General Penalties section of the Code. 
(C)  Reporting to the premises after notification of a false alarm. When responding to an alarm, false or otherwise, at which there are no persons on the premises, the Law Enforcement/Fire Official will contact the owner/occupant to report to the premises for the purposes of resetting the alarm system. 
(D)  Automatic dialing devices. It shall be a violation of this Section for any person to install, maintain, own, possess or operate any automatic dialing device alarm system regulated or programmed to make connection with any telephone number installed in any law Enforcement/Fire Department facility. A fee of Fifty Dollars ($50.00) shall be assessed for each call completed via an automated dialing device. 
(E)  Hearing. Any person who shall be notified of the assessment of any fee prescribed by this Section may, within twenty (20) days in receipt of such notice, file a written appeal of such decision with the City Clerk. Within fifteen (15) days after the receipt of the written notice of appeal to the City Clerk, the City Manager shall set a hearing date, wherein such person(s) requesting the appeal may appear as well as any witnesses, and may submit evidence and show cause as to why such assessment should not be levied; provided, that the person requesting such appeal shall receive a minimum of five (5) days written notice of the hearing. Within three (3) business days after the hearing, the City Manager shall enter a written order affirming, denying, or modifying the decision of the Law Enforcement/Fire Official and such order shall be final. Copies of such order shall be provided to the person(s) making the appeal and to the Law Enforcement/Fire Official. 
(Ord. No. 1461, 1-10-1985; Ord. No. 2031, 6-14-1990; Ord. No. 2471, 3-12-1998; Ord. No. 2833, 2-22-2001; Ord. No. 3824, § 1, 9-27-2012)  
Sec. 16-114. - Parades. 
(A)  Request required. 
1.  No parade shall be allowed on any public right-or-way or upon any other public property until a request, in writing, shall first be approved by the City Manager. 
2.  A request to conduct a parade shall be made in writing, at least forty-five (45) days prior to the event, by the person or persons responsible therefor. Such request shall set forth the desired route along which such parade is to proceed, the desired time of starting, the duration, and the name of the person or organization in control thereof or responsible therefor and the general purpose of such parade. 
If a request for a parade is made by a nonprofit organization, the request shall have attached a copy of the Certificate of Incorporation issued by the Secretary of State, bearing their Charter number. 
(B)  Approval. Prior to submitting a required request for parade approval to City Manager, the person or organization responsible for the parade shall: 
1.  Confer with the Chief of Police, Fire Chief and Public Works Director and obtain their written recommendation to City Manager; 
2.  Obtain and submit to the City Manager a State of Florida Department of Transportation application for the temporary closing of a State Road signed by the Chief of Police; and 
3.  In and submit to the City Manager written approval from Pinellas County and all such other governmental agencies as may be required. 
If the City Manager shall determine that the proposed parade will not unduly interfere with the public use of public rights-of-way or any other public property, and will not unduly interfere with the peace and quiet of City residents, and will not create unreasonable pedestrian or vehicular safety hazards, and will not otherwise unduly endanger the public health and safety, the parade request shall be approved. Upon such approval, the City Manager shall be authorized to sign the State of Florida Department of Transportation application on behalf of the City. The person or organization responsible for the parade shall submit the application to the State of Florida Department of Transportation for approval. 
(C)  License fee. A license fee is required to conduct a parade, pursuant to Chapter 13 (Licenses) of the Code of Ordinances of the City, unless the parade is to be held by a nonprofit community organization or political group, in which case there will be no fee, but City Manager approval is still required as outlined above. 
(D)  Concession stands. Notwithstanding any other provisions of the City Code of Ordinances to the contrary, the person or organization responsible for the parade may request permission to operate one (1) or more concession stands in conjunction with the parade. If the parade request is granted, concession stands may be operated only during the approved hours and at the approved location. The proposed location of all such concession stands and the proposed hours of operation therefore shall be submitted to the City Manager or his designee no later than ten (10) days prior to the date of the parade. The person or organization responsible for the parade shall insure that operation of all concession stands complies with the conditions of approval. 
(E)  Certificate of insurance. The person or organization responsible for the parade shall, as a condition of parade approval, obtain a policy of insurance covering all parade activities in the minimum of Five Hundred Thousand Dollars ($500,000.00), single limit for bodily injury and property damage per occurrence. The City shall be listed as an additional name on the policy. An acceptable Certificate of Insurance containing a thirty-day notice of cancellation provision shall be submitted to the City Manager not later than ten (10) days prior to the date of parade. 
(F)  Revocation. City Manager may, after hearing, revoke a parade permit for noncompliance with the standards as herein set forth. 
(G)  Appeals to City Council. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the City Manager with regard to the issuance or denial of a parade approval, or by a decision of the City Manager with regard to the revocation or the nonrevocation of a parade approval, may appeal such decision to the City Council by filing a written notice of appeal with the City Clerk within five (5) working days after such decision is rendered. The appeal shall be heard by City Council at the first regular meeting which is held seven (7) days from the date of filing of the notice of appeal. Notice of the hearing shall be mailed to the person taking the appeal at least five (5) days prior to the hearing date. 
In deciding any appeal hereunder, City Council shall determine whether the City Manager's decision complies with the provisions of this Section. 
(H)  Severability. It is the intention of City Council that if any provision of this Section 16-114 is declared invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, all other provisions shall remain in effect, valid and enforceable. 
(I)  Penalty. Any person, firm or organization who shall violate any of the provisions of this Section 16-114 shall upon conviction be subject to a fine of not less that Ten Dollars ($10.00) nor more than Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 1475, 3-28-1985)  
Sec. 16-115. - Lodging in or about motor vehicles prohibited. 
(A)  It shall be unlawful for any person to lodge in, on, or about any parked motor vehicle, as the same is defined in F.S. § 320.01(1), in any public or private street, public or private park area, public or private way, right-of-way, public or private parking lot or other property within the limits of the City of Pinellas Park which is not a designated camping area. 
(B)  The term "lodge", as used in this Section, means to take up residence, or to dwell, or to establish a shelter or living quarters, however temporary. There shall be a presumption of lodging where an individual is found sleeping in a car when such individual does not have a permanent residence in the City of Pinellas Park. 
(C)  The provisions of this Section do not apply to such approved and properly designed camping areas, if any, which may have been provided for such use. Any person or persons desirous of using same shall abide by the provisions of Section 2-1032, Camping, of Article X, Parks and Recreation, of Chapter 2, Administration, of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
(D)  Severability. It is the intention of City Council that if any provision of this Section is declared invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, all other provisions shall remain in full force and effect, valid and enforceable. 
(E)  Penalty. Any person convicted of a violation of this Section by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be punished by a fine not to exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 1484, 4-11-1985; Ord. No. 1748, 12-22-1987)  
Sec. 16-116. - Operation of motor vehicles upon the undeveloped land of another without written permission prohibited. 
(A)  Definitions. For the purposes of this Section, the following terms, phrases, and words shall have the meanings herein given: 
Motor vehicle shall mean any vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails, but not including any bicycles or mopeds as defined by F.S. ch. 316. 
Undeveloped land means any land that has not been improved from its natural state by construction or installation of improvements thereon, including but not limited to grading, paving, drainage and structures, that increase the value of or alter the original condition of said land. 
(B)  Written permission required. No person shall operate any motor vehicle on the undeveloped land of another, or upon an undeveloped portion of the land of another, without first securing the written permission of the owner thereof in the form hereinafter specified. Any person operating a motor vehicle on the undeveloped land of another, or upon an undeveloped portion of the land of another, shall have such written permission in his or her possession at all times that he or she is operating a motor vehicle thereon. 
(C)  Form of written permission. The written permission required by this Section for the operation of a motor vehicle on the undeveloped land of another, or upon an undeveloped portion of the land of another, shall be in a form prescribed by the City Manager or his designee, and shall contain the following: 
1.  The name, address, and telephone number of the owner of the unimproved land upon which a motor vehicle may be operated; 
2.  The name, address, and telephone number of the person to whom permission has been given to operate a motor vehicle upon the unimproved land; 
3.  The legal description and street address or general location of the unimproved land upon which the motor vehicle may be operated; 
4.  The effective period (including the beginning date and ending date) of such permission; and 
5.  A sworn statement acknowledging under penalty of perjury that the person(s) signing the permission form is the owner of the therein described unimproved land and that the information therein is true and correct. 
Such form shall be attested and sealed by a Notary Public. 
(D)  Exemptions. The requirements of this Section shall not apply to the operation of construction or other similar equipment if a valid Building permit, Soil Removal permit, or Public Works permit has been issued, provided that such equipment is engaged in the work authorized by such permit. 
(Ord. No. 1540, 9-26-1985)  
Sec. 16-117. - Prepayment of gasoline purchases; penalties. 
(A)  Hours. All businesses within the corporate limits of the City, licensed to dispense gasoline, shall require that customers purchasing gasoline between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. pay for the gasoline prior to dispensing it. 
(B)  Penalty for violations. Any violation of this Section shall be punishable by a fine up to Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment up to sixty (60) days or both. 
(Ord. No. 2183, 1-14-1993)  
Sec. 16-118. - Skateboards and toy vehicles. 
(A)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this Section of the City Code. 
Skateboard means a device with wheels for riding upon, usually standing, not to exclude kneeling, including, without limitations skateboards or all types. 
Toy vehicles means, but is not limited to, coasters, scooters, roller skates, or any other nonmotorized device with wheels or rollers, upon which a person may ride. This Section does not apply, so long as they are used for the purposes for which they are intended, to wagons and strollers or other devices designed and used for the purpose of transporting children, infants, invalids, or incapacitated persons or to carts or other devices intended and used for transporting merchandise or materials. 
(B)  Skateboard on a street. No person shall operate a skateboard or toy vehicle on a public street if there is a sidewalk adjacent or parallel to such street. If no such sidewalk exists, skateboards and toy vehicles may be ridden on the street, providing it shall be done as far to the right side of the road as possible, and in the same direction as traffic. 
(C)  Clinging to a vehicle. No person operating a skateboard, toy vehicle, or other nonmotorized device, shall attach himself or herself to any motor vehicle upon a roadway. No person shall operate a motor vehicle with a person attached, using a skateboard, toy vehicle or other nonmotorized device. 
(D)  Yield right-of-way. Any person operating a skateboard or other toy vehicle must yield right-of-way to any pedestrian or motor vehicle. 
(E)  Skateboarding on private property. 
1.  No person shall operate a skateboard or toy vehicle on the premises of any business, residence, or other private property in violation of a sign complying with this Section. 
2.  Areas in which skateboarding or operation of a toy vehicle is prohibited must be indicated by one (1) or more signs which are positioned to provide notice and which contain the words "No skateboards, scooters, roller skates or other toy vehicles permitted" or any other words or phrases indicating that skateboarding or operation of a toy vehicle is prohibited. Letters on the sign must be clearly legible. 
(F)  Skateboarding on public property. 
1.  No person shall operate a skateboard or toy vehicle in, upon or on the grounds of City Hall, Technical Services Building, Library, Police Station, Public Works Building, Materials Management, or any fire station or on any other public building. 
2.  No person shall operate a skateboard or toy vehicle in violation of a sign erected by the City of Pinellas Park or other governmental entity prohibiting or regulating the use of skateboards and toy vehicles. 
(G)  Damaging city property. No person shall operate a skateboard or toy vehicle on or against any City-owned table, bench, structure, tennis court, parking stop, retaining wall, fountain, statue, or other improvement or structure which may suffer damage by such use. 
(H)  Skateboard ramps. No person shall use or place a ramp, jump, or any other device used to force a skateboard or toy vehicle off the pavement on the grounds of any City-owned parking lot, park, or sidewalk or street. 
(Ord. No. 2051, 10-9-1990)  
Sec. 16-119. - Loud and raucous noise. 
(A)  Prohibited generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully make, continue or cause to be made or continued any loud and raucous noise, which term shall mean any sound which, because of its volume level, duration and character, annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, health, peace or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities within the limits of the City. The term includes the kinds of noise generated by the activities enumerated in Section 16-119(B), except as provided in Section 16-119(D). The term shall be limited to loud and raucous noise heard upon the public streets, in any public park, in any school or public building or upon the grounds thereof while in use, in any church or hospital or upon the grounds thereof while in use, upon on any parking lot open to members of the public as invitees or licensees, or in any occupied residential unit which is not the source of the noise or upon the grounds thereof, and in any event from a location not less than fifty (50) feet from the source of the noise, measured in a straight line from the radio, loudspeaker, motor, horn, or other noise source. 
(B)  Noises specifically prohibited. The following noises as limited by Section 16-119(A) and subject to the exceptions provided in Section 16-119(D), are declared to be public nuisances in violation of Section 16-119, as follows: 
1.  Engines, whistles, etc. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine or any stationary internal combustible engine except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud and raucous noises therefrom. 
2.  Pile drivers, etc. The operation between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on any day or any time on Sunday, of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, dredge, steam or electric hoist or other appliance, the use of which is attended by loud and raucous noise. 
3.  Blowers, fans, etc. The operation of any blower or power fan or any internal engine, the operation of which causes loud and raucous noise, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled or such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to prevent loud and raucous noise. 
4.  Horns, signaling devices, etc. The sounding of any horn, whistle or other audible signaling device so as to create a loud and raucous noise. 
5.  Radios, amplifiers, phonographs, tape players, etc. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio, amplifier, musical instrument, phonograph, tape player or other device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to cause loud and raucous noise. 
6.  Sound trucks. No amplifier or loudspeaker in, upon or attached to a sound truck or other device for amplifying sound shall be operated or permitted to operate within the City for advertising purposes or to attract the attention of the public. 
7.  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, whistling or singing at any time or place so as to create a loud and raucous noise between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on any day. 
8.  Animals, birds, etc. The keeping of any animal or bird which habitually causes a loud and raucous noise. 
9.  Defect in vehicle or load. The use of any motor vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create loud grating, grinding, rattling or other loud and raucous noise, or which is not equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation so as to prevent loud and raucous noise. 
10.  Schools, public buildings, churches, hospitals. The creation of any loud and raucous noise heard within any school, public building, church or any hospital, or the grounds thereof, while in use, which interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or annoys the patrons of such institution. 
11.  Noises to attract attention. The use of any drum or other instrument or device to create a loud and raucous noise. 
12.  Construction or repair of buildings. The erection (including excavating), demolition, alteration or repair of any building so as to create a loud and raucous noise other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on any day, or at any time on Sunday, except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and safety, and then only with a permit from the Building Director, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed three (3) working days or less while the emergency continues and which permit may be renewed for successive periods of three (3) days or less while the emergency continues. If the Building Director should determine that the public health and safety necessitates the issuance of such a permit and will not be impaired by the erection, demolition, alteration or repair of any building or the excavation of streets and highways within the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or on Sunday, he may grant permission for such work to be done within such hours or within a shorter time period during such hours, upon application being made at the time the permit for the work is issued or during the progress of the work. 
(C)  Persons accountable. Any person, owner, agent or supervisor in charge of operating, ordering, directing or allowing the operation or maintenance of the device or machine creating a noise as prohibited in this Section, shall be deemed guilty of violating this Section. 
(D)  Exceptions. The term "loud and raucous noise" does not include noise or sound generated by the following: 
1.  Cries for emergency assistance and warning calls. 
2.  Radios, sirens, horns and bells on Police, Fire and other emergency response vehicles. 
3.  Parades, fireworks displays and other special events including cultural, historical and traditional observances, holidays and ceremonies, for which a permit has been obtained from the City, within such hours as may be imposed as a condition for the issuance of the permit. 
4.  Activities on or in municipal or school athletic facilities and on or in publicly-owned property and facilities, provided that such activities have been authorized by the owner of such property or facilities or his agent. 
5.  Fire alarms and burglar alarms, prior to the giving of notice and a reasonable opportunity for the owner or tenant in possession of the premises served by any such alarm to turn off or repair the alarm. 
6.  Religious worship activities, including but not limited to bells and organs. 
7.  Locomotives and other railroad equipment, and aircraft. 
8.  Noises resulting from equipment or operations incidental to the emergency repair of facilities or restoration of services such as public utilities or other emergency activities in the public interest. 
(E)  Penalty for violations. Any violation of this Section shall be punishable by a fine of up to Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment up to sixty (60) days or both. Each day that such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(F)  Enforcement. The penalty provided for in Subsection (E) hereof shall in no way be construed to limit the power of the City of Pinellas Park to proceed in any other civil or criminal proceeding or to proceed under any other provision of the City of Pinellas Park's Code of Ordinances. 
(G)  Severability. If any Section, Subsection, clause, sentence, phrase, or provision of this Section is held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, the invalidity thereof shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 2145, 4-9-1992)  
Sec. 16-120. - Graffiti. 
(A)  No person shall write, paint, or draw any inscription, figure, or mark of any type on any public or private building or other real or personal property, owned, operated, or maintained by a governmental entity or any agency or instrumentality thereof or by any person, firm, or corporation, unless the express permission of the owner or operator of the property has been obtained. 
(B)  For the purposes of this Section, the term "graffiti" shall mean an inscription or drawing on a wall or other surface visible from the public right-of-way or other parcel of land, whether the land be privately or publicly owned. 
(C)  Any person convicted of a violation of this Section shall be punished by a fine of not more than Two Hundred Fifty Dollars ($250.00) for a first offense, and of not more than Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) for a second or subsequent offense, or by imprisonment in the County Jail for a term not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment in the discretion of the court. Where a minor is found to have violated Subsection (A), the fine imposed by this Section shall be assessed against such minor's parents or legal guardian. 
(D)  Whenever the City becomes aware of the existence of graffiti on any property, including structures or improvements within the City, an Environmental Technician/Building Inspector or any other City employee who is authorized, upon such discovery, to give, or cause to be given, notice to remove or effectively obscure such graffiti to the property owner, the property owner's agent or manager, or other person in possession or control of the property. 
(E)  It shall be unlawful for any person or firm owning property, acting as manager or agent for the owner of property, or in possession or control of property to fail to remove or effectively obscure any graffiti from such property within thirty (30) days from receipt of the notice described in Subsection (D). If the person or firm owning such property, acting as manager or agent for the owner of such property, or in possession or control of such property, fails to remove or effectively obscure the graffiti within the time period enumerated above, the City shall cause the graffiti to be removed or effectively obscured and charge the property owner, or property owner's manager or agent, for the expenses incurred by the City. The City may sue in a court of competent jurisdiction to recover such expenses, together with attorney's fees and costs. 
(F)  Enforcement. The penalty provided for in Subsection (C) hereof shall in no way be construed to limit the power of the City of Pinellas Park to proceed in any other civil or criminal proceeding or to proceed under any other provision of the City of Pinellas Park's Code of Ordinances to obtain enforcement of the provisions of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 2149, 6-25-1992)  
Sec. 16-121. - Commercial animal-drawn carriages prohibited without a business tax receipt and applicable permit. 
(A)  Definitions. As used in this Section, the terms below shall be defined as follows: 
Animal-drawn carriage. Shall include any vehicle, carriage or other apparatus that is powered or propelled by an animal independent of or in conjunction with mechanized means. 
Operation. Shall include operation by the owner or by any agent of the owner or by any person with the owner's knowledge, consent or permission, expressed or implied. 
Permit. Shall mean the grant by the City to operate one (1) or more commercial animal-drawn carriages or vehicles upon the arterial streets of the City of Pinellas Park. 
Person. Shall include any individual, corporation, partnership, association, club, or any other legal entity. 
Public place. Shall mean any public grounds, street, road right-of-way, alley, sidewalk, park or any other open property within the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, to which the general public is licensed or invited to enter, which such open property specifically includes parking lots and parking areas of commercial establishments. 
(B)  Unlawful to operate a commercial animal-drawn carriage in public places. It shall be unlawful except as otherwise permitted in this Section for any person to commercially operate in any public place within the City any animal-drawn carriage. 
(C)  Permitted conduct. Notwithstanding Section 16-121 (B), a person may operate or cause to be operated one or more commercial animal-drawn carriages, on holidays, birthdays, celebrations and other special occasions upon obtaining a business tax receipt and complying with all requirements imposed herein. A copy of the business tax receipt shall be posted on the carriage. Additionally, a permit is required to operate on any arterial street. Arterial streets are designated in the City's Traffic Circulation Element of the City's Comprehensive Plan and currently are: Belcher Road, 49th Street, U. S. Highway 19, Park Boulevard, County Road 296, 66th Street and Gandy Boulevard. A permit application fee of Twenty-Five Dollars ($25.00) shall be submitted with the application. 
1.  Application for permit to operate on an arterial road. Any person desiring to obtain a permit to operate a commercial animal-drawn carriage or vehicle, on an arterial street within the City of Pinellas Park, shall submit to the City Manager or his designee a written application on a form approved by the City, which form shall contain at least the following information: 
(a)  The name, address, telephone number, age, form of business and trade name, if any, of the applicant; 
(b)  The dates of operation and the hours of operation for each day that the animal-drawn carriage or vehicle is to be operated; 
(c)  A thorough description, including a map, of the proposed route(s) to be served or utilized. The City Manager or his designee may change or modify any proposed route and/or hours of operation if the operation of the animal-drawn carriage or vehicle will unreasonably negatively affect the safety or efficient flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic; 
(d)  A photograph of each operator who will be operating the animal-drawn carriages or vehicles and a copy of each operator's current, valid driver's license; 
(e)  An insurance certificate establishing that the applicant has met the insurance requirements of this Section; and 
(f)  Any such additional information that the City Manager or his designee may reasonably require in order to determine whether an application for a permit should be granted. 
2.  Approval/denial of permit; permit conditions; appeal. The City Manager or his designee shall approve or deny an application for a permit within five (5) business days of the submission of a completed application. If the application contains all the information required by this Section, and the applicant meets all requirements herein stated, then the application shall be approved. The City Manager or his designee may issue a permit for up to three (3) days, subject to renewal for up to three (3) additional days.
