A permit may be issued with reasonable conditions intended to insure compliance with the requirements of this Section, a violation of which shall result in cancellation of the permit after a hearing determining such violation before the City Manager or his designee. If the application for permit is denied, the City Manager or his designee shall provide the applicant with the reason(s) for disapproval in writing, in which event no permit will be issued. Any applicant whose application for a permit has been denied or whose application has been granted with conditions may, within thirty (30) days, appeal in writing to the City Council, which shall hear the appeal within thirty (30) days after receipt of the request for appeal. An applicant may seek review by certiorari of a decision of the City Council before a Court of competent jurisdiction within thirty (30) days of the rendering of the Council's decision. 
3.  Required adherence to plan submitted in permit application. Permitees shall adhere to the routes, days, hours of operation, and vehicle number as specified and approved in their application for permit to operate on an arterial street. Any deviation from said application without the prior approval of the City Manager or his designee shall constitute a violation of this Section. 
4.  Required posting of permit. During all times of operation of the animal-drawn carriage or vehicle, the permit shall be attached to and displayed on the carriage/vehicle, along with a photo of the operator, and a copy of the operator's driver's license. 
(D)  Insurance requirements. Each commercial carriage or vehicle shall maintain a Commercial General Liability policy on an occurrence basis with coverage limits of at least Five Hundred Thousand Dollars ($500,000.00) for each occurrence, general aggregate and products completed/operations aggregate. A certificate of insurance outlining insurance coverages must be on file with the City prior to the issuance of a business tax receipt. The certificate must name the City as an additional insured as respects the activity. 
(E)  Safety requirements. All commercial animal-drawn carriages and vehicles shall comply with the following requirements: 
1.  Commercial carriages and vehicles must be operated in accordance with all provisions of State law regulating vehicles and their operation. 
2.  The number of passengers shall not exceed the vehicle's seating capacity. No passengers (except infants) shall be seated on the laps of other passengers and/or on parts of the carriage or vehicle not designated as use for passenger seating. Sideboards are required when there is no seating. Hands and feet are to be kept inside the vehicles. 
3.  Safety equipment shall be required in accordance with applicable State Statute; such equipment shall be properly affixed to the vehicle. 
4.  Each commercial carriage shall be equipped with electric turn signals (or emergency flashing lights), tail lights and front lights which are visible for at least a distance of five hundred (500) feet if the commercial carriage is in operation during the night. 
5.  Each commercial carriage shall be equipped with a slow moving vehicle sign located at the rear. 
6.  Each person shall use reflective material where appropriate on carriages, harnesses and animal forelimbs. 
7.  The animal shall be properly shod with either horse shoes on all four (4) feet or easy boots on all four (4) feet. 
(F)  Traffic regulation requirements. All operators of commercial animal-drawn carriages or vehicles shall operate said vehicles in accordance with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations of the State of Florida, including traffic laws, as well as all applicable traffic-related ordinances enacted or adopted by the City. 
(G)  Sanitation requirements. All operators of commercial animal-drawn carriages or vehicles shall comply with the following sanitation requirements: 
1.  Carriages must be equipped with a device to prevent manure from falling on the pavement. 
2.  Any manure that falls upon the right-of-way or private property, shall be removed, by the person operating the carriage, within one (1) hour. 
(H)  Required qualifications of operators. All operators of commercial animal-drawn carriages or vehicles must be eighteen (18) years of age or older. All operators must have a current, valid driver's license. 
(I)  Prohibited conduct. No operator of a commercial animal-drawn carriage or vehicle shall: 
1.  Leave any commercial animal-drawn carriage or vehicle unattended. 
2.  Store, park or leave any commercial animal-drawn carriage or vehicle overnight on any street or sidewalk or park any such vehicle other than in a regularly marked space in conformance with City, County and State parking regulations. 
3.  Operate in an area or at any time other than that approved by the City. 
4.  Have his or her vehicle in motion while anyone is standing or while anyone is sitting anywhere other than on designated passenger seats. 
5.  Operate any vehicle in such a manner that would unreasonably jeopardize the safety of the passengers transported therein or of pedestrians. 
6.  Park the vehicle in a manner so as to unreasonably disrupt the flow of automobile traffic on public streets, roads and thoroughfares or so as to unreasonably impede the flow of pedestrian traffic. 
7.  Operate a vehicle in disregard of any traffic control device, or in violation of any applicable traffic law. 
8.  Operate a vehicle upon any public sidewalk. 
9.  Operate a vehicle in the wrong direction on a one-way street. 
10.  Operate any vehicle in violation of the provisions of this Section. 
(J)  Proper care and health of the animal. 
1.  The driver of each commercial animal-drawn carriage shall make water and feed available to every animal being used to pull a carriage or vehicle at intervals not to exceed two (2) hours. 
2.  When the temperature is ninety (90) degrees Fahrenheit or greater, no animal shall be allowed to work for more than two (2) hours without a two-hour rest. The animal shall be provided shade where the temperature is less than the temperature in the sun. 
3.  An animal used to draw a carriage or vehicle must be examined at least every six (6) months by a veterinarian qualified to attest to the animal's health. An animal may not be used to draw a carriage or vehicle unless the veterinarian issues a written certificate verifying that the animal is in good health and able to draw a carriage or vehicle. The written certificate must, at a minimum, verify that the animal has: 
(a)  Good flesh and muscle tone; 
(b)  No lameness; 
(c)  No harness sore, wound or other ailment which would adversely affect the animal's ability to perform its work, or that despite such harness sore, wound or other ailment, the animal is nevertheless fit to draw a carriage or vehicle. Any limitations upon the animal's ability to draw a carriage or vehicle due to such harness sore, wound or other ailment shall be noted in the certificate; 
(d)  Received current and properly administered vaccinations for: Equine Rhinopneumonitis, Encephalomyelitis, Eastern and Western Influenza, Tetanus Toxoid and Leptospirosis; 
(e)  No infectious diseases; and 
(f)  Received and passed an annual Coggins test. 
(K)  Penalties. Any person who violates any provisions of this Section shall, upon conviction in a court of competent jurisdiction, be punished by a fine not to exceed Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed sixty (60) days, or by both fine and imprisonment. 
(L)  Severability. If any provision of this Section or the application thereof is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the other provisions or applications of this Section which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or applications, and to this end the provisions of this Section are hereby declared severable. 
(Ord. No. 2197, 3-25-1993; Ord. No. 3538, § 4, 3-22-2007)  
Sec. 16-122. - Major motor vehicle repair and spray painting of motor vehicles prohibited in residential or mixed use zoning districts. 
(A)  Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this Section of the City Code. 
Immediate family. The husband, wife and children related by law, blood, adoption or marriage. 
Major motor vehicle repair. The repair or reconditioning of motor vehicles including: body repair, removal of the head, crankcase, or entire engine, steam cleaning, transmission rebuilding and repair, welding, or other characteristics to an extent greater than normally found in an automotive repair facility (minor). See Section 18-1502.2 (Zoning Code Definition) for definition of "Automotive Repair Facility (Minor)". Note: Removal of an outboard motor from a boat is not considered Major Motor Vehicle Repair. 
Motor vehicle. Any self-propelled vehicle not operated upon rails or guideways (but not including any bicycle or moped) and all boats and all trailers. 
Spray painting. The application of flammable or combustible materials when applied as a spray by compressed air, "airless" or "hydraulic atomization", or by steam, or electrostatic methods or by any other means in continuous or intermittent processes. It also covers the application of combustible powders when applied by powder spray guns, electrostatic powder spray guns, fluidized beds, or electrostatic fluidized beds. 
(B)  Unlawful to perform major motor vehicle repair or spray painting of a motor vehicle in any Residential or Mixed Use Zoning District. It shall be unlawful, except as otherwise permitted below, for any person to perform major motor vehicle repair or spray painting of a motor vehicle in any Residential or Mixed Use Zoning District. 
(C)  Permitted conduct. Notwithstanding Subsection (B) above, a person may perform the following if done repairs in an enclosed building: Body work; rebuilding or reconditioning, including the removal of the head, crankcase or entire engine, steam cleaning, transmission repair and rebuilding, welding or other characteristics to an extent greater than normally found in an "Automotive Repair Facility (Minor)" as defined in Section 18-1502.2. 
1.  The motor vehicle being repaired within a Residential or Mixed Use Zoning District must be owned by the owner or tenant of the property on which it is being repaired, or must be owned by a member of the owner's or tenant's immediate family. 
2.  Upon request by an Environmental Technician, Fire Inspector or Police Officer, any person performing motor vehicle repair in a Residential or Mixed Use Zoning District shall demonstrate that he/she resides on the property on which the repair is being made and that the motor vehicle is owned by him/her or by an immediate member of his/her family or the owner or occupant. Should the person be unable or unwilling for any reason to demonstrate residency or ownership of the motor vehicle being repaired upon request, the person shall be in violation of this Chapter and shall be subject to the penalties as defined by the City Special Master Code Enforcement Board or County Court. 
3.  Minor motor vehicle repairs are permitted in a Residential or Mixed Use Zoning District without the restriction to of being in an enclosed building. 
(Ord. No. 2209, 8-26-1993)  
Sec. 16-123. - Convenience stores. 
(A)  Definitions. 
Convenience store. A retail business establishment that: 
(1)  Is primarily engaged in the retail sale of groceries, or both groceries and gasoline; and 
(2)  Is open for business at any time between the hours of 5:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. 
Convenience store does not include: a business that is solely or primarily a restaurant; a business that always has at least five (5) employees on the premises; or a business that has at least ten thousand (10,000) square feet of retail floor space. 
Employee. Any natural person who is responsible for the on-site day-to-day operation of a convenience store or who is otherwise carrying out employment duties at a convenience store, whether on a full-time or part-time basis. 
Owner. Any person, firm, corporation, partnership, joint venture or other group enterprise having lawful possession of the premises upon which the convenience store is operating. 
Sales transaction area. Any area in which an employee is actively engaged in the retail sale of groceries or gasoline in exchange for cash or any other monetary payment. 
(B)  Visibility of sales transaction area. All convenience stores shall locate the sales transaction area such that the cashier and customer are fully visible from the street at the time of the sales transaction. Any window tinting must allow for a clear unobstructed view of the cash register and sales transaction area from inside or outside of the convenience store and in a normal line of sight. The degree of window tinting shall allow for physical identification of all individuals in the sales transaction area from outside the store and in a normal line of sight at all times. 
(C)  Location of signs. All signs posted in the windows of all convenience stores shall be located so as to provide a clear and unobstructed view of the cash registers and sales transaction areas from the street. 
(D)  Limitation on available cash. All convenience stores shall have a written cash management policy that limits cash on-hand to Fifty Dollars ($50.00) at all times. Said cash management policy shall provide for guidelines for making deposits on a regular basis, but at variable intervals to minimize offender activity resulting from scheduled deposits or scheduled deposit pick ups. A copy of the cash management policy shall be kept on the premises. 
(E)  Required safe. All convenience stores shall install and maintain a drop safe that is bolted to the floor, or installed in the floor or counter, or which weighs at least five hundred (500) pounds, and prevents an employee from accessing surplus cash. All drop safes installed prior to the effective date of this Section shall be installed and maintained as specified by the manufacturer. All drop safes installed subsequent to the effective date of this Section shall meet one (1) of the following requirements: 
1.  The deposit safe classification as described in the 1991 edition of Underwriters Laboratory Standard UL 687 for Burglary Resistant Safes, which edition is incorporated herein by reference; or 
2.  A deposit safe which offers protection against forced entry, while providing a means for depositing currency, checks, coins and the like, contained in bags or envelopes, or directly deposited into the body of the safe. 
(F)  Required signs. 
1.  Safe. All convenience stores shall post a conspicuous sign at the entrance of the store which states that there is a safe on the premises and that it is not accessible to the employees. 
2.  Limited cash. All convenience stores shall post a conspicuous sign at the entrance of the store which states that the cash register contains Fifty Dollars ($50.00) or less. 
(G)  Required lighting. The entire area of all convenience stores which is utilized by customers for parking shall be illuminated at an intensity of at least three (3) foot-candles per square foot at eighteen (18) inches above the surface of the parking area. 
(H)  Required security camera. All convenience stores shall install a security camera capable of recording and retrieving a recognizable and identifiable image of an offender to assist individuals involved in an investigation, in a format that can be enlarged and reproduced for distribution by law enforcement agencies. If one (1) camera is not sufficient, additional cameras shall be installed to capture the image of an offender at all register locations in use. The camera system shall be: 
1.  Positioned to provide photographic coverage of all registers in use and to minimize tampering by customers or offenders; 
2.  Maintained on a routine basis to ensure that the camera system is working properly at all times; 
3.  Capable of continuous operation or activation by a remote triggering device such as a concealed button or bill trap alarm; and 
4.  Verification that the camera system is in proper working order in accordance with the standards listed above shall be maintained on the premises in the form of test photographs produced when the system is installed and at all maintenance intervals. The camera system shall be maintained at intervals no less than once every four (4) months, documented on a maintenance log kept on the premises. 
(I)  Required alarm system. All convenience stores shall install a silent alarm system which activates a signal to a law enforcement or a private security agency. Silent alarms shall have a primary and secondary power source. Silent alarms must be installed by a contractor licensed by the Florida Electrical Contractors' Licensing Board pursuant to the provisions of F.S. ch. 489. Silent alarms shall be maintained regularly in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications and in proper working order at all times. 
(K)  Required height strip. All convenience stores shall be equipped with a conspicuous height strip with digits at least one (1) inch in size located at the inside entrance of the convenience store. 
(L)  Location of outside telephones. All outside telephones shall be located in such a manner that the cash registers inside the convenience store are not visible to any person using the outside telephones. 
(M)  Required training course. All persons who work at a convenience store shall complete a robbery-deterrence training course. The training course, shall at a minimum meet the requirements of "Robbery-Deterrence and Safety Training Guidelines", Form CBS-1, effective April 20, 1993, promulgated by the Bureau of Criminal Justice Programs, Division of Victim Services and Criminal Justice Programs, the Office of the Attorney General, the Capital, Tallahassee, Florida 32399-1050, or its equivalent. The Pinellas Park Police Department shall provide copies of said guidelines to convenience stores upon request. The training course shall be at least one (1) hour in length. 
All current employees of convenience stores shall receive the required robbery-deterrence training within ninety (90) days after this Section becomes effective. New employees shall receive the required robbery-deterrence training within thirty (30) days of commencing employment at a convenience store. Documentation that all employees have received the required training shall be maintained at the convenience store, which documentation shall include: 
1.  The name of the employee; 
2.  The date of the employee's first day of employment; 
3.  The date of the employee's latest training; and 
4.  Identification of the training curriculum received. 
(N)  Time for compliance. All owners of convenience stores shall have one hundred twenty (120) days from the passage of this Section in which to comply with all of the requirements herein. 
(O)  Procedure for waiver of compliance. 
1.  Application for waiver. In the event that the owner of a convenience store has installed and has operating on the premises precautionary measures or devices other than one (1) or more of those specified in this Section which said owner believes provides sufficient protection against loss of life and property and otherwise adequately serves the public interest in the prevention of violent crimes and physical threats, the owner may make written application to the City Manager for a waiver of one (1) or more of the requirements set forth in this Section. 
2.  Opportunity to be heard. Within thirty (30) days of filing an application for waiver, the owner shall request in writing to the City Clerk an opportunity to be heard on the application, otherwise the owner waives the right to be heard and the application shall not be considered. If a request is timely made, the owner shall be afforded the opportunity to be heard on said application before the City Manager or his designee. 
3.  Factors to consider. The City Manager or his designee shall grant or deny the owner's application based on the following factors: 
(a)  The location of the convenience store; 
(b)  The hours of operation of the convenience store; 
(c)  The average number of customers that utilize the convenience store on a daily basis; 
(d)  The merchandise sold at the convenience store; 
(e)  Past incidents of robberies, attempted robberies, physical threats, or acts of violence or a lack thereof at the convenience store; 
(f)  The extent to which the precautionary measures or devices in place at the convenience store adequately protect the public interest against loss of life and property. 
4.  Conditions to waiver. In granting any such waiver, the City Manager or his designee shall find that such waiver will not be contrary to the public interest and may describe appropriate conditions and safeguards. Any violations of such conditions and safeguards shall be deemed a violation of this Section. 
(P)  Penalty for violations. Each violation of this Section shall be punishable by a fine of up to Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment up to sixty (60) days, or both. 
(Q)  Enforcement. The penalty provided for in Subsection (P) hereof shall in no way be construed to limit the power of the City of Pinellas Park to proceed in any other civil or criminal proceeding or to proceed under any other provision of the City of Pinellas Park's Code of Ordinances to obtain enforcement of the provisions of this Section. 
(R)  Severability. If any section, subsection, clause, sentence, phrase, or provision of this Section is held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, the invalidity thereof shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 2278, 9-22-1994)  
Sec. 16-124. - Juvenile curfew. 
Repealed. 
(Ord. No. 3158, 8-11-2005)  
Sec. 16-125. - Illicit synthetic drugs. 
(A)  The foregoing WHEREAS clauses, as set forth and contained in Pinellas Park Ordinance No. 3841 are hereby adopted as legislative findings of the City Council and are ratified and confirmed as being true and correct, and are hereby made a part of this ordinance. 
(B)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to regulate the availability of products which are enhanced with synthetic chemicals, which chemicals mimic the effects of controlled substances on users, because these products are a danger to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(C)  Definitions. For purposes of the following sections, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
Bath Salts, synthetic cathinones, synthetic stimulants means any crystalline or powder product in crystalline, loose-powder, block, tablet, or capsule form, or any stimulant-type product, when the label is in any way false or misleading, or which does not contain a label specifying (1) the identity of the commodity, and (2) the name and place of business of the manufacturer, packer, or distributor. Street names for these products include, but are not limited to: Bliss, Blue Silk, Cloud Nine, Drone, Energy-1, Ivory Wave, Lunar Wave, Meow Meow, Ocean Burst, Pure Ivory, Purple Wave, Red Dove, Snow Leopard, Stardust, Vanilla Sky, White Dove, White Knight, White Lightening, Blizzard, Bonzai Grow, Charge Plus, Charlie, Euphoria, Hurricane, Lunar Wave, Ocean, Pixie Dust, Posh, Scarface, Lovely Dovey, Aura, MDPV, MDPK, MTV, Maddie, Hurricane Charlie, Black Rob, Super Coke, PV, Peeve, Meph, Drone, MCAT. This definition shall include any product to which any Synthetic Chemical or Synthetic Chemical Compound has been added which has no legitimate relation to the advertised use of the product whether or not the label meets the requirements herein. 
Drug means an article that is intended to affect the function of the body of humans. 
Illicit synthetic drugs means spice, synthetic cannabinoids, synthetic marijuana, bath salts, synthetic cathinones, synthetic stimulants, and misbranded drugs as defined herein. 
Misbranded drug means a drug or product that violates F.S. § 499.007, including but not limited to drugs for which (1) the label is in any way false or misleading; (2) the label does not bear the name and place of business of the manufacturer, repackager, or distributor of the finished form of the drug; (3) the label does not bear adequate directions for use; or (4) the label does not bear adequate warnings against use. 
Spice, synthetic cannabinoids, synthetic marijuana means any aromatic plant material in granular, loose leaf or powder form, or in liquid or as a food additive, or any herbal-incense-type stimulant or hallucinogen product, when the label is in any way false or misleading, or which does not contain a label specifying (1) the identity of the commodity and (2) the name and place of business of the manufacturer, packer, or distributor. Street names for these products include, but are not limited to: Bliss, Black Mamba, Bombay Blue, Fake Weed, Genie, Spice, Zohai, K2, K3, Smoke, Pot-Pourri, Buzz, Spice 99, Voodoo, Pulse, Hush, Mystery, Earthquake, Stinger, Ocean Blue, Serenity, Chronic Spice, Spice Gold, Spice Silver, Skunk, Mr. Nice Guy, Mr. Happy, K3 Legal, Sence, Smoke, Chill X, Earth Impact, Galaxy Gold, Space Truckin, Solar Flare, Moon Rocks, Aroma, Scope, Sky High, Atomic, G-20, Guerrilla Warfare, Makes Scents, g-13, Tiger Shark, California Dreams, Dank, Bullet, Mind Trip, Voodoo Child, Jazz, Nightlights, Matrix, Hypnotiq, AK47, Maui Wowie, Cloud 9, Daylights, Joker, Dead Man Walking, Brain Storm, Soul Sence, Kush, Kush Mania, Dragons Fire, Lucid, Mad Hatter, Scooby Snax, D-ZL, OMG, Demon, Barely In, Pineapple Express, Hayze. 
This definition shall include any plant material to which any Synthetic Chemical or Synthetic Chemical Compound has been added which has no legitimate relation to the advertised use of the product whether or not the label meets the requirements herein. 
Synthetic Chemical or Synthetic Chemical Compound means any chemical or chemical compound whose molecular make up is similar to those substances listed as controlled substances in F.S. Ch. 893, (including any isomers, esters, ethers, salts, and salts of isomers, esters, and ethers of such substances) and whose intended use when introduced into the human body is to mimic or simulate the effects of a controlled substance. 
(D)  Prohibition of Illicit Synthetic Drugs. 
1.  It is unlawful for any person (to include not only an individual but any person in charge of or in control of any business entity and also to include the business entity itself), to possess, use, provide, sell, produce, manufacture, or distribute, market, or advertise for sale, any illicit synthetic drug or any product or item packaged, which violates the terms of this ordinance. 
2.  In determining whether a product is prohibited by this division, statements on package labeling such as "not for human consumption" may be disregarded when other relevant factors (viewed alone or in totality) indicate that the product is intended to be consumed or ingested by humans, or is a product regulated by this division. Other relevant factors that may be used to determine whether a product or sale is prohibited by this division include, but are not limited to: verbal or written representations at the point of sale regarding the purpose, methods, use, or effect of the product; aspects of the packaging or labeling suggesting that the user will achieve a "high," euphoria, relaxation, mood enhancement, or that the product has other effects on the body; the cost of the product is disproportionately higher than other products marketed for the same use; the product contains a warning label stating or suggesting that the product is in compliance with state laws regulating controlled substances; the product's name or packaging uses images or slang referencing an illicit street drug; illicit or underground methods of sale or delivery are employed by the seller or provider; the product resembles an illicit street drug such as cocaine, methamphetamine, or marijuana. 
3.  Defense. It shall be a defense to the prosecution of a violation of this division that a product: is specifically excepted by, or regulated within, the Florida Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act (F.S. Ch. 893) or the Federal Controlled Substances Act (21 USC §§ 81 et seq.); is a food product, drug, dietary supplement, cosmetic, or other substance regulated by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and in compliance with that agency's requirements; is regulated by and in compliance with the labeling requirements of the Federal Trade Commission; is regulated by and in compliance with the Federal Fair Packaging and Labeling Act; is regulated by and in compliance with the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act; is regulated by and in compliance with the regulations of the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services; or is a tobacco product regulated by and in compliance with the regulations governing the tobacco industry enforced by the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation, Division of Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco. For the purposes of this section, it shall not be a defense that a product is not subject to regulation by the act or agencies listed above unless the product is specifically exempt from regulation; mere "non-regulation" by these acts without a specific regulatory exemption does not render a product exempt under this section. 
(E)  Sale of Certain Products for Human Consumption Prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to provide or sell a product for human consumption when the product is labeled "not for human consumption" or contains similar warnings. 
(F)  Violation and Seizure. 
1.  Each package possessed, used, provided, sold, produced, manufactured, distributed, offered, displayed, marketed or advertised for sale, shall be considered a separate violation. The fine for each violation shall be Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00). In addition, the City shall be entitled to all of its Court costs, costs of prosecution and attorney's fees in the prosecution or enforcement of this ordinance. 
2.  Any products found in violation of this section may be seized and held as evidence to be used in any future proceeding and may be disposed of as appropriate after their use for evidentiary purposes is no longer required. 
(Ord. No. 3841, § 1, 5-9-2013)

CHAPTER 17 - PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 17-101. - Federal old age benefits extended. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, to extend, effective as of January 1, 1951, to the Employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the System of Old Age and Survivor's Insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 734 of 81st Congress, and by F.S. ch. 650; and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in F.S. § 650.02, performed in the employ of the City by Employees thereof. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, the City shall take such action as may be required by applicable State or Federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 55, 2-14-1952)  
Sec. 17-102. - Agreements with State. 
The Mayor, or other chief executive officer, of the City is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the chairman of the Florida Industrial Commission as the state agency for the State of Florida, or his authorized representative, for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by such System of old age and survivor's insurance to the Employees and officials of this City, which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the City as are found by the state agency to be necessary for the proper and efficient administration thereof, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed after the first day of January, A. D. 1951. 
(Ord. No. 55, 2-14-1952)  
Sec. 17-103. - Salary withholdings. 
Withholdings from salaries, wages, or other compensation of Employees and officials for the purpose provided in Section 17-101 are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable State or Federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Ord. No. 55, 2-14-1952)  
Sec. 17-104. - City contributions. 
There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from ad valorem and cigarette taxes as budgeted for insurance supplemented by contingency funds, such amounts, at such times, as may be required to pay promptly the contributions required of the City as employer by applicable State or Federal laws or regulations which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated State agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Ord. No. 55, 2-14-1952)  
Sec. 17-105. - Records, reports and regulations. 
The City shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable State or Federal laws or regulations, and shall adhere to the rules and regulations of the State agency for the enforcement or such laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 55, 2-14-1952)  
Sec. 17-106. - Adoption of Federal Act. 
The City of Pinellas Park, Florida, does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of Title II of the Social Security Act as amended by Public Law No. 734, 81st Congress, for and on behalf of all the officers and Employees thereof and of its departments and agencies, save and except any such officers and Employees now covered or authorized to be covered by any Retirement System provided by law, and further excepting any official or Employee who occupies any position, office, or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable State or Federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 55, 2-14-1952)  
ARTICLE II. - PINELLAS PARK GENERAL EMPLOYEES' PENSION FUND 
 
Sec. 17-201. - Short title. 
This Article shall be known and cited as the "Pinellas Park General Employees' Pension Fund. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 2631, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005)  
Sec. 17-202. - Consolidation of existing system and preservation of rights. 
(A)  Any officer or Employee who is elected, appointed or employed by the City of Pinellas Park, Florida after the effective date of this System (November 13, 1971) shall not be eligible for membership, rights or any privileges under Ordinance No. 279. 
(B)  The rights of Members of the Employees Pension plan of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, established by Ordinance No. 279, shall not be impaired nor shall their benefits be reduced by virtue of any part of this Article. Upon passage of this Article they shall be subject to the provisions of the "Pinellas Park Retirement System" established by this Article and at Retirement shall have his benefits calculated in accordance with the provisions of Section 17-209 of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 2631, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-203. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases as used in this Article, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, shall have the meanings hereafter set forth, and the same and similar terms when used in connection with any personnel classification System or any other Ordinance for the City of Pinellas Park shall not necessarily apply to the Members of the Retirement System hereby created except when specifically adopted: 
Accumulated contributions: Means the sum of a Member's contribution, if any, without interest received after the effective date of employment. 
Actuary: Means a fellow of the Society of Actuaries or a member of the American Academy of Actuaries or an organization of which one (1) or more members is a fellow of the Society of Actuaries or a member of the American Academy of Actuaries or both. 
Actuarial equivalent: A benefit of equal value or equal cost when computed on the basis of such interest rates, mortality and other actuarial tables as are in effect under the System. 
Annual compensation: 
(a)  Means the total compensation paid a Member during a year, exclusive of bonuses; a "year" is the calendar year. 
(b)  For all Creditable Service earned on or after October 30, 2013, the definition of annual Compensation for all members who are not then already eligible for Normal Retirement as of that date, is defined to include the following pay: pay for hours worked while rendering services to the city; sick, vacation, and personal hours used; holiday pay; lump sum payout for employees at the top of their pay grade; and incentive payments. the definition of annual Compensation shall exclude the following: pay for overtime hours which are in excess of three hundred (300) hours per calendar year, bonuses, and payouts for any accrued but unused sick or vacation hours regardless of when they were accrued, and all other compensation not specifically included. However, payouts for Pre-87 sick hours shall be included as Annual Compensation. 
(c)  Members who become eligible for Normal Retirement prior to October 30, 2013 shall have their Annual Compensation determined pursuant to subsection (a). 
Annuity: Annual payments which shall be payable in equal monthly installments on the first day of each during his or her lifetime or as otherwise provided for in this Article. Such payments shall be made on a calendar month basis and the payment for any month may be prorated if appropriate. 
Average Final Compensation: Effective April 1, 2005, Average Final Compensation means the greater of subsections (a) or (b) defined as follows: 
(a)  The average of a Member's calendar years of compensation for the three (3) calendar years (whether or not consecutive) of the last five (5) calendar years of membership service preceding the date of determination that yields the greatest average. 
(b)  The average of a Member's calendar years of compensation for the five (5) calendar years (whether or not consecutive) of the last ten (10) calendar years of membership service preceding the date of determination that yields the greatest average. 
In determining the three (3) or five (5) calendar years of compensation that yield the greatest average pursuant to subsections (a) or (b), respectively, the inclusion of partial calendar years of compensation in the determination of Average Final Compensation is as follows: 
(c)  If a Member's final calendar year of membership service is not a complete calendar year, such corresponding final calendar year of compensation will be annualized by dividing the Member's final calendar year of compensation by the number of complete calendar months of membership service completed by the Member during the Member's final calendar year of membership service and multiplying this result by twelve (12). The resulting annualized, partial calendar year of compensation is then compared to the Member's next preceding four (4) or nine (9) calendar years of compensation (pursuant to subsection (a) or (b), respectively) for purposes of identifying the calendar years of compensation that will yield the greatest three- or five-year average. The resulting annualized, partial calendar year of compensation is used only to determine if the Member's final calendar year of compensation is among the Member's greatest three (3) or five (5) years of calendar year compensation. 
(d)  If, after determining the Member's annualized, final calendar year of compensation pursuant to subsection (c), as applicable, such annualized, final calendar year of compensation is among the Member's greatest three (3) or five (5) years of calendar year compensation (pursuant to subsection (a) or (b), respectively) the Member's third or fifth greatest calendar year of compensation (pursuant to subsection (a) or (b), respectively) is then prorated complementarily to the annualized, final calendar year of compensation by dividing such third or fifth greatest calendar year of compensation by twelve (12) and multiplying this result by the difference between twelve (12) and the number of complete calendar months of membership service completed by the Member during the Member's final calendar year of membership service. 
(e)  In annualizing the Member's partial final or prorating the Member's third or fifth calendar year of compensation pursuant to subsection (c) or (d), as applicable, a complete calendar year of membership service is considered membership service from January 1 through December 15 of any calendar year and a complete calendar month of membership service is considered membership service from the first day of any calendar month through the fifteenth day of any calendar month. 
Average Monthly Compensation: Means one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of Average Final Compensation. 
Beneficiary: The person(s) designated by the Member via advanced written notice received by the Board of Trustees to receive, in the case of the Member's death, the payment of a Member's Accumulated Contributions, Excess Accumulated Contributions, DROP accumulations, and any final pension annuity payments due. In the case where no Beneficiary exists or one has not been named the Beneficiary shall be the Member's estate. 
Benefit Level 1: A Pension benefit accrual method which provides a basic level of benefits for the Member. 
Benefit Level 2: A Pension benefit accrual method which provides an increased level of benefits for the Member. 
Benefit level selection period: A period commencing August 1, 2006, and continuing through August 31, 2007, during which Members will be provided the opportunity to make an irrevocable change from participation in Benefit Level 1 to participation in Benefit Level 2. 
Board of Trustees: The appointed and elected Members of the Board of Trustees. 
Charter: The Charter of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida as amended. 
City: The City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
City's contribution: The annual contribution needed to fund actuarially the liability for annuities credited to Employees on the basis of actuarial methods and assumptions approved by Council. 
Council: City Council of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
Creditable Service: Means the sum of the Member's Past Service, Prior Service, Military Service, and Future Service allowed within the provisions of this Article, provided that all required Employee contributions, if any, have been paid and all other requirements of this Article have been met 
(a)  If any Mayor and/or Member of City Council who has a break in service as a Member of City Council of four (4) months or less, who does not receive a return of his or her accumulated Employee contributions, if any, and who does not receive Retirement benefits from the System during the break in service, shall be entitled to receive Creditable Service for all services as a Mayor and/or Member of City Council. For any Mayor or Member of City Council who completes an entire term of office, such service shall be computed in whole years to include the full term of office even if the actual length of service is less than the length of the term of office as provided for in the city Charter; provided, however, that for any Mayor or Member of City Council who serves any partial term of office, such service for that partial term of office shall be computed to the nearest whole month of completed service, but not including any fractional parts of a month. 
(b)  In no case shall a Member receive credit for more than one (1) year's service during any twelve-month period. For Members, other than Mayor and Members of City Council, such service shall be computed to the nearest whole month of completed service, but not including any fractional parts of a month. 
(c)  This paragraph is intended to satisfy the minimum requirements of USERRA. To the extent that this paragraph does not meet the minimum standards of USERRA, as it may be amended from time to time, the minimum standards shall apply. In the event an active member dies on or after January 1, 2007, while performing USERRA Qualified Military Service, the beneficiaries of the Member are entitled to death benefits as provided for in Section 17-214(A) or Section 17-214(B) as if the member resumed employment and then died while employed; provided that all Qualified Military Service shall be included in calculating the vesting period, but only up to five (5) years of Military Service shall be included in calculating the benefit amount. 
Death in line of duty: Means death arising out of and in the actual performance of duty required by a Member's employment during his regularly scheduled working hours or irregular working hours as required by the City. The Trustees may require such proof as deemed necessary as to the time, date and cause of death, including evidence from any available witnesses. (Workers' compensation records under the provisions of F.S. ch. 440, may also be used.) 
Dependent: Shall mean a husband or wife of the Member as legally recognized by the State of Florida, a son or daughter of the Member, a legally adopted son or daughter of the Member, a stepson or stepdaughter of the Member (or a descendent of any of the foregoing); or a father or mother of the Member. 
Disability in line of duty: Means an injury or illness arising out of and in the actual performance of duty as required by a Member's employment during his regularly scheduled working hours or irregular working hours as required by the City. The Trustees may require such proof as deemed necessary as to the time, date and cause of any such injury or illness, including evidence from any available witness. (Workers' compensation records under the provisions of F.S. ch. 440, may also be used.) 
Dual service: Means having creditable service under more than one pension fund within the City of Pinellas Park. 
Early retirement date: Means the first day of the month following the date a Member completes ten (10) years of Creditable Service and applies for and is granted Retirement benefits in accordance with this Article. 
Effective date of the System: The date on which the operation of the System is to commence for the purpose of determining eligibility, benefits, and related matters, which is hereby fixed as the thirteenth day of November, 1971. 
Employee: All persons employed by the City and so classified under personnel records of the City, including "probationary" or "regular" Employees. Any appointed officer shall only be qualified under this System under one office and that office being the one from which he or she receives the largest annual salary, compensation or remuneration. Independent contractors are excluded. Part-time Employees are excluded. Temporary Employees are excluded. 
Excess accumulated contributions: Any Member contributions to the Pension Fund which are in excess of any monetary amount which has been previously paid to the Member by the Fund as a pension benefit. 
Future service: Of any Member means service subsequent to date of the Member's participation and may include authorized leaves of absence as provided in Section 17-220. 
Gender: The masculine pronoun shall include the feminine Gender. 
Joint annuitant: A spouse, or other dependent as defined by the pension ordinance, who is a contingent annuitant, in the case of a Member's death, of the Member's monthly pension benefit annuity under Options C or D of the General Employees' Pension Fund. 
Member: Means any officer or Employee who is covered or who becomes covered under the System in accordance with this Article, and who is not employed by the City as a Firefighter as defined by F.S. ch. 175, or Police Officer as defined by F.S. ch. 185. 
Military Service: Shall mean "Qualified Military Service" as defined in Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
New Member: Any "Employee" who becomes a Member of the System after the effective date of the System. 
Normal form of benefit: Shall mean a single life Annuity for the life of the Member. 
Normal Retirement Date and Normal Retirement Age: The Normal Retirement Date of a Member shall be his Normal Retirement Date as determined in accordance with the terms of the System. 
For a Member retiring effective November 13, 1997, or thereafter, means the first day of the month following the date such Member has completed ten (10) or more years of Creditable Service and: 
1.  Attains age sixty-two (62); or 
2.  Completes or would have completed thirty (30) continuous years of Creditable Service, regardless of age. 
Original Member: Any "Employee" of the City who becomes a Member as of the effective date of the System. 
Past Service: Of any Member means the number of years, complete months, recognized and credited by the City and approved by the Trustees, during which he or she was in the active employ of the City prior to the effective date of this System. 
Past Service Redeemed: Means a Member redeems Past Service at the ratio of one for one basis for each year or completed month for such service earned subsequent to the effective date of this Article. All such redeemed service will be computed (for Retirement purposes) in accordance with the provisions of Section 17-209 of this Article. Any unredeemed Prior Service will be computed in accordance with the provision of Section 17-209(3) of this Article. 
Payable: Means an obligation to pay. 
Pension: Means monthly payments to a Retiree derived as provided in this System. 
Pinellas Park General Employees' Pension Fund: The System of Retirement benefits provided under this Article. 
Prior Service: Of any Member means that service for which the Member had credit under Ordinance No. 279. 
Retirement or Retire: Withdrawal from active employment by the City with Retirement income applied for and granted under the provisions of this System. A Member who has elected to participate in the General Employees' Deferred Retirement Option Program shall be deemed to have Retired for purposes of this Pinellas Park General Employees' Pension Fund. 
Social Security Coverage: Means old age, survivors, disability and health insurance as provided by the Federal Social Security Act. 
Survivor Payee: The person(s) designated by the Member via advanced written notice received by the Board of Trustees to receive the remainder of annuity payments due under Option B of the General Employees' Pension Fund. 
System: Shall mean the Pinellas Park Retirement System. 
Treasurer: The Treasurer of the System is the City Finance Administrator. 
Trustee: Shall mean a Member of the Board of Trustees. 
Trust Fund: Means the Trust Fund established in the designated place or places (as determined by the Trustees) by this Article for the purpose of holding and investing the contributions paid by the City of Pinellas Park, and all gifts and donations to the Trust Fund, and paying the benefits to which Members or their beneficiaries may become entitled. 
Vested: Shall mean that the Member has met the age and/or service requirements to be eligible to receive a retirement benefit. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1808, 9-22-1988; Ord. No. 2363, 11-21-1995; Ord. No. 2418, 2-27-1997; Ord. No. 2459, 11-13-1997; Ord. No. 2470, § 1, 2-26-1998; Ord. No. 2631, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2952, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 2945, 1-10-2002; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 1, 10-22-2010; Ord. No. 3869, § 1, 10-24-2013)  
Sec. 17-204. - Administration of System; appropriation. 
The Trustees shall make such rules and regulations as are necessary for the effective and efficient administration of this System. The Trustees shall cause an actuarial study of the System to be made at such intervals as may be required by law, but in any event at least every two (2) years, and shall provide a copy of each such study to the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005)  
Sec. 17-205. - Consolidation of liabilities and assets; existing Plan. 
(A)  Effective November 13, 1971, the existing Pension plan of the Pinellas Park Retirement System shall be consolidated and the System shall assume: 
1.  All liabilities related to the payment of benefits to Members and their beneficiaries. 
2.  All obligations in regard to funding and administering benefits accrued for the benefit of Members, beneficiaries and survivors. 
(B)  Benefits unassignable and not subject to process: The right of any Member or any Beneficiary to any benefits under the System or any other right accrued or accruing to any persons under the provisions of this Article, and the accumulated contributions and the cash securities in the funds created under this Article, shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of any bankruptcy or insolvency law or any other process of law whatsoever and shall not be subject to assignment, pledge or hypothecation unless expressly authorized in this Article. 
(C)  Errors, corrections, and adjustments: Should any change or error in the records of the System be discovered or any error in any calculation be made resulting in any Member, Survivor Payee, Beneficiary, or other person receiving from the System more or less than he or she was entitled to receive, the Board of Trustees shall have the power to correct such error and as far as possible to adjust the payments thereafter to be made in such a manner that the actuarially equivalent of the benefit to which such Member, Survivor Payee, Beneficiary, or other person was correctly entitled to be paid. 
(D)  Payments in case of legal or other disability: Whenever and/or as often as a person entitled to payments hereunder shall be under legal disability, or, in the sole judgment of the Board of Trustees shall otherwise be unable to apply such payments to his best interests and advantage, the Board of Trustees in the exercise of its discretion may direct that all or any portion of the benefits of such Members payable in any one (1) or more of the following ways: 
1.  Directly to such person. 
2.  To his legal guardian or conservator. 
3.  To his spouse or to any person to be expended for his benefit. 
The decision of the Board of Trustees shall in each case be final and binding on all persons, including the affected Member of the System. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 2, 10-22-2010)  
Sec. 17-206. - Contributions and funding. 
(A)  Cost of the System: The cost of the System shall be borne by the City of Pinellas Park, Employees of the City who are Members of the System, excluding DROP participants, and by such other funding sources as may be provided by law. 
(B)  City's contributions. The City shall pay into the Trust Fund amounts required to provide the benefits under this System as shall be determined by an actuarial investigation as provided in Section 17-204. 
(C)  Employee contributions: 
1.  Effective October 1, 2006, there shall be created two (2) benefit level options within the fund; Benefit Level 1 and Benefit Level 2. 
2.  Participation in Benefit Level 2 shall be mandatory for all Employees who become Members of the fund on or after October 1, 2006. 
3.  All Employees who are or will be Members of the fund as of September 30, 2006, are required, during the Benefit Level Selection Period, to make a one-time election in writing to participate in one (1) of the two (2) benefit levels. A Member's election to participate in Benefit Level 2 shall be irrevocable. A Member who elects to begin participation in Benefit Level 2 before October 1, 2006, will begin participation effective October 1, 2006. A Member who elects to begin participation in Benefit Level 2 after September 30, 2006, will begin participation effective October 1, 2007. 
4.  Any Member who has not made the one-time irrevocable election to participate in one (1) of the two (2) benefit levels will be deemed to have made an irrevocable one-time election to participate in Benefit Level 1. All Members who are participating in Benefit Level 1 as of October 1, 2007, shall remain in Benefit Level 1. All Members electing to participate in Benefit Level 2 and those persons who become Members of the fund on or after October 1, 2006, shall be members in Benefit Level 2. 
5.  Effective with the payroll period which includes April 1, 2010 for members of the AFSCME Bargaining Unit and April 15, 2010 for all others, Members participating in Benefit Level 1 shall contribute at the rate of three (3) percent and Members participating in Benefit Level 2 shall contribute at the rate of five (5) percent of their gross compensation, respectively, into the fund. 
6.  All mandatory Member contributions to the Pension fund shall be picked up through a payroll reduction by the City paying the contributions on behalf of the Member in accordance with Section 414(h) of the Internal Revenue Code. The picked up contributions shall be treated as tax-deferred employer picked up contributions. Member contributions picked up under the provisions of this Section shall be treated as City contributions for purposes of determining income tax obligations under the Internal Revenue Code; however, such picked up Member contributions shall be included in the determination of the Member's gross Annual Compensation. The Member's contributions picked up under this Section shall continue to be designated Member contributions and shall be considered as part of the Member's compensation for purposes of determining the amount of the Member's contributions. The provisions of this Section are mandatory, and the Member shall have no option concerning the pick-up and may not receive the contributed amounts directly instead of having them paid by the City to the Trust Fund. The picked up amounts shall be included as wages for FICA purposes. 
(D)  Social Security contributions: Contributions for Social Security by the City in the amount required for Social Security coverage as now or hereafter provided by the Federal Social Security Act, shall be in addition to contributions specified in Subsection (B). 
(E)  Gifts to the Fund: The Board of Trustees may accept gifts, bequests, devises or appropriations to or for the Fund from any source, but shall have the right to reject the same if they are so conditional as to conflict with the Charter or this Article or to make the administration of the same unreasonably difficult. The Board of Trustees shall promptly deposit such gifts, bequests, devises or appropriations with the custodian. 
(F)  Reserved. 
(G)  Investment of the Fund: All monies paid into and held by the Retirement System shall be promptly deposited with the custodian. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1808, 9-22-1988; Ord. No. 2363, 11-21-1995; Ord. No. 2594, 5-13-1999; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 3, 10-22-2010)  
Sec. 17-207. - Compulsory participation. 
The provisions of this law (Article) shall be compulsory as to all officers and regular full-time Employees who are employed after November 13, 1971, who are not Firefighters as defined by F.S. ch. 175, or Police Officers as defined by F.S. ch. 185. Each officer or Employee who is not a Firefighter as defined by F.S. ch. 175, or Police Officer as defined by F.S. ch. 185, shall become a Member of the System as of his date of employment. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005)  
Sec. 17-208. - Rights limited. 
(A)  Participation in the System shall not give any Member the right to be retained in the employ of the City, nor, upon dismissal, to have any right or interest in the fund other than herein provided. 
(B)  No Member who has caused a shortage in a public account, when such shortage is certified by a certified public accountant, may receive any benefits under this Article so long as such shortage exists. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971)  
Sec. 17-209. - Normal Retirement Benefits; limitation upon Normal Retirement Benefit; Early Retirement. 
(A)  Effective November 13, 1997, a Member who attains his or her Normal Retirement date and Retires from employment shall receive a monthly Retirement Benefit, which shall be payable as of the first day of each month thereafter during his or her lifetime or as otherwise provided in this Article. 
(B)  The Member must make a written application on an approved form to the Board of Trustees to be eligible to receive his or her Normal Retirement Benefit or early Retirement Benefit. 
(C)  The amount of the monthly benefit shall be equal to the applicable accrual rate(s) times the number of years and fractional parts of years of Creditable Service times the Average Monthly Compensation. 
(D)  For the purposes of this Section, the accrual rate shall be: 
1.  For a Member who before December 13, 2001, separates from employment as a regular Employee or who enters DROP, whichever comes first: (i) One and six-tenths (1.60) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation up to the date that he or she attains age sixty-two (62) or completes or would have completed thirty-five (35) years of Creditable Service regardless of age; (ii) For a Member who has attained age sixty-three (63) with at least eleven (11) years of Creditable Service, or has completed thirty-six (36) years of Creditable Service regardless of age, one and sixty-three hundredths (1.63) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation; (iii) For a Member who has attained age sixty-four (64) with at least twelve (12) years of Creditable Service, or has completed thirty-seven (37) years of Creditable Service regardless of age, one and sixty-five hundredths (1.65) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation; (iv) For a Member who has attained age sixty-five (65) with at least thirteen (13) years of Creditable Service, or has completed thirty-eight (38) years of Creditable Service regardless of age, one and sixty-eight hundredths (1.68) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation. 
2.  For a Member who on or after December 13, 2001, separates from employment as a regular Employee or who enters DROP, whichever comes first, Creditable Service prior to October 1, 2001, shall be calculated as in Subsection (A)1. above. 
3.  For a Member who on or after December 13, 2001, separates from employment as a regular Employee or who enters DROP, whichever comes first, Creditable Service on or after October 1, 2001: (i) one and seventy hundredths (1.70) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation up to the date that he or she attains age sixty-two (62) or completes or would have completed thirty-five (35) years of Creditable Service regardless of age; (ii) For a Member who has attained age sixty-three (63) with at least eleven (11) years of Creditable Service, or has completed thirty-six (36) years of Creditable Service regardless of age, one and seventy-three hundredths (1.73) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation; (iii) For a Member who has attained age sixty-four (64) with at least twelve (12) years of Creditable Service, or has completed thirty-seven (37) years of Creditable Service regardless of age, one and three-quarters (1.75) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation; (iv) For a Member who has attained age sixty-five (65) with at least thirteen (13) years of Creditable Service, or has completed thirty-eight (38) years of Creditable Service regardless of age, one and seventy-eight hundredths (1.78) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation. 
4.  Effective October 1, 2006, for a Member who is participating in Benefit Level 1 subsequent to October 1, 2006, and separates from employment as a regular Employee or who enters DROP, whichever comes first, the accrual rate shall be as calculated in Subsections (D)1. through 3. above. 
5.  Effective October 1, 2006, for a Member who is participating in Benefit Level 2, and separates from employment as a regular Employee or who enters DROP, whichever comes first, the accrual rate shall be calculated as in Subsections (D)1. through 3. above, except that the accrual rate for each year subsequent to the effective date on which the Member elected to participate in Benefit Level 2 and the longevity increases set forth in subparagraph three (3) shall be increased by four-tenths of a percent. 
(E)  The normal Retirement Benefit or Pension payable to a Retiree who becomes a Member of any Retirement System or plan and who has not previously participated in such plan, on or after January 1, 1980, shall not exceed one hundred (100) percent of his or her Average Final Compensation. However, nothing contained in this Section shall apply to supplemental Retirement benefits or to Pension increases attributable to cost-of-living increases or adjustments. 
(F)  Upon Retirement on his or her Early Retirement Date, the Member shall receive a monthly benefit which shall be payable as of the first day of the month following the month in which the Member Retires and be payable monthly thereafter during his or her lifetime. The amount of each monthly payment shall be computed in the same manner as for a normal Retirement benefit, in accordance with Section 17-209(D), but based on Average Monthly Compensation and Creditable Service as of the Member's Early Retirement Date, and for Members retiring effective November 22, 1995, or thereafter, the benefits so computed shall be reduced by three-twelfths ( 3/12 ) percent for each complete month by which the Early Retirement Date precedes such Member's Normal Retirement Date as provided in Section 17-209. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981; Ord. No. 1827, 2-9-1989; Ord. No. 2459, 11-13-1997; Ord. No. 2952, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 4, 10-22-2010; Ord. No. 3869, § 2, 10-24-2013)  
Sec. 17-210. - Benefits payable for dual Normal Retirement ages and Early Retirement Benefit. 
In the event a Member has performed services to the City of Pinellas Park under Articles III and/or IV as an Employee other than a general Member for purposes of determining eligibility for any Pension benefit in which length of service is a factor, including entry into the DROP, the entire period of full-time Creditable Service served as an Employee of the City of Pinellas Park shall be included, provided however, that the calculation and payment of the Pension benefits shall be pursuant to the terms of the respective Pension plans in effect at the time the Employee ceased participating in the respective Pension plan. Provided, further, for non-line of duty disability Retirement benefits in which the Member's combined years of service results in a monthly benefit of less than the minimum of twenty-five (25) percent, the Member shall be entitled to only one (1) minimum, the payment of which shall be prorated among the respective Pension plans of which the Member has Creditable Service. 
(Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3726, § 5, 10-22-2010)  
Sec. 17-211. - Disability Retirement Benefit. 
(A)  Disability Retirement date: A Member who terminates employment on account of total and permanent disability, as defined in this Subsection after completing five (5) years of Creditable Service from effective date, or a Member of this System who becomes totally and permanently disabled in line of duty regardless of service, shall be entitled to a monthly disability benefit. This disability Retirement date for such Member shall be the first day of the month which coincides with or next follows the date of the final hearing which determines the Member is totally and permanently disabled. 
(B)  Total and permanent disability: A Member shall be considered totally and permanently disabled if, in the opinion of the Trustees, he or she is prevented, by reason of a medically determinable physical or mental impairment, from rendering useful and efficient service as an officer or Employee. The decision of the Trustees on these questions shall be final and binding. 
(C)  Proof of disability: The Trustees, before approving payment of any disability Retirement benefit, shall require proof that the Member is totally and permanently disabled as provided herein. A Member who believes that he or she is eligible for a disability benefit shall apply therefore to the Board of Trustees on a form provided by the Board. A Member's application for disability benefits must be received by the Board of Trustees no later than one (1) year after the date of which the Member terminated employment. The Member's application must include the certification of the Member's total and permanent disability by a licensed physician of the State. No Member shall be granted disability benefits unless the Trustees receive certification of the Member's total and permanent disability by two (2) licensed physicians of the State, selected by the Trustees, and such other evidence of disability as the Trustees may require. 
(D)  Disability Retirement benefit: A Member upon Retirement on his or her disability Retirement date shall receive a monthly benefit as selected from the available options in Section 17-213 which shall be payable as of the first day of the month of his or her disability Retirement and shall be payable monthly thereafter during his or her lifetime and continued disability. The amount of each monthly payment shall be computed in the same manner as for a normal Retirement benefit, in accordance with Section 17-209, but based on the Member's Average Monthly Compensation and Creditable Service as of his or her disability Retirement date, with Creditable Service subject to the following conditions: 
1.  If the Member's disability occurred in the line of duty, his or her monthly benefit shall not be less than forty-two (42) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation as of his or her disability Retirement date; or 
2.  If the Member's disability occurred other than in the line of duty, his or her monthly benefit shall not be less than twenty-five (25) percent of his or her Average Monthly Compensation as of his or her disability Retirement date. 
(E)  Recovery from disability: The Trustees may require periodic re-examination at the expense of the Retirement fund, and: 
1.  If the Trustees find that a Member who is receiving disability benefits is, at any time prior to his or her Normal Retirement Date, no longer disabled, the Trustees shall direct that the benefits be discontinued. The decision of the Trustees on this question shall be final and binding. 
2.  If the Member described in Subsection (E)1. (who recovers from such disability prior to his or her Normal Retirement Date), does not re-enter the employ of the City and had not completed ten (10) years of Creditable Service as of his or her disability Retirement date, he or she shall be entitled to receive a return of any Excess Accumulated Contributions over the total disability benefits received up to his or her date of recovery. 
3.  If the Member described in Subsection (E)1. (who recovers from such disability prior to his or her Normal Retirement Date) does not re-enter the employ of the City but had completed ten (10) or more years of Creditable Service as of his or her disability Retirement date, he or she may elect to receive either: 
(a)  Any Excess Accumulated Contributions over the total disability benefits received up to his or her date of recovery; or 
(b)  A deferred retirement benefit commencing on the first day of the month of his or her Normal Retirement Date which shall be payable on the first day of the month thereafter during his or her lifetime. 
4.  If the Member recovers from disability and re-enters employment of the City within six (6) months after his or her recovery, his or her service will be deemed to have been continuous, but the period beginning with the first month for which he or she received a disability benefit payment and ending with the date he or she re-entered employment will not be considered as Creditable Service for the purpose of computing benefits. 
The amount of monthly benefit shall be computed in the same manner as for a normal Retirement benefit, in accordance with Section 17-209, but based on Average Monthly Compensation and Creditable Service as of the Member's disability Retirement date. 
(F)  Nonadmissible causes of disability: A Member shall not be entitled to receive any disability Retirement benefit if his disability is a result of the following: 
1.  Injury or disease sustained by the Member while willfully participating in riots, civil insurrections or other acts of violence or while committing a felony. 
2.  Injury or disease sustained by the Member after his employment has terminated. 
3.  Intentional, self-inflicted injury. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 2418, 2-27-1997; Ord. No. 2952, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 6, 10-22-2010; Ord. No. 3869, § 3, 10-24-2013)  
Sec. 17-212. - Termination benefits. 
(A)  A Member whose employment is terminated for any reason other than death or Retirement prior to the completion of ten (10) years of Creditable Service shall be entitled to the return of his or her Accumulated Contributions, if any, as of his or her date of termination. 
(B)  A Member whose employment is terminated for any reason other than death or Retirement after the completion of ten (10) years of Creditable Service is a Vested Member who may elect to receive a monthly benefit which shall be payable as of the first day of the month following his or her application and eligibility for normal or early Retirement and shall be payable monthly thereafter during his or her lifetime. The amount of the monthly benefit shall be computed in the same manner as for a normal Retirement benefit in accordance with Section 17-209 or early Retirement benefit in accordance with Section 17-209(F) but based on Average Monthly Compensation and Creditable Service as of his or her date of termination. Benefits deferred to a future date shall be based on the actuarial equivalency factors in effect at the time the benefits are applied for and granted. If a Member who after completing ten (10) years of Creditable Service elects to receive a deferred Retirement benefit dies prior to his or her Normal Retirement Date, the monthly benefit to which the member would have been entitled shall be paid in accordance with Section 17-214(B)1. if the Member is survived by a spouse or other Dependent, or Section 17-214(B)2. if the Member has no spouse or other Dependent. 
(C)  In lieu of the deferred monthly benefit provided in Subsection (B) the terminated Member may elect to receive a lump sum amount equal to his or her Accumulated Contributions, if any, as of his or her date of termination. 
(D)  If any Retired Member dies without having received benefit payments in an amount equal to his or her Accumulated Contributions, if any, and who is not survived by either a Survivor Payee or Joint Annuitant, there shall be payable to his or her designated Beneficiary(ies) an amount equal to the Member's Excess Accumulated Contributions. If no Beneficiary survives the Retiree, or if no Beneficiary has been designated, any such Excess Accumulated Contributions shall be payable to the Member's estate. 
(E)  A Member shall be deemed a terminated Member only at such time as he or she is no longer employed by the City. 
(F)  Any Member who is found guilty in a court of law of competent jurisdiction of committing or aiding and abetting any embezzlement or theft from the City, or bribery in connection with his employment with the City, or any offense specified in F.S. 112.3173 (2)(e), or who is otherwise subject to forfeiture under F.S. 112.3173(3), or any Member whose employment is terminated by reason of his commitment or aiding or abetting an embezzlement or theft from the City, or of bribery in connection with his employment with the City, shall forfeit all rights and benefits under this Article, except the return of any Excess Accumulated Contributions, as of the date of termination, conviction, resignation, or Retirement, whichever occurs first. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981; Ord. No. 1808, 9-22-1988; Ord. No. 2952, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 7, 10-22-2010; Ord. No. 3869, § 4, 10-24-2013)  
Sec. 17-213. - Optional forms of Retirement benefits. 
(A)  This Section applies to the payment of Retirement benefits under Section 17-209, Section 17-210 and Section 17-211. Using a form provided by the Board of Trustees, each Member shall elect either Option A, Option B, Option C or Option D as his or her form of payment. Each Member must also designate his or her Beneficiary(ies), Survivor Payees or Joint Annuitant (if any) on the form. The form must be properly completed and returned to the Board of Trustees prior to the receipt of his first monthly Retirement payment. 
OPTION A: Shall be the Normal Form of Benefit. 
OPTION B: A decreased Retirement benefit payable to the Member during his or her lifetime and, in the event of his or her death within a period of ten (10) years after Retirement, the same monthly amount shall be payable for the balance of such ten-year period to his Survivor Payee(s) or in case the Survivor Payee(s) is deceased, in accordance with Subsection (C) below. 
OPTION C: A decreased Retirement benefit which shall be payable during the joint lifetime of both the Member and his or her Joint Annuitant and which shall continue after the death of either during the lifetime of the survivor in the same amount. 
OPTION D: A decreased Retirement benefit shall be payable during the joint lifetime of the Member and his or her Joint Annuitant and which shall continue after the death of either during the lifetime of the survivor in an amount of sixty-six and two-thirds (66 2/3 ) percent of the amount which was payable during the joint lifetime of the Member and his or her Joint Annuitant. 
(B)  The benefit payable under any option stated above shall be the Actuarial Equivalent, of the Normal Form of Benefit. 
(C)  A Member who elects Option B shall designate Survivor Payee(s) to receive the benefits payable in the event of his or her death. Should no Survivor Payee(s) be alive at the time of the death of the Member, then the estate of the Member shall be the Survivor Payee. 
(D)  A Member who elects Option C or Option D shall, on a form provided for that purpose, designate his or her spouse or other Dependent to receive the benefits which continue to be payable upon the death of a Member. Such person shall be the Joint Annuitant of the Member. After Benefits have commenced under Option C or Option D, a Retired Member may change his or her designation of a Joint Annuitant only twice. The new Joint Annuitant must be either the spouse or other Dependent. If such a Retired Member desires to change his/her designation of a Joint Annuitant, the Member shall file with the Board of Trustees a notarized "change of Joint Annuitant" form and shall notify the former Joint Annuitant in writing of such change.
