Upon receipt of a completed change of Joint Annuitant form, the Board of Trustees shall adjust the Member's monthly benefit by the application of actuarial tables and calculations developed to ensure that the benefit paid is the Actuarial Equivalent of the present value of the Member's current benefit. The consent of a Retired Member's first designated Joint Annuitant to any such change shall not be required. In all cases, the Retiree shall pay for costs incurred in recalculating the benefits. 
(E)  The election of an option shall be null and void if either the Member, designated Survivor Payee, or designated Joint Annuitant shall die before benefits commence. No Member may change his or her retirement option after the date of cashing or depositing his or her first retirement check. 
(F)  Upon the death of a Retired Member, Survivor Payee or Joint Annuitant receiving monthly benefits under this Chapter, the monthly benefits shall be paid through the last day of the month of death and shall terminate, or be adjusted, if applicable, as of that date in accordance with the optional form of benefit at the time of Retirement. 
(Ord. No. 2198, 5-13-1993; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 8, 10-22-2010)  
Sec. 17-214. - Death benefits. 
(A)  If the employment of a Member is terminated by reason of his or her death other than in the line of duty prior to the completion of ten (10) years of Creditable Service, then any Accumulated Contributions shall be paid to his or her Beneficiaries, or if there are none, to the Member's estate. 
(B)  If the employment of a Member is terminated by reason of his or her death other than in the line of duty subsequent to the completion of ten (10) years of Creditable Service but prior to the actual commencement of benefits, it shall be assumed that the Member Retired as of his or her date of death in accordance with Section 17-209 if eligible for normal Retirement benefits or for early Retirement benefits, or Section 17-210 if eligible for benefits payable for dual normal Retirement: 
1.  The death benefit payable under this subsection shall be payable in the form of Option C in accordance with Section 17-213 and paid to the Member's spouse or other Dependent (as documented on a form provided by the Board of Trustees) for his or her lifetime, provided, however, that the value of the benefit determined under this paragraph shall not be less than the value determined under Subsection (A) of this Section. 
2.  If the Member has no spouse or other Dependent, then no death benefit is payable, and the Member's Accumulated Contributions, if any, shall be payable to the Member's designated Beneficiaries, or if there are none, to the Member's estate. 
(C)  Regardless of the Member's length of service, the surviving spouse of any Member killed in the line of duty may receive a monthly Pension equal to one-half (½) of the monthly salary being received by the Member at the time of the Member's death, plus fifty (50) percent of one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of all other earnings paid during the fifty-two (52) weeks ending with the last full pay period immediately prior to the Member's death, or one-half (½) of the Member's "Average Monthly Compensation", whichever is greater, for the rest of the surviving spouse's lifetime; or in lieu of the above, the surviving spouse may elect to receive the benefit provided in Section 17-214(B) of the Article. For purposes of calculating death benefits pursuant to this subsection, "salary" shall include that gross pay which is paid regularly every pay period; and "monthly salary being received by the Member at the time of the Member's death" shall be determined by taking the "salary" as defined herein paid during the last full pay period immediately prior to the Member's death, multiplied by twenty-six (26) and then divided by twelve (12). The surviving spouse of a Member killed in the line of duty whose benefit terminated because of remarriage shall have the benefit reinstated as of July 1, 1994, at the amount that would have been payable had such benefit not been terminated. 
(D)  If the surviving spouse of a Member killed in the line of duty dies, the monthly payments which would have been payable to such surviving spouse had such surviving spouse lived shall be paid for use and benefit of such Member's Dependent child or children until age eighteen (18) or as provided in Subsection (F) below. 
(E)  If a Member killed in the line of duty leaves no surviving spouse, the benefits provided by Subsection (C), normally payable to a surviving spouse, shall be paid for the use and benefit of such Member's Dependent child or children until age eighteen (18) or as provided in Subsection (F) below. If the Member killed in the line of duty leaves no surviving spouse, Dependent child or children, then the Member's Accumulated Contribution shall be payable to the Member's Beneficiaries. 
(F)  As used in Subsections 17-214(C), (D) and (E), "child" or "children" shall include any child of the Member who after attaining eighteen (18) years of age is physically or mentally incapable of self-support, provided such child was financially Dependent for no less than one-half (½) of his or her support from the deceased Member at the time of the death of such Member; and provided, however, such benefits shall cease once the child of the Member becomes capable of self-support or dies. Written proof of such incapacity and financial dependency shall be furnished to the Board of Trustees prior to payment of benefits. The Board of Trustees may require proof of continued incapacity whenever it deems necessary. 
(G)  The Board of Trustees shall require proof of the Dependent status of any individual claiming benefits under this Section. 
(Ord. No. 2332, 4-27-1995; Ord. No. 2631, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 9, 10-22-2010)  
Sec. 17-215. - Designation of death benefits recipients. 
Each Member may, on a form provided for that purpose, signed and filed with the Trustees, designate a choice of one or more Dependents, named in sequence, to receive the death benefits, if any, which may be payable under Section 17-214. If no Dependent is named in the manner provided above, the Trustees shall direct the payment of such benefits to the spouse of the deceased, if living. If the Member's spouse is not alive at the Member's death, any payments to which he or she was entitled shall be paid to the Dependent children of the Member, or on their behalf if under the age of eighteen (18) years or as otherwise provided in Section 17-214. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. 3458, 7-27-2006)  
Sec. 17-216. - Claims procedure. 
(A)  The Board of Trustees shall establish administrative procedures to be utilized in processing written requests on matters which affect the substantial rights of any person, including Members, Retirees, Beneficiaries, or any person affected by a decision of the Board of Trustees. 
(B)  The Board of Trustees shall have the power to subpoena and require the attendance of witnesses and the production of documents for discovery prior to and at any proceedings provided for in such procedures. 
(C)  In the case of an Employee Member who has filed a grievance in appeal of an adverse termination employment action of the City, the Board of Trustees shall take no action regarding pension matters (unless so requested by the Member) until such time that the grievance process has been concluded. 
(Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006)  
Sec. 17-217. - Re-employment after retirement; limitation. 
(A)  Any Member who has Retired and is receiving Retirement compensation under this Chapter may be re-employed by the City in a position designated as part-time, seasonal or temporary for up to five hundred (500) hours during any one (1) fiscal year, and such employment shall not affect the rights of such Retired Member under this Retirement System, including, without limiting the general terms thereof, his or her right to receive his or her Retirement compensation. 
Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, if at any point in the fiscal year the re-employed Member reaches five hundred (500) hours in any position or positions other than as a School Crossing Guard, he or she will no longer be eligible for employment during that fiscal year except as a School Crossing Guard. Provided, however, that a Member who has Retired and is receiving Retirement compensation under this Chapter may be re-employed by the City as a School Crossing Guard for up to a maximum of one thousand one hundred (1,100) hours in any one (1) fiscal year, and such employment shall not affect the rights of such Retired Member under this Retirement System, including, without limiting the general terms thereof, his or her right to receive his or her Retirement compensation. If at any point in the fiscal year the re-employed Member reaches a total of one thousand one hundred (1,100) hours, he or she will no longer be eligible for employment as a School Crossing Guard during that fiscal year. In no event shall a Member who has Retired and who is receiving Retirement compensation under this Chapter be re-employed by the City as a School Crossing Guard and in one (1) or more other positions for more than a total of one thousand one hundred (1,100) hours in any one (1) fiscal year. 
(B)  The re-employment by the City of any Member who has Retired and is receiving compensation under this Chapter, including elected officials, referred to in Subsection (A) of this Section shall have no effect on the Average Final Compensation or years of Creditable Service of such Retired Member. A person who has previously retired under this Chapter and is reemployed in any capacity or serves as an elected official is not eligible to earn further Creditable Service. 
(C)  Any Member who has Retired and is receiving Retirement compensation under this Chapter who is re-employed by the City shall monthly report his or her hours in writing to the Human Resources Administrator or designee. In addition, the re-employed Member shall separately report in writing his or her hours to the Human Resources Administrator or designee when the number of hours worked in any fiscal year is one hundred (100) hours less than the applicable limit set forth in Subsection (A) of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981; Ord. No. 3061, 10-24-2002; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3869, § 5, 10-24-2013)  
Sec. 17-218. - Cost-of-living adjustment of benefits. 
(A)  The purpose of this Section is to provide cost-of-living adjustments in accordance with existing laws at the date of Retirement, or entry into DROP, whichever comes first, or earlier death, to the monthly benefits payable or accrued to certain Retirees, including DROP participants, or to certain of their Survivor Payee(s), Joint Annuitant, or surviving spouse or children, as provided herein. 
(B)  The terms used in this Section are defined as follows: 
1.  Average Cost-Of-Living Index as of an adjustment date means the percentage change in the average of the monthly consumer price index figures for the twelve-months period from April 1 through March 31 immediately prior to the adjustment date, when compared to the average of the monthly consumer price index figures for the preceding twelve-month period from April 1 through March 31 relative to the United States as a whole, issued by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor. 
2.  Base benefit means the total monthly benefit payable or accrued to a Retiree, including DROP participant, Survivor Payee(s) or Joint Annuitant, surviving spouse or children of a Member who dies in the line of duty, in accordance with existing laws as of November 13, 1971; or date of Retirement, or entry into DROP, or earlier death, if later than November 13, 1971. 
3.  Standard benefit means the monthly benefit calculated in accordance with Section 17-209 for normal Retirement, Section 17-210 for early Retirement, Section 17-211 for disability Retirement, Section 17-213 if an optional form of benefit payment was elected by the Member, or Section 17-214 for death benefits. Such determination shall be made assuming: 
(a)  Creditable Service is the number of years of service for which benefits are provided by the System under which benefits are being paid. 
(b)  Average Final Compensation is the compensation base on which benefits are being paid were determined. 
4.  Initial benefit means the first monthly benefit payable or accrued to a Retiree, including DROP participant, Survivor Payee(s) or Joint Annuitant, or surviving spouse or children of a Member killed in the line of duty in accordance with the laws governing the determination of such benefits at the time of Retirement, entry into DROP, or earlier death. 
(C)  On January 1, 1973, the Trustees shall adjust the benefit of all Retirees who, as of November 13, 1971, had attained age sixty-five (65) or who had Retired on account of disability and the benefit of all Survivor Payee(s) or Joint Annuitant of deceased Members who would have attained age sixty-five (65) as of November 13, 1971. The amount of benefit payable to such person for the six-month period commencing January 1, 1973, shall be the greater of Subsections (1) and (2) where: 
1.  Is the Member's base benefit; and 
2.  Is the sum of the Member's initial benefit and a percentage of the Member's standard benefit, such percentage to be equal to the percentage change in the average cost-of-living index over the period between the date of actual Retirement and November 13, 1971. 
(D)  On November 1, 1972, and each November 1st thereafter, the Trustees shall adjust the benefits of all Retirees who, as of the date of adjustment, have attained age sixty-five (65) or who have Retired on account of disability and the benefit of all Survivor Payee(s) and Joint Annuitant(s) of deceased Members who would have attained age sixty-five (65) as of the adjustment date. 
(E)  On November 1, 1989, and each November 1 thereafter, the Trustees shall also adjust the benefit of any Member who after November 1, 1988, but before December 13, 2001, separates from employment or enters DROP, whichever comes first, and who has thirty-five (35) years or more of Creditable Service as a regular Employee. 
(F)  On November 1, 2002, and each November 1 thereafter, the Trustees shall adjust the benefit of any Member who on or after December 13, 2001, separates from employment or enters DROP, whichever comes first, and who has thirty (30) years or more of Creditable Service as a regular Employee. For all Dual Service Members who separate from employment or enter DROP, whichever comes first, on or after January 1, 2010, all years of creditable City service shall be included when determining eligibility of COLA benefits. 
(G)  On November 1, 2002, and each November 1 thereafter, the Trustees shall also adjust the benefit of all Survivor Payee(s) and Joint Annuitant of deceased Members who, at the time of such Member's death had been receiving an adjustment on account of disability or who are likewise eligible for the COLA as set forth in Section 17-218 (F), regardless of the age of the deceased Member's Survivor Payee(s) or Joint Annuitant; and the benefit of all surviving spouses or children who quality for in-line-of-duty death benefits pursuant to Section 17-214(C), (D) or (E), regardless of the age of the deceased Member or surviving spouse. 
(H)  The amount of benefit payable to such person for the twelve-month period commencing on the adjustment date shall be the sum of monthly benefit being received on October 31 immediately preceding the November 1st adjustment date and the immediately preceding "Average Cost-of-Living Index Percentage", not to exceed three (3) percent of such monthly benefit. 
(I)  For Members separating from employment or entering the DROP, whichever comes first, prior to October 30, 2013, and for Members who are then currently eligible for Normal Retirement as of that date, eligibility for a COLA shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of subsections (D), (E), (F), (G), and (H) above. 
(J)  For Members separating from employment or entering the DROP, whichever comes first, on or after October 30, 2013, who become eligible to receive a COLA pursuant to subsections (D), (E), (F), or (G) above, the COLA shall be two (2) percent per year and shall be payable on December 1st of the year immediately following either the Retired Member's attainment of age sixty-five (65) or the anniversary of five (5) full years of Retirement, whichever comes first. 
(Ord. No. 1808, 9-22-1988; Ord. No. 2459, 11-13-1997; Ord. No. 2952, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 3172, 10-9-2003; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 10, 10-22-2010; Ord. No. 3869, § 6, 10-24-2013)  
Sec. 17-219. - Credit for actual Military Service. 
Creditable Service of any Member shall also include Military Service as defined in Section 17-203 provided: 
(a)  The Member was in the active employ of the City immediately prior to such service and notified the City of intent to leave employment to perform military service and is legally entitled to re-employment under the provisions of the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Act of 1994, or other law applicable to such re-employment and, provided further, that said Member shall apply for and be re-employed within ninety (90) days from his date of discharge or separation from active Military Service. 
(b)  The Member makes the required contributions for service credit during such period based on his rate of monthly City compensation as of his date of entry into wartime service plus four (4) percent interest on such contributions compounded annually from the due date of the contribution to date of payment. A Member will not be required to make contributions as set forth in this Section to receive service credit for Military Service as defined herein, provided such Military Service was rendered after October 1, 2003. 
(c)  Any Member who was in the active employ of the City on November 13, 1971, will be granted service credit for Military Service prior to the effective date of this System, where re-employment occurred within ninety (90) days and the Military Service does not exceed four (4) years or initial enlistment, whichever is less. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3726, § 11, 10-22-2010)  
Sec. 17-220. - Future Service to include authorized leave of absence. 
Future Service of any Member as defined in Section 17-203 shall also include authorized leaves of absence without pay, as defined in the City's Personnel and Safety Rules and Regulations, provided: 
(a)  The Member has completed a minimum of ten (10) years of Creditable Service excluding periods of leave of absence. 
(b)  The leave of absence is authorized in writing by the City Manager and approved by the Trustees. 
(c)  The leave does not exceed twelve (12) months at any one time nor twenty-four (24) months in total during his employment. 
(d)  The Member makes the required contributions for service credit during the leave of absence which shall be eight (8) percent of his rate of monthly compensation in effect immediately prior to the commencement of such leave for each month of such period, plus four (4) percent interest on such contribution to date of payment. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981; Ord. No. 3869, § 7, 10-24-2013)  
Sec. 17-221. - Alternate vesting for City Manager. 
(A)  The Mayor, Members of City Councilmen and City Manager on November 13, 1971 will have a fully vested interest in his or her Pension credit earned on November 13, 1971. 
(B)  Vesting for the Mayor and Members of City Council will be as follows: 
1.  All persons elected or appointed to the office of Mayor after November 13, 1971, shall become fully vested after completing a total of either: (i) two (2) consecutive full terms as Mayor, as provided for in the City Charter, even if the actual length of service is less than four (4) years; or (ii) a minimum of four (4) years of membership service as Mayor and/or a Member of City Council. 
2.  All persons elected or appointed as a Member of City Council after November 13, 1971, shall become fully vested after completing a total of either: (i) one (1) full term as a Member of City Council, as provided for in the City Charter, even if the actual length of service is less than four (4) years, or (ii) a minimum of four (4) years of membership service as a Member of City Council and/or Mayor. 
(C)  All persons serving as City Manager after January 1, 2002, will become fully vested at the completion of a total of four (4) consecutive years of service in any capacity as a full-time Employee of the City. 
(D)  Mayors, Members of City Council and City Managers will have the option of either receiving an amount equal to his or her Employee contribution, if any, or remaining in the System and receiving Retirement benefits as set forth in Section 17-209 and 17-210. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981; Ord. No. 2945, 1-10-2002)  
Sec. 17-222. - Amendments. 
Reference in the Article to City, State or Federal laws or agreements are intended to include such laws as they now exist or may hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981)  
Sec. 17-223. - Regulations and administrative action necessary to effectuate this Article on the effective date. 
During the period of time intervening between the date this Article becomes official and its effective date the Trustees shall promulgate such regulations and take such administrative action as necessary to make the provisions of this Article become fully operative upon its effective date. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981)  
Sec. 17-224. - Administration of Plan. 
(A)  General supervision: The general supervision of the administration of the plan shall be by the Board of Trustees. The Board shall be composed of the following Members. 
1.  A Member Trustee selected by the Florida Public Employees Council 79, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, Local 762 from its membership. The Member shall take office on October 1, 2005, and shall serve an initial term ending on September 30, 2008. 
2.  Two (2) elected Member Trustees of the General Employee, who are not Members of the Florida Public Employees Council 79, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, Local 762. One (1) of these positions shall be designated as having a term that expires on September 30, 2006, and the other shall be designed as having a term that expires on September 30, 2007. 
3.  Three (3) residents of the City chosen by Members of the City Council to serve for overlapping terms of three (3) years each. 
4.  A seventh Trustee chosen by a majority of the previous six (6) Trustees. Such person's name shall be submitted to City Council. Upon receipt of the seventh person's name, City Council, as a ministerial duty, shall appoint such person as the seventh Trustee with the same rights as each of the other six (6) Trustees appointed or elected as provided herein. This seventh Trustee shall serve a three-year term, the initial term of which shall begin upon appointment by City Council and end on September 30, 2003. 
The two (2) elected Member Trustees and the Member Trustee selected by the Florida Public Employees Council 79, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, Local 762, shall serve overlapping terms of three (3) years each. To be elected as an elected Member Trustee, a candidate must receive a majority of the votes cast. Each Trustee may succeed himself or herself in office. If a vacancy occurs in the office of Trustee, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the office was previously filled. 
All Members of City Council, City Manager, Finance Administrator and Human Resources Administrator of the City shall be ex officio Members of the Board, having a voice in any proceeding, but no vote. 
(B)  Compensation of Board Members: The Members of the Board of Trustees shall serve without compensation for their service. 
(C)  Meetings of the Board of Trustees: This System and matters related hereto shall be considered and resolved at Board meetings to be held as often as may be required for settlement of matters relating hereto. A majority of the voting membership shall constitute a quorum and all decisions, acts and resolutions of the Board shall be affirmative vote of a majority of the voting Members present. All Members of the Board of Trustees shall receive written notices at least two (2) days prior to a meeting date and a written agenda shall be included therewith. 
(D)  Administrative regulations: The Board of Trustees by Resolution, with the advice and consent of the City Manager, may promulgate written rules and regulations not in conflict with the expressed terms of this Article or the Charter of the City of Pinellas Park to cover the operations of any phase or part of the System as provided by this Article. Copies of such rules and regulations shall be furnished to any Member of the System upon request and at least one (1) copy thereof shall be kept available in the Retirement Services Office for examination by any interested persons at any time during ordinary business hours. Otherwise, a copy of this Article shall fully meet the provisions herein. 
(E)  Interpretation of the Plan: The Board of Trustees has the power to construe all items, rules, conditions and limitations of the System, and its construction made in good faith shall be final and conclusive upon all parties' interests. 
(F)  Agent and Employees: The Board of Trustees shall have the power to select, employ and compensate, or cause to compensate from time to time such consultants, actuaries, accountants, attorneys, investment counsel and other agents and Employees as they may deem necessary and advisable in the proper and efficient administration of the System. 
(G)  Other powers and duties: The powers and duties of the Board of Trustees or of any other persons and set out herein are not intended to be complete or exclusive, but each such body or persons shall have such powers and duties as are reasonably implied under the terms of the Article. Where not in conflict with this Article or the Charter of the City of Pinellas Park, the trust agreement or contract entered into with the insurance company shall govern. 
(H)  Secretary of the Board of Trustees: The Secretary shall be the Plan Administrator or designee. 
(I)  Duties of the Secretary: It shall be the duty of the Secretary to keep accurate minutes and records of the acts of the Board of Trustees under this System separate and apart from the regular minutes of City Council meetings. This provision is made for the express purpose of having all proceedings in connection with this System in one (1) set of books, thereby saving a search of the minutes of City Council meetings for records. They shall be available to the public, City officials and Employees under this System at all times. Copies of all minutes and meeting notifications shall be distributed to each Member of the City Council. 
(J)  Written records: All notices, elections, designations and changes of Beneficiaries and similar writings pertaining to the operation of the System shall be made and preserved in writing or electronically on such forms as the City Manager or Trustees may direct. Whenever there are any notices, elections, designations, complaints, rulings, or other written proceedings relating to a particular Employee, the secretary shall furnish the Trustees or the insurance company, when necessary, with a copy of same, as well as the Employee. 
(K)  Deposit of funds: The Board of Trustees shall have authority to direct that Retirement System funds be deposited with a custodian (as permitted under state statute). The Board of Trustees shall have the authority to negotiate the terms of any contract or contracts with the custodian. In addition, the Board of Trustees shall have the authority to enter into or terminate all contracts with respect to the investment of Trust Fund assets. 
(L)  Annual reports by the custodian: The custodian and each other entity which holds assets of the Trust Fund shall submit a statement of the condition of the funds on deposit to the credit of the System at least once yearly, and may be required to supply copies of such statement to an actuarial consultant designated by the Trustees. The original shall be retained among the records of the Secretary of the Board of Trustees. Annual reports, as provided by State law, shall be furnished to the proper State authorities. 
(M)  Responsibilities of Members, Beneficiaries and others: Each Member, Beneficiary, Survivor Payee, Joint Annuitant or other interested person shall be responsible for advising the Board of Trustees of his correct mailing address, and promptly advising the Board of Trustees relating to any error in whomsoever's favor, in connection with the payment of benefits of any other payment under or in connection with the System. 
(N)  Interest on delayed payments: Pension payments, although not promptly paid for any reason, and any other payments to be made out of the fund, although not paid promptly for any reason, shall not bear interest unless so ordered by the Board of Trustees, who shall have discretion to fix the rate and calculate any such interest, and in such event, the interest to be paid shall not exceed the then current rate of interest being returned on the funds on deposit with the Trustee or the insurance company or other financial institution. 
(O)  Personal liability: Each Member of the Board of Trustees shall use the ordinary care and diligence in the performance of his duties and shall not be liable for any loss unless same results from his own gross negligence, or his or her willful misconduct, nor shall such Members be personally liable upon or with respect to any agreement, act, transaction or omission executed, committed or suffered to be committed himself or herself as one of a Member of said body or any other Member, agent, representative, or Employee of any body, moreover said bodies and Members and agents thereof shall each be fully protected in relying on the advice of the City Attorney or his or her assistants, or upon any other attorney employed by the City or said bodies, or either of them insofar as legal matters are concerned, or any accountant similarly employed insofar as accounting matters are concerned, and of any actuaries similarly employed so far as actuarial matters are concerned. Any person having any claim under the System shall look solely to the assets of the fund for satisfaction to such claims. 
(P)  Small annuities; payments: Whenever any Retirement annuities shall be less than Ten Dollars ($10.00) per month, the Board of Trustees may elect to have payments made quarterly. If the Annuity payable at quarterly intervals shall be less than Ten Dollars ($10.00), the Board of Trustees may elect to pay the commuted value of the same, calculated at regular interest, for a lump sum. Such election shall be made within six (6) months after the Member's Retirement unless he or she consents in writing to a subsequent election by the Board of Trustees under this Section. 
(Q)  Filing defined: When any notice, election or other instrument is required or permitted by this Article to be filed with the Board of Trustees, the same may be filed with the Retirement Services Office. 
(R)  Timing of Benefit Payments: Monthly Retirement Benefit Payments shall be paid one (1) month in arrears and are distributed at the beginning of the month which next follows the month in which they became payable. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981; Ord. No. 2709, 4-27-2000; Ord. No. 2710, 4-27-2000; Ord. No. 3172, 10-9-2003; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3377, 9-22-2005; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 12, 10-22-2010; Ord. No. 3869, § 8, 10-24-2013)  
Sec. 17-225. - Future changes in the operation of the System. 
(A)  General: It is contemplated, and all original and new Members of the System shall be deemed to have notice that the City Council of this City may in the future decide that it is in the best interests of the City and the Members of the System to modify or terminate trust agreements or contracts entered into with an insurance company or companies, to exercise options available to the City under the terms of such trust agreements or contracts, to select another insurance company, trust, or other financial institution, as the depository for Pension funds. 
(B)  Power to amend: The City Council shall have continuous power to amend this Article. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981; Ord. No. 3726, § 13, 10-22-2010)  
Sec. 17-226. - Protection against fraud and deceit. 
Violations and punishments: Whosoever with intent to deceive shall make or cause to be made any statement, report, certificate, election notice, claim or other instrument authorized or required under this Article whether of the enumerated classes or otherwise, which shall be untrue, or who shall falsify or cause to commit to be falsified any record comprising any part of the operation or administration of the System contemplated by this Article shall be punished as follows: By a fine, not exceeding Three Hundred Dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment. Any such violation shall also be punishable as provided under the laws of the State of Florida. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981)  
Sec. 17-227. - Separability and construction. 
In the event any Section, Subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this Article shall be held to be invalid or unconstitutional such adjudication shall not in any matter affect the remaining portions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981)  
Sec. 17-228. - Repeal of conflicting Ordinances. 
All Ordinances and parts of Ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed to the extent of such conflict. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981)  
Sec. 17-229. - Effective date. 
This Article shall become effective November 13, 1971, following the legal jurisdiction as explicitly employed by President Nixon in his ninety-day salary freeze implemented on August 15, 1971, and all subsequent jurisdictions thereto. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1101, 9-10-1981)  
Sec. 17-230. - General Employees Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP). 
Subject to the provisions of this Section, the General Employees Deferred Retirement Option Program, hereinafter referred to as the DROP, is an option under which an eligible Member may elect to have the Member's Pension benefits calculated as of a date certain prior to Retirement, and accumulate benefits plus the investment return pursuant to this section during the DROP calculation period. Participation in the DROP does not guarantee employment with the City during any period of time, including the DROP calculation period as defined in this Section. 
(A)  Eligibility. In order to be eligible for the DROP option, the Member must meet the following eligibility criteria: 
(1)  General Employees (eligible Employees who are not Firefighters or Police Officers) must make the enrollment election either (i) on or after age sixty-two (62), provided such Member shall then have a minimum of ten (10) years of creditable Pension service as a General Employee with this Retirement System, or (ii) any time between obtaining a minimum of thirty (30) and a maximum of thirty-five (35) years of creditable Pension service as a General Employee with this Retirement System. Except that a General Employee who has performed services to the City under Articles III and/or IV shall have his or her combined periods of Creditable Service as a City Employee used for the purpose of satisfying the length of service requirements for entering DROP. Those Employees who as of the date of enactment of this DROP are beyond the dates allowed for election into the DROP, but are otherwise eligible for election into the DROP, shall have until March 17, 2000, to make the election to enroll into the DROP. 
(a)  Members who enter the DROP prior to October 1, 2011, are eligible for a five-year DROP calculation period following the date of entry. 
(b)  Members who enter the DROP on or after October 1, 2011 but prior to October 1, 2014, are eligible for a two-year DROP calculation period following the date of entry. 
(c)  Members who enter the DROP on or after October 1, 2014, are eligible for a three-year DROP calculation period following the date of entry. 
(2)  The Member must meet all eligibility requirements for normal Retirement benefits, other than separation from service as a General Employee. 
(3)  Upon electing to participate in the DROP, the Member shall submit on forms required by the City and the Board of Trustees: 
(a)  An irrevocable written election to participate in the DROP, specifying a DROP benefit beginning calculation date which shall be the first day of a pay period. This DROP benefit beginning calculation date is used to determine the DROP calculation period. 
(i)  For Members who enter the DROP prior to October 1, 2011, the DROP calculation period commences on the DROP benefit beginning calculation date and ends on the earlier of five (5) years from the date the Member entered the DROP; or the Member's separation from service as a General Employee or death. 
(ii)  For Members who enter the DROP on or after October 1, 2011 but prior to October 1, 2014, the DROP calculation period commences on the DROP benefit beginning calculation date and ends on the earlier of two (2) years from the date the Member entered the DROP; or the Member's separation from service as a General Employee or death. 
(iii)  For Members who enter the DROP on or after October 1, 2014, the DROP calculation period commences on the DROP benefit beginning calculation date and ends on the earlier of three (3) years from the date the Member entered the DROP; or the Member's separation from service as a General Employee or death; 
(b)  An irrevocable notice of employment termination as a General Employee to take effect upon the expiration of the DROP calculation period; provided that a DROP participant shall not be precluded from voluntarily terminating employment with the City before the expiration of the DROP calculation period, nor shall the City be precluded from terminating such DROP participant's employment as applicable due to disciplinary action, layoff, or other separation in accordance with the applicable collective bargaining agreement, civil service law, or other applicable law; 
(c)  Any other information required by the Board of Trustees. 
(4)  A Member may only make one (1) DROP election in this Retirement System during the Member's lifetime. 
(B)  Status. For Pension purposes only: 
(1)  During the DROP calculation period, there shall be no Pension contribution deductions made from the earnings, wages, salary, or compensation earned by the DROP participant. 
(2)  Upon entry into the DROP, a DROP participant shall no longer be entitled to Pension disability benefits pursuant to Section 17-211 or Pension death benefits pursuant to Section 17-214. 
(3)  Upon the death of a DROP participant, the named Beneficiary or beneficiaries shall be entitled to receive the benefits accumulated during the DROP calculation period as of the date of death. After the death of such DROP participant, Pension benefits shall be paid as required by Sections 17-209, 17-213 and 17-218. Eligibility to participate in the DROP terminates upon the death of such DROP participant. 
(4)  A DROP participant shall not be eligible to serve as an elected Member on the Board of Trustees. Any elected Member of the Board of Trustees who elects to participate in the DROP shall serve as a defacto Trustee until a replacement is elected in a special election. 
(C)  Benefits under the DROP. 
(1)  A DROP participant's monthly Pension benefits pursuant to Sections 17-209 and 17-213, and the effective date of the participant's Retirement, shall be determined based upon the effective date of the participant's DROP benefit beginning calculation date. 
(2)  The DROP accumulation shall be calculated as follows: 
(a)  The amount of the monthly benefits the Member would have been entitled to receive from the DROP benefit beginning calculation date to the end of the Member's DROP calculation period. 
(b)  The amount of any cost of living adjustments pursuant to Section 17-218 during the DROP benefit calculation period. 
(c)  Investment return accumulation as set forth in this Section. 
(3)  At the conclusion of the Member's DROP benefit calculation period, the Board of Trustees shall distribute the Member's benefits, subject to the following provisions: 
(a)  The Board of Trustees shall receive verification by the City that such DROP participant's employment as a General Employee has terminated. 
(b)  A terminated DROP participant or, if deceased, such participant's named Beneficiary or Beneficiaries, shall elect on forms provided by the Board of Trustees to receive the DROP benefits in accordance with one of the options provided in Subsection (E)1. Once a DROP participant terminates employment, no further investment returns shall be payable to the DROP participant. For a DROP participant or Beneficiary who fails to elect a method of payment within sixty (60) days of termination of DROP participation, the Board of Trustees will pay a lump sum as provided hereafter. 
(D)  Investment returns and administrative costs. Investment returns shall accumulate quarterly during the DROP calculation period, less the actual quarterly cost of administering the DROP, as determined by the Board of Trustees. 
(E)  Payment. 
(1)  Within ninety (90) days after the end of a calendar quarter following the separation of a Member as a General Employee, the balance in the Member's DROP account payable at the option of the terminated DROP participant, or if deceased, such participant's designated Beneficiary or Beneficiaries, shall be distributed, to the extent allowed by law, by rollover to another qualified plan, as a lump sum payment, or as a combination of both, as provided by rules and regulations adopted by the Board of Trustees, provided that such distribution may be adjusted by City Council to maintain Internal Revenue Code qualification of the Fund. 
(2)  If a DROP participant dies during the DROP calculation period, or on or before the DROP participants' full DROP accumulation is distributed, any remaining DROP accumulation shall be distributed to the DROP participant's designated Beneficiary or Beneficiaries, or, if there is no surviving designated Beneficiary, to the participant's spouse, or if there is no surviving designated Beneficiary and no surviving spouse, to the participant's estate. Any such payment shall be made in a lump sum payment, unless the participant had already commenced benefit payment of their DROP accumulation in an optional plan. In such an event, benefits shall continue to be paid pursuant to the optional benefit form selected. A DROP participants survivors are not eligible for Pension death benefits, pursuant to Section 17-214. 
(3)  The form of distribution elected by a DROP participant or surviving Beneficiary must comply with the applicable requirements of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(4)  The accumulated benefits of any DROP participant, including any investment returns thereon, shall not be subject to assignment, garnishment, execution, attachment, or to any legal process whatsoever, except income deduction orders as provided in F.S. § 61.1301, and federal income tax levies. 
(5)  Upon death or termination from employment as a General Employee, a DROP participant's other Pension benefits payable pursuant to Sections 17-209, 17-213 and 17-218 shall be paid in accordance with the requirements of those Sections. 
(F)  The Pension fund benefits of a DROP participant as calculated in accordance with Sections 17-209, 17-213 and 17-218 are to be maintained in the Pension fund for investment. The DROP account will be an account in a bookkeeping sense only until separation from employment as a General Employee and payout of the account. 
(G)  Administration of Program. The Board of Trustees shall make such rules as are necessary for the effective and efficient administration of this Section, provided that such rules are not inconsistent with the terms of any collective bargaining agreement entered into by the City and the certified bargaining agents for General Employees concerning the DROP. The Board of Trustees shall not be required to advise Members of the federal tax consequences of an election related to the DROP but may advise Members to seek independent advice. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Section to the contrary, any provision of this Section shall be construed and administered in such manner that such program will qualify as a qualified governmental Pension plan under existing or hereafter enacted provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of the United States, and City Council may adopt any rule necessary to accomplish the purpose of this Section as is necessary to retain tax qualification. 
(H)  Funds are not transferrable from the Pension fund into any other investment vehicle during the DROP calculation period for any Employee. 
(I)  Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP) Participants as of March 31, 2005: 
(1)  An Employee who is a DROP participant as of March 31, 2005, shall have an election to (a) continue having his or her DROP balance debited or credited, as the case may be, in an amount equal to the return experienced by the fund, such returns to be computed quarterly; or (b) effective April 1, 2005, earn a fixed rate of return of six (6) percent, such return to be credited annually on each September 30, provided however, if a DROP participant separates from service prior to September 30, his or her DROP balance will be credited with a prorated fixed annual rate of return for the period beginning on the October 1 preceding separation from service and ending on the date of separation from service. 
(2)  Prior to April 15, 2005, the Board of Trustees shall provide: (a) a written notice of the right to elect either option described above in Subsection (I)(1), above; and (b) an election form to each Employee who is a DROP participant on March 31, 2005. 
(3)  An Employee who is a DROP participant as of March 31, 2005, must make the election described in Subsection (I)(1), above, no later than April 15, 2005. A DROP participant makes the election by returning a completed election form to the Board of Trustees. 
(4)  An Employee who is a DROP participant as of March 31, 2005, who does not make a timely election to earn a fixed rate of return on his or her DROP balance shall be "deemed" to have elected to continue to have his or her DROP balance debited or credited, as the case may be, in an amount equal to the return experienced by the fund, such returns to be computed quarterly. 
(5)  Once a DROP participant makes the election described in the preceding Sections, he or she may not change the election during the remaining period of the Employee's participation in DROP. 
(6)  If an Employee who is a DROP participant as of March 31, 2005, elects to have fixed earnings attributed to his DROP balance, then such election will apply prospectively. The Board of Trustees will determine the DROP participant's balance as of March 31, 2005, and then shall credit earnings as provided in Subsection (I) (1). 
(J)  Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP) Entrants on or After April 1, 2005 but prior to October 1, 2011: 
(1)  An Employee who enters DROP on or after April 1, 2005, shall have an election to: 
(a)  Have his or her DROP balance debited or credited, as the case may be, in an amount equal to the return experienced by the fund, such returns to be computed quarterly; or 
(b)  Earn a fixed rate of return of six (6) percent, such return to be computed annually as of September 30, provided however, if a DROP participant separates from service prior to September 30, his or her DROP balance will be credited with a prorated fixed annual rate of return for the period beginning on the October 1 preceding separation from service and ending on the date of separation from service (unless it is the first year of DROP participation in which investment returns shall be credited based upon length of participation in the DROP). 
(2)  The Employee's election of an option as set forth in Subsection (A)(1), above, shall be made prior to the Employee's entry into DROP and may not be changed during the period of the Employee's participation in DROP. 
(3)  The Board of Trustees shall provide: (a) a written notice of the right to elect either option described above in Subsection (J)(1), above; and (b) an election form to each eligible Employee. 
(K)  Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP) Entrants on or after October 1, 2011 but prior to October 1, 2014: 
An Employee who enters DROP on or after October 1, 2011 but prior to October 1, 2014, shall have his or her DROP balance adjusted quarterly by an amount equal to the positive or negative return experienced by the fund after expenses. However, the maximum positive quarterly return shall be .75 percent (.75%) and there shall be no limit on the maximum negative quarterly return (loss). 
(L)  Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP) entrants on or after October 1, 2014 who are not subject to and governed by subsection (J) or (K) and who remain employed on or after October 1, 2016: 
(1)  Shall be eligible for a maximum DROP calculation period of three (3) years, but not to exceed a total of creditable Pension service and DROP service of thirty-eight (38) years. 
(2)  Shall have his or her DROP accumulated balance computed and adjusted quarterly by an amount equal to the positive or negative net investment return experienced by the Pinellas Park General Employees' Pension Fund, less the actual quarterly cost of administering the DROP, as determined by the Board of Trustees. Provided however, the maximum net positive quarterly return shall be .75 percent (0.75%) and the maximum net negative quarterly return shall be .75 percent (0.75%). 
(Ord. No. 2663, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2948, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 3325, 4-14-2005; Ord. No. 3458, 7-27-2006; Ord. No. 3726, § 14, 10-22-2010; Ord. No. 3773, § 1, 7-28-2011; Ord. No. 3994, § 1, 9-22-2016)  
ARTICLE III. - RETIREMENT SYSTEM FOR FIREFIGHTERS 
 
Sec. 17-301. - Short title. 
This Article shall be known and cited as the "Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund". 
(Ord. No. 2632, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-302. - Consolidation of existing system and preservation of rights. 
(A)  Any officer or Employee who is elected, appointed or employed by the City of Pinellas Park, Florida after the effective date of this system (November 13, 1971) shall not be eligible for membership, rights or any privileges under Ordinance No. 279. 
(B)  The rights of Members of the Employees pension plan of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, established by Ordinance No. 279, shall not be impaired nor shall their benefits be reduced by virtue of any part of this Article. Upon passage of this Article they shall be subject to the provisions of the "Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund" established by this Article and at retirement shall have his benefits calculated in accordance with the provisions of Section 17-309 of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 2632, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-303. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases as used in this Article, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, shall have the meanings hereafter set forth, and the same and similar terms when used in connection with any personnel classification System or any other Ordinance for the City of Pinellas Park shall not necessarily apply to the Members of the System hereby created except when specifically adopted. 
Accumulated Contributions: Means the sum of a Member's contribution, if any, without interest received after the effective date of employment. 
Actuary: Means a fellow of the Society of Actuaries or a Member of the American Academy of Actuaries or an organization of which one (1) or more Members is a fellow of the Society of Actuaries or a Member of the American Academy of Actuaries or both. 
Actuarial Equivalent: A benefit of equal value or equal cost when computed on the basis of such interest rates, mortality and other actuarial tables as are in effect under the System. 
Annual Compensation: 
(A)  For Firefighters hired prior to October 1, 2009, means the total compensation paid a Member during a year, exclusive of bonuses; a "year" is the calendar year. 
(B)  For Firefighters hired on or after October 1, 2009, means the Firefighters' fixed monthly remuneration including: holiday pay, lump sum payout for Employees at the top of their pay grade, and incentive pays; but excluding hours which are not part of the Employee's fixed monthly remuneration; bonuses; or payments for unused sick time or vacation hours. 
(C)  For all Creditable Service earned after December 27, 2011 the definition of Annual Compensation for all Members who are not then currently eligible for Normal Retirement as of that date, regardless of their date of hire, includes the Firefighters' fixed monthly remuneration, holiday pay, lump sum payout for Employees at the top of their pay grade, and incentive payments; but excludes bonuses and payments for unused sick time or vacation hours. Up to 300 hours per calendar year paid at the overtime rate shall be included, but all hours in excess of 300 hours per calendar year paid at the overtime rate shall be excluded. 
(D)  Firefighters who become eligible for Normal Retirement prior to December 28, 2011, shall have their Annual Compensation determined pursuant to subsection (A) above. 
Annuity: Annual payments which shall be payable in equal monthly installments on the first day of each month during his or her lifetime or as otherwise provided for in this Article. Such payments shall be made on a calendar month basis and the payment for any month may be prorated if appropriate. 
Average Final Compensation: Effective July 1, 2005, Average Final Compensation means the greater of (A) or (B) defined as follows: 
(A)  The average of a Member's calendar years of compensation for the three (3) calendar years (whether or not consecutive) of the last five (5) calendar years of Membership service preceding the date of determination that yields the greatest average. 
(B)  The average of a Member's calendar years of compensation for the five (5) calendar years (whether or not consecutive) of the last ten (10) calendar years of Membership service preceding the date of determination that yields the greatest average. 
In determining the three (3) or five (5) calendar years of compensation that yield the greatest average pursuant to subsection (A) or (B), respectively, the inclusion of partial calendar years of compensation in the determination of Average Final Compensation is as follows: 
(C)  If a Member's final calendar year of Membership service is not a complete calendar year, such corresponding final calendar year of compensation will be annualized by dividing the Member's final calendar year of compensation by the number of complete calendar months of Membership service completed by the Member during the Member's final calendar year of Membership service and multiplying this result by twelve (12). The resulting annualized, partial calendar year of compensation is then compared to the Member's next preceding four (4) or nine (9) calendar years of compensation (pursuant to subsection (A) or (B), respectively) for purposes of identifying the calendar years of compensation that will yield the greatest three (3) or five (5) year average. The resulting annualized, partial calendar year of compensation is used only to determine if the Member's final calendar year of compensation is among the Member's greatest three (3) or five (5) years of calendar year compensation. 
(D)  If, after determining the Member's annualized, final calendar year of compensation pursuant to subsection (C) as applicable, such annualized, final calendar year of compensation is among the Member's greatest three (3) or five (5) years of calendar year compensation (pursuant to subsection (A) or (B), respectively) the Member's third or fifth greatest calendar year of compensation (pursuant to subsection (A) or (B), respectively) is then prorated complementarily to the annualized, final calendar year of compensation by dividing such third or fifth greatest calendar year of compensation by twelve (12) and multiplying this result by the difference between twelve (12) and the number of complete calendar months of Membership service completed by the Member during the Member's final calendar year of Membership service. 
(E)  In annualizing the Member's partial final or prorating the Member's third or fifth calendar year of compensation pursuant to subsection (C) or (D), as applicable, a complete calendar year of Membership service is considered Membership service from January 1 through December 15 of any calendar year and a complete calendar month of Membership service is considered Membership service from the first day of any calendar month through the fifteenth day of any calendar month. 
Average Monthly Compensation: Means one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of Average Final Compensation. 
Beneficiary: Any person in receipt of, or entitled to, an Annuity, Retirement allowance or other benefits as provided by this Article. 
Board of Trustees: The appointed and elected Members of the Board of Trustees as provided in Section 17-322(A). 
Charter: The Charter of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida as amended. 
City: The City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
City's Contribution: The annual contribution needed to fund actuarially the liability for Annuities credited to Employees on the basis of actuarial methods and assumptions approved by the Board of Trustees. 
Council: City Council of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
Creditable Service: Of any Member means the sum of his or her Past Service, Prior Service, Volunteer Firefighter Service, Military Service and Future Service allowed within the provisions of this Article, provided, all required contributions have been paid and all other requirements of this Article have been met. However, in no case shall a Member receive credit for more than one (1) year's service during any twelve-month period. Such service shall be computed to the nearest whole month of completed service but not including any fractional parts of a month. Creditable Service shall also mean the aggregate number of years of service, and fractional parts of years of service, of any Firefighter, omitting intervening years and fractional parts of years when such Firefighter may not have been employed by the City of Pinellas Park, subject to the following conditions: 
(A)  No Firefighter will receive credit for years or fractional parts of years of service if he or she has withdrawn his or her contributions to the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund for those years or fractional parts of years of service, unless the Firefighter repays into the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund the amount he or she has withdrawn, plus interest determined by the Board of Trustees. The Member shall have a maximum of ninety (90) days after his or her reemployment to make repayment. The Member shall be responsible for payment of costs for professional services rendered to the Board of Trustees in connection with the purchase of Creditable Service. 
(B)  A Firefighter may voluntarily leave his or her Accumulated Contributions in the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund for a period of five (5) years after leaving the employ of the fire department, pending the possibility of being rehired by the same department, without losing credit for the time he or she has participated actively as a Firefighter. If he or she is not reemployed as a Firefighter, with the same department, within five (5) years, the Accumulated Contributions shall be returned without interest. 
(C)  Creditable Service shall be provided, as specifically authorized herein, only for service as a Firefighter, as defined in F.S. § 175.032(8), Military Service or service as a volunteer Firefighter with the City of Pinellas Park, and shall not include credit for any other type of service. 
(D)  In determining the Creditable Service of any Firefighter, credit for up to five (5) years of the time spent in the Military Service of the Armed Forces of the United States shall be added to the years of actual service if: 
1.  The Firefighter is in the active employ of the City of Pinellas Park immediately prior to such service and leaves a position, other than a temporary position, for the purpose of voluntary or involuntary service in the Armed Forces of the United States. 
2.  The Firefighter is entitled to reemployment under the provisions of the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act. 
3.  The Firefighter returns to his or her employment as a Firefighter of the City of Pinellas Park within one (1) year from the date of release from such active service. 
(E)  In determining the Creditable Service of any Firefighter, credit as a volunteer Firefighter for the City of Pinellas Park prior to October 1, 1985, shall be added to the years of actual service if: 
1.  The Firefighter did not have a break in service between his or her Volunteer Firefighter Service and regular employment as a Firefighter. 
2.  The Firefighter pays into the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund the required pension contributions for the period of Volunteer Firefighter Service, plus the actuarially determined interest. The required pension contribution shall be equal to the contribution rate in effect at the time the service was earned, but not less than one (1) percent of pension eligible compensation. Interest shall be computed from the time the service was earned until the Firefighter purchases the pension credit. 
3.  The Firefighter is an active Member of this plan and is employed by the City as a Firefighter on December 13, 2001. 
Provided, however, the Firefighter shall not receive Creditable Service for both Volunteer Firefighter Service and regular service for the same period of employment. 
(F)  Creditable Service for Fire Inspector/Investigators, shall be determined as follows: 
1.  Actual service as a Fire Inspector/Investigator prior to March 20, 2002, shall be included as Creditable Service as a General Employee and shall be calculated in accordance with the provisions of the Pinellas Park General Employees' Pension Fund. 
2.  Actual service as a Fire Inspector/Investigator on or after March 20, 2002, shall also be calculated in accordance with and shall be credited for all purposes under the provisions of the Pinellas Park General Employees' Pension Fund if such Fire Inspector/Investigator is not certified as a Firefighter within the period of time provided for in F.S. § 633.35. 
3.  With respect to an individual who is employed as a Fire Inspector/Investigator on March 20, 2002, and who has met the certification requirements of F.S. § 633.35, on March 20, 2002, service as a Fire Inspector/Investigator on or after March 20, 2002, shall be calculated in accordance with and shall be credited for all purposes under the provisions of the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund. If an individual is hired as a Fire Inspector/Investigator on or after March 20, 2002, and is certified under F.S. § 633.35, on his or her date of hire, such individual's service as a Fire Inspector/Investigator shall be calculated in accordance with and shall be credited for all purposes under the provisions of the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund. If an individual was employed as a Fire Inspector/Investigator on March 20, 2002, and had not met the certification requirements of F.S. § 633.35, then such Fire Inspector/Investigator shall be treated as a Fire Inspector/Investigator on March 20, 2002, if such individual meets the certification requirements of F.S. § 633.35, within the period of time allowed by F.S. § 633.35, and such individual's service as a Fire Inspector/Investigator on or after March 20, 2002, shall be calculated in accordance with and shall be credited for all purposes under the provisions of the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund. If an individual is hired as a Fire Inspector/Investigator on or after March 20, 2002, and is not certified under F.S. § 633.35, on his or her date of hire, such individual shall be treated as a Fire Inspector/Investigator from his or her date of employment as a Fire Inspector/Investigator if such individual meets the certification requirements of F.S. § 633.35, within the period of time allowed by F.S. § 633.35, and such individual's service as a Fire Inspector/Investigator shall be calculated in accordance with and shall be credited for all purposes under the provisions of the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund. 
4.  Any individual who is employed as a Fire Inspector/Investigator and fails to meet the certification requirements of F.S. § 633.35, within the period of time allowed by F.S. § 633.35, then such individual shall gain no Creditable Service in the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund for the period on or after March 20, 2002, during which he or she made contributions to the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund; however, provided that such Employee shall otherwise meet all applicable requirements, he or she shall be considered as a Member of the Pinellas Park General Employees' Pension Fund and entitled to Creditable Service therein for such period of time on or after March 20, 2002. 
5.  Any individual who is employed as a Fire Inspector/Investigator on or after March 20, 2002, shall be entitled to a refund of any Employee contributions (without interest) made during such period under this Article if he or she is not certified as a Firefighter within the period of time provided for in F.S. § 633.35. 
(G)  This paragraph is intended to satisfy the minimum requirements of USERRA. To the extent that this paragraph does not meet the minimum standards of USERRA, as it may be amended from time to time, the minimum standards shall apply. In the event an active Member dies on or after January 1, 2007, while performing USERRA Qualified Military Service, the beneficiaries of the Member are entitled to death benefits as provided for in Section 17-314(A) or Section 17-314(B) as if the Member resumed employment and then died while employed; provided that all Qualified Military Service shall be included in calculating the vesting period, but only up to five (5) years of Military Service shall be included in calculating the benefit amount. 
Death In Line of Duty: Means death arising out of and in the actual performance of duty required by a Member's employment during his or her regularly scheduled working hours or irregular working hours as required by the City. The Trustees may require such proof as deemed necessary as to the time, date and cause of death, including evidence from any available witnesses. (Workers' Compensation records under the provisions of F.S. ch. 440, may also be used). 
Disability In Line of Duty: Means an injury or illness arising out of and in the actual performance of duty as required by a Member's employment during his or her regularly scheduled working hours or irregular working hours as required by the City. The Trustees may require such proof as deemed necessary as to the time, date and cause of any such injury or illness, including evidence from any available witness. (Workers' Compensation records under the provisions of F.S. ch. 440, may also be used). 
Dual Service: Means having Creditable Service under more than one Pension fund within the City of Pinellas Park Retirement System. 
Early Retirement Date: Means the first day of the month following the date a Member completes ten (10) years of Creditable Service and applies for and is granted Retirement benefits in accordance with this Article. 
Effective Date of the System: The date on which the operation of the System is to commence for the purpose of determining eligibility, benefits, and related matters, which is hereby fixed as the thirteenth day of November, 1971. 
Employee: All persons employed by the City and so classified under personnel records of the City, including "probationary" or "regular" Employees. Any appointed officer shall only be qualified under this System under one (1) office and that office being the one from which he or she receives the largest annual salary, compensation or remuneration. Independent contractors are excluded. Part-time Employees are excluded. Temporary Employees are excluded. 
Firefighter: Means an Employee employed by the City of Pinellas Park in a position of Firefighter as that term is defined in F.S. ch. 175. 
Future Service: Of any Member means service subsequent to date of the Member's participation and may include authorized leaves of absence as provided in Section 17-320. 
Gender: The masculine pronoun shall include the feminine gender. 
Member: Means any officer or Employee who is a Firefighter who is covered or who becomes covered under the System in accordance with this Article. 
Military Service: Shall mean "Qualified Military Service" as defined in Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
New Member: Any Employee who becomes a Member of the System after the Effective Date of the System. 
Normal Form of Benefit: Shall mean Option B in Section 17-313. 
Normal Retirement Date and Normal Retirement Age: Means the first day of the month following the date such Member has completed ten (10) or more years of Creditable Service and: 
1.  Attains age fifty-five (55); or 
2.  Completes or would have completed twenty-five (25) continuous years of Creditable Service, regardless of age. 
Original Member: Any Employee of the City who becomes a Member as of the Effective Date of the System. 
Past Service: Of any Member means the number of years, complete months, recognized and credited by the City and approved by the Trustees, during which he or she was in the active employ of the City prior to the Effective Date of the System. 
Past Service Redeemed: Means a Member redeems Past Service at the ratio of one (1) for one (1) basis for each year or completed month for such service earned subsequent to the effective date of this Article. All such redeemed service will be computed (for Retirement purposes) in accordance with the provisions of Section 17-309 of this Article. 
Pension: Means monthly payments to a retiree derived as provided in this System. 
Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund: The System of Retirement benefits provided under this Article. 
Prior Service: Of any Member means that service for which the Member had credit under Ordinance No. 279. 
Retirement or Retire: Withdrawal from active employment by the City with Retirement income applied for and granted under the provisions of this System or entry into the Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP). A Member who has elected to participate in the Firefighters' Deferred Retirement Option Program shall be deemed to have Retired for purposes of this Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund. 
Social Security Coverage: Means old age, survivors, disability and health insurance as provided by the Federal Social Security Act. 
System: Shall mean the Pinellas Park Retirement System. 
Treasurer: The Treasurer of the City, who is the City Finance Administrator, shall comply with the provisions of F.S. § 175.301. 
Trustee: Shall mean a Member of the Board of Trustees. 
Trust Fund: Means the Trust Fund established in the designated place or places (as determined by the Trustees) by this Article for the purpose of holding and investing the contributions paid by Members of the City of Pinellas Park, and all gifts and donations to the Trust Fund, and paying the benefits to which Members or their Beneficiaries may become entitled. 
Vested: Shall mean that the Member has met the age and/or service requirements to be eligible to receive a Retirement benefit. 
Volunteer Firefighter Service: Service rendered as a volunteer Firefighter for the City of Pinellas Park prior to October 1, 1985. 
(Ord. No. 2632, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2666, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2765, 9-21-2000; Ord. No. 2953, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 2992, 4-25-2002; Ord. No. 3344, 6-23-2005; Ord. No. 3699, § 1, 9-24-2009; Ord. No. 3790, § 1, 1-12-2012; Ord. No. 3856, § 1, 9-12-2013)  
Sec. 17-304. - Administration of System; appropriation. 
The Trustees shall make such rules and regulations as are necessary for the effective and efficient administration of this system. The Trustees shall cause an actuarial study of the system to be made at such intervals as may be required by law, but in any event at least every two (2) years, and shall provide a copy of each such study to the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 2632, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3344, 6-23-2005)  
Sec. 17-305. - Consolidation of liabilities and assets; existing plan. 
(A)  Effective October 1, 1999, the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund shall assume: 
1.  All liabilities related to the payment of benefits to Firefighters and their beneficiaries. 
2.  All obligations in regard to funding and administering benefits accrued for the benefit of Firefighters, Beneficiaries and survivors. 
3.  All assets which are attributable to Firefighters. 
(B)  Benefits unassignable and not subject to process: The right of any Member or any Beneficiary to any benefits under the system or any other right accrued or accruing to any persons under the provisions of this Article and the accumulated contributions and the cash securities in the funds created under this Article shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of any bankruptcy or insolvency law or any other process of law whatsoever and shall not be subject to assignment, pledge or hypothecation unless expressly authorized in this Article. 
(C)  Errors, corrections, and adjustments: Should any change or error in the records of the system be discovered or any error in any calculation be made resulting in any Member or Beneficiary receiving from the system more or less than he or she was entitled to receive, the Board of Trustees shall have the power to correct such error and as far as possible to adjust the payments thereafter to be made in such a manner that the actuarially equivalent of the benefit to which such Member or Beneficiary was correctly entitled to be paid. 
(D)  Payments in case of legal or other disability: Whenever and/or as often as a person entitled to payments hereunder shall be under legal disability, or, in the sole judgment of the Board of Trustees shall otherwise be unable to apply such payments to his best interests and advantage, the Board of Trustees in the exercise of its discretion may direct that all or any portion of the benefits of such Members payable in any one (1) or more of the following ways: 
1.  Directly to such person. 
2.  To his legal guardian or conservator. 
3.  To his spouse or to any person to be expended for his benefit. 
The decision of the Board of Trustees shall in each case be final and binding on all persons, including the affected Member of the system. 
(Ord. No. 2632, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3699, § 2, 9-24-2009)  
Sec. 17-306. - Contributions and funding. 
(A)  Cost of the system. The cost of the system will be borne by the City of Pinellas Park, by Firefighters of the City of Pinellas Park, by State Remittances to finance retirement of Firefighters in accordance with F.S. ch. 175, and by such other funding sources as may be provided by law. 
(B)  City's contributions. The City shall pay into the Trust Fund amounts required to provide the benefits under this system as shall be determined by an actuarial investigation as provided in Section 17-304. City's contributions shall be deposited at least quarterly. 
(C)  Employee's contributions. Members shall, effective for earnings paid for pay period beginning February 10, 1999, contribute each pay period at the rate of five (5) percent of gross compensation. Commencing with earnings paid June 26, 2002, and thereafter, all mandatory Employee contributions to the fire pension fund shall be picked up and paid by the City in accordance with Section 414(h) of the Internal Revenue Code and shall be treated as tax-deferred employer pick-up contributions. Member contributions picked up under the provisions of this Section shall be treated as City contributions for purposes of determining income tax obligations under the Internal Revenue Code; however, such picked up Member contributions shall be included in the determination of the Member's gross annual compensation. The Member's contributions picked up under this Section shall continue to be designated Member contributions and shall be considered as part of the Member's compensation for purposes of determining the amount of the Member's contributions. The provisions of this Section are mandatory, and the Member shall have no option concerning the pick-up or to receive the contributed amounts directly instead of having them paid by the City to the fire pension fund. The picked up amounts shall be included as wages for FICA purposes. In consideration of collectively bargained increases in benefits provided to the Members of the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund, effective with the first day of the payroll period which includes October 1, 2009, Members shall contribute each pay period at the rate of nine (9) percent of all pension eligible compensation. 
(D)  Social Security contributions. Contributions for Social Security and by the City in the amount required for Social Security coverage as now or hereafter provided by the Federal Social Security Act, shall be in addition to contributions specified in Subsection (B). 
(E)  Gifts to the Fund. The Board of Trustees may accept gifts, bequests, devises or appropriations to or for the fund from any source, but shall have the right to reject the same if they are so conditional as to conflict with the Charter or this Article or to make the administration of the same unreasonably difficult. The Board of Trustees shall promptly deposit such gifts, bequests, devises or appropriations with the custodian. 
(F)  Reserved. 
(G)  Investment of the Fund. All monies paid into and held by the retirement system shall be promptly deposited with the custodian. 
(H)  Funds received from State. All State and other funds received by the City pursuant to F.S. ch. 175, shall be deposited by the City immediately and under no circumstances more than five (5) days after receipt, with the Board of Trustees. The City Manager may provide authorization to the Division of Retirement of the State of Florida for the direct payment of the premium tax to the Board of Trustees.
