If it is determined by the Internal Revenue Service Code that any provision of the Share Program which cannot be corrected, or the operation or administration of the Share Program that cannot be corrected, such as to disqualify the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund from being tax exempt under the applicable provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, then all assets of the Share Program shall be used to provide "extra benefits" in such a manner as to not disqualify the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund. 
(P)  Cost of claims to the City. The Board of Trustees of the Pinellas Park Firefighters' Pension Fund, solely out of the assets of the Share Program, shall reimburse the City of Pinellas Park and its officers, agents, staff, and employees for all of its financial losses due to any claims, demands, damages, fines, expenses, fees, suits, proceedings, actions and costs of actions, including appeals, and including attorneys' fees of any kind or nature arising from the creation, implementation, operation, and administration of the Share Program. 
(Ord. No. 3699, § 16, 9-24-2009)  
ARTICLE IV. - RETIREMENT SYSTEM FOR POLICE OFFICERS 
 
Sec. 17-401. - Short title. 
This Article shall be known and cited as the "Pinellas Park Police Officers' Pension Fund". 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-402. - Consolidation of existing system and preservation of rights. 
(A)  Any officer or Employee who is elected, appointed or employed by the City of Pinellas Park, Florida after the effective date of this system (November 13, 1971) shall not be eligible for membership, rights or any privileges under Ordinance No. 279. 
(B)  The rights of Members of the Employees pension plan of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida, established by Ordinance No. 279, shall not be impaired nor shall their benefits be reduced by virtue of any part of this Article. Upon passage of this Article they shall be subject to the provisions of the "Pinellas Park Police Officers' Pension Fund" established by this Article and at retirement shall have his benefits calculated in accordance with the provisions of Section 17-409 of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-403. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases as used in this Article, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, shall have the meanings hereafter set forth, and the same and similar terms when used in connection with any personnel classification or any other Ordinance for the City of Pinellas Park shall not necessarily apply to the Members of the retirement system hereby created except when specifically adopted: 
Accumulated contributions: Means the sum of a Member's contribution, if any, without interest received after the effective date of employment. 
Actuary: Means a fellow of the Society of Actuaries or a Member of the American Academy of Actuaries or an organization of which one (1) or more Members is a fellow of the Society of Actuaries or a Member of the American Academy of Actuaries or both. 
Actuarial equivalent: A benefit of equal value or equal cost when computed on the basis of such interest rates, mortality and other actuarial tables as are in effect under the system. 
Annual compensation: 
(A)  Means the total cash remuneration including overtime of up to three hundred (300) hours paid to a Police Officer for services rendered to the City, during a year. A "year" is the calendar year. Compensation for services rendered to a secondary employer after October 1, 2009 is not included in the definition of Annual Compensation. 
(B)  For all Creditable Service earned on or after September 18, 2013 the definition of Annual Compensation for all Members who are not then already eligible for Normal Retirement, as of that date, is defined to include the following: pay for hours worked while rendering services to the City, sick, vacation, and personal hours used; holiday pay, lump sum payout for employees at the top of their pay grade, and incentive pays. The definition of Annual Compensation shall exclude the following: all other compensation not specifically included, pay for overtime hours which are in excess of three hundred (300) hours per calendar year, bonuses, and payouts for any accrued but unused sick or vacation hours regardless of when they were accrued . However, payouts for Pre-87 sick hours shall be included as Annual Compensation. 
(C)  Police Officers who become eligible for Normal Retirement prior to September 18, 2013, shall have their Annual Compensation determined pursuant to subsection A. 
Annuity: Annual payments which shall be payable in equal monthly installments on the first day of each month during his or her lifetimes or as otherwise provided for in this Article. Such payments shall be made on a calendar month basis and the payment for any month may be prorated if appropriate. 
Average final compensation: Means, effective for Members separating from employment as a Police Officer or entering DROP on or after January 1, 2010, the three (3) calendar years of membership that yields the highest average. In determining the three (3) calendar years of compensation that yield the greatest average, the inclusion of partial calendar years of compensation in the determination of average final compensation is as follows: 
(A)  If a Member's final calendar year of creditable service is not a complete calendar year, such corresponding final calendar year of compensation will be annualized by dividing the Member's final calendar year of compensation by the number of complete calendar months of service and multiplying this result by twelve (12). The resulting annualized, partial calendar year of compensation is used only to determine if the Member's final calendar year of compensation is among the Member's greatest three (3) years of calendar year compensation. 
(B)  If the Member's final calendar year of compensation pursuant to subsection (A), is among the Member's greatest three (3) years of calendar year compensation, the Member's third greatest calendar year of compensation is then prorated complementarily to the annualized, final calendar year of compensation by dividing such third greatest calendar year of compensation by twelve (12) and multiplying this result by the difference between twelve (12) and the number of complete calendar months of membership service completed by the Member during the Member's final calendar year of Membership service. 
(C)  In annualizing the Member's partial final or prorating the Member's third calendar year of compensation pursuant to subsection (A) or (B), as applicable, a complete calendar year of creditable service is considered membership service from January 1 through December 15 of any calendar year and a complete calendar month of membership service is considered membership service from the first day of any calendar month through the fifteenth day of any calendar month. 
Average monthly compensation: Means one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of average final compensation. 
Beneficiary: Any person in receipt of, or entitled to, an annuity, retirement allowance or other benefits as provided by this Article. 
Board of Trustees: The appointed and elected Members of the Board of Trustees as provided in Section 17-424(B). 
Charter: The Charter of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida as amended. 
City: The City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
City's contribution: The annual contribution needed to fund actuarially the liability for annuities credited to Employees on the basis of actuarial methods and assumptions approved by the Board of Trustees. 
Council: City Council of the City of Pinellas Park, Florida. 
Creditable service: Of any Member means the sum of his or her past service, prior service, military service and future service allowed within the provisions of this Article, provided, all required contributions have been paid and all other requirements of this Article have been met. However, in no case shall a Member receive credit for more than one (1) year's service during any twelve (12) month period. Such service shall be computed to the nearest whole month of completed service but not including any fractional parts of a month. Creditable service shall also mean the aggregate number of years of service and fractional parts of years of service of any Police Officer, omitting intervening years and fractional parts of years when such Police Officer may not have been employed by the City of Pinellas Park subject to the following conditions: 
(A)  No Police Officer will receive credit for years or fractional parts of years of service if he or she has withdrawn his or her contributions to the fund for those years or fractional parts of years of service, unless the Police Officer repays into the fund the amount he or she has withdrawn, plus interest as determined by the Board. The Member shall have a maximum of ninety (90) days after his or her reemployment to make repayment. The Member shall be responsible for payment of costs for professional services rendered to the Board in connection with the purchase of creditable service. 
(B)  A Police Officer may voluntarily leave his or her Accumulated Contributions in the Fund for a period of five (5) years after leaving the employ of the police department, pending the possibility of his or her being rehired by the same department, without losing credit for the time he or she has participated actively as a Police Officer. If he or she is not reemployed as a Police Officer with the same department within five (5) years, his or her Accumulated Contributions shall be returned to him or her without interest. 
(C)  Creditable service shall be provided, as specifically authorized herein, only for service as a Police Officer, as defined in F.S. § 185.02(11), or for military service and shall not include credit for any other type of service. 
(D)  In determining the creditable service of any Police Officer, credit for up to five (5) years of the time spent in the military service of the Armed Forces of the United States shall be added to the years of actual service, if: 
1.  The Police Officer is in the active employ of the City of Pinellas Park prior to such service and leaves a position, other than a temporary position, for the purpose of voluntary or involuntary service in the Armed Forces of the United States. 
2.  The Police Officer is entitled to reemployment under the provisions of the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act. 
3.  The Police Officer returns to his or her employment as a Police Officer of the City of Pinellas Park within one (1) year from the date of his or her release from such active service. 
(E)  This paragraph is intended to satisfy the minimum requirements of USERRA. To the extent that this paragraph does not meet the minimum standards of USERRA, as it may be amended from time to time, the minimum standards shall apply. In the event an active Member dies on or after January 1, 2007, while performing USERRA Qualified Military Service, the beneficiaries of the Member are entitled to death benefits as provided for in Section 17-414(A) or Section 17-414(B) as if the Member resumed employment and then died while employed; provided that all Qualified Military Service shall be included in calculating the vesting period, but only up to five (5) years of Military Service shall be included in calculating the benefit amount. 
Death in line of duty: Means death arising out of and in the actual performance of duty required by a Member's employment during his or her regularly scheduled working hours or irregular working hours as required by the City. The Trustees may require such proof as deemed necessary as to the time, date and cause of death, including evidence from any available witnesses. (Workers' compensation records under the provisions of F.S. ch. 440, may also be used). 
Disability in line of duty: Means an injury or illness arising out of and in the actual performance of duty as required by a Member's employment during his or her regularly scheduled working hours or irregular working hours as required by the City. The Trustees may require such proof as deemed necessary as to the time, date and cause of any such injury or illness, including evidence from any available witness. (Workers' compensation records under the provisions of F.S. ch. 440, may also be used). 
Dual service: Means having creditable service under more than one (1) pension fund within the City of Pinellas Park. 
Early retirement date: Means the first day of the month following the date a Member completes ten (10) years of creditable service and applies for and is granted retirement benefits in accordance with this Article. 
Effective date of the system: The date on which the operation of the system is to commence for the purpose of determining eligibility, benefits, and related matters, which is hereby fixed as the thirteenth day of November, 1971. 
Employee: All persons employed by the City and so classified under personnel records of the City, including "probationary" or "regular" Employees. Any appointed officer shall only be qualified under this system under one (1) office and that office being the one from which he or she receives the largest annual salary, compensation or remuneration. Independent contractors are excluded. Part-time Employees are excluded. Temporary Employees are excluded. 
Future service: Of any Member means service subsequent to date of the member's participation and may include authorized leaves of absence as provided in Section 17-420. 
Gender: The masculine pronoun shall include the feminine gender. 
Member: Means any officer or Employee who is a Police Officer who is covered or who becomes covered under the system in accordance with this Article. 
Military service: Shall mean "Qualified Military Service" as defined in Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
New Member: Any "Employee" who becomes a Member of the system after the effective date of the system. 
Normal form of benefit: Shall mean Option B in Section 17-413. 
Normal retirement date and normal retirement age: Means the first day of the month following the date such Member has completed ten (10) or more years of creditable service and: 
1.  Attains age fifty-five (55); or 
2.  Completes or would have completed twenty-five (25) continuous years of creditable service, regardless of age. 
Original Member: Any "Employee" of the City who becomes a Member as of the effective date of the system. 
Past service: Of any Member means the number of years, complete months, recognized and credited by the City and approved by the trustees, during which he or she was in the active employ of the City prior to the effective date of this system. 
Past service redeemed: Means a Member redeems past service at the ratio of one (1) for one (1) basis for each year or completed month for such service earned subsequent to the effective date of this Article. All such redeemed service will be computed (for retirement purposes) in accordance with the provisions of Section 17-409 of this Article. 
Pension: Means monthly payments to a retiree derived as provided in this system. 
Pinellas Park Police Officers' Pension Fund: The system of retirement benefits provided under this Article. 
Police Officer: Means an Employee employed by the City of Pinellas Park in a position of Police Officer as that term is defined in F.S. Ch. 185. 
Prior service: Of any Member means that service for which the Member had credit under Ordinance No. 279. 
Retirement or retire: Withdrawal from active employment by the City with retirement income applied for and granted under the provisions of this system or entry into the Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP). A Member who has elected to participate in the Police Officers' Deferred Retirement Option Program shall be deemed to have retired for purposes of this Pinellas Park Police Officers' Pension Fund. 
Social Security coverage: Means old age, survivors, disability and health insurance as provided by the Federal Social Security Act. 
System: Shall mean the Pinellas Park Retirement System. 
Treasurer: The Treasurer of the City, who is the City Finance Administrator, shall comply with the provisions of F.S. § 185.30. 
Trustee: Shall mean a Member of the Board of Trustees. 
Trust Fund: Means the Trust Fund established in the designated place or places (as determined by the Trustees) by this Article for the purpose of holding and investing the contributions paid by Members of the City of Pinellas Park, and all gifts and donations to the Trust Fund, and paying the benefits to which Members or their Beneficiaries may become entitled. 
Vested: Shall mean that the Member has met the age and/or service requirements to be eligible to receive a retirement benefit. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2766, 9-21-2000; Ord. No. 2954, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005; Ord. No. 3671, § 1, 2-27-2009; Ord. No. 3711, § 1, 12-10-2009; Ord. No. 3861, § 1, 9-26-2013)  
Sec. 17-404. - Administration of system; appropriation. 
The Trustees shall make such rules and regulations as are necessary for the effective and efficient administration of this system. The Trustees shall cause an actuarial study of the system to be made at such intervals as may be required by law, but in any event at least every two (2) years, and shall provide a copy of each such study to the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005)  
Sec. 17-405. - Consolidation of liabilities and assets; existing plan. 
(A)  Effective October 1, 1999, the Pinellas Park Police Officers' Pension Fund shall assume: 
1.  All liabilities related to the payment of benefits to Police Officers, and their Beneficiaries. 
2.  All obligations in regard to funding and administering benefits accrued for the benefit of Police Officers, Beneficiaries and survivors. 
3.  All assets which are attributable to Police Officers. 
(B)  Benefits unassignable and not subject to process. The right of any Member or any Beneficiary to any benefits under the system or any other right accrued or accruing to any persons under the provisions of this Article and the accumulated contributions and the cash securities in the funds created under this Article, shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of any bankruptcy or insolvency law or any other process of law whatsoever and shall not be subject to assignment, pledge or hypothecation unless expressly authorized in this Article. 
(C)  Errors, corrections, and adjustments. Should any change or error in the records of the system be discovered or any error in any calculation be made resulting in any Member or Beneficiary receiving from the system more or less than he or she was entitled to receive, the Board of Trustees shall have the power to correct such error and as far as possible to adjust the payments thereafter to be made in such a manner that the actuarially equivalent of the benefit to which such Member or Beneficiary was correctly entitled to be paid. 
(D)  Payments in case of legal or other disability. Whenever and/or as often as a person entitled to payments hereunder shall be under legal disability, or, in the sole judgment of the Board of Trustees shall otherwise be unable to apply such payments to his best interests and advantage, the Board of Trustees in the exercise of its discretion may direct that all or any portion of the benefits of such Members payable in any one or more of the following ways: 
1.  Directly to such person. 
2.  To his legal guardian or conservator. 
3.  To his spouse or to any person to be expended for his benefit. 
The decision of the Board of Trustees shall in each case be final and binding on all persons, including the affected Member of the system. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3671, § 2, 2-27-2009)  
Sec. 17-406. - Contributions and funding. 
(A)  Cost of the system. The cost of the system will be borne by the City of Pinellas Park, by Police Officers Employees of the City of Pinellas Park, by State Remittances to finance retirement of Police Officers in accordance with F.S. ch. 185, and by such other funding sources as may be provided by law. City's contributions shall be distributed at least quarterly. 
(B)  City's contributions. The City shall pay into the Trust Fund amounts required to provide the benefits under this system as shall be determined by an actuarial investigation as provided in Section 17-404. 
(C)  Employee's contributions. Members shall, effective for earnings paid for pay period beginning November 22, 1995, contribute each pay period at the rate of three (3) percent of gross compensation; provided however, that Members shall, effective for earnings paid for pay period beginning April 5, 2000, contribute each pay period at the rate of five (5) percent of gross compensation. Commencing with earnings paid June 26, 2002, and thereafter, all mandatory Employee contributions to the Police Pension Fund shall be picked up and paid by the City in accordance with Section 414(h) of the Internal Revenue Code and shall be treated as tax-deferred employer pick-up contributions. Member contributions picked up under the provisions of this Section shall be treated as City contributions for purposes of determining income tax obligations under the Internal Revenue Code; however, such picked up Member contributions shall be included in the determination of the Member's gross annual compensation. The Member's contributions picked up under this Section shall continue to be designated Member contributions and shall be considered as part of the Member's compensation for purposes of determining the amount of the Member's contributions. The provisions of this Section are mandatory, and the Member shall have no option concerning the pick-up or to receive the contributed amounts directly instead of having them paid by the City to the Police Pension Fund. The picked up amounts shall be included as wages for FICA purposes. In consideration of collectively bargained increases in benefits provided to the Members of the Pinellas Park Police Officers' Pension Fund, effective with the first day of the payroll period which includes January 1, 2010, Members shall contribute each pay period at the rate of eight (8) percent of all pension eligible compensation. 
(D)  Social Security contributions. Contributions for Social Security by the City in the amount required for Social Security coverage as now or hereafter provided by the Federal Social Security Act, shall be in addition to contributions specified in subsection (B). 
(E)  Gifts to the Fund. The Board of Trustees may accept gifts, bequests, devises or appropriations to or for the Fund from any source, but shall have the right to reject the same if they are so conditional as to conflict with the Charter or this Article or to make the administration of the same unreasonably difficult. The Board of Trustees shall promptly deposit such gifts, bequests, devises or appropriations with the custodian. 
(F)  Reserved. 
(G)  Investment of the Fund. All monies paid into and held by the retirement system shall be promptly deposited with the custodian. 
(H)  Funds received from State. All State and other funds received by the City pursuant to F.S. ch. 185, shall be deposited by the City immediately and under no circumstances more than five (5) days after receipt, with the Board of Trustees. The City Manager may provide authorization to the Division of Retirement of the State of Florida for the direct payment of the premium tax to the Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees shall deposit such moneys in the Pinellas Park Police Officers Pension Fund immediately, and under no circumstances more than five (5) days after receipt. 
(Ord. No. 536, 11-11-1971; Ord. No. 1808, 9-2-1988; Ord. No. 2363, 11-21-1995; Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2766, 9-21-2000; Ord. No. 2954, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005; Ord. No. 3711, § 2, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 17-407. - Compulsory participation. 
The provisions of this law (Article) shall be compulsory as to all regular full-time officers and Employees who are employed after November 13, 1971, as a Police Officer. Each officer or Employee shall become a Member of the system as of his or her date of employment as a Police Officer. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005)  
Sec. 17-408. - Rights limited. 
(A)  Participation in the system shall not give any Member the right to be retained in the employ of the City, nor, upon dismissal, to have any right or interest in the fund other than herein provided. 
(B)  No Member who has caused a shortage in a public account, when such shortage is certified by a certified public accountant, may receive any benefits under this Article so long as such shortage exists. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-409. - Normal Retirement Benefits; Limitation upon Normal Retirement Benefit; Early Retirement. 
(A)  Effective November 13, 1997, or thereafter, a Member who attains his or her Normal Retirement Date and Retires from employment shall receive a monthly benefit which shall be payable on the first day of each month thereafter during his or her lifetime or as otherwise provided for in this Article. 
(B)  The Member must make a written application on an approved form to the Board of Trustees to be eligible to receive his or her normal Retirement benefit or early Retirement benefit. 
(C)  The amount of monthly benefit shall be equal to the applicable accrual rate(s) times the number of years and fractional parts of years of Creditable Service times the Average Monthly Compensation. 
(D)  For Members hired prior to October 1, 2009, the accrual rate shall be as follows: 
1.  For a Member who before April 1, 2000, separates from employment as a Police Officer or who enters DROP, whichever comes first, two (2) percent for each year of creditable service. 
2.  For a Member who on or after April 1, 2000, but before December 13, 2001, separates from employment as a Police Officer or who enters DROP, whichever comes first, (i) two (2) percent for each year of creditable service prior to April 1, 2000; and (ii) two and one-half (2.5) percent for each year of creditable service on or after April 1, 2000. 
3.  For a Member who on or after December 13, 2001, separates from employment as a Police Officer or who enters DROP, whichever comes first, (i) two (2) percent for each year of creditable service prior to October 1, 1993; (ii) two and one-half (2.5) percent for each year of creditable service on or after October 1, 1993, but prior to October 1, 2002; (iii) three (3) percent for each year of creditable service on or after October 1, 2002, but prior to October 1, 2003; and (iv) three and one-fourth (3.25) percent for creditable service on or after October 1, 2003. 
(E)  . For Members hired on or after October 1, 2009, the accrual rate shall be three percent (3%). 
(F)  The normal retirement benefit or pension payable to a retiree who becomes a Member of any retirement system or plan and who has not previously participated in such plan, on or after January 1, 1980, shall not exceed one hundred (100) percent of his or her average final compensation. However, nothing contained in this Section shall apply to supplemental retirement benefits or to pension increases attributable to cost-of-living increases or adjustments. 
(G)  Upon Retirement on his or her Early Retirement Date, the Member shall receive an immediate monthly benefit which shall be payable on the first day of the month following the month in which the Member Retires and be payable on the first day of each month thereafter during his or her lifetime. The amount of each monthly payment shall be computed in the same manner as for a normal Retirement benefit, in accordance with Section 17-409, but based on Average Monthly Compensation and Creditable Service as of the Member's Early Retirement Date, and the benefit so computed shall be reduced by five-twelfths ( 5/12 ) percent for each complete month by which the Early Retirement Date preceded his or her Normal Retirement Date. For Members retiring effective November 22, 1995, or thereafter, such benefits shall be based on the Average Monthly Compensation and Creditable Service as of the Member's Early Retirement Date, and the benefits so computed shall be reduced by three-twelfths ( 3/12 ) percent for each complete month by which the Early Retirement Date precedes such Member's Normal Retirement Date as provided in Section 17-409. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2954, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005; Ord. No. 3671, § 3, 2-27-2009; Ord. No. 3711, § 3, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 17-410. - Benefits payable for dual normal retirement ages. 
In the event a Member has performed services to the City of Pinellas Park, under Articles II and/or III as an Employee other than a Police Officer, for purposes of determining eligibility for any pension benefit in which length of service is a factor, including entry into DROP, the entire period of full-time Creditable Service served as an Employee of the City of Pinellas Park shall be included; provided however, that the calculation and payment of the pension benefits shall be pursuant to the terms of the respective pension plans in effect at the time the Employee ceased participating in the respective Pension plan. Provided, further, for non-line of duty disability retirement benefits in which the member's combined years of service results in a monthly benefit of less than the minimum of twenty-five (25) percent, the Member shall be entitled to only one (1) minimum, the payment of which shall be prorated among the respective pension plans of which the Member has creditable service. 
(Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 3671, § 4, 2-27-2009)  
Sec. 17-411. - Disability retirement benefit. 
(A)  Disability retirement date. A Member who terminates employment on account of total and permanent disability, as defined in this subsection after completing five (5) years of creditable service from effective date, or a Member of this system who becomes totally and permanently disabled in line of duty regardless of service, shall be entitled to a monthly disability benefit. This disability retirement date for such Member shall be the first day of the first month after the Board of Trustees determines such entitlement. However, the monthly retirement income shall be payable as of the date the board determines such entitlement, and any portion due for a partial month shall be paid together with the first payment. 
(B)  Total and permanent disability. A Member shall be considered totally and permanently disabled if, in the opinion of the Trustees, he or she is prevented, by reason of a medically determinable physical or mental impairment, from rendering useful and efficient service as a Police Officer and will be considered permanently disabled if, in the opinion of the Board of Trustees, he or she is likely to remain so disabled continuously and permanently from a cause other than specified in F.S. § 185.18(3). The decision of the Trustees on these questions shall be final and binding. 
(C)  Proof of disability. The Trustees, before approving payment of any disability retirement benefit, shall require proof that the Member is totally and permanently disabled as provided herein. A Member who believes that he or she is eligible for a disability benefit shall apply therefore to the Board of Trustees on a form provided by the Board. A Member's application for disability benefits must be received by the Board of Trustees no later than one (1) year after the date on which the Member terminated employment. The Member's application must include the certification of the Member's total and permanent disability by one (1) of two (2) duly qualified physicians or surgeons, selected by the Trustees, and such other evidence of disability as the Trustees may require. 
(D)  Disability retirement benefit. A Member upon retirement on his or her disability retirement date shall receive a monthly benefit as selected from available options in Section 17-413 which shall be payable on the first day of the month following his or her disability retirement and shall be payable on the first day of each month thereafter during his or her lifetime and continued disability. The amount of each monthly payment shall be computed in the same manner as for a Normal Retirement Benefit, in accordance with Section 17-409, but based on the Member's average monthly compensation and creditable service as of his or her disability retirement date, with creditable service subject to the following conditions: 
1.  If the Member's disability occurred in the line of duty, his or her monthly benefit shall not be less than forty-two (42) percent of his or her average monthly compensation as of his or her disability retirement date; or 
2.  If the Member's disability occurred other than in the line of duty, his or her monthly benefit shall not be less than twenty-five (25) percent of his or her average monthly compensation as of his or her disability retirement date. 
(E)  Recovery from disability. The Trustees may require periodic re-examination at the expense of the retirement fund; and 
1.  If the Trustees find that a Member who is receiving disability benefits is, at any time prior to his or her Normal Retirement Date, no longer disabled, the Trustees shall direct that the benefits be discontinued. The decision of the Trustees on this question shall be final and binding. 
2.  If the Member described in subsection (E)(1) (who recovers from such disability prior to his or her Normal Retirement Date), does not re-enter the employ of the City and had not completed ten (10) years of creditable service as of his or her disability retirement date, he or she shall be entitled to the excess, if any, of his or her accumulated contributions over the total disability benefits received up to his or her date of recovery. 
3.  If the Member described in subsection (E)(1) (who recovers from such disability prior to his or her Normal Retirement Date) does not re-enter the employ of the City but had completed ten (10) or more years of creditable service as of his or her disability retirement date, he or she may elect to receive: 
(a)  The excess, if any, of his or her accumulated contributions over the total disability benefits received up to his or her date of recovery. 
(b)  A deferred benefit commencing on the first day of the month of his or her normal retirement date which shall be payable on the first day of the month thereafter during his or her lifetime. 
The amount of monthly benefit shall be computed in the same manner as for a normal retirement benefit, in accordance with Section 17-409 but based on average monthly compensation and creditable service as of the Member's disability retirement date. 
4.  If the Member recovers from disability and re-enters employment of the City after his or her recovery, his or her service will be deemed to have been continuous, but the period beginning with the first month for which he or she received a disability benefit payment and ending with the date he or she re-entered employment will not be considered as creditable service for the purpose of computing benefits. The term "accumulated contributions" for such Members wherever used in the Section after recovery shall mean the excess of a member's accumulated contributions as of his or her disability retirement date over total disability benefits received under subsection (E)(3) of this Section. 
(F)  Nonadmissible causes of disability. A Member shall not be entitled to receive any disability retirement benefit if his or her disability is a result of any cause listed in F.S. 185.18(3). 
(G)  Diseases of Police Officers in line of duty; presumption. The provisions of F.S. § 185.34, are incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2766, 9-21-2000; Ord. No. 2954, 12-13-2001; Ord. No. 3174, 10-9-2003; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005; Ord. No. 3671, § 5, 2-27-2009)  
Sec. 17-412. - Termination benefits. 
(A)  A Member whose employment is terminated for any reason other than death or Retirement prior to the completion of ten (10) years of creditable service shall be entitled to the return of his or her accumulated contributions, if any, as of his or her date of termination. 
(B)  A Member whose employment is terminated for any reason other than death or Retirement after the completion of ten (10) years of creditable service is a vested employee who may elect to receive a deferred monthly benefit which shall be payable on the first day of the month following his or her application and eligibility for normal or early Retirement and shall be payable on the last day of each month thereafter during his or her lifetime. The amount of the monthly benefit shall be computed in the same manner as for a normal Retirement benefit in accordance with Section 17-409 or early Retirement benefit in accordance with Section 17-409(G) but based on average monthly compensation and creditable service as of his or her date of termination. Benefits deferred to a future date shall be based on the actuarial equivalency factors in effect at the time the benefits are applied for and granted. 
(C)  In lieu of the deferred monthly benefit provided in subsection (B) the terminated Member may elect to receive a lump sum amount equal to his or her accumulated contributions, if any, as of his or her date of termination. 
(D)  If any Retired Member who has selected Option A dies without having received in benefit payments in an amount equal to his or her accumulated contributions, if any, there shall be payable to his or her designated Beneficiary an amount equal to the excess, if any, of the Member's accumulated contributions over the total monthly payments made to the Member prior to his or her date of death. If the Member's Beneficiary predeceases him or her or if no beneficiary has been designated, the excess accumulated contribution, shall be payable to the Member's estate. 
(E)  A Member shall be deemed a terminated Member only at such time as he or she is no longer employed by the City. If a vested and terminated Member dies prior to receiving retirement benefits, the designated Beneficiary shall be entitled to the benefits otherwise payable to the Member at early or normal retirement age. On a form provided by the plan, the designated Beneficiary shall elect either Option B or Option C in accordance with Section 17-413. If Member dies leaving no designated Beneficiary, the benefits due the member shall be payable to the Member's estate. 
(F)  Any Member who is found guilty in a court of law of committing an offense specified in F.S. 112.3173 (2)(e), or who is otherwise subject to forfeiture under F.S. 112.3173(3), shall forfeit all rights and benefits under this Article except the return of his or her accumulated contributions, if any, as of the date of termination, conviction, resignation, or Retirement, whichever occurs first. 
(G)  Pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 185.185, upon conviction of a violation described therein, a Member or Beneficiary may, in the discretion of the Board of Trustees, be required to forfeit the right to receive any or all benefits to which the person would otherwise be entitled herein. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005; Ord. No. 3671, § 6, 2-27-2009; Ord. No. 3711, § 4, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 17-413. - Optional forms of retirement benefits. 
(A)  This Section applies to the payment of Retirement benefits under Section 17-409, Section 17-410, and Section 17-411. On an approved form, each Member shall elect either Option A, Option B, Option C or Option D as his or her form of payment. Each Member must also designate his or her Beneficiary or joint annuitant (if any) on this form. The form must be properly completed and returned to the Board of Trustees, prior to the receipt of his or her first monthly Retirement payment. 
OPTION A: Retirement benefits payable to the Member during his or her lifetime. 
OPTION B: Effective December 5, 2007, Option B shall be the Normal form of retirement benefit and shall be a ten (10) year certain and life annuity payable to the member during his or her lifetime and, in the event of his or her death within a period of ten (10) years after retirement, the same monthly amount shall be payable for the balance of such ten (10) year period to his or her beneficiary(ies). Actuarial equivalent optional forms of benefit are available pursuant to this section. 
OPTION C: A Retirement benefit which shall be payable during the joint lifetime of both the Member and his or her joint annuitant and which shall continue at one hundred (100) percent after the death of either during the lifetime of the survivor. 
OPTION D: A Retirement benefit shall be payable during the joint lifetime of the Member and his or her joint annuitant and which shall continue after the death of either during the lifetime of the survivor in an amount of either (1) seventy-five (75) percent; or (2) sixty-six and two-thirds (66 2/3 ) percent; or (3) fifty (50) percent of the amount which was payable during the joint lifetime of the Member and his or her joint annuitant. 
(B)  The benefit payable under any option stated above shall be the Actuarial Equivalent of the Normal Form of Benefit. (Ord. 2633 - 09.09.99; Ord. 3345 - 06.23.05) 
(C)  A Member who elects Option A or B, shall designate a Beneficiary(ies) on a form provided by the Board of Trustees to receive the benefits payable, if any, in the event of his or her death. Such person shall be the Beneficiary(ies) of the member. If the Beneficiary(ies) is not alive or is not in existence at the time of the death of the Member, then the estate of the Member shall be the Beneficiary. 
(D)  A Member who elects Option C or Option D shall, on a form provided by the Board of Trustees for that purpose, designate his or her joint annuitant to receive the benefits which continue to be payable upon the death of the Member. Such person shall be the joint annuitant of the Member. After benefits have commenced under Option C or Option D, a Retired Member may change his or her designation of a joint annuitant twice without the approval of the Board of Trustees. There shall be no requirement that the joint annuitant being replaced agree to the change, be in good health, or even be alive. If such a Retired Member desires to change his or her designation of a joint annuitant, the Member shall file with the Board of Trustees a notarized "change of joint annuitant" form. Upon receipt of a completed change of joint annuitant form, the Board of Trustees shall adjust the Member's monthly benefit by the application of actuarial tables and calculations developed to ensure that the benefit paid is the actuarial equivalent of the present value of the Member's current benefit. In all cases, the Retiree shall pay for costs incurred in recalculating the benefits. 
(E)  The election of an option shall be null and void if either the Member, designated Beneficiary, or designated joint annuitant shall die before benefits commence. No Member may change his or her retirement option after the date of cashing or depositing his or her first retirement check. 
(F)  The Board of Trustees shall adopt appropriate actuarial tables and calculations necessary to ensure that the benefit paid is the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which the Member is otherwise entitled under Option B. 
(G)  Upon the death of a Retired Member or Beneficiary or joint annuitant receiving monthly benefits under this Chapter, the monthly benefits shall be paid through the last day of the month of death and shall terminate, or be adjusted, if applicable, as of that date in accordance with the optional form of benefit at the time of retirement. 
(H)  This Section shall be administered pursuant to F.S. 185.161(2). 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2677, 9-21-2000; Ord. No. 2766, 9-21-2000; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005; Ord. No. 3671, § 7, 2-27-2009; Ord. No. 3711, § 5, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 17-414. - Death benefits. 
(A)  If the employment of a Member is terminated by reason of his or her death other than in the line of duty prior to the completion of ten (10) years of Creditable Service, there shall be payable to his designated Beneficiary the member's accumulated contributions without interest. If no Beneficiary is designated or if there is no surviving designated Beneficiary, the accumulated contributions shall be made payable to the Member's estate. 
(B)  If the employment of a Member is terminated by reason of his or her death other than in the line of duty subsequent to the completion of ten (10) years of Creditable Service but prior to the actual commencement of benefits, it shall be assumed that the Member retired as of his date of death in accordance with Section 17-409 if eligible for normal retirement benefits or for early Retirement benefits, or Section 17-410 if eligible for benefits payable for dual normal Retirement, having elected Option B in accordance with Section 17-413 (A). Alternately, upon providing a written election, the designated Beneficiary may choose to receive benefits payable under Option C for his or her lifetime. If no Beneficiary is named or if there is no surviving designated Beneficiary, the benefits due the Member shall be made payable to the Member's estate. 
(C)  Regardless of the Member's length of service, the surviving spouse who is also the designated Beneficiary of any Member who dies in the line of duty, may receive a monthly pension equal to one-half (½) of the monthly salary being received by the Member at the time of the Member's death, plus fifty (50) percent of one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of all other earnings paid during the fifty-two (52) weeks ending with the last full pay period immediately prior to the Member's death, or one-half (½) of the Member's "average monthly compensation", whichever is greater, for the rest of the surviving spouse's lifetime; or in lieu of the above, the surviving spouse may elect to receive the benefit provided in Section 17-414(B) of this Article. For purposes of calculating death benefits pursuant to this subsection, "salary" shall include that gross pay which is paid regularly every pay period; and "monthly salary being received by the Member at the time of the Member's death" shall be determined by taking the "salary" as defined herein paid during the last full pay period immediately prior to the Member's death, multiplied by twenty-six (26) and then divided by twelve (12). The surviving spouse of a Member killed in the line of duty whose benefit terminated because of remarriage shall have the benefit reinstated as of July 1, 1994, at the amount that would have been payable had such benefit not been terminated. 
(D)  If the surviving spouse receiving benefits under paragraph (C) above dies, the monthly payments which would have been payable to such surviving spouse had such surviving spouse lived, shall be paid for use and benefit of such member's child or children until age eighteen (18) or as provided in subsection (F) below. However, the minimum benefit payable by the fund under this paragraph, to all beneficiaries combined, shall be actuarially equivalent to the Option B benefit. 
(E)  If a Member who dies in the line of duty leaves no surviving spouse, and the children are named as the designated beneficiary, the benefits provided by subsection (C), normally payable to a surviving spouse, shall be paid for the use and benefit of such Member's child or children until age eighteen (18) years or as provided in subsection (F) below. However, the minimum benefit payable by the fund under this paragraph, to all beneficiaries combined, shall be actuarially equivalent to the Option B benefit. 
(F)  As used in subsections 17-414(D), (E), and (G) "child" or "children" shall include any child of the Member who after attaining eighteen (18) years of age is physically or mentally incapable of self-support, provided such child was financially dependent for no less than one-half (½) of his/her support from the deceased Member at the time of the death of such Member; and provided, however, such benefits shall cease once the child of the Member becomes capable of self-support or dies. Written proof of such incapacity and financial dependency shall be furnished to the Board of Trustees prior to payment of benefits. The Board of Trustees may require proof of continued incapacity whenever it deems necessary. 
(G)  If a member dies in the line of duty prior to completing ten (10) years of service and does not designate the spouse or "child" or "children" as defined in subsection (F) as the beneficiary, then the Member's accumulated contribution without interest shall be payable to the Member's designated Beneficiary. If no Beneficiary is designated or if there is no surviving designated Beneficiary, the accumulated contributions shall be made payable to the Member's estate. 
(H)  If a Member dies in the line of duty subsequent to the completion of ten (10) years of Creditable Service and leaves no designated Beneficiary or if there is no surviving designated Beneficiary, the Option B benefits due the Member shall be made payable to the Member's estate. 
(I)  If a member dies in the line of duty subsequent to the completion of ten (10) years of Creditable Service and is survived by a designated Beneficiary who is not the surviving spouse, the Option B benefits due the Member shall be payable to the Member's designated Beneficiary. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005)  
Sec. 17-415. - Reserved.  
Sec. 17-416. - Claims Procedure. 
(A)  The Board of Trustees shall establish administrative procedures to be utilized in processing written requests on matters which affect the substantial rights of any person, including Members, Retirees, Beneficiaries, or any person affected by a decision of the Board of Trustees. 
(B)  The Board of Trustees shall have the power to subpoena and require the attendance of witnesses and the production of documents for discovery prior to and at any proceedings provided for in such procedures. 
(C)  In the case of an Employee Member who has filed a grievance in appeal of an adverse termination employment action of the City, the Board of Trustees shall take no action regarding pension matters (unless so requested by the Member) until such time that the grievance process has been concluded. 
(Ord. No. 3671, § 9, 2-27-2009) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3671, § 9, adopted February 27, 2009, repealed the former § 17-416, and enacted a new § 17-416 as set out herein. The former § 17-416 pertained to denial of benefits and derived from Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999.  
Sec. 17-417. - Re-employment after Retirement; limitation. 
(A)  Any Member who has retired and is receiving Retirement compensation under this Chapter may be re-employed by the City, in a position designated as part-time, seasonal or temporary for up to five hundred (500) hours during any one (1) fiscal year, and such employment shall not affect the rights of such Retired Member under this Retirement system, including, without limiting the general terms thereof, his or her right to receive his or her Retirement compensation. 
Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, if at any point in the fiscal year the re-employed Member reaches five hundred (500) hours in any position or positions other than as a School Crossing Guard, he or she will no longer be eligible for employment during that fiscal year except as a School Crossing Guard. Provided, however, that a Member who has Retired and is receiving Retirement compensation under this Chapter may be re-employed by the City as a School Crossing Guard for up to a maximum of one thousand one hundred (1,100) hours in any one (1) fiscal year, and such employment shall not affect the rights of such Retired Member under this Retirement system, including, without limiting the general terms thereof, his or her right to receive his or her Retirement compensation. If at any point in the fiscal year the re-employed Member reaches a total of one thousand one hundred (1,100) hours, he or she will no longer be eligible for employment as a School Crossing Guard during that fiscal year. In no event shall a Member who has Retired and who is receiving Retirement compensation under this Chapter be re-employed by the City as a School Crossing Guard and in one (1) or more other positions for more than a total of one thousand one hundred (1,100) hours in any one (1) fiscal year. 
(B)  The re-employment by the City of any Member who has Retired and is receiving compensation under this Chapter, including elected officials, referred to in subsection (A) of this Section shall have no effect on the average final compensation or years of creditable service of such Retired member. 
(C)  Any Member who has Retired and is receiving Retirement compensation under this Chapter who is re-employed by the City shall monthly report his or her hours in writing to the Human Resources Administrator. In addition, the re-employed Member shall separately report in writing his or her hours to the Human Resources Administrator when the number of hours worked in any fiscal year is one hundred (100) hours less than the applicable limit set forth in subsection (A) of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3063, § 1, 10-24-2002)  
Sec. 17-418. - Cost-of-living adjustment of benefits. 
(A)  The purpose of this Section is to provide cost-of-living adjustments in accordance with existing laws at the date of Retirement, or entry into the DROP, whichever comes first, or earlier death, to the monthly benefits payable or accrued to certain Retirees, including DROP participants, or to certain Beneficiaries, or joint annuitants, or to the surviving spouse of children as provided herein. 
(B)  The terms used in this Section are defined as follows: 
1.  Average cost-of-living index as of an adjustment date means the percentage change in the average of the monthly consumer price index figures for the twelve-month period from April 1 through March 31 immediately prior to the adjustment date, when compared to the average of the monthly consumer price index figures for the preceding twelve-month period from April 1 through March 31 relative to the United States as a whole, issued by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor. 
2.  Base benefit means the total monthly benefit payable or accrued to a Retiree, including a DROP participant, Beneficiary, or joint annuitant, or surviving spouse or children of a Member who dies in the line of duty, in accordance with existing laws as of November 13, 1971; or date of Retirement, or entry into the DROP, or earlier death, if later than November 13, 1971. 
3.  Standard benefit means the monthly benefit calculated in accordance with Section 17-409 for normal Retirement, Section 17-410 for Dual Service Retirement, Section 17-411 for disability Retirement, Section 17-413 if an optional form of benefit payment was elected by the Member, or Section 17-414 for death benefits. Such determination shall be made assuming: 
(a)  Creditable service is the number of years of service for which benefits are provided by the system under which benefits are being paid. 
(b)  Average final compensation is the compensation base on which benefits are being paid were determined. 
4.  Initial benefit means the first monthly benefit payable or accrued to a Retiree, including DROP participant, Beneficiary or joint annuitant, or surviving spouse of children of a Member killed in the line of duty in accordance with the laws governing the determination of such benefits at time of retirement, entry into the DROP, or earlier death. 
(C)  On January 1, 1973, the Trustees shall adjust the benefit of all retirees who, as of November 13, 1971, had attained age sixty-five (65) or who had retired on account of disability and the benefit of all Beneficiaries of deceased Members who would have attained age sixty-five (65) as of November 13, 1971. The amount of benefit payable to such person for the six-month period commencing January 1, 1973, shall be the greater of 1. and 2. where: 
1.  Is the Member's base benefit; and 
2.  Is the sum of the Member's initial benefit and a percentage of the Member's standard benefit, such percentage to be equal to the percentage change in the average cost-of-living index over the period between the date of actual retirement and November 13, 1971. 
(D)  On November 1, 1972, and each November 1 thereafter, the Trustees shall adjust the benefits of all Retirees who, as of the date of adjustment, have attained age sixty-five (65) or who have retired on account of disability and the benefit of all Beneficiaries of deceased Members who would have attained age sixty-five (65) as of the adjustment date. 
(E)  On November 1, 1988, and each November 1 thereafter the Trustees shall also adjust the benefit of any Members retiring after that date who have served twenty-five (25) years as a Police Officer or as a Police Officer and Firefighter combined. For all Dual Service Members retiring on or after January 1, 2010, all years of creditable City service shall be included when determining eligibility of COLA benefits. 
(F)  On November 1, 2002, and each November 1 thereafter, the Trustees shall also adjust the benefit of all Beneficiaries and joint annuitants of deceased Members who, at the time of such Member's death had been receiving an adjustment on account of disability who are likewise eligible for the COLA as set forth in Section 17-418(E), regardless of the age of the deceased Member or surviving Beneficiary or joint annuitant; and the benefit of all surviving spouses or children who qualify for in-line-of-duty death benefits pursuant to Section 17-414(C), (D), or (E), regardless of the age of the deceased Member of surviving spouse. 
(G)  The amount of benefit payable to such person for the twelve-month period commencing on the adjustment date, shall be the sum of the monthly benefit being received on October 31 immediately preceding the November 1 adjustment date and the immediately preceding "Average Cost-of-Living Index Percentage" not to exceed three (3) percent of such monthly benefit. 
(H)  For Members separating from employment as a Police Officer or entering the DROP, whichever comes first, prior to September 18, 2013, and for Members who then currently eligible for Normal Retirement as of that date, eligibility for a COLA shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of subsections (D), (E), (F) and (G) above. 
(I)  For Members separating from employment as a Police Officer or entering the DROP, whichever comes first, on or after September 18, 2013, who become eligible to receive a COLA pursuant to subsection (D), (E), or (F) above, the COLA shall be two (2) percent per year and shall begin with the benefit payment occurring on December 1st of the year immediately following either the Retired Member's attainment of age sixty-five (65) or the anniversary of five (5) full years of Retirement, whichever comes first. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3174, 10-9-2003; Ord. No. 3711, § 6, 12-10-2009; Ord. No. 3861, § 2, 9-26-2013)  
Sec. 17-419. - Credit for actual military service. 
Creditable service of any Member shall also include military service as defined in Section 17-403 provided: 
(A)  The Member was in the active employ of the City as a Police Officer immediately prior to such service and is legally entitled to re-employment under the provisions of the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994, or other law applicable to such re-employment and, provided further, that said Member returns to his or her employment as a Police Officer within one (1) year from the date of release from such active military service. 
(B)  The Member makes the required contributions for service credit during such period based on his or her rate of monthly City compensation as of his or her date of entry into military service plus four (4) percent interest on such contributions compounded annually from the due date of the contribution to date of payment. A Member will not be required to make contributions as set forth in this Section to receive service credit for military service as defined herein, provided such Military Service was rendered after October 1, 2003. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2766, 9-21-2000; Ord. No. 3345, 6-23-2005)  
Sec. 17-420. - Future service to include authorized leave of absence. 
Future service of any Member as defined in Section 17-403 shall also include authorized leaves of absence, provided: 
(a)  The Member has completed a minimum of ten (10) years of creditable service excluding periods of leave of absence. 
(b)  The leave of absence is authorized in writing by the City Manager and approved by the Trustees. 
(c)  The leave does not exceed twelve (12) months at any one (1) time nor twenty-four (24) months in total during his employment. 
(d)  The Member makes the required contributions for service credit during the leave of absence which shall be eight (8) percent of his rate of monthly compensation in effect immediately prior to the commencement of such leave for each month of such period, plus four (4) percent interest on such contribution to date of payment. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-421. - Amendments. 
Reference in the Article to City, State or Federal laws or agreements are intended to include such laws as they now exist or may hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-422. - Administration of plan. 
(A)  General supervision. The general supervision of the administration of the plan shall be by the Board of Trustees. The membership of the Board of Trustees shall consist of five (5) members, two (2) of whom, unless otherwise prohibited by law, shall be legal residents of the City of Pinellas Park, who shall be appointed by City Council, and two (2) of whom shall be Police Officers as defined in F.S. § 185.02, who shall be elected by a majority of the active Police Officers who are Members of such plan. The fifth Member shall be chosen by a majority of the previous four (4) Members as provided for herein, and such person's name shall be submitted to City Council. Upon receipt of the fifth person's name, City Council shall, as a ministerial duty, appoint such person to the Board of Trustees as its fifth member. The fifth Member shall have the same rights as each of the other four (4) Members appointed or elected as herein provided, shall serve as Trustee for a period of four (4) years, and may succeed himself or herself in office. Each resident Member shall serve as Trustee for a period of four (4) years, unless sooner replaced by City Council at whose pleasure he or she shall serve, and may succeed himself or herself as a Trustee. Each Police Officer Member shall serve as a Trustee for a period of four (4) years unless he or she sooner leaves the employment of the City of Pinellas Park as a Police Officer, whereupon a successor shall be chosen in the same manner as an original appointment. Each Police Officer may succeed himself or herself in office. 
(B)  Compensation of Board Members. The Members of the Board of Trustees shall serve without compensation for their service. 
(C)  Meetings of the Board of Trustees. This system and matters related hereto shall be considered and resolved at Board meetings to be held as often as may be required, but at least quarterly each year, for settlement of matters relating hereto. A majority of membership shall constitute a quorum and all decisions, acts and resolutions of the Board shall be affirmative vote of at least three (3) Members. All Members of the Board of Trustees shall receive written notices at least two (2) days prior to a meeting date and a written agenda shall be included therewith. 
(D)  Administrative regulations. The Board of Trustees by Resolution, may promulgate written rules and regulations not in conflict with the expressed terms of this Article or the Charter of the City of Pinellas Park to cover the operations of any phase or part of the system as provided by this Article. Copies of such rules and regulations shall be furnished to any Member of the system upon request and at least one (1) copy thereof shall be kept available in the office of the Human Resources Administrator for examination by any interested persons at any time during ordinary business hours. Otherwise, a copy of this Article shall fully meet the provisions herein. 
(E)  Interpretation of the plan. The Board of Trustees has the power to construe all items, rules, conditions and limitations of the system, and its construction made in good faith shall be final and conclusive upon all parties' interests. 
(F)  Agent and Employees. The Board of Trustees shall have the power to select, employ and compensate, or cause to compensate from time to time such consultants, actuaries, accountants, attorneys, investment counsel and other agents and Employees as they may deem necessary and advisable in the proper and efficient administration of the system. To assist the Board of Trustees in meeting its responsibilities, the Board of Trustees, if it so elects, may: 
1.  Employ independent legal counsel at the pension fund's expense. 
2.  Employ an independent actuary, as defined in F.S. § 185.02(8), at the pension fund's expense. 
3.  Employ such independent professional, technical, or other advisers as it deems necessary at the Pension Fund's expense. 
If the Board of Trustees chooses to use the City's legal counsel or actuary, or chooses to use any of the City's other professional, technical, or other advisers, it must do so only under terms and conditions acceptable to the Board of Trustees. 
(G)  Other powers and duties. The powers and duties of the Board of Trustees or of any other persons and set out herein are not intended to be complete or exclusive but each such body or persons shall have such powers and duties as are reasonably implied under the terms of the Article. Where not in conflict with this Article or the Charter of the City of Pinellas Park, the trust agreement or contract entered into with the insurance company shall govern. 
(H)  Chair and Secretary of the Board of Trustees. A Chair and a Secretary of the Board of Trustees shall be elected by a majority vote of the Members of the Board of Trustees. The Chair and Secretary shall be Members of the Board of Trustees. 
(I)  Duties of the Secretary. It shall be the duty of the Secretary to keep accurate and complete minutes and records of the actions, proceedings or hearings of the Board of Trustees under this system separate and apart from the regular minutes of City Council meetings. This provision is made for the express purpose of having all proceedings in connection with this system in one (1) set of books, thereby saving a search of the minutes of council meetings for records. They shall be available to the public, City officials and Employees under this system at all times. Copies of all minutes and meeting notifications shall be distributed to each Member of the City Council. 
(J)  Written records. All notices, elections, designations and changes of Beneficiaries and similar writings pertaining to the operation of the system shall be made and preserved in writing on such forms as the Trustees may direct. Whenever there are any notices, elections, designations, complaints, rulings, or other written proceedings relating to a particular employee, the Secretary shall furnish the Trustees or the insurance company, when necessary, with a copy of same, as well as the Employee. 
(K)  Investment of Funds. Authorized investments of the Board of Trustees are as set forth in F.S. § 185.06. 
(L)  Annual reports by the custodian. The custodian and each other entity which holds assets of the Trust Fund shall submit a statement of the condition of the funds on deposit to the credit of the system at least once yearly, and may be required to supply copies of such statement to the enrolled actuary designated by the Board of Trustees. The original shall be retained among the records of the Secretary of the Board of Trustees. Annual reports, as provided by State law, shall be furnished to the proper State authorities. The Board of Trustees shall keep in convenient form such data as shall be necessary for an actuarial valuation of Pinellas Park Police Officers' Pension Fund for checking the actual experience of the Fund. 
(M)  Responsibilities of Members and Beneficiaries. Each Member or Beneficiary or other interested Member shall be responsible for advising the Board of Trustees of his or her correct mailing address, and promptly advising the Board of Trustees relating to any error in whomsoever's favor, in connection with the payment of benefits of any other payment under or in connection with the system. 
(N)  Interest on delayed payments. Pension payments, although not promptly paid for any reason, and any other payments to be made out of the Fund, although not paid promptly for any reason, shall not bear interest unless so ordered by the Board of Trustees, who shall have discretion to fix the rate and calculate any such interest, and in such event, the interest to be paid shall not exceed the then current rate of interest being returned on the funds on deposit with the Trustee or the insurance company or other financial institution. 
(O)  Personal liability. Each Member of the Board of Trustees shall use the ordinary care and diligence in the performance of his or her duties and shall not be liable for any loss unless same results from his or her own gross negligence, or his or her willful misconduct, nor shall such Members be personally liable upon or with respect to any agreement, act, transaction or omission executed, committed or suffered to be committed himself or herself as one of a Member of said body or any other member, agent, representative, or Employee of any body, moreover said bodies and Members and agents thereof shall each be fully protected in relying on the advice of independent legal counsel by the Board of Trustees or the City Attorney or his or her assistants, or upon any other attorney employed by the City or said bodies, or any of them insofar as legal matters are concerned, or any accountant similarly employed by the Board of Trustees or City insofar as accounting matters are concerned, and of any actuaries similarly by the Board of Trustees or City employed so far as actuarial matters are concerned. Any person having any claim under the system shall look solely to the assets of the Fund for satisfaction to such claims. 
(P)  Small annuities; payments. Notwithstanding any provision of the plan to the contrary, if the monthly retirement income payable to any person entitled to benefits hereunder is less than One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) or if the single-sum value of the accrued retirement income is less than Two Thousand Five Hundred Dollars ($2,500.00) as of the date of Retirement or termination of service, whichever is applicable, the Board of Trustees, in the exercise of its discretion, may specify that the actuarial equivalent of such Retirement income be paid in a lump sum. 
(Q)  Filing defined. When any notice, election or other instrument is required or permitted by this Article to be filed with the Board of Trustees, the same may be filed with the Human Resources Administrator of the City. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2710, 4-27-2000; Ord. No. 2766, 9-21-2000; Ord. No. 3671, § 10, 2-27-2009; Ord. No. 3711, § 7, 12-10-2009; Ord. No. 3770, § 1, 6-9-2011)  
Sec. 17-423. - Future changes in the operation of the system. 
(A)  General. It is contemplated, and all original and new Members of the system shall be deemed to have notice that the City Council of this City may in the future decide that it is in the best interests of the City and the Members of the system to modify or terminate trust agreements or contracts entered into with an insurance company or companies, to exercise options available to the City under the terms of such trust agreements or contracts, to select another insurance company, trust, or other financial institution, as the depository for pension funds. 
(B)  Power to amend. The City Council shall have continuous power to amend this Article 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 3711, § 8, 12-10-2009)  
Sec. 17-424. - Protection against fraud and deceit. 
(A)  Violations and punishments. Whosoever with intent to deceive shall make or cause to be made any statement, report, certificate, election notice, claim or other instrument authorized or required under this Article whether of the enumerated classes or otherwise, which shall be untrue, or who shall falsify or cause to commit to be falsified any record comprising any part of the operation or administration of the system contemplated by this Article shall be punished as follows: By a fine, not exceeding Three Hundred Dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment. Any such violation shall also be punishable as provided under the laws of the State of Florida. 
(B)  False, misleading or fraudulent statements made to obtain public Retirement benefits. The provisions of F.S. § 185.185, are incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999; Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-425. - Separability and construction. 
In the event any Section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this Article shall be held to be invalid or unconstitutional such adjudication shall not in any matter affect the remaining portions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-426. - Repeal of conflicting Ordinances. 
All Ordinances and parts of Ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed to the extent of such conflict. 
(Ord. No. 2633, 9-9-1999)  
Sec. 17-427. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 3671, § 11, adopted February 27, 2009, repealed § 17-427, which pertained to implementation of Chapter 99-1, Laws of Florida and derived from Ord. No. 2667, 12-9-1999; Ord. No. 2766, 9-21-2000.  
Sec. 17-428. - Police Officers Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP). 
Subject to the provisions of this Section, the Police Officers Deferred Retirement Option Program, hereinafter referred to as the DROP, is an option under which an eligible Member may elect to have the Member's pension benefits calculated as of a date certain prior to Retirement, and accumulate benefits plus the investment return pursuant to this Section during the DROP calculation period. Participation in the DROP does not guarantee employment with the City during any period of time, including the DROP calculation period as defined in this Section. 
(A)  Eligibility. In order to be eligible for the DROP option, the Member must meet the following eligibility criteria: 
1.  A Police Member must make the enrollment election either: (i) on or after age fifty-five (55), provided such Member shall then have a minimum of ten (10) years of creditable pension service as a Police Officer; or (ii) any time between obtaining a minimum of twenty-five (25)years and a maximum of thirty (30) years of creditable pension service as a Police Officer. For the purposes of determining eligibility in the DROP for dual service employees, refer to Section 17-410. Those Police Officers who as of the date of enactment of this DROP are beyond the dates allowed for election into the DROP, but are otherwise eligible for election into the DROP, shall have until March 17, 2000, to make the election to enroll into the DROP. 
2.  The Member must meet all eligibility requirements for normal Retirement benefits, other than separation from service as a Police Officer. 
3.  Upon electing to participate in the DROP, the Member shall submit on forms required by the City and the Board of Trustees: 
(a)  An irrevocable written election to participate in the DROP, specifying a DROP benefit beginning calculation date which shall be the first day of a pay period. This DROP benefit beginning calculation date is used to determine the DROP calculation period, which commences on the DROP benefit beginning calculation date and ends on the earlier of the expiration of the Member's participation eligibility period as outlined elsewhere in this section; or the Member's separation from service as a Police Officer or death; 
(b)  An irrevocable notice of employment termination as a Police Officer to take effect upon the expiration of the DROP calculation period; provided that a DROP participant shall not be precluded from voluntarily terminating employment with the City before the expiration of the DROP calculation period, nor shall the City be precluded from terminating such DROP participant's employment as applicable due to disciplinary action, layoff, or other separation in accordance with the applicable collective bargaining agreement, civil service law, or other applicable law; 
(c)  Any other information required by the Board of Trustees. 
4.  A Member may only make one (1) DROP election in this plan during the Member's lifetime. 
(B)  Status. For pension purposes only: 
1.  During the DROP calculation period, there shall be no pension contribution deductions made from the earnings, wages, salary, or compensation earned by the DROP participant. 
2.  Upon entry into the DROP, a DROP participant shall no longer be entitled to pension disability benefits pursuant to Section 17-411 or pension death benefits pursuant to Section 17-414. 
3.  Death benefits under the DROP. Upon the death of a DROP participant, the named Beneficiary or Beneficiaries shall be entitled to receive the benefits accumulated during the DROP calculation period as of the date of death. After the death of such DROP participant, pension benefits shall be paid as required by Sections 17-409, 17-413 and 17-418. Eligibility to participate in the DROP terminates upon the death of such DROP participant. 
4.  A DROP participant shall not be eligible to serve as an elected Member on the Board of Trustees. Any elected Member of the Board of Trustees who elects to participate in the DROP shall serve as a de facto Trustee until a replacement is elected in a special election. 
(C)  Benefits under the DROP. 
1.  A DROP participant's monthly pension benefits pursuant to Sections 17-409 and 17-413, and the effective date of the participant's Retirement, shall be determined based upon the effective date of the participant's DROP benefit beginning calculation date. 
2.  The DROP accumulation shall be calculated as follows: 
(a)  The amount of the monthly benefits the Member would have been entitled to receive from the DROP benefit beginning calculation date to the end of the member's DROP calculation period. 
(b)  The amount of any cost of living adjustments pursuant to Section 17-418 during the DROP benefit calculation period. 
(c)  Interest accumulation as set forth in this Section. 
3.  At the conclusion of the Member's DROP benefit calculation period, the Board of Trustees shall distribute the Member's benefits, subject to the following provisions:
